text:
Sections

 

The Colonial Beginnings of Radio Broadcasting (1922-41)
Radio Broadcasting in World War II (1941-45)
The Period of the Third Republic (1945-72)
The Period of the Fourth Republic (1972-86)
The Period of the Fifth Republic (1986-Onward)
Conclusion

 

Since the 1920s, broadcasting has played many roles in Philippine society. First, it has functioned as a potent tool for economic convenience and political interests. Philippine broadcasting has always been intricately linked with politics and commerce, with both government and business interests always intervening in the governance, operations, and directions of the industry. It has often been at the mercy of capital and the state, for which it has often been criticized as the “lapdog” of the dominant. Politics and economics became intensely intertwined with broadcasting as it became not only a profitable investment but also an arena for political power matches. The value of broadcast for political and business interests has also rested on the fact that broadcasting in the Philippines has not only been national in impact but transnational in varying features and contexts.

Second, broadcasting has served as an agent of social change at crucial moments of history. With such close links between politics and business, broadcasting has made its presence profoundly felt in crucial and important historical watersheds that significantly shaped the terrain and directions of the life of the nation. At such crucial moments, its presence often served to subvert the dominant order, ushering change that can be dramatic and radical. The irony is two-fold, however. The resistances are subtler and sometimes unintended, but the consequences nonetheless may subvert the cultural designs of the dominant, undermining its political agenda.

 
 

In serving private stakes, government interests, and the public good, broadcasting is always at the intersection of contradicting and contrary claims, assertions, negotiations, and appropriations about the nation. Indeed, it constantly creates the art of the everyday: malleable, yet firm when the democratic foundations of our country are threatened; raw, yet able to represent everything about society with fastidious care; mundane, yet capable of imagining possibilities. Broadcasting constantly feels the stirrings of daily life, and is always embedded in the constantly moving agitations of the everyday making of the nation, uniting the people in the midst of differences.

 

The Colonial Beginnings of Radio Broadcasting (1922-41)

 

Politics, Commerce, and Broadcasting. The introduction in 1922 of radio to the Philippines by the American government was simultaneous with its colonial project of convincing Filipinos of the goodness and desirability of American culture, progress, and modernity. Apart from being a product to sell, radio became a promising new medium for advertising the myriad merchandise the Americans brought into the Philippines, such as typewriters, safes, bicycles, automobiles, phonographs, phonograph records, radio sets, fountain pens, firearms, electric ice boxes, office equipment, neckties, evening gowns, insurance, cigars, toothpastes, detergents, and soaps.

 

 

The colonial administration subsidized radio broadcasting in its first several years, but advertising was a critical support to bankroll operations. Businesses that previously advertised only in newspapers and magazines began buying radio airtime. The first to set up radio broadcasting facilities to support the primary business of retailing were Henry Herman, Isaac Beck, and William H. Anderson.

 

Government Regulation and Intervention. Philippine radio broadcasting, being a product of wireless telegraphy and part of the mail system, was first regulated by the Bureau of Posts, which granted permits for the operation of broadcast stations until 1931. Federal law in the United States regarding radio, however, did not apply to the colony. The policies that developed on radio broadcasting in the Philippines reflected the stance of the United States, articulated in 1928 by then US president Calvin Coolidge in an executive order, that the development of privately owned and operated radio facilities should be encouraged, but that these facilities should be available for national defense in time of war or any similar national emergency.

 

The colonial Philippine legislature passed Act 3846 in 1931, or the Radio Control Law, which transferred the regulation of the industry from the Bureau of Posts to the newly-created Radio Control Board. The board was put under the supervision of the secretary of the Department of Commerce and Industry, while the public works and communications secretary approved the construction of radio facilities and transmitting stations. One of the major provisions of the law was on broadcast licensing and ownership. The law provided that licenses could be granted or transferred only to citizens of the United States or of the Philippines, or to firms or companies that were incorporated under the laws of the Philippines or of any US state or territory. The law also provided that the US president or the governor-general of the Philippines, in time of war, public peril, calamity, or disaster, could order the closing of any radio station in the Philippines or authorize the temporary use or possession of any radio station by any department of the government upon just compensation to the owners.

 

 

In 1932, Gov-Gen Theodore Roosevelt Jr ordered the purchase of radio receiving sets and their installation in public squares where communities may listen to broadcasts from Manila. In 1936, Pres Manuel L. Quezon attempted to nationalize broadcasting and use it against his critics, but he failed to expropriate the radio stations from private ownership.

 

With war looming on the horizon in the late 1930s, radio became an indispensable propaganda device for both the Allies and the Axis powers in fighting a global war. The American colonial administration kept under surveillance radio station owners and staff, both Americans and Filipinos, to check their loyalty in light of the ominous events in Europe and China. Quezon issued emergency rules through the National Emergency Administration in 1941, which included new regulations governing electrical communication and radio installations, the sale or repair of radio sets or radio parts, which should all be registered with the government, and the surveillance of unlicensed radio transmitter installations.

 

In 1941, the government established KZND (with ND standing for national defense), which used a confiscated one-kilowatt transmitter, for its own broadcast voice. However, it ceased broadcast as the United States Army Forces in the Far East (USAFFE), the combined Filipino and American forces under Gen Douglas MacArthur’s command, retreated to Bataan and Corregidor while Japanese invasion forces pushed toward Manila around the end of Dec 1941.

 

 

Transnational Broadcasting. During the early years of Philippine radio, broadcasting signals from the Philippines crossed the oceans and foreign lands by shortwave, a wireless technology that transmitted signals over very long distances. The few stations of the period mainly used long wave, which sent signals over relatively short distances.

As early as 1925, Isaac Beck, who put up KZIB on the air, experimented on using shortwave. Henry Herman’s Radio Corporation of the Philippines (RCP), which by then had merged with Far Eastern Radio Inc (FERI), conducted shortwave experiments in 1927. In 1929, RCP’s KZRM broadcast to the world and received reports of good reception from distant countries and ships in the high seas.

It must be noted, however, that some of the islands within the archipelago were already electronically connected to each other and to other countries even before the Americans came. Cable telegraph lines linked Manila to Corregidor in 1867, then to Hong Kong in 1879, and soon to Cebu, Bacolod, Capiz, and Iloilo. In 1890, the first telephone system was put in place. In the 1920s, wireless telegraphy was the main means of long-distance communication. Voice was transmitted through the dozens of radio stations from ship to shore and back, including those of the US military and the government. However, these were principally for point-to-point communication rather than for broadcasting. Historians of broadcast technology understand its development as an offshoot of these earlier means of electronic communication over long distances.

 

 

 

Having shortwave transmitting capacity also meant having receiving capacity. In 1930, KZRM began carrying American and other foreign programs. On the other hand, the American network National Broadcasting Company (NBC) also carried Manila programs in the United States, occasionally to a nationwide audience. This went on throughout the 1930s until the eve of World War II. With the war underway in Europe at the close of the 1930s, NBC rival Columbia Broadcasting System or CBS, with a network of 110 stations, put Commonwealth president Manuel L. Quezon on the air from Malacañan a number of times.

With broadcast stations invested in shortwave transmitters, Philippine broadcasting was able to air transnationally, enabling Manila programs to be heard not only in some continents but also on ships at sea. Radio personalities received fan mail from all over Asia and the United States. When KZRH went on the air, it covered the entire Philippines and also reached much of Asia, the United States, and Europe through shortwave.

With the introduction to the market of radio sets with shortwave-receiving capacity, an average of 15 hours of foreign broadcast programs were heard in the Philippines every day in 1930. Moreover, the dozens of shortwave stations from all over Asia, North and South America, and Europe that were heard in the Philippines exposed the Filipinos as well as foreigners in the Philippines to a transnational range of program material.

 

Programming and Program Formats. The program formats were a takeoff from American radio. Mostly entertainment, many programs combined music and readings of English poetry, prose, and drama, while others took off from the vaudeville style of mixing music with comedy skits or comic repartees. Though with less airtime, also broadcast were news and the occasional live coverage of events, as well as live annotations of sports events, children’s programs, educational and instructional programs, religious programs, and various kinds of talk shows. The announcement of the correct time was integrated into the programs, while bulletins about the weather, road and traffic reports, foreign exchange rates, and even the search for missing persons were regularly heard. Notices to mariners, distress signals or SOS, and police information for purposes of keeping peace and order and for safeguarding sea voyages were also heard on radio in the 1920s and the 1930s due to the less distinct functions of broadcasting and point-to-point communication.

 

Recorded music from the United States and Europe was aired, but most of the music heard on the air were live performances by a mostly Filipino host of musicians and singers. Stations invested not only in recorded music but also in the training of musical talent for live performances on the air. Filipino artists who performed jazz and movie music on the air were popular. Among the first composer-arrangers whose music went on the air were Miguel Velarde Jr, Ariston Avelino, Restituto Umali, and Tito Arevalo. Popular radio talents of the vaudeville-type of music and comic skits were Pugo and Togo, German San Jose and Leonora Reyes, Andoy Balun-balunan and Dely Atay-atayan, and Vicente Ocampo and Diana Toy.

 

Fans inside the studio provided live laughter and applause. They organized themselves into clubs, with some radio celebrities having several fan clubs competing for attention. Many considered radio stars brighter than movie stars as the movie industry then produced at most a few dozen movies a year, while radio turned out program after program on a daily basis. Thus radio had more newspaper publicity, which may explain why many movie stars also kept a presence on the air.

 

Advertisers courted public tastes and preferences through radio, which were evident in the titles of the shows they supported, with the product name carrying the title of the program. These sponsors were the first blocktimers in Philippine broadcasting. Blocktiming is the network practice of selling airtime to individuals or groups. On KZRM, some examples include the variety quiz and contest show Chevrolet Jamboree by the Chevrolet automobile; the amateur singing contest Listerine Amateur Hour by a toothpaste company; the music program Saturday Night Klim Party by a powdered milk brand; and the newscasts El Conde de Guell and Sunkist News by brands of cigars and juice drink, respectively. On KZIB, examples were the music program Crystal Arcade, sponsored by a shopping mall; the featured dramatizations of excerpts from movies on Lux Toilet Soap Theatre of the Air, sponsored by a brand of bath soap; and the variety show Purico Troubadors by a cooking lard brand.

 

Appropriations and Nation Building. Radio broadcasting was one ideological tool that imported America into the Philippines. Words and music in the language and accent of the colonizers won the Filipinos over to acceptance of American rule far more effectively than the use of weapons had. The very same medium of colonial radio that the Americans employed as one of the tools to reshape Filipino consciousness, however, was appropriated by Filipino broadcasters who played Filipino music and used Philippine languages on the air. The immense popularity of such programs forced the American investors in the business of radio to respond favorably to the demands of the Filipino audience.

 

Many of these songs suggested criticism of American colonization, such as Dely Atay-atayan’s song “Alila” (Slave), clearly referring to the Philippines’ subjugation to American rule. The comedy acts that accompanied the performance of this and other such songs detracted from the rebellious tone, but others were straightforward in expressing nationalism and distress over the colonization of the Philippines: kundiman (love song) pieces such as “Hibik ng Pilipinas” (Lament of the Philippines), “Ibong Sawi” (Broken-Hearted Bird), and “Kantahin ng Ulila” (Song of the Orphan). Through radio, the Filipino language undeniably began to reach the farthest parts of the archipelago, slowly fashioning what would become a lingua franca of all regions.

 

The Philippine broadcasting business toward the end of the 1940s was on its way to becoming an industry. It was exciting, glamorous, and merry, and the audience size was growing exponentially. Regarded primarily as a commercial activity, it enjoyed relative freedom from the control of government, in spite of Quezon’s threat to take over it. In 1941, however, the political, economic, and cultural conditions in the Philippines drastically changed as the Americans lost control of the country to Japanese military forces. Radio broadcasting took on various roles as the contending ideologies and worldviews of the Americans and yet another invader exploited radio for the realization of their respective global expansion designs.

 

Radio Broadcasting in World War II (1941-45)

 

Government Regulation and Intervention. During World War II, the Japanese attempted to reengineer Filipino consciousness through a restructuring of the educational system, the teaching of the Japanese language, and even the reorientation of religious activities. The invading forces set aside the business aspect of broadcasting.

The Japanese controlled broadcasting by rigging radio sets to suppress broadcast signals from the enemy, and severely punished those caught clandestinely listening to such signals.

The Japanese had a propaganda corps, called the Sendenhan, which included broadcasters. It was later renamed Hodobu—the Department of Information—to avoid the negative connotation of the name Sendenhan. Beginning in 1942, KZRH and the dailies Tribune and Taliba, which the Hodobu also took over, became the principal propaganda outlets of the invaders.

In 1942, radio receiving sets had to be registered with the Customs Office. In 1943, the Japanese Military Administration ordered the “reconditioning” of all shortwave receivers, except those permitted by the Japanese army. “Reconditioning” meant that sets were converted or refit so that their shortwave tuners could receive only broadcasts made by the Japanese military or those originating from Japan.

 

By the end of the war in 1945, the US Congress passed legislation empowering Philippine Commonwealth president Sergio Osmeña to grant temporary operating permits to private citizens and groups who wanted to go into the radio business to encourage the revival of commercial radio broadcasting. Two commercial stations almost immediately were granted permits: the Manila Broadcasting Company (MBC), which bought KZRH from H. E. Heacock Co, and the Philippine Broadcasting Corporation (PBC), which was the new name of the old Far East Broadcasting Corporation, owner of the prewar KZRM and KZRF. The following year, on the occasion of the declaration of Philippine independence from the United States and the inauguration of Manuel Roxas as president on 4 Jul 1946, MBC’s KZRH and PBC’s KZPI went on the air and resumed commercial broadcasting in the country. Also, the US Information Service (USIS) of the US State Department took over KZFM.

 

Transnational Broadcasting. The technology of broadcasting through shortwave and the principle of relay broadcasting, where a transmitter picks up signals from a broadcast source and rebroadcasts the same signal to another area, continued the transnationalization of radio broadcasting from the Philippines during World War II. The signals of the resistance radios Voice of Freedom and Voice of Juan de la Cruz were picked up by KGEI in San Francisco, California, a private shortwave station taken over by the US Army during the war. When the Japanese revived KZRH and later changed its call letters to PIAM, which stood for Philippine Islands A Manila, its signals were beamed abroad, particularly across the Pacific Ocean toward the United States, via PIRN, which stood for Philippine Islands Radio Nippon. Filipinos were banned from receiving signals from foreign radio stations except those from Tokyo and Japanese-controlled Taiwan. The Japanese Military Administration implemented this by requiring all radio sets to be submitted to authorities to disable their shortwave receivers. However, many risked lives by restoring the shortwave function of their radio sets in order to listen to programs from KGEI, the BBC in England, and other stations supporting the Allied powers of the United States and Great Britain. KGEI aired programs in several Philippine languages aimed specifically at Filipino audiences in Japan-occupied Philippines.

 

Programming and Program Formats. Radio under the Japanese deprived Filipinos of the vibrant music and the lively talk of American-style programming, and imposed on them what was perceived as overt propaganda through endless lectures, political speeches, and Japanese marches. The local radio’s programming was strictly controlled to air only approved material. The programs were broadcast mostly in Tagalog but also in Nihongo, Spanish, English, Ilonggo, and Cebuano. Newscasts in English, Tagalog, and Spanish of 15 minutes each were aired three times a day. Eventually, the news was also regularly read in Nihongo. Documentaries on Japanese history and culture, and language lessons on Nihongo were frequently heard. Church services, lectures aimed at women and children, and literary readings in Japanese were allotted airtime, as well as Tagalog comedy skits. Filipino music, as well as Western classical music, was played on the air. Since Japan did not have recorded music yet, Japanese songs and music were performed live with the guidance of music sheets.

 

A Japanese pianist, Filipino pianist Jose V. Carreon, and Filipino musicians and singers provided the live music. Fidela Magpayo, better known to postwar radio fans as Tiya Dely, became the most popular radio singer during the period. She sang mostly Filipino songs, but she and Polish-Filipina Nellie Bialovlovsky, known as Ginger on the air, also sang Japanese songs repeatedly on the air. KZRH, later PIAM, broadcasters included Leon Ma. Guerrero III, Norman Reyes, Clodualdo del Mundo, Alfredo Saulo, Hernando Ocampo, I. V. Mallari, and Manuel Viray.

 

In keeping with their policy of “Asia for Asians,” the Japanese promoted the use of Tagalog, alongside Nihongo, and allocated time for Filipino composers, performers, and music, particularly classical Filipino music such as the kundiman.

 

Broadcasting during the war evolved from an almost purely entertainment medium to that which was a source of news and information. News programs gained prominence during the war not only on Japanese-controlled radio but on banned shortwave stations. There was hunger for credible news that was so critical for Filipinos, as well as for the foreigners in the country, to know about the progress of the war in the Philippines and around the world.

 

Subversions and Resistance. World War II was as much a contest of might as it was a battle of ideologies, and radio broadcasting was a critical combat zone.

At the beginning of the Japanese occupation, the resistance radio Voice of Freedom valiantly rallied Filipinos to continue resisting the Japanese, until the moment of defeat. Filipinos in Cebu and nearby provinces monitored the war in Luzon by listening to the Voice of Freedom, whose signals were picked up and relayed by KZRC. The Voice of Freedom silenced, another went on the air, the Voice of Juan de la Cruz, whose broadcasters braved the doom that awaited them.

 

Around the world, the Allies and the Axis powers used radio for coded communication and espionage, and radio broadcasting for propaganda. In the Philippines, Filipinos listened to Japanese-controlled radio—the only broadcasting sanctioned during the period—but also monitored underground signals emanating from resistance groups broadcasting within and outside the country. No matter the intent of the Japanese in promoting Tagalog and Filipino music, the strategy may have aided the growth of Tagalog and other Filipino languages on radio after the war, as well as the increased airtime devoted to Filipino music.

 

The only officially permitted radio signals came from PIAM, which the people listened to, as it paid to know the enemy propaganda, but at the same time they maligned. PIAM, to some, stood for “Putang Ina Ang Maniwala!,” which roughly translates to “He who believes [the radio propaganda] is a son of a bitch!” (Ampil 1986; Malay 1984).

 

Many prewar broadcasters avoided recruitment by PIAM, among them Koko Trinidad and Lamberto Avellana, who acted as couriers for guerrillas.

 

KGEI was a critical source of news from the United States. Its programs were intended specifically for the Filipino audience. Particularly popular was the program of Carmen Ligaya, who was KGEI’s answer to NHK’s Tokyo Rose. Guerrilla groups in the rural areas as well as individuals in the cities who had access to shortwave radio clandestinely transcribed KGEI broadcasts for underground circulation. Those who were found out by the Japanese and their Filipino agents paid with their lives or suffered torture.

 

The American military forces under Gen Douglas MacArthur were the first to operate several radio facilities in the Philippines toward the end of World War II following the silence of the Japanese-controlled PIAM at the close of 1944. MacArthur integrated the remaining few into one station in Manila with the call letters KZFM, first managed by the Office of War Information of the US Department of National Defense, then turned over to the newly organized USIS under the US State Department. Later that year, several other American military broadcast stations began operating, among them WVLC, WVTM, and the US Armed Forces Radio Service, signaling to Filipinos that the Americans were back by airing familiar American music and other programs.

 

The Period of the Third Republic (1945-72)

 

Politics, Commerce, and Broadcasting. The years following World War II witnessed politics and economics bonding together again to highly influence the direction of Philippine broadcasting. Businessmen brothers Joaquin Miguel Elizalde and Manuel Elizalde were the first to operate a radio station in early 1946. They purchased Samuel Gaches’s H. E. Heacock Co, which owned the KZRH of the American period, and called their new enterprise the Manila Broadcasting Company. Another station, KZPI (PI for Philippine Islands), also acquired a permit to go on test broadcast in early 1946. It was operated by the Philippine Broadcasting Corporation, the new name of the prewar Far East Broadcasting Corporation (FEBC), which used to run KZRM and KZRF. J. Amado Araneta, who owned FEBC before the war, took on new partners Leo Prieto, Jose Avelino, Jack Preysler, and Andres Soriano, and formed PBC. Also in 1946, during the second anniversary of MacArthur’s landing on Leyte on 20 Oct, the USIS turned over KZFM to the new Philippine government’s Department of Foreign Affairs, the secretary of which was Elpidio Quirino. In 1947, Roxas moved the station to the Philippine Broadcasting Service (PBS), which he created as a unit under the Office of the President. PBS then grew into a nationwide network of government broadcast stations.

 

Soon after putting KZRH on the air, MBC acquired a franchise for another station, KZMB. PBC, on the other hand, put up KZOK in addition to KZPI. Not long after the inaugural broadcast of KZOK, the Elizaldes acquired PBC, which had KZPI and KZOK in Manila, and KZBU in Cebu, and became the most powerful broadcast operators from the late 1940s until television came in 1953. Araneta bowed out of broadcasting. Isaac Beck revived KZIB but it folded up after just a few months.

 

Many radio stations, owned by religious groups, educational institutions, and new industry players, mushroomed during the period. Cebu was again the site of the first radio stations outside Manila. In 1947, KZRC, operated by MBC affiliate Cebu Broadcasting Company (CBC), went on the air.

 

Television in the country was born in 1953, just eight years into the new Republic. Americans, as well as Filipinos, invested in the rising broadcast industry. James Lindenberg, an American entrepreneur who operated in Manila, established in 1946 the Bolinao Electronics Corporation (BEC), a company that manufactured radio transmitters and similar electronic devices. His franchise to operate a radio and television station was granted by Congress in 1950, but he focused on radio because of strict import controls that made it difficult to operate a television facility.

 

The period saw a noticeable increase in the number of Filipinos staking their claim on the operation of radio and television. Former trial court judge Antonio Quirino established the first television station in the Philippines. He bought 70 percent of BEC from Lindenberg, renamed BEC as Alto Broadcasting Company (ABS) with call letters DZAQ, which was finally given a permit to import equipment to transmit television signals on Channel 3 in 1952. The television station went on the air in 1953, mainly as a major political machinery to support the presidential reelection bid of Antonio’s brother, President Elpidio, who, however, lost in the Nov 1953 national elections.

 

The business elites, some of whom were also into print journalism, established the major television networks during the period. The Canoy brothers founded Radio Mindanao Network (RMN) in Cagayan de Oro City in 1952. American businessman Dick Baldwin started operating the Inter-island Broadcasting Corporation (IBC) TV Channel 13 in 1960. The Elizaldes expanded to television, putting up MBC-TV Channel 11 in 1962. Businessman Andres Soriano Sr, who also owned the Philippines Herald, bought both IBC-TV 13 from Baldwin as well as the controlling interest in RMN in 1962.

 

Eugenio Lopez Sr of Iloilo City, who owned the daily newspaper Manila Chronicle, obtained a franchise to operate the Chronicle Broadcasting Network (CBN) in 1955, began the broadcast of its radio station CBN-DZXL in 1956, bought ABS from Quirino and Lindenberg in 1957, and merged their radio and television stations to establish ABS-CBN in 1961. Like the Quirinos, the Lopezes had very powerful political connections. Eugenio Sr’s brother, Fernando, was a member of the Senate at the time they were establishing their broadcasting network and was vice president of the Philippines in 1965, under Ferdinand Marcos as president, both of whom were under the Nacionalista Party (NP).

 

The Roces family, which published the Manila Times, the leading newspaper of the country in the two decades prior to the martial law period, began their family’s television enterprise under the Associated Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) in 1960, using the call letters DZMT and the Channel 5 slot. Joaquin “Chino” Roces, the helmsman of the daily and the television station, would become a staunch critic of the Marcos administration.

 

American war correspondent Robert “Bob” Stewart established DZBB Radio in 1950, DZXX in 1955, and DZBB-TV Channel 7 in 1961. The broadcast network changed its name to Republic Broadcasting System (RBS) in 1963, then to Greater Manila Area (GMA) Channel 7 during the martial law period. Stewart was seen as a supporter of reelectionist president Carlos P. Garcia of the NP in the Nov 1961 elections. It may be noted that DZBB-TV obtained its franchise under the Garcia administration. When Diosdado Macapagal of the Liberal Party defeated Garcia in the 1961 presidential elections, Malacañan took steps to have Stewart deported from the country.

 

Roberto S. Benedicto, who owned the Philippine Daily Express and had substantial investments in the sugar industry in Negros Occidental and in the Traders Commercial Bank, put station DZKB on the air under the Kanlaon Broadcasting System (KBS) in 1960 and KBS TV Channel 9 in 1969. Benedicto enjoyed the full trust and confidence of Ferdinand Marcos, a close friend in law school and college fraternity brother in the University of the Philippines (UP), who in 1965 was elected president of the Philippines.

 

Government Regulation and Intervention. Major shifts unfolded after the war. The call letters of broadcast stations changed soon after the inauguration of the Third Philippine Republic in 1946. Having been declared independent, the Philippines was given call letters, replacing the American call letters “KZ.” The International Telecommunications Union (ITU) in New Jersey, USA, took a punitive stance against “KZ” for Nazi Germany’s misuse of radio during the war. The Union then distributed the call letter “D” to several newly independent countries, including the Philippines, removing from Germany the exclusive use of the call letter. Thus, KZFM became DZFM, KZRH became DZRH, and so on. Later the Philippine government assigned secondary letters based on location—DZ for stations based in Luzon, DY in the Visayas, and DX in Mindanao. DW was later given to FM stations in Luzon.

 

Many prewar laws were restored, including Act 3846, or the Radio Control Act of 1931, which regulated radio stations and radio communications in the Philippines. The law was also applied to television stations. The law required radio stations to obtain a legislative franchise as a prerequisite to operation, thus effectively shifting the power to grant broadcast franchises from the Office of the President back to the legislature. The law permitted ownership of media businesses not only by Filipinos but also Americans.

 

Programming and Program Formats. Postwar broadcasting in the Philippines bore a strong imprint of American colonial broadcasting. American music and talk, as well as the new format of soap opera, fueled by advertising, filled the air. News and news commentary increased in significance as Filipinos continued to hunger for credible news that was in short supply during the war. English returned as the dominant language of broadcasting, while Tagalog maintained a clear and growing presence. Other Filipino languages also flourished on the air as new radio stations began to operate outside Manila, mindful of the audience expecting broadcasters to speak their tongue. This trend extended to music played on radio and later on television as the Philippine recording industry was born and began to press records of local talent singing traditional Filipino songs and more recent local compositions as well as covers of foreign songs. The first successful commercial FM station in the country, DZFX of the Makati Broadcasting Network, broadcast mood music, film soundtracks, and period pieces with high fidelity stereophonic sound.

 

Audiences multiplied as the number of radio stations grew phenomenally, including noncommercial stations operated by government and religious organizations. The popularity of radio was bolstered by the introduction and eventual increase in the production and distribution of transistor radios, which became a regular household item all over the country, in both urban and rural areas. By the 1950s, the era called “golden years of radio” was underway, which lasted until the unspeakable era of martial law began in 1972. With radio and television becoming widely accepted by audiences, the period saw the rise of radio and television personalities as national celebrities, gaining the stature of public figures.

 

Program formats became varied. The attractiveness of musical programs to Filipino audiences bred the amateur singing contest format, which includes Purico Troubadours, Purico Show, Purico Amateur Hour, and Tawag ng Tanghalan (Call of the Stage). A program type that emerged after the war was the personality platter show in which an announcer, later called disc jockey or the DJ, played selected music records and engaged the listeners in a light chat. The Philippine Broadcasting System began airing educational programs in the 1950s, mostly about agriculture, but it was in the 1960s that the program type gained popularity and became part of regular programming of several AM stations. Radio dramas, called soaps or soap operas, came in several formats: the melodrama, the situational comedy or sitcom, the sitcom cum satire, horror or fantasy and science fiction narratives, and the occasional detective drama. Ilaw ng Tahanan (Light of the Home), written by Liwayway Arceo, was the first postwar soap, which began airing on DZRH in 1949. DZRH later produced the highly popular drama series Gulong ng Palad (Wheel of Fate) by Lina Flor. Among the most remarkable drama anthologies on television were ABC Channel 5’s Balintataw (The Mind’s Eye), Salamisim (Reflections), and Santa Zita and Mary Rose. The first horror program on television was Hiwaga sa Bahay na Bato (Mystery in the House of Stone). The action-detective format was best exemplified by Kwatro Bidas (Four Heroes). The sitcom was best represented by Tang-Tarang-Tang. A new format of the counseling genre, in English, went on the air in 1957; this was Father Bob and His Telephone hosted by Bob Garon. The variety show, a mélange of musical performances, comic skits, and light banter among hosts and guests, was a popular genre on radio and later on television. Popular examples of the variety program were the daily noontime program Student Canteen on DZXL-TV Channel 9 and the weekly variety show Buhay Artista (Actor’s Life) on Channel 3. Derivatives of the variety show genre, programs with music and dance, were popular, such as An Evening with Pilita on Channel 3. A pioneer of the daily morning talk show was the news-magazine program The Morning Show. The most popular of the game shows in the 1960s was Kuarta o Kahon (Cash or Box) on ABS-CBN. There were also children’s educational and entertainment programs, such as Eskuwelahang Munti (Little Schoolhouse) on RBS Channel 7. News and news commentary increased in significance, with Rafael Yabut as one of the most well-remembered radio commentators and ABS-CBN’s DZAQ and Radyo Patrol (Patrol Radio) as one of the highly rated news programs.

 

News commentators on television were likewise critical of the administration, including Luis Beltran on Channel 11 and Jose Ma. Velez on Channel 5. Television stations also showed imported canned programs, some of which were animated. Local and foreign movies were also shown on television.

 

The period witnessed the initial recognition of broadcasting as an art through the establishment of the first awards for meritorious works, given from 1965 to 1972 by the Citizens Awards for Television or CAT of the Citizens’ Council for Mass Media, formerly called the Citizens’ Council for Better Motion Pictures Television Committee.

 

One of the crucial roles played by broadcasting during the period was its use in politics. Until the simultaneous declaration of Philippine independence from the United States and the inauguration of Pres Manuel Roxas in 1946, radio coverage of political events focused only on similar ceremonial political occasions and on war reporting in connection with World War II. Radio became a powerful tool by the government in its campaign against the communist Hukbong Mapagpalaya ng Bayan (HMB), a peasant organization established in 1950. The HMB, with a strong foothold in Central Luzon, sprang from the Hukbo ng Bayan Laban sa Hapon or Hukbalahap movement during the Japanese occupation. In 1953, the use of broadcasting for partisan politics began when radio, as well as the newly inaugurated DZAQ Channel 3, was mobilized for the election campaign for the presidency. This set a pattern for subsequent political contests.


Criticality and Protest. While program content in general was tacitly supportive of the status quo, broadcasting, along with newspapers and magazines, served as media of critical social and political commentary through news and public affairs programs and even entertainment programs like dramas and sitcoms. For example, Kuwentong Kutsero (Tall Tales), which first aired in 1938 before the war and went on until the 1960s, interrupted only by the Japanese occupation, combined satire with comedy-drama and spoofed Filipino manners, politics, customs, and government.

 

The press freedom of the period, sometimes criticized as licentious, was practiced more openly in news and news commentary, which helped heighten the audience’s sense of vigilance and interest in local as well as global politics and economics. Broadcast media, which chronicled, analyzed, and critiqued political events in the country, intensely played its role as the so-called watchdog of those who ran the government and others in power. This was not to last, however, with the imposition of martial law in 1972.

 

The Period of the Fourth Republic (1972-86)

 

Government Regulation and Intervention. A major step in the execution of martial law was the closure of the media companies, with the exception of the Philippines Daily Express and the KBS (later RPN) broadcast facilities, that was specified in Letter of Instruction 1, which directed the secretaries of the Department of National Defense and the Department of Public Information to take over and control all media in the country. The Philippine Constabulary carried out their directives. Also in 1972, Pres Marcos issued Presidential Decree (PD) 36, which canceled all legislative franchises issued by Congress to radio and television stations prior to the proclamation of martial law, with the Mass Media Council (MMC) serving as a clearing house. Marcos also made it unconstitutional for foreigners to own and operate the media, including broadcast networks, effectively Filipinizing ownership of Philippine media for the first time. In Jan 1973, Marcos announced that the 1973 Constitution was approved by the people. To erase the impression that the military was in charge of the regulation of the media under martial law, the president issued PD 191, which replaced the MMC with the Mass Media Advisory Council (MMAC), this time composed of more civilian members. MMAC, however, was later abolished and its powers were transferred to two distinct bodies—namely, the Philippine Council for Print Media (PCPM) and the Broadcast Media Council (BMC). The technical aspects of broadcast media operations, such as transmitter strength and frequency assignments, were regulated by the Radio Control Office, replaced in 1974 by the Telecommunications Control Bureau. Marcos issued Executive Order (EO) 546 in 1979, vesting in the National Telecommunications Commission regulatory powers regarding technical matters over the broadcast media.

 

An important development was the creation in 1973 of an association of broadcast media owners, the Kapisanan ng mga Brodkaster sa Pilipinas (KBP), which served as a self-regulatory body of the industry. Broadcast news, accountable to Marcos, was monitored and censored by the Office of Civil Affairs. As expected, they were not allowed to criticize the Marcos administration. All broadcast programs were monitored by the government’s Board of Censors, which did not allow programs or parts of programs that were considered politically or morally unfit for broadcast. The Lumauig Bill threatened to limit the free expression of artists.

 

The lifting of martial law by the president in 1981 carried with it the abolition of the PCPM and the BMC, which, however, did not automatically mean full freedom for the broadcast media. Any broadcaster who created trouble could be charged with subversion and detained indefinitely. Marcos already had his cronies running the media, and other similar repressive laws remained in place, such as the Arrest, Search and Seizure Order, the National Security Act, and the Public Order Act, all of which deal with people who undermined the objectives of Marcos’s New Society, specifically those deemed by the government as obscene, rebellious, and seditious.

 

The main form of regulation in the broadcast media (and the film industry) was by censorship, which was mainly a function of the Board of Censors for Motion Pictures, created through Republic Act 3060 in 1961, later renamed Board of Review for Motion Pictures, Television and Live Entertainment through EO 868 in 1983, then finally to Board of Review for Motion Pictures and Television (BRMPT) through EO 876, also in 1983. The banning for public exhibition of the Lino Brocka film Bayan Ko: Kapit sa Patalim (My Country: Gripping the Knife’s Edge) by the BRMPT in 1984 sent the message to media practitioners, especially those in the broadcasting industry, that the Marcos dictatorship, in spite of the growing protest movement following the assassination of oppositionist Benigno Aquino Jr in 1983, still had full control of what it can allow to be shown to the public. From censorship, the move proceeded to classification, which applied to all broadcast materials. The BRMPT was abolished with the creation of the Movie and Television Review and Classification Board (MTRCB), created through Presidential Decree 1986 in 1985.

 

Transnational Broadcasting. During the martial law period, the broadcast media industry, as part of the bigger telecommunications industry, functioned as a conduit of transnational advertising and capital operating under Marcos’s crony capitalism. The telecommunications industry became one of the most concentrated areas of business ownership and one of the primary generators of foreign investments in the country. Crony companies had to tie up with foreign conglomerates because of the capital-intensive building of mass media and telecommunications infrastructures.

 

Major players in the telecommunications industry had close ties with Marcos. Media mogul Roberto S. Benedicto expanded the nationwide reach of his television network, RPN, through domestic satellite communications or DOMSAT, which was supplied mainly by Marubeni, a Japanese television manufacturer. RPN eventually attracted transnational corporations for its advertisements. Benedicto was also one of the principal partners of Eastern Telecommunications Philippines (ETPI), which was granted by the Marcos government the exclusive rights to the communications market of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations. ETPI’s top user was the US military. Ramon Cojuangco, the pro-Marcos wing of the landed Cojuangco family, owned the Philippine Long Distance Telephone Company (PLDT), which had million-dollar contracts with General Telephone and Electronics (GTE) Corporation of the United States and Siemens' Corporation of the Federal Republic of Germany for electronic switching equipment. PLDT’s principal international toll users were hotels and foreign oil companies. Both Benedicto and Cojuangco, together with Marcos defense minister Juan Ponce Enrile, were principal partners in the Philippine Communications Satellite (Philcomsat), which had the US military as its largest and single-end user. Another major player was Philippine Communications Corporation (Philcom) of Radio Corporation of America (RCA), nominally headed by former ambassador to the United States Ernesto V. Lagdameo, with Enrile and energy minister Geronimo Z. Velasco among its major stockholders. Among Philcom’s largest wideband users were the US military, Pan Am, and IBM, while its narrowband users were US and Japanese transnational corporations. The family of Zobel de Ayala was a major business partner in the International Telephone and Telegraph (ITT) Corporation of Globe-Mackay Radio Corporation. ITT operated several telephone and communications systems.

 

The telecommunications industry linked the so-called offshore operations that foreign investments established in the Philippines into the centers of these operations in industrialized countries. The industry, with interlocking local and global interests, made it possible for these investments to market their products and services under the full protection and support of the Marcos government. The expansion of international capital informed the transnationalization of the broadcast media, which, in turn, fed into the strategic development goals of the Marcos government that favored the concentration of capital among friendly members of the elite, which would later be termed as crony capitalism.

 

Television specials hosted by the Philippine government that had simultaneous international broadcasts were the 23rd Miss Universe Pageant in 1974 and Thrilla in Manila, the third and final boxing match between Muhammad Ali and Joe Frazier in 1975, both of which were broadcast live by RPN 9.

 

Programming and Program Formats. Radio AM programming during the period was predominantly entertainment, consisting of soaps, personality programs, and music, which was mainly foreign. The AM band catered primarily to audiences of the lower socioeconomic class. Top AM music stations during the period were DWBL, DWKW, and DZRJ-AM in Metro Manila, and DYRC, DYHP, DYGB, DYFM, DYBU, and DYLA in the Visayas.

 

FM radio stations with a music orientation began to flourish during the martial law period. Among different sectors of the broadcast industry, FM radio was the least affected by the political situation of the country mainly because it concentrated on music programming that aired politically safe music pieces. Various program formats began to emerge: adult contemporary; easy listening, middle-of-the-road, pop music programming; contemporary hit radio or the Top 40 format; and album-oriented programming. During the end of the martial law period, niche programming became the prevailing pattern, with FM radio stations targeting specific audiences. With DWRT 99.5 trailblazing the trend, a number of other format-oriented radio stations soon followed suit and eventually made a mark in Philippine FM radio history.

 

The KBP and the Broadcast Media Council issued a regulation requiring all radio stations to play on the air what were called original Pilipino music (OPM), which referred to a song or piece composed by a Filipino, or any song or piece performed by a Filipino, or a song or piece composed by a Filipino but performed by a foreigner. Before martial law, popular Filipino music referred primarily to folk songs and the kundiman. OPM during martial law took on a more distinctively younger sound, incorporating elements of Filipino culture with pop, jazz, folk, and rock music. This paved the way for the birth of “The Manila Sound.” The move challenged the dominance of foreign music and talents. Beginning with one song per program hour in 1975, the requirement was brought up to four in 1982. From the mid-1970s until the middle of the 1980s, local composers, singers, and musicians enjoyed unprecedented exposure on radio and achieved a measure of maturity in their craft. As a result of that broadcasting rule, the local recording industry enjoyed tremendous growth.

 

Development communication was stressed during the martial law years. Educational programs were produced to push the concept of development communication, such as Ating Alamin (Let Us Find Out) and Tele-Aralan ng Kakayahan (Knowledge Educational TV). The concept of development communication extended to the government’s effort to usher in what it termed as renaissance programming in Philippine broadcasting, which meant bringing “culture” closer to the people by airing educational and cultural programs during prime time. The idea of renaissance television, unfortunately, was not commercially viable and it was soon forgotten.

 

On news programming, BBC went on the air in 1973 and introduced BBC Balita (BBC News), the first primetime news program in Filipino after the declaration of martial law; it would later be given a new title, Balita Ngayon (News Today), which would become the only news program in Filipino until the launch of TV Patrol on ABS-CBN in 1987 following the ouster of Marcos.

 

Public affairs news programs followed two tracks. Government-produced talk shows, such as Pulong-Pulong sa Kaunlaran (Public Forum for Development) and Face the Nation, spoke positively about the government and its officials. Critically mild public affairs talk programs came out, such as Jullie Yap Daza’s Tell the People on RPN 9 and Ricardo “Dong” Puno Jr’s Viewpoint on GMA 7. Charity shows were the trend in many public service programs, such as Damayan (Helping One Another) and Kapwa Ko, Mahal Ko (I Love My Fellowman). On radio, DZRH launched the after-midnight program Operation Tulong (Operation Assistance). These shows assisted those in need of all kinds of help, mainly medical.

 

Variety programs were plentiful during the martial law period, which were a mix of musical numbers and interviews with personalities; some had segments on games or contests usually promoted by commercial sponsors. On television, Student Canteen and Eat Bulaga! (Lunchtime Peek-a-Boo!) dominated the noontime programming, while Ariel con Tina (Ariel with Tina) was a favorite in the early evening time slot. Nora Aunor thrilled her fans with the weekly musical show Superstar, Joe Quirino hosted the musical variety-talk show Seeing Stars with JQ, and star builder German Moreno started his series of entertainment programs, like Germside, later retitled Germspesyal, then GMA Supershow. Prominent, but often maligned, television entertainment programs were Inday Badiday’s Nothing but the Truth, Would You Believe?, and See-True. Late-night talk magazine programs include Two for the Road, Ms. Ellaneous, Tell the People, and Something with Pilita. Excellent magazine programs were the morning show Good Morning, Manila, which featured personalities, the weather, sports, and other cultural facts, but less on news, and Metro Magazine, a combination of talk, travelogue, and mini-documentaries.

 

Comedy shows that became extremely popular during the period were the sitcoms John en Marsha (John and Marsha), featuring Dolphy and Nida Blanca, and Iskul Bukol (School Bumps) of the triumvirate of Tito, Vic, and Joey. The show that attracted the higher end of TV audiences was the social commentary-cum-gag show Champoy of Noel Trinidad, Subas Herrero, Gary Lising, Tessie Tomas, and Mitch Valdes. Socially relevant sitcoms Baltic & Co., Juan Tamad (Lazy Juan), and Prinsipe Abante (Prince Abante) went on the air, but did not enjoy the popularity of most family sitcoms. A relevant comedy that became highly popular was “Doña Buding,” a stand-up gag segment of the live weekly music variety program Penthouse Live. An interesting socially satirical sitcom produced during the waning years of the Marcos administration until the early years of the post-EDSA period was U.F.O.: Urbana, Felisa, and Others.

 

Philippine drama programs on television during the martial law period were weekly one-hour melodrama anthologies, followed later on by daily serials. Some weekly television drama anthologies that followed the social realist tradition started by the pre-martial law Balintataw were those produced by Armida Siguion-Reyna, such as Maskara (Mask), Rosas (Rose), and Ilaw ng Tahanan (Light of the Home). Siguion-Reyna also produced Malayo Pa ang Umaga (The Morn Is Yet So Far) in 1979, aired weekly on RPN 9. The drama could be considered the first miniseries on Philippine television, later to be billed telenovela in the 2000s. Other noteworthy drama anthologies include Lino Brocka Presents, Panata (Oath), Tipanan (Rendezvous), Alindog (Allure), Katha (Stories), Hiyas (Gem), Mga Kuwento ng Pag-ibig (Stories of Love), Tanghalan (Stage), and Dahong Ginto (Golden Leaf). The daily serialized drama on television was introduced in 1977 via Gulong ng Palad, reincarnated from the daily radio soap of the same title created by writer Lina Flor that aired on DZRH during the postwar period. The period also witnessed the stiff competition of two daily late afternoon soaps that each featured children: Flordeluna on RPN 9 and Anna Liza on GMA 7. Weekly drama anthologies during the period relied less on good narrative than on the audience-drawing power of stars. Ang Makulay na Daigdig ni Nora (The Colorful World of Nora) and Coney Reyes-Mumar Drama Studio showed gems in some of their episodes. Many weekly television drama programs featured real-life stories of viewers who sent in their narratives to popular counseling programs, such as Eddie Ilarde’s Kahapon Lamang (Just Yesterday) and Helen Vela’s Lovingly Yours, Helen. Some of the directors of these television drama programs were Lino Brocka, Ishmael Bernal, Mario O’Hara, Maryo J. de los Reyes, Romy Suzara, Elwood Perez, Joey Gosiengfiao, Nick Lizaso, and Tony Santos Sr.

 

Important music and dance programs were Aawitan Kita (I Shall Sing for You), At Long Last, Celeste!, Sunday Sweet Sunday, Concert at the Park, Paco Park Presents, Return Engagement, Discorama, and Penthouse Seven. Noteworthy directors of musical variety programs were Mitos Villareal, Fritz Ynfante, and Al Quinn. Local children’s shows were more entertainment in orientation, and the themes revolved around discipline, cooperation, and the nationalism of the New Society. Examples were Kaluskos Musmos (Kiddie Noise), Kulit Bulilit (Curious Children), and Uncle Bob’s Lucky 7 Club. A pioneer of culinary shows was Cooking It Up with Nora.

 

Canned programs, usually dramas, comedies, action, religious, musicals, children’s educational, and animation came from the United States and the United Kingdom; dramas, action, and musicals from China; and, later, animation from Japan. All these programs were well-received by Filipino audiences. Notable were the educational program Sesame Street and the animated program Voltes V.

 

Subversions, Protest, and the Revival of Democracy. When Marcos imposed martial law in 1972, the first institution he emasculated was the media, closing down all broadcast and print facilities except those of his allies, and allowing their reopening only under strict control and monitoring. This was the state of the media until resistance and protest began to build up again.

 

During the height of martial law in the 1970s, mainstream media, controlled by those with economic and political power, was either lying about the conditions of the country or reluctant to report events that run counter to the stance of government. During the waning years of the Marcos dictatorship beginning in the early 1980s, mainstream commercial and government media continued to lie or limit the expanse of truth. During this period, the technology of orality and the alternatives proffered by progressive groups became more reliable than the technology of “hard” electronic equipment for people in areas with limited or no access to mainstream media. These various forms of “narrowcasting” by the underprivileged and the politically marginalized served as a parallel form of broadcasting.

 

Marginalized and socially underprivileged groups, such as peasants, indigenous peoples, and workers, relied on traditional folk media to “broadcast” news and analyses about their locality. Folk communication and literary forms were revitalized, infused with liberative messages. Progressive artists produced video and film documentaries that exposed human rights violations, poverty, and the corruption of the Marcos regime and the role of the United States in the political affairs of the country. Foremost among these artists were those who formed in 1982 the alternative video group Asia Visions. Protest theater on the stage and on the streets became the more reliable outlet than broadcast media for the discussion of contemporary social issues.

 

When Marcos oppositionist leader Ninoy Aquino was gunned down at the tarmac of the Manila International Airport in 1983, local commercial media, especially the broadcast networks, were not considered the site of reliable news. The search for the truth was played out elsewhere, this time mainly on Betamax units at home and in offices. Betamax tapes recorded mainly by people abroad enabled the Filipinos to view Aquino’s assassination.

 

While only Radio Veritas gave complete coverage of Aquino’s fateful arrival, other networks found the courage to present some news and commentary about the murdered man on whom so many Filipinos had pinned their hopes. Though GMA 7 dared only show eight seconds of Aquino’s 10-hour funeral rites, with millions paying tribute, on its primetime news, the network’s Two for the Road devoted 15 minutes to a special honoring Aquino and showed more scenes from his funeral. On the same channel, Ricardo “Dong” Puno’s talk program Viewpoint carried an interview with newly widowed Corazon Aquino. Orly Mercado produced and hosted a GMA exclusive on the Marcos hidden wealth.

 

Inspired by Veritas, other radio stations in both Manila and the provinces grew more daring in expressing opposition to the regime. Before long, Philippine broadcasting’s huge potential to tilt the balance of political power saw its transformation into an actual movement for social change in the years leading to the EDSA Revolt in 1986. This was instigated by widespread belief of cheating in the 1986 elections, in which Marcos and his vice-presidential running mate were announced to have won. The people openly protested, and Juan Ponce Enrile and Gen Fidel Ramos of the military turned against Marcos. People responded to the plea of Jaime Cardinal Sin on Radio Veritas to show support for these men by gathering on EDSA. Broadcast, movie, and theater personalities, one of whom was June Keithley, rallied the people to join the military mutineers through Radio Veritas and then on DZRJ, dubbed Radyo Bandido, when the former’s facilities were destroyed by the military. The EDSA Revolt, while beginning as a shooting battle between military coup plotters and state defenders, was principally a battle over airwaves, ultimately won by achieving freedom to broadcast to the people. The Marcos regime was brought to an end by the EDSA Revolt mobilized by radio messages. And broadcast media regained its freedom along with the Filipino people.

 

The Period of the Fifth Republic (1986 Onward)

 

Politics, Commerce, and Broadcasting. Three important developments contributed to the growth of Philippine broadcasting beginning in the 1990s. These were the move toward decentralization, resulting in the growth of provincial media, the rapid revolution in communication technology, and the liberalization and deregulation of the telecommunications sector. These developments coincided with the return and expansion of the democratic space after the EDSA Revolt, and the promotion and protection of the free enterprise system.

 

One of the first acts of Corazon Aquino as president of what was called a “revolutionary” government was to sequester broadcast networks RPN 9, IBC 13, and BBC 2, media outlets believed to have been illegally acquired by Marcos cronies and relatives.

 

Because of the capital-intensive nature of media and the low return on investment of newspapers and broadcast networks, media ownership remained in the hands of individuals and families engaged in diverse business interests. The Elizaldes continued the broadcast of their radio network, the Manila Broadcasting Company. The Lopezes recovered and relaunched ABS-CBN in 1986. RBS was later changed to Greater Manila Area (GMA) Radio Television Arts by its triumvirate owners Gilberto M. Duavit Sr, Felipe L. Gozon, and Menardo R. Jimenez. Both ABS-CBN and GMA would lord over the ratings game, which defined the character of commercial broadcasting of the post-EDSA period. Telecommunications mogul Manuel “MVP” Pangilinan bought TV5 of the Associated Broadcasting Company. The early years of the post-EDSA period saw the rise of the big conglomerates, with broadcast networks, some of which were already into energy production and public utilities, expanding to other ventures, such as movie production, music recording, publications, cable television, and global telecommunications. Later, those involved in other interests, such as mining, would also get involved in broadcasting.

 

Government Regulation and Intervention. The adoption of the 1987 Philippine Constitution was the most significant development during the Aquino administration. It institutionalized the Filipinization of mass media, mainly in terms of media ownership, retaining the provision on 100 percent ownership of mass media by Filipinos, one of the legacies of Marcos.

 

Executive Order 205, issued in 1987, governs the regulation of cable antenna television or CATV and requires a network to obtain a certificate of authority to operate for not more than 15 years, which can be renewed for a similar period. The Kapisanan ng mga Brodkaster ng Pilipinas (KBP) continued to regulate the broadcast industry, but since membership was no longer compulsory, its regulation applied only to its members. Individual networks and stations have started to internally regulate themselves, but only ABS-CBN and GMA and the online platform Rappler have full-time ombudspersons in charge of monitoring and regulating their programs, journalists, and staff. Two important state agencies continued to regulate broadcast media content: the Movie and Television Review and Classification Board (MTRCB), which screens and classifies TV programs, commercials, and publicity materials according to audiences; and the Presidential Appeals Board, which addresses issues raised by parties pertaining to decisions made by the MTRCB.

 

Remnants of Marcos’s censorship continued to haunt the regulation of the broadcast media. The MTRCB under Manoling Morato banned the 55-minute TV documentary Dear Sam … Sumasaiyo, Juan (Dear Sam … Yours, Juan), 1989, for its resolute anti-US bases position. The prohibition raised multisectoral protests. The issue became the subject of a Senate investigation, which ruled in favor of airing the TV special. It also gave a two-week suspension to television documentary i-Witness in 2006 after it showed an episode titled “Lukayo: Hindi Ito Bastos” (Lukayo: This Is Not Vulgar), on lukayo, a wedding practice in a town in Laguna wherein carvings of phalluses are used by old ladies in performing a dance.

 

Transnational Broadcasting. The post-EDSA period saw a different turn in the transnationalization of Philippine broadcasting. With the diaspora becoming a significant phenomenon for Filipinos, local media networks responded to the transnational presence and diasporic experiences of Filipino audiences in various parts of the globe. ABS-CBN’s The Filipino Channel, formed in 1994, was the Lopez company’s response to the ever-growing demand of overseas Filipinos for news on the Philippines and Filipino television and film productions. GMA Pinoy TV broadcasts GMA shows to North America, East Asia, the Middle East, and Africa. Its most lucrative market is Southeast Asia where Filipino TV drama productions are avidly followed. TV5 Network Inc has formed Kapatid TV5 to distribute Kapatid TV and Aksyon TV shows to its clients in the United States, Middle East, North Africa, and Guam.

 

Filipino TV productions became popular with foreign audiences. When broadcast in other countries, shows were given subtitles and not dubbed, unlike Latin and Asian telenovelas that were brought into the Philippines. The soap opera Pangako Sa ’Yo (The Promise) was exported to Southeast Asia and East Africa, where it was a hit. The longest-running daily noontime show Eat Bulaga! has been franchised by a leading television network in Indonesia, to which it exports all its contents and segments.

 

Programming and Program Formats. AM radio stations after the 1986 EDSA Revolt continued to be providers mainly of news and information. Most AM stations either strengthened their news programming or completely shifted from entertainment to news and public affairs. These stations created their respective news departments. They enhanced their newscasts with more voice clips, spot reports, and live or phone-patched interviews. The format, however, remained mainly news and talk.

 

FM radio continued to be oriented toward music and entertainment. The Top 40 format, also known as contemporary hit radio, which was a major trend in the 1970s, began to lose its appeal to radio audiences during the post-EDSA period, mainly due to the innovations in programming introduced by many stations that preferred niche programming, a type of programming that targets specific audience groups. English remained the main language used in most FM radio stations, but there was a rise in the number of bilingual FM stations, appealing to a broader market. By the mid-1990s, talk-oriented programs slowly crept into the FM programming scene, caused primarily by the need to get more listeners, particularly the so-called masa (mass) group composed of the C, D, and E economic classes, which comprise the bulk of the radio-listening public. The A and B markets began shifting to more high-end electronic equipment, downloading music onto their new mobile devices without the need for an FM radio station. A milestone in the history of Philippine FM radio was the entry of Media Quest Holdings Inc, led by telecommunications mogul Manuel “MVP” Pangilinan, into FM radio in 2010 via 92.3 News Radio, aka Radyo Singko (Radio Five), a news and talk-oriented radio component of TV5 of the Associated Broadcasting Company.

 

The phenomenal program that significantly altered local television programming was Marimar which aired in 1996 on RPN 9. The success of Marimar provided the impetus for broadcast networks to produce daily drama serials in the early evening primetime programming, the first of which were the back-to-back tandem of ABS-CBN’s 30-minute drama series Mula sa Puso (From the Heart) and Esperanza, both from 1997 to 1999. Mara Clara, ABS-CBN’s popular daily series in the afternoon slot, was also moved to the early evening programming. By the late 1990s, the daily drama serials, either locally produced or imported, started to flood the airwaves, with Latin American telenovelas dominating the evening programming. Telenovelas are limited-run drama serials. Later chinovelas (Chinese telenovelas) from Taiwan, such as Meteor Garden, and koreanovelas from Korea, such as Full House and Jewel in the Palace, flooded the evening primetime programming in the 2000s. All these new imported drama serials, together with Japanese anime programs, were dubbed in Filipino.

 

Entertainment talk and variety programs took the late morning and early afternoon time slots. Documentaries and public affairs programs were relegated to the late evening block, some of which were canceled, moved to weekend programming, or transferred to free UHF channels.

 

News programs were especially valued after the 1986 EDSA Revolt as it was believed that people could expect the shows to give them the truth now, unlike in martial law. ABS-CBN was foremost in presenting news in Filipino, reviving their Balita Ngayon, which was to become TV Patrol. News and public affairs programs, including entertainment news, on VHF adopted a combination of information and entertainment in their format, but were, and continue to be, tabloid in character filled with stories of crime, violence, and mundane celebrity trivia that bordered on sensationalism, all in the rush for scoops. In spite of the trend toward sensationalism, a significant development in news reporting beginning in the late 1990s and the 2000 onward was the war coverage of leading broadcast media companies. It has since become imperative for Philippine broadcast media to achieve coverage of several events happening outside the country, present the geopolitical implications of worldwide developments, and analyze the impact of such events on Filipinos scattered all over the globe.

 

A significant development during the post-EDSA period was the entry of civil society groups into the broadcast scene, first on radio, then on TV. Commercial networks relied on these blocktimers to fill in the airtime with relevant programs, such as the documentaries Dear Sam … Sumasaiyo, Juan (Dear Sam … Yours, Juan) and Batas Militar (Martial Law); the drama anthologies Direksiyon: Lino Brocka, Handog ng PETA (An Offering of PETA), PETA-bisyon (PETA Vision), and Dear Teacher; the political drama Melinda; and the talk show Woman Watch. The experiment with the democratic space opened up for civil society groups by the commercial broadcasting industry was only transitory, however. When the commercial networks had secured and consolidated their resources, alternative programs, often those that criticized government policies and private interests impinging on politics, were either pushed to late-night programming or went off the air involuntarily. These programs were replaced by entertainment shows, which were given priority again by the networks.

 

Some blocktimers came from other sectors aligned with media, such as Broadcast Marketing of Jun Sison, movie outfits Regal Films by Lily Monteverde, Viva Films by Vic del Rosario, and Loca-Lobo Productions of Inday Badiday. Television and Production Exponents (TAPE) continued its success in practically all the programs it produced as a blocktimer, especially Eat Bulaga!. Cheche Lazaro’s Probe Productions produced intelligent TV programs covering different types of formats: the investigative news magazine The Probe Team, the children’s program 5 & Up, the agricultural-entrepreneurial magazine show AgriLink, and the sports and leisure program Game Plan.

 

Eat Bulaga! continued to dominate noontime programming in spite of serious threats posed by rival programs Wowowee and It’s Showtime. Daily and weekend variety shows were focused on celebrities, mainly young and upcoming stars, especially Ang TV (The TV), That’s Entertainment, and Walang Tulugan with the Master Showman (Awake All Night with the Master Showman).

 

Among public affairs talk programs, the game changer was Truth Forum, hosted by Randy David, the first talk show that used Filipino as a language of serious discussion about current issues of the country. Game changers also include Cheche Lazaro’s The Probe Team, which pioneered investigative broadcast journalism in the country, and the news investigative program Magandang Gabi, Bayan (Good Evening, Nation), which functioned as the critical fourth estate, but which tended to focus more on Noli de Castro’s image as a mediator between the masses and those in power than the ability of the program’s masa audience to rely on their own agency to challenge government ineptness.

 

Documentaries on radio also became a common trend, particularly produced by civil society groups and educational institutions. Documentaries, however, saw their full potential on television, the most politically significant of which were those produced by IBC 13 during the early years of the Corazon Aquino administration, such as Ramut: The Roots of Revolution in the Cordillera and Tiempo Muerto: Crisis and Poverty in Negros (Down Time: Crisis and Poverty in Negros). Important public affairs documentary programs of the period were The Correspondents and The Inside Story on ABS-CBN; i-Witness and Reporter’s Notebook on GMA; and Investigative Documentaries, Reel Time, and Front Row on GMA News TV. Significant magazine documentaries include Apple Pie, Patis, Pâté, Atbp. (Apple Pie, Fish Sauce, Pâté, Etc.), Tatak Pilipino (Filipino Trademark), and Pep Talk.

 

Comedy programs that took on a more critical position were the weekly sitcom Abangan ang Susunod na Kabanata (Watch for the Next Chapter), the gag show Sic O’Clock News, and the spoof Mongolian Barbecue. Significant art magazine programs include For Art’s Sake, By Design, Tipong Pinoy (Filipino Style), Art Republik, Pinoy, Eh!, and Arttalk.

 

The phenomenal growth in the 1990s was in cable television, where one can get a smorgasbord of international programs: news on CNN, BBC, NHK, ANC, and other networks; shows for the young on Nickelodeon; cartoons on the Cartoon Network; nature documentaries on the National Geographic channel; foreign movies on HBO, Showtime, AXN, and Star Movies; local movies on Cinema One and Pinoy Box Office; sports on ESPN, Star Sports, and Solar Sports; music on MTV and Myx; and many more in various languages from various continents.

 

New broadcast platforms and program formats emerged. Radio and television had to adapt to fast-changing shifts in technology, with the teleradyo (television-radio) as one prime example of simulcasting resulting from these changes in technology. Portable electronic news gathering devices, video phones, and miniature cameras have made it possible to cover events on the spot or brought into the private lairs of suspected notorious individuals. Text messaging through mobile phones and the use of any electronically mediated platform by the viewers and listeners have been utilized for a more interactive broadcasting and livestreaming experience. Websites and other social media platforms began to be used to supplement real-time broadcasting. Audiences, meanwhile, have shown their capacity at “produsage,” portmanteau of the words “production” and “usage,” where users of the medium produce and exhibit their productions, sometimes providing an alternative programming to mainstream media, which, at times, are picked up by the industry and incorporated into their programming.

 

Talent search competitions and reality TV programs have served as an entry point for those who wanted to gain entry into the industry and are ready to be exhibited to the public as a spectacle. Also common was the rise of Internet stars, some of whom successfully transitioned into the mainstream media.

 

Many game shows and public service programs became a rich source of hope for the helpless, the hapless, and the hopeless. In addition, the networks established their respective foundations, extending all sorts of help to those in need, especially to individuals who require medical attention and communities ravaged by natural and human-induced calamities and tragedies. These foundations were not initially integral to the nature of the broadcasting industry, but have eventually become good vantage points from where to launch the networks’ programs and stars.

 

In spite of the commercialism that has characterized much of broadcast programming, one significant development, although short-lived, was the effort of the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) to recognize broadcast works that exemplified excellence through its Gawad CCP para sa Radyo and Gawad CCP para sa Telebisyon from 1987 until the mid-1990s. The recognition for the best programs on radio and television focused more on the aesthetic contributions and social significance of the programs—in short, on the integrity of the entire program—than on individual accomplishments of broadcast celebrities and personalities. Similarly, the Gawad Plaridel of the UP College of Mass Communication, beginning in 2004, has succeeded in recognizing outstanding radio and TV personalities, both national and regional, who have dedicated their lives to the creation and popularization of media programs that are critical, liberative, and liberating for the Filipino people.

 

Resistance and Mobilization. The Corazon Aquino administration and the broadcast media during the tenuous post-martial law period of political transition became easy targets of military coup attempts. Rightist or disgruntled members of the Armed Forces of the Philippines, either coming from Marcos loyalists or Gregorio Honasan’s Reform the Armed Forces Movement, launched six coup plots to topple the Aquino administration from 1986 to 1989. Three of these coup attempts involved the seizure of broadcast networks, specifically ABS-CBN 2, GMA 7, and PTV 4, to bring down the new government.

 

A remarkable development in the operation of mass media during the period was the coverage of impeachment trials of the country’s leaders, most popularly Pres Joseph Estrada in 2000-2001 and Chief Justice Renato Corona in 2012, and numerous legislative hearings on the scandalous corruption and violence perpetrated by top government officials. Broadcast networks covered live such procedures, with the viewing public avidly following the progress of those cases. Media have also become an effective and staple vehicle for citizen mobilization during times of emergency.

 

Audiences, however, have not been repositories alone of mediated hopes and aspirations. They have shown that they, too, have the power to find meaning in their everyday interaction with the broadcast media and its content and, at times, resist or subvert their intended and embedded meanings. This resistance can sometimes bring about collective action against the highly commercial leanings of the broadcast industry.

 

Conclusion

 

Broadcasting has served as a reflection and a repository of the hopes, dreams, and struggles of Filipinos. More than witnessing and chronicling both the mundane and significant moments of our history, radio and television have engaged themselves as actors, together with the public, in the creation of a nation.
