article.value: Experimentation on radio broadcasting, as differentiated from point-to-point wireless communication, is believed to have begun during this period of robust wireless telegraphy activity in the colony. A Mrs Redgrave, possibly an American woman employed by the United States in the Philippines, broadcast from a military installation, the Nichols Air Base, with a five-watt transmitter in early 1922. Regrettably, no other detail of this experiment is extant today, and judging by the location of the experiment, it was probably not for commercial purposes.

The distinction of having conducted the first commercial radio broadcasting experiment goes to Henry Herman, who began test broadcasts in Jun 1922 from three 50-watt transmitters—one in Manila, one in Pasay, and one a mobile station—airing music and news. The last two stations perhaps served as relay to the Manila station as 50 watts could not have gotten the signal farther than a few blocks. A veteran of the Philippine-American war, Herman retired from active duty and, with an incentive pay from the US government, stayed in the colony to help Americanize it. He ran an electrical supply store in Manila, the Electrical Supply Company, where the merchandise included radio sets imported from the United States.

KZKZ. Two years after Herman’s experimental broadcasts, he merged the three stations with a 100-watt transmitter and aired from the Monte de Piedad building on Plaza Santa Cruz across the Santa Cruz Church, then moved the studio shortly to his home in Pasay. With the call letters KZKZ, he nicknamed his station Krazy Krazy. The call letters of radio stations in the Philippines during the period began with KZ, as in Hawaii and all stations west of the Mississippi River in the United States.

Within the same year, Herman registered the Radio Corporation of the Philippines (RCP) and moved ownership of KZKZ from the Electrical Supply Company to RCP on 4 Oct 1924. Within two months, he increased the station’s transmitting power to 500 watts. Herman wanted to model RCP after the Radio Corporation of America (RCA), a leading broadcasting and telegraph company in the United States, which was the parent corporation of the National Broadcasting Company (NBC), today the oldest broadcasting network in the United States. RCP attempted to expand from broadcasting to the lucrative wireless telegraphy business, which from technological and business viewpoints was seen as closely related.

However, the Far Eastern Radio Inc (FERI), already handling wireless telegraph traffic between ships and shore, launched an aggressive takeover of RCP. FERI succeeded; the merger was signed on 3 Sep 1925. Though the name RCP was retained, Herman was bought out. A year later, RCA bought RCP and kept it as a subsidiary. RCA received a franchise to install a high-powered radio station near Manila for wireless telegraph communication with the United States and other countries in Asia. Exactly two years after the merger, RCP, now its subsidiary, killed KZKZ in favor of another broadcast station for which it had a franchise, KZRM.

KZIB. While Herman was in a tug-of-war with FERI, another station, KZIB, secured a franchise and went on the air on 9 Nov 1925. The call letters IB stood for Isaac Beck, an American businessman who owned the department store IBeck Escolta on Manila’s fashionable Escolta Ave, where he set up his studio. Beck used KZIB to advertise his goods, which included radio sets and phonographs. At first it was a low-power broadcast at 20 watts. The radio advertising worked so well that six years later, Beck increased its transmitting power to a full kilowatt, then moved his store and station to the famous Crystal Arcade, at the time the most magnificent piece of modern architecture in the country. Also on Escolta and remembered as the first mall in the Philippines, the building housed the Manila Stock Exchange and elegant stores and restaurants.

Beck was also the Philippine distributor of Columbia Records, which counted among its recording talents Filipino artists such as the soprano Nati Arellano, also called by her nicknames Nati and Tinay. Arellano performed in vaudeville and radio shows in the United States in the early 1920s. She also recorded for the American recording label Victor, but was pirated by rival Columbia, for which she recorded “Paalam sa Pagkadalaga” (Farewell to Maidenhood) and “Ang Dalagang Pilipina” (The Filipino Maiden). Her records were a hit among Filipino migrant workers in the United States, as well as with local audiences upon hearing them on KZIB.

Of the few stations that went on the air during the first 20 years of broadcasting in the Philippines, KZIB appeared to be the most stable. It was untouched by hostile takeovers and sellouts. It also seemed the most appreciative of Filipino talent and music, indicated by extant records of the musicians and announcers that went on the air on KZIB and its programs, some of which Beck himself produced.

KZRM and KZRC. As mentioned above, RCP retired KZKZ and in its place KZRM went on the air beginning 3 Sep 1927. With RCA’s state-of-the-art studio equipment, KZRM, for Radio Manila, had better sound quality than KZKZ. Through RCP, RCA also released new models of receivers that the listening public found gave clearer signals. Just after a year, on 27 Nov 1928, RCP amped KZRM’s transmitting power to two kilowatts, surpassing KZIB in reach and signal strength.

The following year, RCP also established in 1929 the first radio station outside Manila—KZRC in Cebu City. It began broadcasting from a small studio on Colon St, then it moved to the Lim Bon Fing Building on Carmelo St, which is now P. Lopez St. RCP intended KZRC to be an experimental station, serving as relay for KZRM in Manila. However, its transmitting power at one kilowatt was strong enough to reach not only Cebu audiences but those of the rest of Southern Visayas. KZRC later built its own programming for the Visayas audience.

It is not clear why RCP bowed out of radio broadcasting in 1931 and sold the stations to the department store Erlanger & Galinger. With the sale came the exclusive distributorship of all RCA products. Soon, in addition to the two stations in Manila and one in Cebu, Erlanger & Galinger founded another.

KZRM and KZRC plus KZEG. The American brothers Simon and Isodore Erlanger started the department store Erlanger & Galinger as a provisions supplier to the American occupying forces during the Philippine-American war. The business grew when relative peace came as they imported from the United States goods required by the growing commercial activities in the colony, such as typewriters and safes, bicycles and automobiles, and even insurance. In 1915, the brothers sold the business to retired army officer and veteran of the Philippine-American war Maj William H. Anderson. Keeping the original name of the company, Anderson expanded the range of goods sold at the store by carrying Victor phonographs, radio sets, and phonograph records. The store at one point kept the largest stock of phonograph records in the Philippines, as many as 150,000, with its sales responsible for half of the department store’s business.

Anderson acquired KZRM and KZRC from RCP in 1931, perhaps to replicate the success Beck had with KZIB, boosting sales of merchandise in his stores and promoting the sales of phonograph records. Like Beck, he produced recordings of famous local opera and sarsuwela singers favored by the local elite, but Beck did this for Columbia Recording Company and Anderson for Victor Records. He also continued operating KZRC, but extant records show that KZRC broadcasts may have discontinued in 1935.

A year later, Anderson obtained a franchise for another station, KZEG, in honor of the founders of the department store but also perhaps to generate name recall for the store. KZEG first went on the air on 11 Jul 1932. In 1938, Anderson sold KZRM and KZEG to Far Eastern Broadcasting Corporation (FEBC) owned by Filipino businessman J. Amado Araneta. It appears KZRC was not part of the sale as the Cebu station would resurface later under another ownership.

KZRF and KZRH. On 1 Jul 1938, KZRM and KZEG began airing under FEBC, but with different call letters for KZEG, now called KZRF for Radio Filipinas. Unlike Herman, Beck, and Anderson, FEBC’s Araneta did not own a store. Owners of vast sugar lands in Iloilo and Negros provinces, his family had interests in the Debate–Mabuhay–Herald–Monday Mail (DMHM) chain of newspapers. The sale marked the beginning of a new model of radio station proprietorship—combined with newspaper ownership, a trend that had already started in the United States.

But the old model persisted. Another big department store in Manila, the Heacock Department Store, which also carried radio sets from the United States, was granted a franchise to operate KZRH, for Radio Heacock. The department store, owned by the H. E. Heacock Co, which American Samuel Gaches acquired from its original owner H. E. Heacock, was one of the biggest at the time, with its own building on Escolta Ave. Bringing the number of radio stations in Manila to four, KZRH first went on the air on 14 Jul 1939. It instantly became the infant broadcast industry’s leader by broadcasting at a then staggering power of 10 kilowatts and with the most modern equipment of the time, reaching every point in the Philippines and rivaling the power of KZRM, which, until that time, was the only one of the three stations before KZRH that was heard practically all over the Philippines.

Furthermore, Gaches acquired KZRC from Erlanger & Galinger in the same year, 1939, with an inaugural broadcast on 2 Mar 1940, transmitting at a power of one kilowatt. There was also a Heacock building housing a branch of its department store on Magallanes St in Cebu City, where KZRC set up its new studio. There was a Heacock department store in Baguio, Cebu, Davao, and Iloilo, and agents nearly everywhere in the colony, selling everything from fountain pens to firearms, electric ice boxes to office equipment, and neckties to evening gowns. Gaches clearly intended to use radio to promote his stores and merchandise. He was in fact anticipating television and believed that broadcast franchises and frequencies would become invaluable assets in the future.

Transnational Broadcasting. In 1929, radio broadcasting signals from the Philippines crossed the oceans and foreign lands by shortwave. As early as 1925 when he put KZIB on the air, Beck started experimenting with shortwave, a wireless technology that transmitted signals over very long distances, as opposed to long wave used for regular broadcasting over relatively shorter distances. RCP also conducted shortwave experiments from 1927. In 1929, with RCA’s powerful transmitter, RCP’s KZRM broadcast to the world and received reports of good reception from distant countries and ships in the high seas.

In turn, the following year, in 1930, KZRM began carrying American and other foreign programs. Having shortwave transmitting capacity also meant having receiving capacity. On the other hand, the American network NBC also carried Manila programs in the United States, occasionally to a nationwide audience. This went on throughout the 1930s, until the eve of World War II. With the war underway in Europe at the close of the 1930s, NBC rival Columbia Broadcasting System (CBS) put Commonwealth president Manuel L. Quezon on the air from Malacañan a number of times. In one broadcast, Quezon pledged allegiance to the United States. CBS’s network of 110 stations was hooked up.

Broadcast stations in the 1930s aired on at least two frequencies, at least one on shortwave and at least one on long wave. Stations thus invested in shortwave transmitters, allowing Philippine broadcasting to air transnationally, enabling Manila programs to be heard not only in some continents but also on ships at sea. Radio personalities received fan mail from all over Asia and the United States. When KZRH went on the air, it boasted that it not only covered the entire Philippines; it also reached much of Asia, the United States, and Europe through shortwave, with some listeners reporting clear reception.

With the introduction to the market of radio sets with shortwave receiving capacity, an average of 15 hours of foreign broadcast programs were heard in the Philippines every day in 1930. Moreover, the dozens of shortwave stations from all over Asia, North and South America, and Europe that were heard in the Philippines exposed the Filipinos as well as foreigners in the Philippines to a transnational range of program material.
Colonial Programming

Gaches hired former KZRM announcer and NBC man Bert Silen as station manager of KZRH, with Filipino-American Johnny Harris as program director, and an all-American announcing staff with radio broadcasting experience in the United States. At its inaugural broadcast in 1939, Gaches called the new station the Voice of the Philippines while Silen declared that KZRH will give this voice “a genuine American accent.” Silen emphasized that “the continuous use of proper English over KZRH will be of great assistance to the educational system in the Islands, as it will enable students of English to check their own knowledge in diction and pronunciation” (Philippines Free Press 1939, 48).

Evidently, the goal was to fashion out of the Voice of the Philippines, the Voice of America, which came into the homes of Filipinos through programming that mimicked that of American radio, highlighting Western music, particularly American jazz, blues, swing, and other danceable tunes, and the idiom of American English. The program formats were also a takeoff from American radio. Mostly entertainment, many programs combined music and readings of English literature (poetry, prose, drama) while others took off from the vaudeville style of mixing music with comedy skits or comic repartees. With less airtime but noticeably part of the programming were news and the occasional live coverage of events as well as live annotations of sports events, children’s programs, educational and instructional programs, religious programs, and lectures and various kinds of talk.

The announcement of the correct time was integrated into the programs, while bulletins about the weather, road and traffic reports, foreign exchange rates, and even the search for missing persons were regularly heard. Notices to mariners, distress signals or SOS, and police information for purposes of keeping peace and order and for safeguarding the safety of sea voyages were also heard on radio in the 1920s and the 1930s due to the less distinct functions of broadcasting and point-to-point communication.

Recorded music from the United States and Europe was aired, but most of the music heard on the air were live performances by a mostly Filipino host of musicians and singers. Stations invested in recorded music but also in the training of musical talent for live performances on the air. KZRH boasted of a “great library of classical and popular recordings” but also featured on the air live performances of the Manila Symphony Orchestra and Europe-trained opera singers such as Isang Tapales, Jovita Fuentes, and Jose Mossesgeld Santiago (Philippines Free Press 1939, 48). Amateur singing contests served as the winners’ tickets to a radio and recording career. In addition, Spanish and Latin music, especially tango, rhumba, and conga, as well as marches and concert and opera music from Europe, were popular. While not as much airtime was devoted to it in the beginning, Filipino music invaded the air and gained immense popularity as Filipino talents performed them.

Filipino artists who performed jazz and movie music on the air were especially popular. The creative flexibility of jazz suited Filipino musicians and their adaptability influenced the assimilation of elements of Western music in local compositions. Local composers who scored movies adopted the American tone, and their compositions were popularized not only through the movies but more so by broadcasting. Among the first of these composer-arrangers were Miguel Velarde Jr, Ariston Avelino, Restituto Umali, and Tito Arevalo.

Humor and witticisms were part of many musical shows. Programs that wove together lively music and comic skits à la vaudeville had fans inside the studio to provide live laughter and applause. Copied from US formats, comic partners sang and made fun of each other. While America had Amos and Andy, Abbott and Costello, and George Burns and Gracie Allen, Philippine radio had Pugo and Togo, German San Jose and Leonora Reyes, Andoy Balun-balunan and Dely Atay-atayan, and Vicente Ocampo and Diana Toy.

News was considered an important part of programming even if it did not enjoy as much airtime as entertainment. Locally produced news programs as well as news from American radio delivered via shortwave were heard. Given the colonial connection between the Philippines and the United States, events in the United States were considered news in the Philippines. Occasional stories from other countries, particularly Europe and especially toward the end of the 1930s when war clouds were gathering, were also on the air. Interviews, scripted and rehearsed, were part of news and other programs. While news announcers had been on the air since the beginning of broadcasting in the colony, stations did not hire news reporters until the late 1930s as World War II drew near and airtime devoted to news increased.

Some events were covered live, such as the opening of the sessions of the National Assembly, athletic competitions, and even theater productions like the popular sarsuwela Walang Sugat (No Wounds) when it was staged at the Metropolitan Theater in Manila on 3 Jun 1939. The show was annotated to KZRM audiences by Don Alva and Harry Fenton. KZRH covered live the anniversary celebration of the magazine Foto News, which Gaches also owned. Radio stars and news personalities performed live at the Heacock Building with a live audience while a radio audience joined the festivities by listening at home. Whitey Smith and His Orchestra and Lolita Carvajal gave the musical numbers, Leon Ma. Guerrero of the Philippines Free Press and Ralph Hawkins of the Manila Daily Bulletin provided news commentary, and Susan Magalona lectured on how society girls like her could perform their civic duty.
Advertising as Radio Lifeblood

The colonial administration subsidized radio broadcasting in its first several years, but advertising was a critical support to bankroll operations. The growing and bustling consumer economy grew ripe not only for local products but especially for imported goods from the United States, partly as an offshoot of aggressive marketing. As radio gained popularity, businesses that previously advertised only in newspapers and magazines began buying radio airtime. Initially, the advertisers were Herman, Beck, and Anderson, who were among the first to set up radio broadcasting to support the business of retailing. In 1932, advertising of products and services by other companies began. Soon radio was dubbed the “super salesman” of cigars, soaps, toothpastes, and other products.
Advertisers realized the efficiency with which radio promoted their products and services, so they began courting public tastes and preferences through radio broadcasting.

Advertising support for programs was nowhere more evident than in the titles of the shows. The practice was to integrate the product name into the program title when entire shows were sponsored, which was the norm. For example, on KZRM, Chevrolet Jamboree was a variety show of quiz, contest, and music sponsored by the Chevrolet automobile; White Horse was a musical sponsored by an alcoholic drink; Listerine Amateur Hour was an amateur singing contest sponsored by a toothpaste; Kolynos Hour was a live singing performance by the most popular jazz singer of the 1930s, Priscilla, the Kolynos Girl, sponsored by another toothpaste; Saturday Night Klim Party was a musical featuring Koko Trinidad sponsored by a powdered milk brand; and El Conde de Guell and Sunkist News were newscasts sponsored by brands of cigars and juice drink, respectively. On KZIB, Crystal Arcade was a music program sponsored by the shopping mall; Lux Toilet Soap Theatre of the Air featured dramatizations of excerpts from movies sponsored by a brand of bath soap; and Purico Troubadors and Purico Radio Show were variety shows sponsored by a cooking lard brand. Other examples: Quaker Oats Spelling Bee was a spelling contest sponsored by a brand of oatmeal, and Palmolive Newsreel of the Air was a newscast sponsored by a brand of bath soap.

The advertising device was clever and efficiently generated brand recall. It was customary for the sponsors to produce the programs themselves or hire producers and artists, and then pay the stations for the airtime. Programs typically lasted 15 minutes each. In 1937, KZRM, which had the highest audience share before the coming of KZRH, charged 42 pesos for every 15 minutes of airtime. There were but a few station-produced programs, sustained by the stations to fill unsponsored airtime until an advertiser came along. It was easy to tell these shows apart because they did not carry brand names, such as Air Giggles, an amateur singing contest; Spelling Bee, a spelling contest; Newsreel of the Air, a dramatic presentation of the news; Sunrise Club, a musical; and the Glossy Merrymakers, another musical.

The institutionalization of advertising as a critical support of radio programs in the 1930s led to a standard of professionalism in program production. Advertisers demanded polished programs and required hours of rehearsals before a program went on the air. A 15-minute program was typically rehearsed to perfection, for at least three hours. Since all programs were aired live, with very little recorded music, a mistake could not be corrected once it had gone on the air, so the discipline was strict and nothing was left to chance. Everything was scripted thoughtfully and carefully, even short spiels introducing recorded music. Musical numbers were selected carefully, with each announcer required to be thoroughly familiar with the station record library. Singers and other performers first passed a rigid auditioning process, even if only to join amateur singing contests. Filipinos working in radio at the time internalized the work ethic enforced in the stations to a point that it made them indispensable to the running of the rising broadcast industry in the 1930s.
The Radio Stars

Advertising played a significant part in the development of radio artists. Advertisers and their producers selected, hired, trained, and polished the radio performers and turned them into celebrities. One of the most memorable of the radio stars was Priscilla, the Kolynos Girl, who sang jazz for 15 minutes twice a week on the show The Kolynos Hour on KZRM in the 1930s. Her real name was Presentacion Bataclan, but Lina Flor, another radio personality on KZRM who doubled as its publicity manager, gave her the shorter and, according to Flor, better-sounding name that could pass as both Filipino and American. It was already common to adopt what were considered glamorous radio names. Flor herself shortened her name from the longer Carolina Flores. Priscilla, who was 13 when she started singing on the air, received an average of 100 letters a week from her fans, including a marriage proposal every now and then, not only from the Philippines but also from India, Burma, Singapore, Indonesia, Malaysia, and the United States. Her program’s theme song, The Sunshine of Your Smile, became one of the best-selling records of the time. She was one of the better-paid, if not the best paid, radio artists before the outbreak of World War II. She received a weekly fee of 15-30 pesos per performance—which was considered an enormous sum in those days when even established radio artists received only one peso per performance.

Fans organized themselves into clubs, with some radio celebrities having several fans clubs competing for attention. Many considered radio stars brighter than movie stars as the movie industry then produced at most a few dozen movies a year while radio turned out program after program on a daily basis. Thus radio had more newspaper publicity, which may explain why many movie stars also kept a presence on the air, particularly in shows where snippets of upcoming movies were dramatized on radio to encourage listeners to watch the movies. Fans also came to the stations to provide a live audience for some programs. In turn, the radio celebrities dressed the part—long gowns and linen suits—even if the listeners at home could not see them. The shows were often recreated through vaudeville-like stage shows where the radio stars personally appeared and performed on stage at fiestas and other special occasions.

There were several competitions that indicated the popularity of radio and radio celebrities, including those conducted annually by the Literary Song-Movie Magazine and Graphic magazine. Readers sent in their votes by clipping ballots from the magazines, boosting circulation given the legion of radio fans. In its 1934 search for the best radio performers, Graphic received over 16,000 ballots to name the best radio singers of popular, classic, Filipino, and Spanish songs, best announcers, best pianists, best orchestras, and best programs. Most of the singers, pianists, and orchestras who made the list were Filipinos, Filipino Americans, and Spanish Filipinos while four of the five best programs were music shows of Filipino performers.

In the list of five best male singers of popular music were four Filipinos and Filipino Americans: Ding Yalong, Cecil “The Mystery Singer” Lloyd, Francisco “Koko” Trinidad, and Rodrigo “Bimbo” Danao. Among the five best female singers of popular music were three Filipinas: Melita Castillo, Cielito Franquelli, and Lily Raquiza. Among the five best male singers of classical music were four Filipinos: J. Corominas, Juan P. de Tagle, V. Villanueva, and Mario del Rio. Among the five best female singers of classical music were three Filipinas: Anita Galan, Mercedes Matias, and Gorgonia Acosta. The five best singers of what were called native songs were four Filipinos—Melita Castillo, A. Siauinco, Carmen Rosales, and Lita Pascual—and a Filipino American: Cecil Lloyd. All five best singers of Spanish songs were Filipinos or Spanish Filipinos: Carmela “Morning Star” Hernandez, Mario del Rio, Ramon Estella, Lily Raquiza, and Simplicio Hernandez. The five best pianists were four Filipinos—Rafael Artigas, Miguel Velarde Jr, Ariston Avelino, and Elizabeth Soliman—and a Filipino American, Johnny Harris. All five best orchestras were led by Filipinos: Polo Club Orchestra, Lyric Music House Orchestra, Bay View Hotel Orchestra, La Loma Cabaret Orchestra, and Felix Barcelo Orchestra. Four of the five best programs featured Filipino singers: Sunrise Club, Mickey Mouse Bubble Gum, Air Giggles, and Chevrolet Jamboree.

It is noticeable that the list of best announcers included only Americans as this was 1934, a year before Filipinos would first break into newscasting and major announcing roles. Setting the tone and standards not only of the music aesthetic of radio but of announcing styles, the leading voices on the air were those of Americans: Bert Silen, Ted Wallace, Wally King, George Vogel, Johnny Wightman, Don Bell, Dave Harvey, and Maurice Naftaly. However, Filipinos and Filipino-Americans began to break into the major announcing roles in the mid-1930s: Ira Davis, Johnny Arville, Koko Trinidad, Vero Perfecto, and Ignacio Javier, the radio name of Leon Ma. Guerrero, who was already a noted newspaper journalist at the time. There were newscasts in Spanish read by local Spaniards, among them Conchita Garriz. There were numerous Filipino singers and musicians, among them Katy de la Cruz, Atang de la Rama, Fernando Poe, Alma Corro, Ramon Escudero, Diana Toy, Ramon Alberto, Ramon Estella, the Molina Boys (brothers Celso and Paquito), Ning Navales, Lina Flor, Dely Magpayo, the Carvajal Sisters (Fe, Lulu, and Pacita), Russ Arañas, the Mat Castro Family (father Remigio and daughters Luz and Milagros), and the Silos Trio (Dolores, Remedios, and Lourdes).

Renowned classical singers were also popular on the air, including Nati Arellano, Enya Gonzales, Dalisay Aldaba, and Conchita Gaston. Stage and movie actors straddled the movies and stage and radio, particularly in programs where excerpts of films and plays were performed live on the air both by actors in films and stage as well as talents from radio stations, among them Carmen Rosales, Ely Ramos, and Leopoldo Salcedo. Many were crossing over from bodabil to radio, including komedya performer and comedian Conde Ubaldo, the couple Andoy Balun-balunan and Dely Atay-atayan (Alejandro Villegas and Adela Fernando), Frankie Gomez, Jerry Brandy and his Romancers, and the comedians Chichay, Tolindoy, and Vicente Ocampo.

In Cebu, while KZRC mostly relayed programs from KZRM in Manila, Cebuano programs were also making radio stars out of the performers on KZRC. Amateur Hour and Sunday Night Serenata, both musical shows, made Iyo Karpo—the composer-actor Ben Zubiri—a household name. With trilingual programming, Jose del Mar and Gaudencio Peña read the news in Spanish while Jose Bautista announced the news and handled other shows in Cebuano, some of them with comedian Leonardo Gutierrez. American Harry Fenton read the news in English.

One yardstick used to measure the quality of the Filipino radio singers was the extent by which they could sound like, even imitate, the voice timber and style of American singers. Contests were held to pick the best “So-and-So” of the Philippines. Ding Yalong was named Bing Crosby of the Philippines; Koko Trinidad was proclaimed Dick Powell of the Philippines; Lolita Carvajal, with her throbbing voice, was the Dorothy L’Amour of the Philippines; and the Silos Trio were dubbed the Pickens Trio of the Philippines.
Blocktiming

As mentioned above, the first advertisers were the owners of the pioneer radio stations, whose investment in radio was principally in support of their retail businesses. When beginning in 1932 other businesses advertised products and services, the mode was through the sponsorship of entire 15-minute blocks of programs. By the mid-1930s, airtime was filled with practically all sponsored programs. A show was typically sponsored by one product advertiser, implied by the program title that carried the name of the product brand. Soon, blocktimers were also buying blocks of airtime, producing variety programs à la vaudeville, and reselling airtime spots to advertisers who could not afford to sponsor entire programs. Thus blocktime programs were probably the first to have multiple sponsors. Blocktimers were often the performers in their shows, directing an ensemble of other radio artists. Most produced shows in Tagalog while a few produced shows for the Spanish and Chinese listeners.

Blocktiming was good business. Most blocktimers earned more than those hired directly by the stations. Some of the successful ones were Francisco “Frankie” Gomez, the husband-and-wife team of Alejandro Villegas and Adela Fernando (who would later be better known as Andoy Balun-balunan and Dely Atay-atayan), Remigio Mat Castro, and Conde Ubaldo. Ubaldo, whose real name was Ubaldo Urbina Andres, for example, made an average of 57.50 pesos a week, a fortune in those days when top-level civil servants were earning 30-35 pesos a month. He wrote, produced, read, and performed his own commercials, as was done in those days by blocktimers, who tended to carry the sponsorship of small local business enterprises. Among his clients were the Ma Mon Luk restaurant, the bus company Halili Enterprises, Lavaliere Cosmetics, Bronx Tailoring, Malig Electrical Service, and a grocery store. Among Villegas’s clients, on the other hand, were a wet market and a battery, for which he produced the program Kiko Baterya, Kiko Bumbilya, modeled after the variety show Eveready Hour on American radio.

While many radio artists, both American and Filipino, were identified with particular stations, blocktimers were more fluid. They produced programs simultaneously in several stations and took their stable of artists along with them as they hopped from station to station. The audience was largely unaware of such arrangements and the press tended to focus on the programs and the artists rather than the business relationships between stations and producers. Thus, there were probably at least a few blocktimers, or artists who worked with and for blocktimers, among the many names above.

Investment in Broadcasting. Businessmen invested in radio broadcasting during the American colonial period expecting several kinds of financial rewards. The first was through merchandise sales in the department stores owned by the investors, for which radio served as advertiser, particularly of radio sets, phonographs, phonograph records, and music sheets. The second was through the profitable radio telegraph business. This was what both Herman and FERI (later RCP) were after, with both wanting to crowd out the other to corner the market. The third was from advertising, which did not happen until the beginning of the 1930s but proved quite profitable when it took off.

Araneta and Gaches, who did not venture into radio until at least 16 years after Herman’s first experiments, were notably already in the media business when they acquired broadcast stations. Araneta’s family had interests in the DMHM chain of newspapers while Gaches in the magazine Foto News. Both designed ways to synergize operations. For example, Araneta put DMHM journalist Carlos P. Romulo at the helm of KZRM and KZRF while Gaches integrated several activities of KZRH and Foto News. Furthermore, Araneta may have viewed broadcasting as a tool for the protection of his financial holdings, apart from its potential as a business on its own. Like many members of the elite, his investments were anchored on political and economic ties with the United States, and the talk of independence at this time worried him. Independence meant the loss of preferential trade agreements with the United States and would thus jeopardize the sugar business. Radio, together with the newspapers, was a strategic ally in swaying public opinion and sympathy. Gaches, on the other hand, was counting on radio to become an important and valuable tool to provide not only entertainment but also education or instruction. Invested in agriculture and mining, he was optimistic that the Philippines would thrive. He was already prospecting for television, knowing that its development as the next broadcast technology, with more financial promises, could already be anticipated.

It may have seemed that Americans dominated the broadcasting business, with the exception of Araneta, but along with Americans, Filipino businessmen as well as businessmen of other nationalities operating in the Philippines were invested in radio as early as the mid-1920s. Only 13.5 percent of the stock ownership of FERI, before it merged with RCP, was owned by Americans while Filipino businessmen held 41 percent. The largest stockholder as a group were the Spaniards, who held 43.2 percent, while the rest, amounting to 2.3 percent, were held by Chinese, French, English, and Russian investors. However, most of the stocks held by some of the Spaniards and Spanish companies, or 25.5 percent of the total holdings of the company, were considered Filipino capital as they represented individuals and firms domiciled in the Philippines. This meant 66.5 percent of the total holdings of FERI was domestically sourced. It is also noticeable that the two largest individual stockholders were Filipinos—Marcos Roces and Francisco Ortigas, who owned 11 percent and 10 percent of the total stocks, respectively. If FERI could be taken as typical of the broadcasting business structure during the time, it may be assumed that no single individual was entirely responsible for the capital needed to put any broadcast station on the air. American businessmen solicited investments and put together the start-up capital to open a station, spreading the risk involved in prospecting in a new type of business. Americans may have been considered the “natural” leaders in the broadcast business since the technology was principally imported from the United States, and since commercial broadcasting was a distinctly American model of broadcasting. But the ventures were backed up by capital of multinational sources, with a considerable proportion contributed by Filipinos.
The Audience of Colonial Radio

The colonial administration allowed the importation of various radio apparatus and parts duty free as long as they were made in the United States. Thus, at least 95 percent of receiving sets in the country were of American make. Still, they were costly in relation to the ordinary person’s income. In the late 1930s, a crystal radio receiver cost around 45 pesos or the equivalent of about two months’ salary of a middle-level government bureaucrat. The more modern tube receiver sold at a staggering price of 125-500 pesos each. Nevertheless, sales of the radio receivers were good, aided by the availability of installment schemes that ranged from five pesos to 20 pesos monthly. In 1927, 734 sets were bought by the public. Given the population of 12,326,000, there was one radio set for every 16,838. By 1935, with a population of 14,442,000, there were 28,258 radio sets sold, which meant there was one radio set for every 511 persons in the colony.

The figures indicate the exponential growth of radio broadcasting audiences during the period. Other estimates of the size of the listening public vary, but considering that the government distributed radio sets to municipalities throughout the country particularly in the first several years, and that many of these sets were positioned in plazas, making radio listening a community activity, the audience size for each radio set must have been bigger than one family. Unlike in the United States, owners of receivers in the Philippines were required to register their sets and pay a registration fee, which the government collected and used to subsidize broadcasting and purchase radio receivers for the remote barrios. Apart from plazas, homes that had radio sets attracted crowds of neighbors hoping to catch a program or two. In Cebu, for example, a local newspaper report estimated a peak ratio of 400 listeners to a radio set in 1940. It is then possible that the size of the growing audience was much larger than the estimates. By 1940, there were 78,089 licensed sets. There were unregistered sets, and if they were counted, the number could reach 100,000.

Apart from radio sets supplied by the central administration in Manila to remote areas, other receivers were typically owned by the parish priest and the mayor, who shared their radios with the rest of the community. Receivers were stood by their windows so neighbors could hear the programs. In some provinces, radio signals were heard through loud speakers installed in plazas. The Kolynos Hour was promoted by Kolynos delivery trucks painted with Priscilla’s smiling face and gleaming teeth, with loud speakers inviting the people to listen to her program as the trucks drove through rural towns.

Broadcast Regulation and Colonial Policy. Since the technology of radio broadcasting emerged out of wireless telegraphy, which was part of the mail system, it was first regulated by the Bureau of Posts, which granted permits for the operation of broadcast stations, including amateur stations, until 1931. Given the growing number of wireless stations operating in the colony, including those in private hands, the colonial government made a request to Washington, DC, for guidance, to which the reply was that federal law in the United States regarding radio did not apply to the colony. However, the policies that developed on radio broadcasting in the Philippines reflected the stance of the United States, articulated in 1928 by then US president Calvin Coolidge in an executive order, that the development of privately owned and operated radio facilities should be encouraged, but that these facilities should be available for national defense in time of war or similar national emergency.

Aside from national defense, the colonial government and the American business community were looking at “splendid vistas of utility, progress and education” that radio broadcasting opened up as “every hamlet, no matter how small and distant, can be put into instantaneous touch with the center of the country’s business, industrial, social and educational activities … making the country more homogenous.” Calling radio a tremendous impetus for civilization, American businessmen in Manila saw overwhelming possibilities for commerce and considered radio a new and important force for progress.

The colonial government also saw radio’s utility for disseminating official news to its administrators in remote areas and the public. As early as 1929, the colonial government began distributing receivers to isolated areas. When he arrived in Mar 1932, Gov-Gen Theodore Roosevelt Jr apparently shifted the expense to municipalities, which he ordered to purchase radio receiving sets and install these in public squares where communities may listen to broadcasts from Manila. Roosevelt justified the service by drawing attention to the inadequacy of transportation in the islands that prevented the quick and more massive circulation of newspapers and magazines, which until then were the traditional means of disseminating public information.

The regulation of radio broadcasting passed from the Bureau of Posts to the newly created Radio Control Board on 11 Nov 1931 when the colonial Philippine legislature passed Act 3846, or the Radio Control Law. The board was put under the supervision of the secretary of the Department of Commerce and Industry while the secretary of the Department of Public Works and Communications approved the construction of radio facilities and transmitting stations. The Radio Control Board examined applications for licenses to operate radio, allocated band frequencies, and conducted inspections for the office of the commerce and industry secretary. The law provides that licenses could be granted or transferred only to citizens of the United States or of the Philippines, or to firms or companies that were incorporated under the laws of the Philippines or of any state or territory of the United States of America. Licenses were not to be granted or transferred to any company or corporation in which an alien was employed as officer or director or to any company or corporation whose 20 percent of capital stock could be voted by aliens or their representatives, or by a foreign government or its representatives, or by any company, corporation, or association organized under the laws of a foreign country. The law also provided that the president of the United States or the governor-general of the Philippines, in time of war, public peril, calamity, or disaster, could order the closing of any radio station in the Philippines or authorize the temporary use or possession of any radio station by any department of the government upon just compensation to the owners. Unmistakably, the law was designed to allow government control in time of war, and control by forces friendly to government in time of peace.

The new law gave the Radio Control Board the power to regulate all radio stations and radio communications in the colony except those of the US Army and Navy. It was composed of a representative of the US Army, a representative of the US Navy, and a representative of the Department of Public Works and Communications. In spite of the official view that radio broadcasting was a commercial activity, the board’s composition and mandate belied the acute interest of the colonial government, particularly the military, in broadcasting. In fact, before the law was passed, the US Department of State wrote the Department of War on 21 Aug 1931 to inform the latter that radio stations in the Philippines and the Panama Canal Zone were under the jurisdiction of the Department of War.

To support the program to reach the entire archipelago through broadcasting, another law was passed in 1932, Act 3997, creating the National Radio Broadcasting Fund, built from the annual collection of radio receiver licenses, similar to car registration fees. The collection of radio receiver license fees was a significant departure from the practice in the United States, but was justified to subsidize both broadcasting and listening. Called the Radio Broadcasting Law, it also created the Radio Regulation Office under the secretary of commerce and communication. Its task was to fund programs that would air news from the government, educational programs, and other programs approved by the secretary of commerce and communication. The fund was to support a minimum of six hours daily of government programming as well as provide subsidy to broadcast stations when necessary. But even before the law was passed, annual registration fees of two pesos for crystal receivers and 10 pesos for tube sets were collected, with exemptions granted to receivers used by the colonial administration and the US Army and Navy. Part of the collection was used to subsidize a government committee for broadcasting and some of the first radio broadcasting stations including KZRM. As mentioned above, prior to 1932, part of the fund underwrote the purchase of radio sets for the rural areas. In 1938, Quezon’s Commonwealth government reduced the radio registration fees, abolished the subsidy to the radio stations, and poured the fund into the purchase of sets for distribution to the municipalities.

Accusing newspapers of inaccurate reporting, Quezon attempted to nationalize broadcasting and use it against his critics. With his powerful sway over the First National Assembly of the Commonwealth, a law was passed in Jun 1936 authorizing Quezon to create a radio board whose task was to study ways and means for the nationalization and acquisition by the government of radio broadcasting stations and to censor all programs to be broadcast or rebroadcast by all stations, whether sustained by the stations or sponsored by advertisers. The takeover did not happen, though, probably hampered by the lack of funds to expropriate the radio stations from private ownership. Quezon did get a chance to control one radio station for a short period of time—KZND, in 1941, shortly before World War II arrived on Philippine shores.
The Emergence of Philippine Radio

The institutions the Americans built in the colony appear to have eroded nationalistic fervor among many Filipinos, who embraced the public school system, appreciated the effects of the health and sanitation programs, and anticipated a perceived modernization to be brought about by American culture. For the local elite, the political reconfigurations from the Spanish period, the economic structures, and secularism introduced by Americans presented promising opportunities. To the colonizers, Americanization of the islands was an expressed goal and radio broadcasting came in handy to speed up the process. Filipinos loved the music and enjoyed the talk.

Filipino radio performers learned American music and spoke like American announcers and newscasters. Filipino producers formatted their programs according to American radio programs, following the technical standards and organizational structure of American radio. However, almost from the beginning, fragments of expressions of the local inserted themselves into the programming. In 1929, the director of the National Library Teodoro M. Kalaw noted that the frequent airplay of local songs increased their popularity such that the music sheets of the Tagalog love song called kundiman outsold the music sheets of jazz, reviving its popularity as well as that of other Filipino music forms like the Visayan folk song balitaw. Among the more memorable Tagalog compositions that gained wide recognition through radio were “Dahil sa Iyo” (Because of You), “Ang Tangi Kong Pag-ibig (My Only Love), and “Maalaala Mo Kaya?” (Will You Remember?). By this time, the American recording companies Victor and Columbia had been recording the local songs for distribution to the growing Filipino community in the United States. KZIB, KZRM, and KZEG played the records on the air, maximizing profit for the local distributors of Victor and Columbia phonograph records and phonographs, which after all were distributed by the department stores IBeck Escolta and Erlanger & Galinger.

The other recordings by Filipino music artists that Victor and Columbia pressed included songs where Tagalog and English were mixed, whether originally composed in English or Filipino. For example, Katy dela Cruz recorded the bouncy Tagalog folk song “Magtanim Ay Di Biro” (Planting Rice Is No Joke) in a mix of Tagalog and English lyrics initially for Filipinos in the United States, carrying the English title “Planting Rice.” It was her first known recording. Another example is the version of the American popular song “Singing in the Rain” recorded in both English and Filipino, with comic repartee between lines, by German San Jose and Leonora Reyes for Columbia. There were also recordings in Spanish to appeal to the local Spanish community as well as mixes of English and Spanish in some songs that were originally in English, such as Louis Garcia’s “Preguntas a las Estrellas” (Ask the Stars). There were also recordings by Filipino artists of American popular music, such as Bimbo Danao’s “Boulevard of Broken Dreams” for Victor as well as local compositions in English, like “Rosalinda,” recorded by Filipino-American Cecil Lloyd, also known as the Mystery Singer.

As local music artists gained a following, local singing groups sang their recordings more frequently on the air. The Silos Trio began to sing more local and Spanish songs than English as their popularity increased. Also called the SSS Trio and recognized as the best harmony team in local radio, they debuted in the program Music Radiolite in 1935 when the twins Dolores and Remedios Silos were 13 and their sister Lourdes was 11. Cecil Lloyd, called The Mystery Singer, sang swings, rumbas, and other American popular music, but also kundiman and Spanish compositions to the accompaniment of Lux Orchestra.

Around the beginning of the 1930s, there were entire programs in Tagalog. On KZIB, five of the six programs sponsored by companies were in Tagalog and only one was in English. In 1934, the program Balagtasan on the Air (Poetic Joust on the Air), sponsored by Elizalde & Co, began airing on KZRM, featuring Filipino poets and writers and supporters of Tagalog literature Florentino Collantes, Emilio Mar Antonio, Domingo Carasig, and Epifania Alvarez. By the late 1930s, all four commercial stations in Manila aired Tagalog programs, including KZRH, the self-appointed teacher of correct English speech to Filipinos. In 1938, an early model of the Tagalog soap opera–cum–advice program, Si Aling Juanang Mapag-impok (The Thrifty Madam Juana), hosted by Lina Flor, debuted. In the same year, the precursor of the situation comedy in Tagalog, Kuwentong Kutsero (Tall Tales), which was a satire on Filipino manners, politics, customs, and government, first appeared. Its forerunner was the variety show called Common Weal Hour, both produced by Horacio de la Costa, who would later become a Jesuit priest. De la Costa produced Kuwentong Kutsero to fight the divorce bill introduced in the National Assembly, which notably did not prosper in the legislature. Kuwentong Kutsero poked fun at the establishment, especially government officials, until the 1960s, interrupted only by World War II. The program must have inspired producers in KZRC in Cebu where commentaries on politics, graft, and other issues were also heard on the air. By 1940, most of KZIB’s programs were in Tagalog. Among the memorable programs in 1941 were Filipino Program and Tagalog Program on KZIB; News in Tagalog, Tagalog Gospel Hour, Tagalog Music, and Songs of the Islands on KZRF; and The Mystery Singer (featuring American-Filipino Cecil Lloyd) and Manila Hotel Orchestra on KZRH.

Blocktimers were the first to use Tagalog as the language of broadcasting, play local music on the air, and inject a local sense of humor and even subversive material into the programming. Most blocktime programs were variety shows that combined short skits, comedy routines and singing, à la bodabil, such as Camay Theater of the Air, the long-running Glossy Merrymakers on KZIB, and The San Miguel Brewery Hour on KZRF produced by Alejandro Villegas. Another variety show, the University of the Air, mixed the English and Tagalog languages, with half of the program consisting of comic skits in Tagalog. The program Purico Troubadours, sponsored by the Philippine Manufacturing Company, featured Tagalog and Visayan music performed by a string orchestra conducted by Remigio Mat Castro. Extant recordings of some of the songs sung by blocktimers on the air, including original compositions and racy novelty songs, reveal a number that were critical of the colonial condition, such as Dely Atay-atayan’s song “Alila” (Slave), a thinly veiled metaphor for the colonized country. The sharp element of protest in this and other songs was softened by the comic routines that accompanied their rendition, but some were more explicitly nationalistic, bewailing the colonial condition of the country in such kundiman pieces as “Hibik ng Pilipinas” (Lament of the Philippines), “Ibong Sawi” (Broken-Hearted Bird), and “Kantahin ng Ulila” (Song of the Orphan).

Subjected to American measures of broadcast quality, Filipino broadcasters were forced to acquire the accent of American announcers and newscasters and the idiom of American English. In the mid-1930s, Filipino announcers began handling announcing and newscasting in English. Among the first ones were Koko Trinidad, Ira Davis, Vero Perfecto, and Norman Reyes. Trinidad, like most, began his long radio career as a singer. He was the first Filipino to be given an English newscasting assignment after an audition on KZRM, beating American applicants.

Gradually, too, Filipinos began to take more important positions in the stations. Trinidad rose to the position of production manager of KZRM before World War II broke out. By this time, 1938, KZRM had transferred ownership from Anderson’s Erlanger & Galinger to Araneta’s Far East Broadcasting Corporation (FEBC). Apart from KZRM news, the newscasts remained mostly in American hands, but in dramatized news documentaries, the Filipinos outclassed the Americans. In their production of weekly news summaries in 1941, Trinidad and Lamberto Avellana, both good mimics, dramatized the news by impersonating the voices of important political personalities from around the world. The use of drama to tell the news was a successful innovation of the American network CBS in cooperation with Time magazine. Visiting broadcast journalists Fritz Lang and Bill Dunn were impressed, thinking that the Filipinos beat them at replicating the CBS format.

The American community generally regarded radio as an effective medium for the Americanization of the colony, but American station managers sensed an appetite for Filipino elements in the programming when advertising for Tagalog programs began to increase, so the goal of Americanization came into tension with the demands of making a profit. As businessmen, station owners and managers understood that satisfying the preferences of listeners created the critical mass of audiences that advertisers sought, which by the early 1930s had become the most important source of income of radio stations. Listeners mailed their requests for musical numbers not only in Tagalog but also in other Philippine languages, and it became the job of the broadcasting manager to find individuals who could perform the requested numbers. The use of Tagalog in media gained additional support when Quezon signed the law proclaiming it as the basis of the national language in 1938.

Toward the end of the 1930s, the broadcasting business was on its way to becoming an industry. It was exciting, glamorous, and merry, and the audience size was growing exponentially. Regarded primarily as a commercial activity, it enjoyed relative freedom from the control of government, in spite of Quezon’s threat to take it over. In 1941, however, the political, economic, and cultural conditions in the Philippines drastically changed as the Americans lost control of the country to Japanese military forces. Radio broadcasting took on various roles in presenting the contending ideologies and worldviews of the Americans and yet another invader who exploited Philippine radio for the realization of their own global expansion designs. Written by Elizabeth L. Enriquez
