article.value: KZND. The emergency rules prohibited the issuance of new broadcasting permits, but the government itself earlier inaugurated on 30 Apr 1941 the new station KZND. Its call letters stood for national defense. The establishment of KZND was not intentional. In early 1941, acting on intelligence information, the government seized a one-kilowatt transmitter from an Axis national. It was an opportunity to have its own broadcast voice, so the government put the confiscated transmitter to use and went on the air. Vero Perfecto was appointed station manager. For a few hours in the evenings, KZND aired newscasts, warned people about the imminence of war, conducted emergency drills, and instructed listeners on safe and proper behavior during air raids. KZND’s operation lasted less than eight months. Along with the commercial stations, it ceased broadcast as the United States Army Forces in the Far East (USAFFE), the combined Filipino and American forces under Gen Douglas MacArthur’s command, retreated to Bataan and Corregidor while Japanese invasion forces pushed toward Manila around the end of Dec 1941.
War and Propaganda Radio

Radio broadcasters in Manila signed on in the morning of 8 Dec 1941 with the news that the Japanese had bombed Pearl Harbor in Hawaii. Several hours later, the news was about Japanese bombs that had just been dropped on Baguio City and Clark Air Field in Pampanga without warning. The usual entertainment programs immediately made way for newscasts, which were aired not only to Philippine audiences but also to the United States via shortwave. It soon became apparent that reinforcements of MacArthur’s ground forces were not immediately forthcoming while the pressure of superior numbers of the invading forces was increasingly felt.

On 26 Dec 1941, as the Japanese aggressively advanced toward Manila from the north, MacArthur declared Manila an Open City, abandoning it to retreat west to Bataan Peninsula and Corregidor Island off Manila Bay, evacuating with him the Commonwealth government in the persons of Quezon and his vice president, Sergio Osmeña, and their respective families. The declaration was aimed at sparing the city from battle. However, MacArthur understood the critical role radio would play in the war, so he ordered his troops to destroy private and commercial radio broadcast equipment before leaving the city to render them useless to the Japanese. Large transmitters were blown up but portable transmitters were commandeered and brought to Corregidor.

In the meantime, US High Commissioner Francis B. Sayre appointed KZRH station manager Bert Silen as chief coordinator of information to “propagate favorable news for the Allies and create anti-Japanese feelings and propaganda until such time as the American forces shall liberate us.” Silen in turn enlisted as his assistants KZRH program director Johnny Harris, announcer Ramon Escudero, and technician Simeon Cheng. Cheng was a Chinese national who studied radio engineering at the Philippine School of Arts and Trade before joining KZRH. On Silen’s instruction, Cheng pulled out and brought to Corregidor a shortwave transmitter and other radio parts and equipment (Cheng Papers, n.d.).

The Voice of Freedom. While awaiting reinforcements from the United States, MacArthur and his troops dug in to repel the Japanese onslaught toward Bataan and Corregidor. At the same time, it was important to keep up the propaganda to prevent demoralization of both the USAFFE and the civilian population they left behind, so an improvised radio station was quickly rigged. Military radio engineers led by KZRH announcer and chief engineer Ted Ince (Ted Wallace on the air) assembled inside the Malinta Tunnel a commandeered transmitter and other radio equipment, including equipment brought by Cheng. On 5 Jan 1942, the station, named by MacArthur, went on the air with the program of the same name, Voice of Freedom. For over four months, until early May 1942, the Voice of Freedom broadcast nightly at six o’clock, on varying frequencies to elude interference. The listeners followed on the dial.

Signing on with the American anthem “Star-Spangled Banner,” journalist-publisher Carlos P. Romulo of the prewar Debate–Mabuhay–Herald–Monday Mail chain of newspapers, who was also the general manager of the Far Eastern Broadcasting Corporation, the holding company of prewar KZRM and KZRF, introduced himself as the voice of freedom without identifying himself. Commissioned as a Philippine Army reserve major, he gave updates on the efforts to stall the southward thrust of the Japanese forces from Lingayen Gulf into Bataan. Romulo, Leon Ma. Guerrero III, and Salvador P. Lopez wrote the news and commentary in English which Romulo, Guerrero, and Norman Reyes took turns reading on the air. (Romulo and Lopez would, in the postwar period, be appointed presidents of the University of the Philippines while all three became diplomats, with Romulo enjoying the distinction of being the first Asian to be elected president of the United Nations General Assembly.)

The English newscast and commentary were followed by the program Tinig ng Kalayaan—Tagalog for voice of freedom. The voice was that of Philippine Army lieutenant Francisco Isidoro, who translated the English scripts to Tagalog and delivered them on the air. It was Quezon’s idea to have a Tagalog speaker deliver the news and commentary in Tagalog on the station, and it was he who identified Isidoro for the job.

America’s failure to send immediate rescue doomed the siege at Bataan and Corregidor. Patriotic encouragement from the Voice of Freedom was not enough to calm the hunger, fatigue, and frustration of the Filipino-American troops in the face of the relentless and savage offensive of the Japanese, whom the Americans and the Filipinos by this time realized they underestimated. With mounting casualties from battle and disease and impending defeat, Quezon, Osmeña, and their families were evacuated to the United States to set up a government in exile while MacArthur was evacuated to Australia in Mar 1942 to plan a return to the Philippines, leaving Lt Gen Jonathan Wainwright in command on Corregidor and Gen Edward King in Bataan. Romulo was also evacuated to Australia just before USAFFE troops in Bataan were overwhelmed on 9 Apr 1942. Taking over the announcing job completely, Reyes is best remembered for his dramatic and emotional reading of Lopez’s script on the air announcing the fall of Bataan, which Isidoro translated to Tagalog and then read on the air after Reyes. Lopez’s script, which described the defeated Philippine-American troops with “heads bloody but unbowed,” would later be considered a classic piece of wartime journalistic writing. With his powerful prose, Lopez portrayed the men “of unshakable faith … made of something more than flesh, but … not made of impervious steel.” While he conceded that the flesh had to yield and the battle had to end, Lopez ended with optimism, declaring that the spirit that made Bataan stand was a beacon to all the liberty-loving peoples of the world, and could not fail (Buencamino 2003; Romulo 1943; Ongpauco 1982; Tayag 1946).

With the remaining 70,000 USAFFE troops in Bataan now prisoners of war, the Japanese then turned to the 3,500 still on Corregidor, who were by then greatly weakened. To prevent further loss of life, General Wainwright ended the Filipino-American resistance in Corregidor and surrendered to the Japanese in early May 1942. Conscious of the effect of a radio broadcast on the Filipinos who thought the Americans invincible and the Japanese as no match, the latter made him announce the surrender on the air at around 11:30 pm on 7 May 1942. It was on a station that the Japanese built out of remnants of KZRH equipment, for which they kept the same call letters. Until almost midnight, Wainwright called on American and Filipino troops still fighting in the field to surrender to the Japanese. The Voice of Freedom then fell silent.

KZRC–Voice of Freedom. While the battles in Bataan and Corregidor were still raging, Filipinos in Cebu and nearby provinces monitored the war in Luzon by listening to the Voice of Freedom, whose signals were picked up and relayed by KZRC. KZRC was not covered by MacArthur’s order to tear down the broadcast stations on the eve of Japanese assault on Manila, so it continued broadcasting freely until the Japanese overran the province in May 1942 and literally burst through the station door. In addition to the news and commentary from Corregidor, KZRC broadcast its own commentary on the war. Its station manager, American Harry Fenton, was well-known in Cebu for his fierce and lengthy on-air denunciations of the Japanese.

The Voice of Juan de la Cruz. About a week after the surrender of Corregidor silenced the Voice of Freedom in early May 1942, the Voice of Juan de la Cruz went on the air. It was the voice of 18-year-old Carlos Malonzo. Malonzo picked up information from the shortwave broadcast of Chungking radio in China, which he echoed with his own comments on the air. Chungking (also spelled Chongqing), in Southwest China, was at the time under the control of Generalissimo Chiang-Kai-shek, who was allied with the Americans. Malonzo thought Chungking radio, part of which broadcast was presumably in English, was more outspoken against Japan and the Axis powers and more optimistic in its claims than either the British Broadcasting Corporation (BBC) or KGEI—a shortwave station in San Francisco, California, under US military control during the war. Malonzo mocked and insulted the Japanese using coarse language. When the Japanese offered a reward of 2,500 pesos for information leading to his capture, he retorted and offered one peso for every Sakdal (member of a supposedly pro-Japanese organization), five pesos for every Filipino official collaborating with the Japanese, “and for that SOB [Japanese Military Commander] General Homma, P7.50” (Hartendorp 1967).

Malonzo, who was not a professional broadcaster, was not initially militant against the Japanese. However, witnessing a Japanese sentry slap an elderly Filipino woman for failing to bow in obeisance infuriated him. He then gathered his friends and together they stole 50,000 pesos worth of goods from Japanese supply warehouses and sold the items in the black market to finance the launching and operation of the station. He hired radio technician Tony San Juan to assemble radio parts and equipment, scriptwriter Oscar Arellano, a Japanese-speaking interpreter, another technician, and four others who served as lookouts and bodyguards. KGEI picked up and acknowledged the signal of the Voice of Juan de la Cruz. With radio broadcasting equipment being relatively portable, the station was constantly on the move within Manila and its suburbs to avoid detection. Like the Voice of Freedom, it signed on with the “Star-Spangled Banner,” which Malonzo himself sang and recorded with guitar accompaniment by his technician Tony San Juan on a rigged recorder. On 4 Jul 1942, he married Violet Brown. Six days later, the Japanese cornered them and their staff and locked them up in Fort Santiago. Brown was released and carried on the broadcast until Sep 1942 with some members of the group who eluded arrest. Refusing to cooperate with the Japanese, Malonzo and eight of his men were executed after four months of incarceration.
Japanese Propaganda Radio

The Japanese came to conquer not only the land and its resources but also the hearts and minds of Filipinos. It had a propaganda corps, which included broadcasters. It was called the Sendenhan—literally, propaganda corps—in the first few months of the occupation. It was later renamed Hodobu—the Department of Information—to avoid the negative connotation of the name Sendenhan. As soon as they entered Manila on 2 Jan 1942, the broadcast engineers among the corps searched for radio equipment to be able to begin radio propaganda, having found the facilities of KZRH, KZRM, KZRF, KZIB, and KZND useless. They salvaged an antenna at a transmitting station in a Manila suburb (present-day Cubao, Quezon City), a few pieces of KZRH equipment hidden in the basement of the Heacock Building on Escolta Ave where the station’s studios were located, and transmitting equipment found concealed at the Jai Alai Building on Taft Ave, which was being set up by an underground resistance group to communicate with Corregidor.

In less than two weeks, the Japanese broadcasters were on the air, on 14 Jan 1942, from the old KZRH studio, keeping its call letters. KZRH and the newspaper dailies Tribune and Taliba, which the Hodobu also took over, became the principal propaganda outlets of the invaders. Initially broadcasting for five hours daily from 7:00 pm until midnight, the Japanese-controlled KZRH began broadcasting with announcements from the Japanese Military Administration (JMA), the news in Nihongo (Japanese language) and English, and music. In the beginning, the music played on the air was American light classical music, records of which were found at the KZRH studio. There were no recordings of Japanese music yet, and only later would live Japanese songs and music be heard on the air.

Programming soon expanded to several more hours a day. As early as May 1942, the station signed on at 7:55 am and signed off at 11:00 pm. A year later, in Apr 1943, airtime increased further and the station began to sign on at 6:55 am and sign off at 11:15 pm. The programs were broadcast mostly in Tagalog but also in Nihongo, Spanish, English, Ilonggo, and Cebuano. Newscasts in English, Tagalog, and Spanish of 15 minutes each were aired three times a day. Eventually, the news was also regularly read in Nihongo. Documentaries on Japanese history and culture were frequently heard. Church services, lectures aimed at women and children, and literary readings in Japanese were allotted airtime, as well as Tagalog comedy skits. K. Hinomizu and K. Okazaki gave lessons on the Nihongo language as a regular part of the programming.

Filipino music, as well as Western classical music, was played on the air. Since Japan did not have recorded music yet, Japanese songs and music were performed live with the guidance of music sheets. A Japanese pianist, Filipino pianist Jose V. Carreon, and Filipino musicians and singers provided the live music. Fidela Magpayo, better known to postwar radio fans as Tiya Dely, became the most popular radio singer during the period. She sang mostly Filipino songs but she and Polish-Filipina Nellie Bialovlovsky, known professionally as Ginger, also sang Japanese songs repeatedly on the air, which their Japanese managers thought was the best way to teach the Filipinos Japanese music. Somewhat emulating the practice prior to the war, Carreon, Magpayo, and Ginger, who were all in radio before the war, made personal appearances in the rural areas near Manila.

Lessons in Nihongo as well as Tagalog were also on the air, which increased as the war progressed. In the early part of 1942, the Nihongo lessons were given by a Professor Kusama. Later, other Japanese professors gave the lessons as a regular part of the programming, including Professor Matsukawa, K. Hinomizu, and K. Okazaki. Lessons on the Tagalog language were also on the air, given by Lope K. Santos, who later would be recognized as the “Ama ng Balarila” (Father of the Pilipino Grammar and Tagalog Orthography). In conjunction with the language lessons, a Linggo ng Nihongo, or Japanese Language Week, was celebrated every last week of August while there was a Linggo ng Pilipino, or Pilipino Language Week, every last week of December.

Rajio Taiso. A program that today would sound odd was Rajio Taiso, with which the station signed on at 7:55 am beginning not later than Oct 1942. It was a 15-minute calisthenics program called Rajio Taiso, which government employees and schoolchildren were required to tune in to so they could follow the exercise commands of the odd unseen instructor. The program was repeated at noon. Some historians link the physical exercise program to the station’s objective: the “Japanization” of Filipinos, best expressed through obedience to an invisible authority, as in the way the Japanese revered their emperor, who, until then, was not seen in public.

Filipino Broadcasters. Most of the broadcast staff of the Japanese-controlled radio station were Filipinos, from the announcers and performers to the engineers and technicians, recruited by the Japanese, some forcibly. While some accepted the job for practical considerations, a few worked in the station to gain access to information that they passed on to various resistance groups. The radio staff enjoyed some special privileges such as rations of rice and sugar, which were among the commodities that were in short supply during the occupation.

Among the announcing staff were, ironically, KZND station manager Vero Perfecto and Voice of Freedom news writer, commentator, and announcer Leon Ma. Guerrero III. Following the surrender of Corregidor, Guerrero was imprisoned at the Capas internment camp. Upon his release, JMA-appointed chairman of the Executive Commission Jorge Vargas took Guerrero to write speeches, messages, and special articles. The Executive Commission was the Japanese-controlled Philippine government in the first 20 months of the occupation. The Hodobu then put Guerrero in KZRH (later PIAM) as a news commentator where he used the name Bienvenido Javier while he also used his prewar pseudonym Ignacio Javier. In the meantime, the Japanese took Norman Reyes to Japan to work at the Japanese propaganda radio in Tokyo where he was made the announcer on The Zero Hour, a program of American music and anti-American propaganda news intended for American soldiers in the South Pacific.

Some of the other Filipino broadcasters became well-known and accomplished writers and artists after the war, such as Clodualdo del Mundo, who became a novelist, playwright, essayist, short story writer, journalist, screenwriter, teacher, critic, and radio soap opera writer; Alfredo Saulo, who became a historian and rebel leader and later wrote the book Communism in the Philippines: An Introduction, 1990; Hernando Ocampo, who was a fictionist, playwright, editor, and later National Artist for visual arts; I. V. Mallari, essayist and literary and art critic; and Manuel Viray, who became a poet in English. Many others were already in radio before the war, such as Harry Johnson, Simoun Almario, Gavino Tabuñar Jr, Lina Flor, Amado Pe, Zacarias Nuguid, Gonzalo Rialp, Marcelo Victoriano, Mauricio Santos, Manuel Esposo, Bienvenido Potenciano, Monserrat Iglesias, Georgina Escamilla, Alma Corro, Yay Panlilio, Vicente Coloso, Manuel Buenafe, Pablo Hidalgo, Quisling Calderon, Amadeo Dacanay, Rizalino Castro, Alfredo Cabasal, Angelo Castro, Demy Alejandro Jr, Porfirio Miraflores, Liberato C. Poblador, and Carmelo Mendoza. Myrtle Listen was the local equivalent of Tokyo Rose, the name given by Allied troops to a number of female radio voices emanating from Tokyo who played popular American music, interspersed with intriguing low-voiced sexy talk and skillfully crafted propaganda aimed at confusing and demoralizing the American soldier. Listen, an American mestiza, imitated Rose’s style and was called Manila Myrtle.

PIAM. On 14 Oct 1943, the Japanese declared “independence” for the Philippines. On the same day, the call letters of KZRH, which until then bore the American call letters KZ, were changed to PIAM, for Philippine Islands A Manila. Relay stations were established outside the capital: the PIBC, for Philippine Islands B Cebu; the PICD, for Philippine Islands C Davao; and the PIDI, for Philippine Islands D Iloilo. The relay stations, apart from carrying PIAM programs emanating from Manila, may have also aired their own programs in Cebuano and Ilonggo. Other relay stations were erected in Naga, Baguio, Zamboanga, Cotabato, and Legaspi. A relay station was planned for Tuguegarao but did not push through. PIAM also aired on shortwave with the call letters PIRN, probably for Philippine Islands Radio Nippon, for the benefit of listeners outside the Philippines (Ampil 1986; BMC-KBP, n.d.; Yearbook of the NHK 1998; Enriquez 2013; Records of the Foreign Broadcast Intelligence Service, RG 262).

More Tagalog and Japanese music then replaced American music. Jazz, deemed by the Japanese as one of the symbols of the degenerate American culture, was completely suppressed. In May 1943, the Philippine Symphony Orchestra was formed, and their performances of classical music were put on the air. As the war progressed, lessons in Nihongo as well as Filipino languages increased and more newscasts and talk programs urging people to produce food and other necessities went on the air. In stark contrast to radio programs before the war, incessant speeches and exhortations by Japanese officials and Japanese-appointed officials of the Filipino government were aired, including those of Japanese-installed president Jose P. Laurel. Laurel urged the USAFFE members who were still in the resistance “to offer themselves for registration” and called upon the United States on the air to recognize Philippine Independence. On 8 Dec 1943, the second anniversary of the bombing of Pearl Harbor and the Philippines, Laurel delivered a speech over PIAM in celebration of Greater East Asia Day, extolling the virtues of the Japanese and its ideology. The Japanese attempted to forge an alliance of Asian countries, including the Philippines, called the Greater East Asia Co-Prosperity Sphere. At the center and top of this alliance was Japan. On 23 Sep 1944, Laurel went on the air to declare war against the United States and Great Britain (Records of the Foreign Broadcast Intelligence Service, RG 262; People’s Court Records, Case No. 1507).

Other officials went on radio to urge the Filipino youth to collaborate with the Japanese-installed government and to invite those who were still waiting for the return of the Americans to give up that hope and begin cooperating with the new republic, such as Quintin Paredes, who was public works and communications commissioner. Senator Vicente Madrigal, who was one of the drafters and signatories of the Philippine Constitution during the occupation, lauded Japan on radio. Representative Benigno S. Aquino, also a drafter and signatory of the said constitution and Speaker of the wartime National Assembly as well as director general of the Kapisanan sa Paglilingkod sa Bagong Pilipinas or Kalibapi, a Japanese-style neighborhood association, called America treacherous in a talk on PIAM and tagged the day the Americans occupied the Philippines, 13 Aug 1898, a day of national humiliation. Vice Minister for Foreign Affairs Emilio Abello spoke on the role of the Philippines in the Greater East Asia Co-Prosperity Sphere. Assistant commissioner of the Department of Education, Health and Public Welfare Camilo Osias went on overseas broadcast to the United States about the policies of the “newly independent” Philippines (Tribune 1942; People’s Court Records, Case No. 3530; Jose L. Llanes Guerilla Papers; People’s Court Records, File No. 53-453; People’s Court Records, Case No. 3528).

During the siege of Bataan and Corregidor, Emilio Aguinaldo, leader of the Philippine Revolution against Spain who was captured and marginalized by the Americans, urged MacArthur to surrender in view of what he termed the obvious superiority of Japanese arms. Vargas delivered many speeches on radio while his wife Marina and daughter Nena were also made to air a birthday greeting to Aurora Quezon in the United States and to appeal to her to return to the Philippines. American prisoners of war and American civilians interned in camps in the Philippines were also put on the air to read approved scripts justifying Japanese occupation of the Philippines.

Radio Reconditioning. Winning over the Filipinos to the Japanese side through broadcasting involved not only managing program content but, the Japanese found out, also controlling listening. As early as Feb 1942, the JMA realized that without the prewar commercial stations and with only the Japanese-controlled KZRH on the air, Filipinos turned to shortwave broadcasts from the United States, Britain, and Australia. The Japanese immediately banned aerials (antennae). Then they soon realized that most of the radios in the country were of the latest technology that did not require external antennas to receive overseas broadcasts. Six months later the Hodobu decided on another strategy to restrict radio listening. On 13 Aug 1942, KZRH announced that radio receiving sets must be registered with the Customs Office. On 6 Jan 1943, the JMA ordered the “reconditioning” of all shortwave receivers, except those permitted by the Japanese army. “Reconditioning” meant that sets would be converted or refit so that their shortwave tuners could receive only broadcasts made by the Japanese military or those originating from Japan (Hartendorp 1967; Records of the Foreign Broadcast Intelligence Service, RG 262).

The measure was supposed to protect the Filipinos from “harmful” foreign influences (Terami-Wada 1984). The Japanese called enemy broadcasts deadlier than enemy bombs from which Filipinos had to be shielded. On 17 Jan 1943, the wartime newspaper Tribune justified Japanese control of radio, saying that the ruling was necessary to save the Filipinos from the pernicious influence of hostile propaganda and mental sabotage via radio.

The deadline to submit radio sets for reconditioning was extended to 30 Jun 1943, and again to 31 Oct 1943 for radio sets outside Manila. Realizing the persistence of many Filipinos to listen to unauthorized shortwave broadcasts, defiance of the order became punishable by torture or death. Nevertheless, less than half of the estimated 80,000 sets, which another estimate put at 100,000, were registered. Many that were registered were restored, sometimes in better condition, to receive shortwave signals, often by the Filipinos who constituted the corps of technicians tasked with the reconditioning of the radio sets. Some of them surreptitiously sold expensive removable converters that owners hid at inspection.

The only officially permitted radio signals came from PIAM, which the people listened to as it paid to know the enemy propaganda, but at the same time they maligned. PIAM, to some, stood for “Putang Ina Ang Maniwala!,” which roughly translates to “He who believes [the radio propaganda] is a son of a bitch!” (Malay 1984; Ampil 1986).

Subversions and Resistances. KGEI was a critical source of news from the United States. Apart from its American broadcasters, at least nine Filipinos were in its staff, including Gregorio San Diego, Jaime V. Catuira, Eddie Ramos, Paciano B. Sanchez, Florencio Marquez, and Marcelino Tanjuatco, whose programs were intended specifically for the Filipino audience. They translated and read the news in English to Tagalog, Ibanag, Ilocano, Pangasinan, Pampango, Bicol, Hiligaynon, Cebuano, and Moro. Tagalog phonograph recordings as well as American music were played on the air for the benefit of the Filipinos caught in the war across the Pacific Ocean. Particularly popular was the program of Carmen Ligaya, who was KGEI’s answer to NHK’s Tokyo Rose.

Guerrilla groups in the rural areas as well as individuals in the cities who had access to shortwave radio clandestinely transcribed KGEI broadcasts for underground circulation. Those who were found out by the Japanese and their Filipino agents paid with their lives, or suffered torture. Among them were Harris and Cheng, who delivered KGEI transcripts to Silen, who was interned at the Santo Tomas Internment Camp, where thousands of Americans and a few other foreigners were imprisoned by the Japanese. Harris was caught and executed but Cheng escaped and subsequently survived the war. Inside the internment camps for prisoners of war and civilians, in spite of the impossible conditions, news about the war circulated either through radio transcripts smuggled in by visiting family and friends or by operating clandestine receivers, which received shortwave signals from Radio Chungking, BBC, and KGEI.

Many prewar broadcasters avoided recruitment by PIAM, among them Koko Trinidad who argued that he was already involved in cultural work on another front. Trinidad and Lamberto Avellana organized the Philippine Artists League and staged shows at the Avenue, Lyric, and Strand Theaters, marking the evolution of bodabil into the stage show, in the absence of American-sounding radio and Hollywood movies. Trinidad, Avellana, and a few others in the league acted as couriers for guerrillas through a nipa shed that was the drop-off and pickup points of coded messages. Briefly within the Japanese-controlled KZRH was a spy, Yay Panlilio, a Filipino-American, who broadcast coded messages aimed at Corregidor. Secretly warned by Hernando Ocampo that she had been found out, she calmly walked out of the station one day and joined the guerrilla group Marking’s Guerillas.

Inside Malacañan Palace itself was a shortwave radio receiver secretly operated by Philippine Constabulary captain Angelo Frago, who supplied Laurel with Allied radio dispatches from Oct 1943 until late 1944, allowing Laurel to form a balanced picture of the war developments. Laurel discreetly recruited Frago and his men who smuggled the radio parts piece by piece into the palace, which they assembled and operated in a photographic darkroom, suspected but never found by the Japanese. Aware of the sentiments of many Filipinos, Laurel refused to comply with the JMA order to address the country by radio to announce the formation of a government-in-exile in Tokyo as he was evacuated by the Japanese Supreme War Council, together with his cabinet, toward the end of 1944.
The Voice of Freedom Returns

From Australia, MacArthur launched a campaign to take the Philippines back from the Japanese. Upon landing on Palo Beach, Leyte, on 20 Oct 1944, he went on the air and announced, “This is the Voice of Freedom. General MacArthur speaking. People of the Philippines, I have returned.” Thousands of concealed radio sets were tuned in. The new Voice of Freedom was the naval radio station VLC-6, one of the stations Filipino guerrillas monitored on shortwave while it was in the high seas, now a land station called WVLC, with the American call letter W assigned to ship stations at the time. With its powerful 50-kilowatt transmitter, WVLC flooded the air with the speeches of MacArthur, Philippine Commonwealth president Sergio Osmeña, who assumed the presidency upon Quezon’s death in the United States, and Carlos P. Romulo, now a general, with CBS war correspondent William J. Dunn as announcer. Osmeña announced US president Roosevelt’s promise that full independence would be granted the Philippines as soon as the Japanese were driven out. The broadcast emanated from equipment set up on a weapons carrier parked on the beach of Palo, which was shortly moved to a Tacloban schoolhouse where the Signal Corps constructed a makeshift studio. From there the station reported on the war that was about to end and aired American music and other shows sorely missed by Filipinos (DeLay 1951; Dunn 1988; Sunday Times Magazine 1946; Voice of Freedom 1944; Trinidad 1953).

Soon after MacArthur’s “I have returned” broadcast, PIAM’s Filipino staff dwindled. Programming hours were reduced. The station began signing on as late as 11:00 am and signing off as early as 10:00 pm. On 30 Dec 1944, PIAM ceased broadcast in Manila. The Japanese evacuated Laurel and his cabinet to Baguio City, then to Japan, while the Americans reclaimed the country in the bloody and deadly battles that followed (Magpayo 2000; Tribune 1942-44; Sato 1998).

Five months after MacArthur’s broadcast, the WVLC studio was moved to Manila, broadcasting beginning 26 Mar 1945 on shortwave from a special radio ship named Apache, which was moored in the Pasig River near the shattered Jones Bridge beside the walls of Intramuros. MacArthur directly supervised its operation until it was sent to Japan two months later with the American invasion forces. In the meantime, another US army station, WVTM, which had been transmitting from Polo, Bulacan, was moved to Manila and broadcast from the 6th floor of the scarred Insular Life Building on Plaza Cervantes, where RCA communications operated before the war. By this time, several other American military broadcast stations were operating. The US Armed Forces Radio Service, established in 1942 in the midst of war, constructed 10 temporary radio stations throughout the country to signal to Filipinos that the Americans were back by airing familiar American music and other programs. Apart from Manila, the stations were located in Cebu, San Fernando, Puerto Princesa, Agusan, Zamboanga, Tolosa, and Iloilo. Many were roving stations which broadcast from the back of trucks that moved with American troops.

Like WVLC, some of these stations were subsequently sent to Japan. The rest were integrated into one station under the US Department of National Defense Office of War Information with the call letters KZFM, and around the end of World War II in Aug 1945 taken over by the United States Information Service of the US State Department. Transmitting at five kilowatts, it aired news, information, and entertainment programs. KZFM was named after Frederic Marquardt, one of the American newsmen on the prewar Philippines Free Press and MacArthur’s close friend. Marquardt was in MacArthur’s party that landed on Leyte the previous year. The first KZFM staff was headed by Bill Sanford and Abigail Jacobs. Jacobs later established the Silliman University radio in Dumaguete. In the production and announcing staff were Koko Trinidad, Johnny Arville, Jess Fernandez, Gene Ildefonso, Mon Ylanan, and Eddie Avelino. Gabby Tabuñar and Simoun Almario, who survived their stint at the Japanese-controlled KZRH/PIAM, also joined the staff. Gumsy Alba, another prewar radio announcer, emerged from the hills as a guerrilla and joined the KZFM staff.

With the war over, the US Congress passed legislation empowering Osmeña to grant temporary operating permits to private citizens and groups who wanted to go into the radio business to encourage the revival of commercial radio broadcasting. Two commercial stations were almost immediately granted permits: the Manila Broadcasting Company (MBC), which bought KZRH from H. E. Heacock Co, and the Philippine Broadcasting Corporation (PBC), which was the new name of the old Far East Broadcasting Corporation, owner of the prewar KZRM and KZRF. The following year, on the occasion of the declaration of Philippine Independence from the United States and the inauguration of Manuel Roxas as president on 4 Jul 1946, MBC’s KZRH and PBC’s KZPI went on the air and resumed commercial broadcasting in the country.

There was profound resistance to the Japanese-controlled radio, but it should be noted that the cultural policy of the Japanese, intentionally or not, contributed to the flowering of Filipino languages, particularly Tagalog. The Japanese plan was to make Nihongo the lingua franca in the country, and indeed Japanese lessons were on the air, in the newspapers, and at school. However, Nihongo and Tagalog were proclaimed official languages not only because Tagalog was necessary to facilitate translation from Nihongo but also because it appealed to the Filipino sense of nationalism. Historians have described it as a Japanese propaganda strategy that benefited the local culture. Before the war, English was the principal language on radio, even if Tagalog and other Filipino languages began to be heard in many programs in the 1930s. During the war, Tagalog surpassed English on radio. After the war, while English returned as the dominant broadcast language in the beginning, those who invested in the radio industry that was growing tremendously at this time, realized that the Filipino audience expected broadcasting that spoke their tongue, such that stations with all-Tagalog programming began to go on the air.

Broadcasting during the war evolved from an almost purely entertainment medium to that which is a source of news and information. News programs gained prominence during the war not only on Japanese controlled radio but on banned shortwave stations. There was hunger for credible news that was so critical for Filipinos and for the foreigners in the country as well, to know about the progress of the war in the Philippines and around the world. News perceived as credible gave them a vision of when, not if, liberation from the Japanese stranglehold was to take place. The effect of this persisted after the war. Whereas news programs were a minor part of programming during the American period, they became a critical component of radio’s program mix after the war. Filipino broadcasters realized that there was an audience for news and news commentary. A few years after the war, the all-news radio format began to appear.

The beginning of the new era of broadcasting in the Philippines was marked by several other changes: KZFM became the first of what would become a nationwide network of government broadcast stations. Other networks followed, including religious stations. There were new call letters for Philippine radio stations as a result of the International Radio Conference of the International Telecommunications Union in the United States. Audience size swelled, and a local music recording industry was born. A notable change in programming was more time devoted to news. But entertainment and advertising were back with a vengeance, especially with the new genre called soap opera. Soon, an era that some called the golden age of radio in the Philippines began, later to be followed by a new broadcast medium that mesmerized the Filipinos—television.Written by Elizabeth L. Enriquez

text:
Sections

Early Postwar Radio Broadcasts
The Growth of the Broadcast Industry
The Golden Age of Philippine Radio
The Age of Television

Broadcasting in the Philippines in the years following World War II bore a strong imprint of American colonial broadcasting in spite of and possibly in reaction to the Japanese imposition of its culture and anti-American propaganda via radio. American music and talk as well as the new format of soap opera, fueled by advertising, filled the air. News and news commentary increased in significance as Filipinos continued to hunger for credible news that was in short supply during the war. However, the impact of the Japanese cultural policy left traces, which were evident on many cultural fronts, including radio. With both Nihongo and Tagalog proclaimed as official languages of the country, Tagalog surpassed English as the language of broadcasting during the war, even as daily on-air lessons on Nihongo were intended to supplant English. While English returned as the dominant language of broadcasting after World War II, Tagalog maintained a clear and growing presence. Other Filipino languages also flourished on the air as new radio stations began to operate outside Manila, mindful of the audience expecting broadcasters to speak their tongue. This trend extended to music played on radio and later on television as the Philippine recording industry was born and began to press records of local talent singing traditional Filipino songs and more recent local compositions as well as covers of foreign songs.

 

Television was born just eight years into the new Republic, in 1953. It was the second to air in Asia, only eight months behind the first, the NHK in Japan. As it was before the war, Americans as well as Filipinos invested in the rising broadcast industry, until the 1973 constitution restricted ownership of all media businesses to Filipinos. But there was a noticeable increase in the number of Filipinos staking their claim on the operation of radio and television. Not only was it profitable in the case of commercial stations; it was believed powerful not only in selling products but also in shaping tastes, captivating audiences, and molding consciousness that won elections and consolidated political power. In the postwar years, politics and economics became even more intensely intertwined with broadcasting as it became not only a profitable investment but also an arena of political power matches.

 
 

Other shifts unfolded after the war. The call letters of broadcast stations changed soon after the inauguration of the Third Philippine Republic in 1946, which followed the end of World War II in 1945. Audiences multiplied as the number of radio stations grew phenomenally, including noncommercial stations operated by government and religious organizations. By the 1950s, the era called “golden years of radio” was underway, which lasted until the unspeakable era of martial law began in 1972.

 

Early Postwar Radio Broadcasts

 

As expected, the American military forces under Gen Douglas MacArthur were the first to operate several radio facilities in the Philippines toward the end of World War II following the silence of the Japanese-controlled PIAM at the close of 1944. MacArthur sent several of the transmitters to Japan in early 1945 with the US military takeover forces and integrated the remaining few into one station in Manila with the call letters KZFM. It was first managed by the US Department of National Defense Office of War Information, then turned over to the newly organized United States Information Service (USIS) under the US State Department. To encourage the revival of commercial broadcasting, the US Congress passed a law empowering Sergio Osmeña, who became Philippine Commonwealth president upon the death of Manuel Quezon in the United States while awaiting the end of World War II, to grant temporary radio operating permits to private citizens and groups.

 

 

Businessmen brothers Joaquin Miguel Elizalde and Manuel Elizalde were the first to take the incentive in early 1946. They purchased Samuel Gaches’s H. E. Heacock Co, which owned the KZRH of the American period, and called their new enterprise the Manila Broadcasting Company (MBC). With the help of prewar KZRH station manager Bertrand Silen, the Elizaldes imported broadcast equipment from the United States and set up its studios at the old Insular Life Building along Plaza Cervantes in Binondo, a few meters from the west end of Escolta, where KZRH used to be. Meanwhile, another station, KZPI (PI for Philippine Islands), also acquired a permit to go on test broadcast in early 1946. It was operated by the Philippine Broadcasting Corporation (PBC), the new name of the prewar Far East Broadcasting Corporation (FEBC), which used to run KZRM and KZRF. J. Amado Araneta, who owned FEBC before the war, took on new partners—Leo Prieto, Jose Avelino, Jack Preysler, and Andres Soriano—and formed PBC.

 

On 4 Jul 1946, the three stations, KZFM, KZRH, and KZPI, covered live the declaration of Philippine Independence and the investiture of Manuel Roxas as the first president of the Third Republic of the Philippines and his vice president, Elpidio Quirino. It also marked the end of the Commonwealth government. Three and a half months later, on 20 Oct 1946, the second anniversary of MacArthur’s landing on Leyte, the USIS turned over KZFM to the new Philippine government’s Department of Foreign Affairs, the secretary of which was Quirino. In August of the following year, Roxas moved the station to the Philippine Broadcasting Service (PBS), which he created as a unit under the Office of the President. PBS then grew into a nationwide network of government broadcast stations.

 

 

Cebu was again the site of the first radio stations outside Manila. On 21 Sep 1947, KZRC, operated by MBC affiliate Cebu Broadcasting Company (CBC), went on the air. CBC bought the station from Harry Fenton, who took over the station from the H. E. Heacock Co after the war. It is not clear, however, how the takeover took place. The following year, 1948, PBC inaugurated KZBU.

 

Soon after putting KZRH on the air, MBC acquired a franchise for another station, KZMB. PBC, on the other hand, put up KZOK in addition to KZPI. Not long after the inaugural broadcast of KZOK, the Elizaldes acquired PBC, which had KZPI and KZOK in Manila, and KZBU in Cebu. Araneta bowed out of broadcasting while the Elizaldes quickly became the most powerful broadcast operators from the late 1940s until television came in 1953. Notably, there was no law that regulated and limited the number of broadcast stations that any one individual, family, or company could own, and this is true until today.

 

In the meantime, Isaac Beck revived KZIB but it folded up after just a few months. Thus, the ownership of radio broadcasting had totally shifted before the decade of the 1940s was over.

 

 

New Call Letters. A change in call letters took effect on 1 Jan 1949 following a conference of the International Telecommunications Union (ITU) in Atlantic City in New Jersey, USA in 1947, where the fledgling Republic applied for a new set of call letters for its radio stations—PI for Philippine Islands in lieu of the American KZ. Citing bureaucratic problems, the ITU denied the request and gave the Philippines the letter series from DUA to DZZ. The entire D series was originally held by Germany (for Deutschland, which is German for Germany), but the ITU took a restrictive stance against it for Nazi Germany’s misuse of radio during the war. Thus, KZFM became DZFM, KZRH became DZRH, and so on. Later the Philippine government assigned secondary letters based on location—DZ for stations based in Luzon, DY in the Visayas, and DX in Mindanao. DW was later given to FM stations in Luzon.

 

With the new Republic came the restoration of many prewar laws, including Act 3846, or the Radio Control Act of 1931, which regulated radio stations and radio communications in the Philippines. Since television involves radio, this law also applied to television stations. Moreover, the law required radio stations to obtain a legislative franchise as a prerequisite to operation, thus effectively shifting the power to grant broadcast franchises from the Office of the President back to the legislature. It should be noted that the law permitted ownership of media businesses not only by Filipinos but also Americans.

 

 

The Growth of the Broadcast Industry

 

Wealthy families other than the Elizaldes, like the Lopezes, the Roceses, and the Sorianos, also saw a future in broadcasting after the war and eventually followed suit. However, the motive for profit was often coupled with the imperative to acquire or maintain political power through the media, which in turn protected the business interests of those who invested in media. This symbiosis led to a trend that became more transparent with the entry of television in the early 1950s. As the number of radio stations multiplied and audience numbers rose, the idea of television appeared more promising, which led to several radio stations expanding into radio-television networks. Furthermore, broadcast operations were often integrated with newspaper publishing, so newspapers and broadcasting mutually promoted and strengthened each other as well as other investments of their owners.

 

The early postwar stations, like KZRH and KZPI, were mostly commercial stations. Among the first of these was DXCC in Cagayan de Oro City in Mindanao. In 1948, the brothers Henry and Reuben Canoy conducted test broadcasts, which provided the blueprint of the future Radio Mindanao Network that later grew into a nationwide network that at one time involved television. Station DXCC, however, did not receive a franchise from Congress until 1952. Meanwhile, in 1949, the University of Mindanao Broadcasting Network put up radio station DXMV in Cotabato City, making it the first radio station with an orientation toward audiences living in Muslim-dominated areas in Mindanao to officially go on the air. In 1963, Ramon Jacinto, a young music enthusiast, put up radio station DZRJ under the family-owned Rajah Broadcasting Network (RBN). This AM-band station specialized in rock and roll music. RBN still operates in the country today with the controlling interest held by Ramon Jacinto Holdings Inc. It was also in 1963 when Abelardo Yabut Sr, a businessman from Mindanao, founded the Nation Broadcasting Corporation (NBC). The enterprise initially consisted of radio station DXYZ in Zamboanga City and radio station DZAM in Manila, which then grew into a nationwide network of radio stations. In the same year, the Mareco Broadcasting Network owned by the Manila Record Company began its operations. Local music found a home in this station. In 1968, the Eagle Broadcasting Corporation (EBC) began its broadcasts on DZEC. Members of the Iglesia ni Cristo religious group comprised the stockholders of EBC, which operated DZEC as a commercial station.

 

 

A number of noncommercial operations, like KZFM, went into broadcasting for reasons other than profit. In 1948, a group of Protestant evangelists established radio station KZAS, later DZAS, under the Far Eastern Broadcasting Company (FEBC), the first radio station in the country with a religious type of programming. The station was renamed DZFE, which later became an FM station, allowing FEBC to apply for a new franchise for DZAS on AM. The evangelists behind FEBC, not to be confused with the prewar Far East Broadcasting Corporation, broadcast in China beginning in 1945, but the civil war between nationalist and communist forces forced it to move its operations elsewhere. The Roman Catholic Church in the Philippines did not follow suit in using radio for evangelization until 1969 when it began operations of DWRV Radio Veritas, which had the strongest radio transmitter in Southeast Asia prior to the imposition of martial law in the Philippines in Sep 1972. While some universities operated commercial radio, the University of the Philippines (UP) in Diliman, Quezon City, started noncommercial shortwave radio experiments from its College of Engineering building under the call letters DZUP in 1958. When the station ran out of funds the following year, the UP Alumni Association raised funds to help keep the radio station operating. Later the University moved its studio to the College of Arts and Sciences and began broadcasting on the AM band. In 1964, the University of the Philippines in Los Baños, Laguna, established DZLB to provide educational programs to the rural communities surrounding the campus. In 1965, notwithstanding DZFM and the growing network of PBS stations around the country, the government’s National Media Production Center (NMPC) under the Office of the President began operating DZRP, the Voice of the Philippines (VOP), on both the AM and shortwave bands. It was the local counterpart of the Voice of America. NMPC’s head office was located along Santa Potenciana St in Intramuros, Manila.

 

By 1968, local and foreign manufacturers of phonographs were promoting the stereo—a large electronic appliance that had a phonograph, a radio component designed to receive both AM and FM radio transmissions, and two separate speakers, which made stereophonic listening possible. It allowed the listener to adjust bass and treble through the twist of a knob. The stereo also doubled as a piece of decorative furniture because of its polished wooden exterior. Mass production of various models made the stereo affordable. National and Radiowealth were the leading stereo brands at that time. The popularity of the stereo inevitably created an audience for FM radio transmissions, which was tried in the 1950s but did not succeed due to the absence of FM-capable radio sets. This time, broadcast companies saw an opportunity and made plans for going on the air via the FM band. The first to do so was DZFX of the Makati Broadcasting Network, which went on the air in 1968. The first successful commercial FM station in the country broadcast mood music, film soundtracks, and period pieces with high-fidelity stereophonic sound. Its studio and transmitter were located at the top of the new Insular Life Building along Ayala Ave in Makati, which was then a municipality of Rizal Province.

 

 

From five radio stations before World War II, the number grew to 33, 10 years after the end of the war. By 1968, sources put the number at more than 200, and 280 just before martial law was declared in 1972. It was an indication of the burgeoning audience, driven partly by the availability of a new radio technology—the transistor—beginning around the end of the 1950s. The new radio sets were portable and could be operated on small batteries, a stark contrast to the older radio appliance that was heavy and bulky and that required connection to an electrical outlet. Moreover, the sets, imported from the United States and Japan, were designed to receive FM transmissions. When the local manufacture of portable transistor radio receiver sets and radio-phonographs, such as those made by Avegon, brought the price of the sets down, the audience size grew exponentially. However, while radio remained the most popular mass medium of the time, television began to captivate audiences before the decade of the 1950s was over. The story of its growth cannot be divorced from the political motivations of its pioneers in the Philippines.

 

BEC and ABS. On 13 Jun 1946, James Lindenberg, an American entrepreneur who operated in Manila, established the Bolinao Electronics Corporation, a company that manufactured radio transmitters and similar electronic devices. The enterprise was named after Bolinao, a municipality in Pangasinan and the native town of Lindenberg’s Filipino wife. Four years later, on 14 Jun 1950, Congress granted Lindenberg a franchise to operate a radio and a television station. Supplies were difficult to acquire, however, due to strict import controls in force at the time, making it difficult for Lindenberg to operate a television facility immediately. He thus decided to focus on the radio business in the meantime.

 

Meanwhile, a motivation other than entrepreneurship was driving the birth of television in the country. By the middle of 1952, Pres Elpidio Quirino was eyeing reelection in the Nov 1953 polls. His administration was perceived as corrupt by many, especially the youth. Antonio Quirino, a former trial court judge and the younger brother of President Quirino, saw radio and television as means to counter public opinion and improve the chances of the reelection of the president. He had a problem to overcome though—Congress was not willing to grant him a legislative franchise. Antonio Quirino found a solution through Lindenberg. Before 1952 was over, Antonio Quirino bought 70 percent of BEC from Lindenberg, became a partner of the American businessman, and renamed the venture the Alto Broadcasting System (ABS), with DZAQ as its call letters. Alto is a combination of AL, the first two letters of the nickname of Qurino’s wife, Aleli Guzman-Quirino, and TO, the first two letters of Tony, his nickname. The letters A and Q in DZAQ are the initials of Antonio Quirino. With BEC’s television franchise, ABS obtained permission to transmit television signals on Channel 3. The original ABS radio studio was located along Florentino Torres St in the Santa Cruz district of Manila, where the newsrooms of the leading newspapers of the period were situated. Its transmitter was located at a corner lot along P. Guevarra St, right across Sitio Alto, a large estate in the district of Little Baguio in San Juan, which was then a municipality of Rizal province. Sitio Alto was where Antonio Quirino and his family resided.

 

To promote DZAQ-TV Channel 3, Quirino needed to import television sets into the Philippines. He obtained a loan of 60,000 pesos from Joe’s Radio and Electrical Supply, a leading electronic equipment store along Raon St in the Quiapo district of Manila, which in turn became the first to sell television sets in the country. In 1953, that amount was enough to acquire 120 bulky RCA Victor television sets manufactured by the Radio Corporation of America, then the leading brand in the United States known for its high fidelity or capability of faithfully reproducing sound. By the middle of 1953, Quirino had convinced rich families in Manila and the suburbs to buy RCA Victor television sets, with each one costing at least 1,200 pesos—the equivalent of several months of an average salary in Manila, with the minimum daily wage then set at four pesos. It was considered a status symbol to own a television set, so wealthy and prominent families bought them. Quirino invested the profit he realized from the sales of the TV sets in the business. To generate a bigger audience, Quirino published and distributed announcements inviting the general public to see the new medium at strategic areas in the commercial districts of Manila in early Oct 1953. From six to ten o’clock every evening, selected establishments located at the Quiapo, Santa Cruz, and Binondo districts of Manila opened RCA Victor television sets at their respective display areas for everyone to watch what Quirino called “the pre-inaugural telecasts of DZAQ-TV Channel 3.” The television sets were located at Poulex Department Store and Kairuz Department Store along the Escolta; Sub Bros and Francis Department Store along Dasmariñas St; 15¢ and Up Department Store and Automatic Electrical Appliances store along Rizal Ave; Joe’s Radio and Electrical Supply along Raon St (now Gonzalo Puyat St); and the Saulog Transportation ticket office along Florentino Torres St.

 

In Oct 1953, DZAQ began its radio and television broadcasts. While DZAQ Radio followed the typical program format of other radio stations, it was partial to news that put the administration of President Quirino in a favorable light. Meanwhile, the premiere telecast of DZAQ-TV Channel 3 finally took place on 23 Oct 1953, which showcased a garden party at Sitio Alto. Although color television technology was already available in the United States, the DZAQ telecast was in black and white. Fifty-two sponsors of this telecast actually paid for the birth of Philippine television. The event made Antonio Quirino, and not James Lindenberg or Eugenio Lopez Sr as others claim, arguably the father of the Philippine television industry.

 

Buoyed by the success of its premiere telecast, ABS continued its broadcasts for four hours, from six to ten o’clock every evening. Its programs consisted of feature films borrowed from foreign embassies, and religious and cultural plays organized and directed by James Reuter, the well-known Jesuit priest who began using broadcasting for evangelization in the late 1930s. His best-remembered television production was a 1953 adaptation of the classic piece Cyrano de Bergerac. From 1953 to 1956, ABS had a monopoly over the Philippine television industry. In the meantime, Filipino industrialist and civic leader Domingo M. Guevara saw a large business potential in the television industry, so in 1955, his Radiowealth company began manufacturing and selling local black-and-white television sets bearing the brand Radiowealth-Motorola. Until then, American brands like RCA Victor, Motorola, Zenith, and Admiral dominated the local market.

 

Although Antonio Quirino succeeded in establishing the first television station in the Philippines, he failed to get his brother reelected to the presidency in the Nov 1953 national elections. Despite this setback, Quirino went on with his radio and television enterprise. In 1956, he launched DZYL-FM, the first radio station to broadcast via frequency modulation (FM). However, it did not do well as FM was yet unheard of, with most radio receivers at the time having no provision for the reception of FM transmissions. With competition looming in the horizon in 1955, and with the death of former president Elpidio Quirino in 1956, Antonio Quirino considered retiring from the broadcast industry.

 

ABS-CBN. In 1955, the prominent Lopez family of Iloilo headed by Eugenio Lopez Sr obtained a legislative franchise to operate a radio and a television station under the Chronicle Broadcasting Network (CBN). The family had been in the sugar industry since the 1800s and by this time was already invested in other businesses, including the daily newspaper Manila Chronicle, the second most widely circulated newspaper in the country at the time. On 24 Sep 1956, CBN began its radio broadcasts on CBN-DZXL Radio. Its studio and transmitter were located at the CBN Building along Aduana St in Intramuros, Manila. In the weeks that followed, Eugenio Lopez Sr sent overtures to Antonio Quirino about the possible sale of ABS to the Lopez family. Antonio Quirino was open to the idea because the brother of Eugenio Lopez Sr, Fernando Lopez, was the vice president of Pres Elpidio Quirino from 1949 to 1953, even as the Quirino and Lopez families parted ways in 1953 when Fernando Lopez, instead of running for reelection as vice president under the Liberal Party with Pres Elpidio Quirino, ran for the Senate and won under a secondary opposition party. Lindenberg was also open to the idea of selling his share of the business.

 

On 24 Feb 1957, Eugenio Lopez Sr bought ABS from Quirino and Lindenberg. This purchase made Lopez the biggest investor in the broadcast industry of the Philippines. With his brother in the Senate, he also had very powerful political connections. By 1962, the Lopez business empire included majority ownership of the Manila Electric Company. The strong political clout of the Lopez family grew even stronger in Nov 1965 after Senators Ferdinand Marcos and Fernando Lopez were elected president and vice president of the Philippines, respectively, under the banner of the Nacionalista Party (NP). Marcos anchored his campaign on the nationwide publicity generated by Iginuhit ng Tadhana (Destined by Fate), a motion picture about his life, which was a box-office success throughout the country. Lopez, on the other hand, enjoyed the free publicity he got from the family-owned ABS-CBN broadcast network and their newspaper, the Manila Chronicle. It was the second time Fernando Lopez was elected vice president. He was also the secretary of agriculture and natural resources in the Marcos cabinet, a post he held from 1965 to 1971.

 

For four years, ABS radio and television stations were operated separately from CBN stations, their common ownership notwithstanding. In 1958, ABS transferred its facilities from Santa Cruz in Manila and San Juan, Rizal, to its new studio and transmitter site on Roxas Blvd in Pasay City. In the same year, on 19 Apr, CBN began its television broadcasts on CBN-DZXL-TV Channel 9 using its facilities in Intramuros. In 1961, ABS and CBN stations began using the name ABS-CBN. At the same time, on 14 Jun 1961, ABS-CBN opened its television station in Cebu City. In 1963, ABS-CBN tested the first color television transmission in the Philippines using technology imported from the United States. It was the beginning of color television broadcasting in the Philippines, and by 1966, television programs in color reached the homes of affluent Filipinos. In 1968, the Sony Trinitron color television set made its world debut, making it the leader in television technology until well into the 21st century. In the meantime, before the end of 1967, the Radiowealth Company was manufacturing and selling locally made color television sets for 2,500 pesos each, a pioneering effort that made the Philippines the third country in the world to manufacture color television sets, next to the United States and Japan. Japanese brands like National and Sony alsot made it to the Philippine market when the Precision Electronics Corporation assembled National audio and video products in Oct 1967, and when Solid Industries Inc began distributing Sony radio and television appliances in the country in 1971.

 

By the start of 1967, with the opening of more stations throughout the country, ABS-CBN was the Philippines’ largest network, and its stations’ identification segments proudly proclaimed its status. On 12 Feb 1967, ABS-CBN launched its iconic logo, which features an aerial transmitter and three concentric rings symbolizing broadcast waves, in the primary colors of red, green, and blue, and the letters ABS on top of the graphic and the letters CBN below it.

 

On 18 Dec 1968, ABS-CBN moved its radio and studio facilities to its new headquarters called Broadcast Plaza, located along Bohol Ave (now Sergeant Esguerra Ave) in Diliman, Quezon City. The following year, the old ABS studio along Roxas Blvd in Pasay City was sold to the Kanlaon Broadcasting System (KBS) owned by Roberto S. Benedicto. KBS acquired a legislative franchise in 1969 to operate a television station, which necessitated a reallocation of the VHF and UHF channel frequencies. Eventually, the government assigned Channels 2 and 4 to ABS-CBN and reassigned Channel 9 to KBS.

 

With the broadcast technology then still in analog format, the broadcast transmission made by one channel, which was too proximate to the transmission made by another channel, affected both transmissions as they interfered with each other. This was why, prior to the entry of KBS in the Philippine television landscape, television channel assignments were in odd numbers: 3, 5, 7, 9, 11, and 13. Although Eugenio Lopez Sr did not find the transfer to Channel 2 objectionable, he was upset about the transfer to Channel 4, which caused technical problems to both ABS-CBN-TV Channel 4 and another station, ABC-RTV Channel 5. Joaquin “Chino” Roces, the owner of the latter, shared the sentiments of Lopez.

 

By this time, Lopez Sr was a very powerful oligarch; Roces was a prominent critic of the Marcos administration; and Benedicto, who operated a daily newspaper and a commercial bank, was a very close friend of Pres Marcos. Political observers saw the reallocation of channels in 1969 as a strategy on the part of Pres Marcos to reduce the political power and industrial might of Lopez, to dilute the influence of Roces in the arena of public opinion, and to pave the way for Benedicto to become his powerful ally in a largely anti-Marcos media industry. Lopez Sr’s resentment in this regard was the first of many reasons that ultimately led to the deterioration of relations between him and his brother Fernando, on the one hand, and Pres Marcos on the other. When Marcos declared martial law in 1972, ABS-CBN was taken over by government and Benedicto. In 1986, after Marcos’s ouster, the Lopezes recovered one television station and a number of radio stations.

ABC Channel 5. On 19 Jun 1960, the Associated Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) began its television operations using the call letters DZMT and the Channel 5 slot. This enterprise was owned and operated by another prominent Filipino family—the Roces family—which published the Manila Times, the leading newspaper of the country in the two decades prior to the martial law period. The letters MT in DZMT stood for Manila Times. Joaquin “Chino” Roces, the helmsman of the daily, was also the top man in DZMT. ABC used to operate from its studio along Roxas Blvd in Pasay City until it moved to a new facility along Pasong Tamo Road in Makati, near Epifanio de los Santos Ave. Its transmitter tower was located at Antipolo in Rizal Province. To avoid being mistaken for the American Broadcasting Company in the United States, the ABC management identified itself first as ABC-RTV-DZMT and eventually simply as ABC-RTV. The operations of both ABC and the Manila Times ground to a halt upon the declaration of martial law in 1972, and never resumed under the Roces family even after the ouster of Marcos in 1986.

 

RBS Channel 7. The Republic Broadcasting System (RBS), present-day GMA 7, traces its roots to Robert “Bob” Stewart, an American war correspondent of the Mutual Broadcasting Company who arrived in the Philippines with the liberation forces of Gen MacArthur in 1944. When the war ended, Stewart remained in the country and went into the radio and television industry in the Philippines. Stewart married a Filipina, Loreto Feliciano, with whom he put up the corporation Loreto F. de Hemedes Inc on 1 Mar 1950. On 14 Jun 1950, the corporation established DZBB Radio, operating from the fourth floor of the Calvo Building on the Escolta. Stewart played an active role in the radio station, doing most of the promotional announcements himself. In 1955, the couple expanded their operation to include DZXX, an AM-band station with a music format. It was the first popular music radio station in the country. In 1957, DZBB and DZXX moved their operations from the Escolta to a new site near Kamuning in Diliman, Quezon City. On 29 Oct 1961, Stewart became part of the television landscape through DZBB-TV Channel 7. His radio and television business was now located at a building of its own along EDSA in Diliman, Quezon City, with its transmitter tower right beside the building. The tower had a triangular base, and near the top, each side bore the number 7 illuminated in green neon light. The lighted signs were like celestial lanterns dotting the evening skies, until Typhoon Yoling destroyed them in 1970.

 

Stewart was seen as a supporter of reelectionist president Carlos P. Garcia of the NP in the Nov 1961 elections. It may be noted that DZBB-TV obtained its franchise under the Garcia administration. When Diosdado Macapagal of the Liberal Party (LP) defeated Garcia in the 1961 presidential elections, Malacañan took steps to have Stewart deported from the country. In the meantime, Stewart’s Uncle Bob’s Lucky 7 Club, a children’s program, developed an extensive following. Stewart avoided deportation because thousands of children who regularly watched his show asked their parents to protest to President Macapagal, thus forcing the president to call off the deportation proceedings. Since then, Stewart refrained from getting personally involved in Philippine politics.

 

Unlike the other radio and television station operators, Stewart did not publish a newspaper, but he enjoyed substantial investments from the American Broadcasting Company of the United States. In 1963, Loreto F. de Hemedes Inc changed its name to Republic Broadcasting System (RBS). It is believed that RBS stood for Robert “Bob” Stewart. Subsequently, during the martial law period, a sale will cause another name change, this time to GMA 7.

 

KBS Channel 9. Roberto S. Benedicto, a lawyer and former corporate officer in the Lopez companies, invested in the radio business in 1960. On 29 Jun, he put station DZKB on the air under the Kanlaon Broadcasting System. Observers say that the letters KB in DZKB refer to the initials of his daughter, Kitchie Benedicto. By then, his commercial interests included substantial investments in the sugar industry in Negros Occidental and investments in the Traders Commercial Bank, which was later renamed Traders Royal Bank. He also owned a daily newspaper, the Philippines Daily Express. Benedicto also enjoyed the full trust and confidence of Ferdinand Marcos, a close friend in law school and college fraternity brother in the University of the Philippines, who in 1965 was elected president of the Philippines.

 

In 1969, Congress granted KBS a franchise to operate a television station, KBS-TV Channel 9. As previously mentioned, KBS purchased the old ABS television studio along Roxas Blvd in Pasay City for its television broadcasts following ABS-CBN’s move from its old studio to its new headquarters in Quezon City. With KBS now a part of the television industry, government regulators reallocated the frequency assignments of ABS-CBN to accommodate the newcomer. ABS-CBN’s Channel 3 and Channel 9 were replaced with Channel 2 and Channel 4, respectively. Channel 9 was assigned to KBS. Like other broadcasting companies in the country, KBS was a stock corporation. In 1970, Benedicto decided to raise investments from the public sector by listing KBS in the stock exchange. This meant that shares of stock of KBS could be purchased by the public. It subsequently changed its name to Radio Philippines Network (RPN) during the martial law period, but kept the name Kanlaon Broadcasting System in its official corporate records.

 

MBC Channel 11. The Manila Broadcasting Company of the brothers Federico, Joaquin Miguel (“JM”), and Manuel Elizalde, which put up KZRH, later DZRH, the first commercial station at war’s end, expanded its operations to include DZRH-TV after it was granted the corresponding franchise by Congress in 1960. Joaquin Miguel Elizalde had political connections. He served the government as foreign affairs secretary under Pres Elpidio Quirino from 1948 to 1950 and from 1952 to 1953. On 11 Apr 1962, MBC-TV Channel 11 began broadcasting. Its television studio was also located alongside its radio facilities at the old Insular Life Building at Plaza Cervantes in Binondo, Manila. Unlike the other television stations, MBC-TV did not broadcast imported programs, except for a few films to fill the airtime.

 

The station suffered from broadcast stoppages due to chronic problems with its transmitter. To address the problem, MBC transferred its television studio to a new location along J. P. Rizal St in the Project 4 district of Quezon City, behind the Quirino Memorial Hospital, known at that time as the Labor Hospital, in the early months of 1972. Its broadcast operations at its new location, however, were short-lived due to the proclamation of martial law in Sep 1972, which led to the closure of the television operations of all stations except KBS. Although MBC was allowed to continue its operations several weeks before the end of 1972, the management decided to abandon its television business and to focus instead on their radio broadcasts.

 

RMN-IBC-TV Channel 13. In 1960, the Inter-Island Broadcasting Corporation (IBC) owned by American businessman Dick Baldwin obtained from Congress a franchise to operate a television station. His station, called DZTV, was assigned television Channel 13. On 1 Mar 1960, IBC-TV 13 made its premiere telecast. In 1962, Andres Soriano Sr, a businessman with huge investments in both the A. Soriano Corporation (also known as Anscor) and the San Miguel Corporation (SMC, a giant food and manufacturing conglomerate and the Philippine franchise holder of Coca-Cola back then) bought both IBC-TV 13 from Baldwin as well as the controlling interest in Radio Mindanao Network (RMN) from the Canoy brothers, who founded the network in Cagayan de Oro City in 1952. Later that year, Soriano established DZHP Radio in Manila under the RMN banner, extending RMN’s reach to Manila, and merged his radio and television acquisitions into one entity—RMN-IBC. Soriano housed his radio and television enterprise at the old ABS transmitter site in Little Baguio, San Juan, which he renovated and improved after acquiring it from ABS-CBN. At that time, Soriano owned a daily newspaper, the Philippines Herald.

 

When Soriano passed away in 1964, his son Andres Soriano Jr took over the family businesses, including the media enterprises. The proclamation of martial law in Sep 1972 led to the temporary closure of the radio and television operations of RMN-IBC and to a stoppage in the publication of the Philippines Herald. Before the end of 1972, however, the radio and television facilities of RMN-IBC were operational once more since the martial law administration did not consider Soriano a threat to national security. The Philippines Herald, however, never resumed publication, even after the end of the Marcos administration.

 

The Canoy brothers subsequently bought back RMN during the martial law period while Soriano sold IBC to Roberto Benedicto, who was by then operating two television stations: Banahaw Broadcasting System (BBC) Channel 2 and RPN Channel 9. Benedicto renamed his newest broadcast station the Intercontinental Broadcasting Corporation, keeping the initials IBC.

 

The Golden Age of Philippine Radio

 

Veteran radio personalities and executives locate the so-called golden age of Philippine radio (also called golden years of Philippine radio) in the decades after the war, with some claiming it started as early as the late 1940s and ended with the declaration of martial law in 1972. What defined the era was the flourishing of a radio style that began to acquire what was perceived as Filipino, even if strong American influences remained. American voices stayed on but began to be edged out by Filipinos. English persisted as the gold standard of radio announcing, but Tagalog and other languages in the regions slowly but surely took over the air lanes. Western popular music endured but the development of the local recording industry introduced many songbirds whose fame on radio rivaled those of American and English music icons. The new art of the soap opera, the bodabil-inspired variety shows that included comedy skits and quizzes, and amateur singing contests hooked legions of listeners of all ages to the radio set. Advertising nourished the medium and its popularity was fanned by the new technology of the portable, battery-operated, and relatively inexpensive transistor radio. Radio was a national pastime, with more listeners than newspaper and magazine readers, even with the introduction of television in the 1950s, which took a few decades to surpass radio in audience subscription.

 

Music Programs and the Local Recording Industry. When the American troops returned at the end of 1944, the broadcasters among them flooded the air with American popular music, which Filipinos sorely missed as the Japanese banned them during the occupation. This had been the regular music fare on radio until a few years after the war when import restrictions limited the entry of foreign music records. The dearth encouraged the birth of the local recording industry, which pressed covers of American popular hits by Filipino singers, but also waxed contemporary local compositions as well as Filipino traditional and folk music such as the kundiman (love song) and harana (serenade). Among the first recording companies were Bataan Recording, Royal, Riego, Mater, Molave, Excelsior, and Villar Recording Company. Others were Union, Mico, Alpha, Super, Scoop, Fama, LVM, Badjao, Jessica, Imperial, Vicor, Blackgold, and Octo-Arts, few of which survived more than a few years. Acclaimed Hari ng Kundiman (King of Kundiman) Ruben Tagalog was among the first to be recorded by Riego and Mabuhay Records. Another successful singer was American-Filipino Cecil Lloyd, called The Mystery Singer, who put up his own recording studio, the Philippine Recording System (PRS) in 1948, and counted besides himself Sylvia La Torre, Pancho Magalona, and Leopoldo Silos as his first artists.

 

The establishment of Villar Recording Company in the Philippines in 1950 made recordings of Philippine songs and music readily available to radio stations and, more importantly, affordable to many Filipinos. Villar labels included Mareco (Manila Record Company) and Mabuhay. The company radio jingle went like this: “Remember your friends abroad, remember your friends abroad, send them lasting gifts of Philippine music on Villar records.” However, most of the radio stations were reluctant to play local music at first, mainly because of the perception that audiences preferred Western popular music and the fact that there were more American selections than there were local ones.
