It took some time before a few radio stations in the country picked up the trend and began including Philippine music in their regular programming, making stars out of Filipino singers, including Bimbo Danao, Phil Delfino, Belle Gonzales, and Don David in the 1950s; Pilita Corrales, Sylvia La Torre, RJ Jacinto, and teenage bands in the 1960s; and in the 1970s, Nora Aunor, Basil Valdez, Sharon Cuneta, Hajji Alejandro, Celeste Legaspi, Jose Mari Chan, Ryan Cayabyab, and the artists of the so-called Pinoy Rock and Manila Sound, the precursor of what is often called original Pilipino music (OPM).

 

Music records were successfully used for some political campaigns, the most memorable of which was Mambo Magsaysay. Elpidio Quirino’s opponent from the opposition Nacionalista Party when he ran for reelection in 1953 was Ramon Magsaysay, who was Quirino’s secretary of national defense. The mambo was the dance craze of the period, and so Magsaysay’s strategists came out with a likeable, danceable song they called “Mambo Magsaysay,” composed by his aide Raul Manglapus, who later became a senator, and recorded by Rosita de la Vega-Da Roza. Recordings of the song were distributed free to the different radio stations in the country and to NP provincial leaders for distribution to cities, towns, and barrios. As a result, the recording was played on the air almost everywhere in the country while people in town fiestas and similar public gatherings danced to the tune. “Mambo Magsaysay” virtually did the campaigning for Magsaysay, who won the election.

 

The 1960s saw Pilita Corrales, then nicknamed Asia’s Queen of Song, serenading radio audiences with her renditions of timeless local pieces, particularly Visayan songs. Helen Gamboa was also a regular singing voice on radio back then. Later in the decade and well into the early 1970s, songbird Nora Aunor, who won the Tawag ng Tanghalan (Call of the Stage) television competition in 1967 with her rendition of “Moonlight Becomes You,” and jukebox king Eddie Peregrina, who was known for “What Am I Living For” and “Together Again” were heard frequently on the AM band. Humorous ballads like “Naku Inday Bakit Mo Binigay” (Oh Inday Why Did You Give It) sung by the yodeling Fred Panopio, and Yoyoy Villame’s now famous “Magellan” were also well received by local radio audiences. Some stations allowed naughty Tagalog translations of certain songs such as the 1964 piece “A Hard Day’s Night” and “Candida,” which came out in 1970.

 

The 1960s was also a memorable decade for Philippine radio, which played foreign musical greats like the Beatles, the Monkees, Tom Jones, Engelbert Humperdinck, and Simon and Garfunkel. After the Beatles performed at the Rizal Memorial Stadium in Manila on 4 Jul 1966, the younger generation of Filipinos turned to the radio to listen to their singing idols, which was more practical than a vinyl record because radio programs were for free while records were not. Moreover, an unlimited access to songs was available to radio listeners while those who used phonographs could listen only to whatever vinyl records they had.

 

The attractiveness of musical programs to Filipino audiences bred the format amateur singing contest. Among the most popular of these was the program variously called Purico Troubadours, Purico Show, and Purico Amateur Hour. Purico is the brand of a cooking lard manufactured by the Philippine Manufacturing Company (PMC), the local licensee of Procter & Gamble. The show had its origins in prewar radio and was revived after the war. The game shows Purico Jamboree and Timpalak ng Purico (Purico Contest) on postwar KZRH were also sponsored by the brand and attained much popularity, but not as much as the amateur singing contest. It ended though when Purico in 1956 began sponsoring Tawag ng Tanghalan on DZBB, which had been on the air since 1950. The program featured aspiring singers who competed with each other in the hope of getting a crack at the professional scene. Winning contestants were allowed to finish their pieces. The losers were interrupted by the sound of a gong or a bell, which meant the contestant was eliminated. Among the contestants who emerged as singing champions and subsequently made a name for themselves were Pepe Pimentel, who later became one of the hosts of the show when it moved to television, Diomedes Maturan, Cenon Lagman, Eva Adona, Ofelia Dayrit, Novo Bono Jr, Ric Manrique Jr, Edgar Mortiz, Jonathan Potenciano, and Nora Aunor. The original hosts of the show were the comedians Rodolfo Quizon, better known as Dolphy, and his sidekick Alfonso Alba, better known as Panchito. When it went on the road, Dolphy left the show due to his movie commitments, so he and Panchito were replaced by another comedy pair, Lopito and Patsy (full name: Pastora Mateo).

 

Soap Operas. Radio dramas, called soaps or soap operas because the first such productions in the United States were sponsored by soap products with the Colgate-Palmolive brands, came in several formats: the melodrama, the situational comedy or sitcom, the sitcom-cum-satire, horror or fantasy and science fiction narratives, and the occasional detective drama. Ilaw ng Tahanan (Light of the Home), written by Liwayway Arceo, was the first postwar soap. It aired on DZRH in Mar 1949, followed a week later by Gulong ng Palad (Wheel of Fate) by Lina Flor, also on DZRH. Both programs, which aired daily for 15 minutes, were about the highs and lows in the life of ordinary Filipino families and their friends. DZRH enjoyed a virtual monopoly of famous radio dramas in the 1950s, a number of which carried the names of their sponsors. These programs included Gabi ng Shell (Shell’s Evening), sponsored by the Shell petroleum company and which featured the famous Lolita Rodriguez and her partner Eddie Arenas; Tang-Tarang-Tang, a sitcom about a dysfunctional Filipino family and its patriarch; the fantasy adventures Prinsipe Amante (Prince Amante), written by Clodualdo del Mundo, and Kapitan Kidlat (Captain Lightning); the detective serial Johnny Davao; another Lina Flor opus, Ginang Hukom (Madam Judge), a legal drama; Genoveva Edroza-Matute’s Aklat ng Pag-ibig (Book of Love), in which unique stories lasted only months instead of the usual years of a typical melodrama; and Gabi ng Lagim (Night of Terror), a horror drama. In 1953, Fidela Magpayo aka Tiya Dely and Dely Magpayo, who had been on radio since 1938 and, during the Japanese period, joined DZRH. She hosted a new drama format titled Ito ang Inyong Tiya Dely (This Is Your Aunt Dely) and pioneered the counseling type of radio programming, which began with the dramatization of a letter sender’s dilemma in life, followed by advice dished out by Magpayo. Her program quickly gained a huge and loyal following and became the model for counseling-and-drama programs both on radio and television.

 

Other memorable soaps of the period include DZPI’s child-oriented Mga Kuwento ni Lola Basyang (Stories of Grandma Basyang), based on Severino Reyes’s serial in Liwayway magazine, Clodualdo del Mundo’s Recuerdo (Memento), and the melodrama Mercedes Cruz; DZBB’s Tony Narra, which was the first detective-type of narrative on Philippine radio, Gloria Villaraza-Guzman’s love stories Mga Lihim ng Puso (Secrets of the Heart), and Camay Theater of the Air, a Sunday-night-60-minute reenactment of an upcoming Filipino movie, with the film actors coming to the studio and reenacting the movie dialogue live; and DZBC’s Panata ng Puso (Heart’s Promise) and Digmaan ng Damdamin (Battle of Emotions), both written and directed by Artemio Marquez, and the horror drama Sepulturero sa Lumang Libingan (Gravedigger in the Old Cemetery).

 

A most unforgettable program that combined satire with comedy-drama was Kuwentong Kutsero (Tall Tales), which first aired in 1938 before the war and went on until the 1960s, interrupted only by the Japanese occupation. It spoofed Filipino manners, politics, customs, and government, with scripts written first by Narciso Pimentel and Jesus Paredes, and later by Epifanio Matute. Conceptualized by Horacio de la Costa and James Reuter, both Jesuit priests, the show’s format was successfully replicated in the provincial stations. Other memorable postwar soaps were Fundador Soriano’s Kahapon Lamang (Just Yesterday) and Flordeluna. The latter first aired in Cebu radio and was later translated to Tagalog and produced for Manila television audiences in the late 1970s, like other popular soaps that were later reproduced on television or made into movies.

 

The golden years of Philippine radio were marked by the prominence of classical Tagalog—the kind associated with the great poet Balagtas. It was clearly felt in most program genres and in advertisements, but especially in drama. However, dramas in English were on the air until the 1950s, many produced by college dramatic guilds such as Cathedral Players on DZRH, managed by Ateneo de Manila’s James Reuter; Bedan Barristers on DZPI, made up of thespians of San Beda College led by Noe Nebrida; and Republic Players on DZBB, composed of several stage actors, directors, scriptwriters, and producers transitioning to radio, television, and, later, film. To the local broadcast and cinema industries they brought the literary styles and conventions of the Western stage acquired from school-based dramatic clubs.

 

Variety shows. The variety show, a mélange of musical performances, comic skits, and light banter among hosts and guests, was a popular genre on radio and later on television. A takeoff from the prewar bodabil and the wartime stage show, the variety show later included quizzes, games, and contests. A common feature of variety shows was the live audience in the studio, who participated in the program by joining the contests and providing live laughter and applause.

 

An example of the variety show that appealed to young adults was on DZXL, which scored a hit in 1958 with its innovative noontime program CBN Canteen, which was aired from the cafeteria of the CBN studio in Intramuros. CBN Canteen was hosted by Eddie Ilarde, Bobby Ledesma, and Leila Benitez. It was so popular with the student population that the CBN management decided to rename the show Student Canteen. The next year, Student Canteen became a noontime television program on DZXL-TV Channel 9. Other popular variety shows were DZXL’s Darigold Jumbo Jamboree, hosted by two of the funniest pairs of comics at the time—Dolphy and Panchito, and Leila Benitez and Eddie Ilarde; the gag-filled The Big Broadcast on DZRH, produced and hosted by Conde Ubaldo and Luz Mat Castro, featuring the brightest stars of the film studio Sampaguita Pictures; DZFM’s Edong Mapangarap (Edong the Dreamer), a string of comic skits; and the memorable Reyna ng Vicks (Queen of Vicks) on DZRH, sponsored by Vicks Vaporub vaporizing ointment, which interviewed on the air five female members of the studio audience. They all spoke about their unique experiences and the one who was applauded the loudest was declared “queen” for a day.

 

Variety shows that appealed to children enjoyed considerable airtime during the golden years of Philippine radio. Most of these programs consisted of quiz shows and spelling bees. Radio Schoolhouse on DZPI, hosted by Ira Davis, conducted quizzes for grade school kids, while Knowledge Unlimited on DZRH, hosted by Ray Oliver and Louie Garcia, held competitions for high school and college students. Every correctly spelled word was rewarded 50 centavos in Spell to Win, hosted by Norman Reyes and Hal Bowie. Eskuwelahang Munti (Little Schoolhouse) on DZBB, produced and hosted by Tino Lapus, featured aspiring child performers, which launched the careers of then child actors Vilma Santos, Edgar Mortiz, Esperanza Fabon, and Ike Lozada. On DZPI was Campus Capers, made up of comic skits about college life, hosted by Al Spencer with Tita Muñoz, Veronica Palileo, Arling Gonzales, and Al Wayne. Professor Quiz was a game show on DZMB that asked participants general information type of questions. Its main announcers were Hal Bowie and Don Lee while Ray Oliver, Larry Ng, Ric Tierro, Jess Fernandez, Simeon Bonzon, and Rafael Yabut took turns in selecting the contestants.

 

Sportscasts. The prewar stations regularly covered sporting events, especially baseball, the most popular sport in the United States, and basketball, by annotating the game to a radio audience that imagined the event they did not see. The practice continued after the war until the visual medium of television took over in the late 1950s, but not before radio made stars of sportscasters Willie Hernandez, Jake Romero, and Jack Garcia, who gave listeners play-by-play accounts of boxing, tennis, and basketball matches. The games of the basketball leagues Manila Industrial and Commercial Athletic Association (MICAA) and the National Collegiate Athletic Association or NCAA were especially popular. Ric Tierro covered baseball while Ben Francisco and Ben Hernandez joined the basketball coverage team. Henry Diy covered tennis matches while Taby Tabaniag annotated the boxing program Fistorama before it moved to television.

 

Old and New Formats. Interrupted by the war, a program that began to go on the air in 1934 returned on DZRH in the 1950s—the Balagtasan, a poetic joust usually about a social issue or a cultural tradition. Hosted by poet Emilio Mar Antonio every Sunday, he engaged a guest makata (poet) in a debate in Tagalog verse, with the debate topic phrased in questions like, “Should divorce be introduced in the Philippines?” or “Should the Philippines be a state of the United States of America?” (Jimenez 1996, 33B; Aniceto 2007, 508).

 

The absence of American programs during the war created an appetite for radio shows from the United States, which came recorded in 16-inch discs. Many of these were wartime variety productions aimed at the American soldier fighting the war in Europe and in the Pacific, such as The Lucky Strike Show with Bob Hope, The Coca-Cola Show with Giselle MacKenzie, The Perry Como Show with Jo Stafford, The Martin and Lewis Show, and the scary drama thriller Witching Hour.

 

In the meantime, a new format of the counseling genre, one in English, with no accompanying tearful dramatizations of listeners’ lives, went on the air in 1957. This was Father Bob and His Telephone hosted by Bob Garon, a young Roman Catholic priest. Listeners were encouraged to call up the station and seek help regarding their personal problems, without revealing their real names. The program launched the media career of Father Garon.

 

The PBS began airing programs that targeted farmers in the 1950s, but it was in the 1960s that the program type gained popularity and became part of regular programming of several AM stations. Usually aired in the early morning at around five o’clock, announcers discussed new ways of increasing agricultural productivity with information coming from the Department of Agriculture, UP Los Baños, the International Rice Research Institute, the Philippine Rural Reconstruction Movement, and the International Institute for Rural Reconstruction.

 

A program type that emerged after the war was the personality platter show in which an announcer, later called disc jockey or the DJ, played selected music records and engaged the listeners in a light chat. Several of these shows entertained requests by listeners sent by mail, with some DJs indulging their fans by dedicating the music they played to admirers. The shows boosted sales of records, particularly of popular music, while many DJs became household names. Among these programs were Cashmere Bouquet Top Tunes hosted by Larry Ng, Voice of Firestone featuring Broadway melodies and hosted by Ray Oliver, Silahis ng Pag-asa (Ray of Hope), featuring light classics and hosted by Ric Tierro, Latina Americana hosted by Louie Garcia, Roll of Honor hosted by Eddie Mercado, and the so-called request-dedication platter shows such as Request Jamboree hosted by Dick Taylor, Night Owl hosted by Lito Gorospe, All Night Stand hosted by Jo San Diego, Mailbag Jukebox hosted by Angelo and Cherrie Castro, and Platter Bungalow hosted by Bong Lapira.

 

Radio Advertising. In the decades following the war, almost all of the advertising aired on both radio and television was of the hard-sell type, and mostly done in Tagalog and other major Philippine languages. The products advertised consisted mainly of detergents, beauty soaps, dental creams (toothpaste), pomade, cigarettes, soft drinks, milk, instant coffee, gasoline, over-the-counter medicine, milk, beauty products, cooking oil, soy sauce, and many other consumer products. Many of these consumer products were manufactured by the Philippine Manufacturing Company, the local branch of Procter & Gamble, the biggest advertising spender at the time, which poured 90 percent of its advertising budget into radio, until television began to eat into radio’s share of the advertising pie during the martial law years. PMC’s main competitor was the Philippine Refining Company, the local licensee of Lever Brothers, present-day Unilever. Another corporate competitor of the period was Colgate-Palmolive (Philippines) Inc. The boundary then between broadcast announcers and executives, on the one hand, and advertising men, on the other, was porous. Many crossed over or did both at the same time, producing and hosting programs while writing and voicing ad copy and servicing clients. Some memorable ad lines that were initially produced for radio were later reproduced for television: “Johnson yata ’yan!;” “Say mabuhay with Tanduay;” “Kiko Baterya, Kiko Dinamo;” “I’m walking on clouds in my Camara shoes;” and “National Zippers slide up and down!” (Davis 2007, 223-26).

 

During election seasons, political adverttising outnumbered commercials for consumer products. Then and now, it was a significant source of income for both radio and television stations.

In the mid-1950s, television was getting increasingly popular in the country, and radio industry leaders saw a need to address a potential problem. Specialized programming was seen as a means of keeping the radio industry alive and competitive. DZXX, which began to specialize in popular music, set the trend in reinventing programming to cater to specific audience groups. Soon, other radio stations reinvented themselves. DZRJ concentrated on popular pieces and dance music, and it became a favorite among teenagers. Office workers, wage earners, and housewives became avid listeners of drama on DZAQ, DZRH, and DZXL. DWOW catered to commuters and focused on local popular music and pieces performed by local singers. Highly politicized listeners could choose from several early-morning commentators of the different AM-band radio stations. Listeners on the FM band who liked old-fashioned music and instrumentals tuned in to DZFX.

 

Toward the end of the decade, radio survived the competition from television by developing its own loyal following during the early morning and late evening hours. While television competed with radio in the nation’s urban areas, radio dominated the countryside and rural communities, especially those with no access to electricity.

 

The Age of Television

 

The cost of a television set was prohibitive when it was first introduced in the 1950s, so it took another decade for urban middle-class families to have it in their homes. However, as in the early years of radio, television owners invested in programming in the belief that television would eventually become a profitable business. In the meantime, programs had to be put on the air. There were two sources: American TV stations that sold canned serials and existing local radio programs transmuted into the visual medium. Buying canned shows from the United States was a practice that prevailed for decades as it was a lot less expensive to buy them than produce original shows. Moreover, it was a guaranteed investment as the Filipino audience was already conditioned to enjoy American programs. But while it was more capital-intensive to produce television programs locally, the formats and popularity of several radio shows suggested that they could be migrated to television successfully in terms of production values and audience reception. Besides, the television owners also owned the counterpart radio stations that produced the thriving programs on radio. That gamble paid off. Thus, early television programs in the country had their origins in radio. Many carried the original radio titles while others used new program titles but with the same formats. From the 1960s up to 1972, television stations in the Philippines broadcast from five o’clock in the morning and ended their broadcast day at midnight, supported and sustained by advertising. It was an indication of a growing and loyal television audience.

 

Variety Shows. Radio’s variety programs were the first and easiest to be replicated in television. In 1959, the variety program Student Canteen on CBN-DZXL radio became a noontime television program on then CBN-DZXL-TV Channel 9. It retained its hosts Eddie Ilarde, Leila Benitez, Bobby Ledesma, and Pepe Pimentel. It was enormously popular but in 1964, Ilarde, Benitez, and Ledesma left the show following a misunderstanding with the managers of ABS-CBN-TV Channel 9 and moved to another television program, Darigold Jamboree, on Manila Broadcasting Company’s TV Channel 11, which also had its origins as a radio program on DZRH. Pepe Pimentel remained on Student Canteen but he was unable to sustain the popularity of the show, thus leading to its termination in 1965. The management replaced Student Canteen with Stop, Look and Listen hosted by Eddie Mesa. Later, during the martial law years, Student Canteen was revived as a television program on RBS-TV Channel 7, which Ilarde and Ledesma hosted with Helen Vela.

 

Philippine comedy king Rodolfo V. Quizon, also known as Dolphy, made his television debut in 1964 on the weekly variety show Buhay Artista (Actor’s Life), also on Channel 3. He shared the television limelight with his cinema sidekick Alfonso Alba, also known as Panchito. Among the new television programs that went on the air on ABS-CBN-TV Channel 3 in 1965 was Magandang Tanghali (Good Afternoon), a noontime variety show hosted by Pancho Magalona. In 1967, the evening variety show Oras ng Ligaya (Happy Hour) began airing on Channel 3.

 

Meanwhile, ABS-CBN-TV Channel 9 is remembered for The Lucky Strike Show, an evening variety program hosted by Nelda Navarro; The Baby O’Brien Show, another variety program hosted by Baby O’Brien, and Da Best Show. All three began airing in the early 1960s. At around the same time, Everyday Holiday, a post-noontime variety program hosted by actor and singer Sylvia La Torre and comedian Doro de los Ojos, went on the air. Its opening song described the show in this manner: “Every day, holiday, oras ng kasiyahan every day!” (Every day, holiday, happy hour every day!) Some of ABS-CBN’s variety programs were hybrids of variety and musical-dance or sitcom, such as The Nida-Nestor Show, a highly popular late-evening program starring Nida Blanca and Nestor de Villa, whose dance routines were legend, and Da Pakulo (The Gimmick).

 

The Chiquito Show hosted by comedian Chiquito, Augusto Valdez Pangan in real life, aired on ABC-RTV Channel 5. One of the most popular local shows on Channel 5 was Seeing Stars with Joe Quirino, where host Joe Quirino interviewed international celebrities who happened to be in town. Often, Quirino got his guests to sing or perform an act, and gave them their cue with his immortal line, “Take it away,” seasoned with a thick Ilocano accent. Joe Quirino was the Philippine equivalent of America’s celebrated television showman Ed Sullivan.

 

On RBS TV Channel 7, Robert Stewart hosted The Bob Stewart Show, which featured guests who discussed with him almost anything of interest to television audiences. During the early years of the martial law era, this program became The Maestro and Uncle Bob, and later on, Uncle Bob and Friends. On MBC TV Channel 11, the most well-known program was Darigold Jamboree, a noontime variety show that first aired as Darigold Jumbo Jamboree on DZRH radio, hosted by veteran performers Eddie Ilarde, Bobby Ledesma, Leila Benitez, and Johnny Wilson, and sponsored by Darigold Milk, a leading American franchise brand of the day. As mentioned above, Darigold Jamboree migrated from radio after Ilarde, Ledesma, and Benitez, who were the hosts of Student Canteen on CBN-TV Channel 9, had left Student Canteen after a disagreement with CBN-TV management. Arrangements to have Pepe Pimentel and comedian Bentot (Arturo Vergara Medina in real life) join Darigold Jamboree did not materialize. For a time, Darigold Jamboree faced tough competition from The Big Show, another variety show aired on a rival television channel and sponsored by Liberty Milk, another American franchise brand. Darigold Jamboree aired from 1964 to 1972.

 

Musicals and Dance Programs. Derivatives of the variety show genre, programs with music and dance were popular. Coinciding with the year 1961 when ABS and CBN stations began using the name ABS-CBN, Channel 3 inaugurated Jam Session, a musical program that specialized in youth-oriented music starring Bobby Ng and a band called the Hi-Jacks. A memorable Channel 3 musical was An Evening with Pilita, hosted by Pilita Corrales, who was then dubbed Asia’s Queen of Song, and aired on prime time from 1965 to 1972. A variant of the musical show was the singing contest, which had enjoyed immense following on radio. Also on Channel 3, the television version of Tawag ng Tanghalan (Call of the Stage), hosted by Pepe Pimentel, aired also in 1965, until 1969. Tawag ng Tanghalan produced a champion in 1967 who became one of the more iconic and respected stars on the Philippine film, television, radio, and the music industries—Nora Aunor. Winning the championship on her second try, Aunor’s victory assured her of roles in other ABS-CBN television programs like the evening variety show Oras ng Ligaya (Happy Hour) on Channel 3. Another popular singing contest was Hamon sa Kampeon (Challenge to the Champion), hosted by Dely Magpayo and Pepe Pimentel. A discotheque program called Nineteeners began airing on ABS-CBN Channel 9 in 1966.

 

Competing with An Evening with Pilita were the evening musical programs Helen of Song, hosted by Helen Gamboa, and Carmen on Camera, featuring veteran singer Carmen Soriano on ABC RTV Channel 5, in the 1960s. On RBS TV Channel 7, Dancetime with Chito went on the air late at night, hosted by a socialite, Chito Feliciano. The program was one of the few local programs on Channel 7 broadcast live from the studio within a Spartan studio set. It was the first of its kind in the Philippines, becoming a model for subsequent dance programs on television. Feliciano and his guests demonstrated the latest dance steps to the audience. Meanwhile, on MBC TV Channel 11, DJ Dance Time and The Nite Owl Dance Party rivaled RBS TV’s highly popular Dancetime with Chito. In 1970, Channel 11 cashed in on the popularity of filmdom’s teen idol Tirso Cruz III, from the musical Cruz family, with the song-and-dance Catch Up with Tirso.

 

There were several imported canned musical programs in the 1960s, among them This Is … Tom Jones, which aired on ABS-CBN Channel 3, and The Engelbert Humperdinck Show on KBS TV Channel 9, both starring popular pop singers in England.

 

Soaps and Other Narratives. Dramatic shows on television may be loosely classified into melodramas, fantasy-horror, action-adventure, and family-oriented dramas. While there were a few daily soaps or the drama serial whose episodes continued the narrative from day to day over a period of years, many were weekly anthologies where a unique story was featured in every series. Among the most remarkable of these drama anthologies was ABC Channel 5’s Balintataw (The Mind’s Eye), which featured productions of the Philippine Educational Theater Association beginning in 1967, with Cecile Guidote, Lupita Concio, Alberto Florentino, and Nick Lizaso as producers. Its directors, who all subsequently launched careers in TV and movie directing, include Lino Brocka, Elwood Perez, and Joey Gosiengfiao. Among its most notable episodes were “Isang Gabi ng Tagsibol” (A Night in Spring), Alberto Florentino’s TV adaptation of Nick Joaquin’s May Day Eve; “Kabalyerong Tanso” (Fake Knight) an adaptation by Elizabeth Acaylar (a pseudonym) of Wilfrido Nolledo’s Rice Wine; “Pag-iisa” (Being Alone), an original teleplay by Florentino; and “Kudyapi” (Two-Stringed Lute), which Brocka adapted from Bienvenido Santos’s The Day the Dancers Came (Video 48 2008).

 

Salamisim (Reflections) was another of Channel 5’s drama anthologies, hosted by Marlene Dauden, which competed with ABS-CBN’s Panagimpan (Dream). Dauden subsequently also hosted the latter when she left Channel 5. Santa Zita and Mary Rose, a memorable Sunday afternoon Catholic-oriented drama about household helpers, also aired on ABC. Evolving from a radio counseling program, it was hosted by Mary Rose Jacinto and featured stage thespian Zeneida Amador under the direction of James Reuter, sponsored by the Jacinto Steel Company.

 

Canned dramas from American and English television aired on local TV, such as Marcus Welby, M.D. on ABS-CBN, Peyton Place on RBS Channel 7, the original hospital emergency room drama Ben Casey, and the courtroom dramas Perry Mason and Ironside on RMN-IBC Channel 13.

 

Locally produced but short-lived horror programs Hiwaga sa Bahay na Bato (Mystery in the House of Stone) and Limbo aired on ABS-CBN in the 1960s. Programs that imitated American and British action shows include Agent 69 and Kwatro Bidas (Four Heroes), a program considered unique because it is a serious drama that featured four known comedians—Doro de los Ojos, Teroy de Guzman, Cachupoy, and Ading Fernando—as special law enforcers who are experts in martial arts. Since it cost less for TV stations to buy canned programs from other countries than produce original shows, several imported dramas, especially the horror-fantasy and action-adventure types, aired on local TV. On ABS-CBN, there were quite a few, such as the serialized Westerns Alias Smith and Jones, Bonanza, Gunsmoke, Lancer, The High Chaparral, Wanted: Dead or Alive, and The Wild, Wild West; the adventure dramas The Rat Patrol, Route 66, Tarzan, and The Twilight Zone; a family-oriented drama, The Doris Day Show; the police and detective shows Cannon, Dan August, Hawaii Five-O, The Mod Squad, Sarge, and The NBC Mystery Movie, which was not a movie but a “wheel show” or “umbrella show” that rotated several programs within the same time period. In this case, the program rotated different detective shows including McCloud, Millan & Wife, Columbo, and Quincy, M.E., each broadcast at intervals of three to five weeks. A British-made television program, The Baron, was also on ABS-CBN.

 

ABC Channel 5 also aired canned American action-adventure programs, including the detective shows It Takes a Thief, Mannix, The Protectors, and Randall and Hopkirk; and the mystery anthology Alfred Hitchcock Presents. Channel 5 became known for The Samurai, a Japanese television series dubbed in English and shown in mid-morning and early evening time slots. Through his connections in the United States, especially friends from the American Broadcasting Company, Stewart obtained for RBS Channel 7 a substantial volume of the most popular American television programs of the period, dominating the station’s primetime programming up to the early 1970s. They include the war action classic Combat!; the iconic Mission: Impossible and The Fugitive; the camp program Batman; the series on the adventures of a female private investigator titled Honey West; the futuristic adventure program called The Man from U.N.C.L.E. and its spin-off The Girl from U.N.C.L.E.; Westerns such as Bat Masterson, Daniel Boone, The Rifleman, and The Virginian; the detective adventure shows The Green Hornet and The Persuaders!; mystery science fiction adventures Star Trek, Voyage to the Bottom of the Sea, Land of the Giants, The Time Tunnel, and Lost in Space; other family-oriented serials like Gilligan’s Island, Flipper, and The Patty Duke Show; action programs 77 Sunset Strip, The Untouchables, and Hawaiian Eye; and Flash Gordon, a science fiction serial produced by Universal Pictures in 1936.

 

RMN-IBC Channel 13, on the other hand, aired the police-detective program The FBI, a detective show based on extrasensory perception called The Sixth Sense, and One Step Beyond, a horror-thriller patterned after The Twilight Zone. There were two British productions broadcast also on prime time: The Avengers and The Saint. Both programs were about British agents who fought foreign spies and other enemies of the West.

 

Sitcoms and Gag Shows. A most memorable program of this genre began airing on radio in 1938, during the American colonial period, the Kuwentong Kutsero (Tall Tales). Interrupted during the Japanese occupation, the show went back on radio after the war and in the 1960s was produced by ABS-CBN Channel 3 as a television sitcom. By the middle of the 1960s, Channel 3 also had Tang-Tarang-Tang, a Saturday evening situation comedy about a dysfunctional family and its naughty patriarch. ABS-CBN produced other situational comedies such as Mrs. Milyonarya (Mrs Millionaire), starring Chichay, and Wanted Boarders, starring Pugo; and the gag show Super Laff-In. ABC RTV Channel 5, on the other hand, produced Gorio and His Jeepney and Tisoy (moniker for someone of mixed race, usually Filipino and Caucasian mix), both of which were adaptations of popular comic strips of the same respective titles in the Manila Times. Chiquito played the character of Gorio while the cast of Tisoy was composed of Jimmy Morato, Pilar Pilapil, Bert Marcelo, and Moody Diaz. In 1967, MBC-TV Channel 11 began the telecast of the sitcom Etcetera, Etcetera.

 

Imported canned sitcoms were numerous. ABS-CBN had The Flying Nun, Get Smart, Hogan’s Heroes, The Partners, and The Partridge Family while ABC Channel 5 aired the fantasy-comedy program Bewitched. RBS Channel 7 imported the slapstick comedy The Addams Family and the romantic comedy I Dream of Jeannie while KBS Channel 9 aired the sitcoms From a Bird’s Eye View, Hey, Landlord, My Favorite Martian, My Mother the Car, and Temperatures Rising; a slapstick comedy featuring one-liners, Rowan & Martin’s Laugh In; and the drama anthology My World … and Welcome to It. Early morning and mid-afternoon programs on RMN-IBC Channel 13 consisted of episodes of the original slapstick comedy series The Three Stooges.

 

Game Shows. The visual medium of television offered greater audience involvement than radio in programs that featured contests and games with prizes. Perhaps the most popular of these shows in the 1960s was Kuarta o Kahon (Cash or Box), which debuted on ABS-CBN Channel 3 in 1962, with Pepe Pimentel as host. Contestants were asked to choose between a sum of money and a mystery prize inside a randomly selected box. This show lasted until 1969, but returned to television during the martial law era via Barangay Broadcasting Corporation (later renamed Banahaw Broadcasting Corporation) Channel 2, with Pepe Pimentel as the mainstay host. Other game shows on ABS-CBN were Winner Take All and the American canned show The Game Game. ABC RTV Channel 5 meanwhile aired Kwarta Na! (Money Already!), a game show where everyone seemed to win.

 

A different type of game was on KBS Channel 9, the Pintakasi, a Sunday afternoon live television coverage of the Philippine betting game called sabong (cockfights) held in selected cockpits in the metropolis. Hosted by Ray Pedroche, Pintakasi afforded fans the convenience of watching a cockfight, called tupada, and the betting, too, without leaving home. Pintakasi left the air in Sep 1972. Another betting game was on Channel 11, the weekend horse races at the San Lazaro and Santa Ana hippodromes. The announcer always began his spiels with the line, “There they go … and they’re running …”

 

Children’s Programs and Animation. TV stations invested in programs for children more during the postwar years than the subsequent periods of Philippine broadcasting. RBS Channel 7 aired the hour before lunchtime on Sundays the children’s educational and entertainment program Eskuwelahang Munti (Little Schoolhouse). The title was taken from a Tagalog motion picture of the same title starring Luis Gonzales and Gloria Romero. Another program on Channel 7 was the Uncle Bob’s Lucky Seven Club, a weekly late afternoon television program where Bob Stewart interviewed youngsters and gave away prizes. Bespectacled and friendly, Stewart called himself everybody’s “Uncle Bob.” On ABC Channel 5 was a short-lived children’s program featuring Subas Herrero, Mr. Jumbo.

 

One of the few local programs KBS Channel 9 produced during the period was Clubhouse 9, the most popular local program on the station prior to the martial law period, which made its television debut in 1970. It was a late afternoon children’s live television program hosted by veteran showman Pepe Pimentel inside the KBS studio filled with children accompanied by their parents or guardians. It went on the air Mondays to Saturdays, 5:30-7:00 pm. The show opened with a young boy or girl, a bulilit announcer, introducing both the program and the host. The term “bulilit” is a Tagalog idiomatic expression which means “diminutive or extremely small.” Pauline Bonnevie, the sister of local film actress Dina Bonnevie, was one of the most famous bulilit announcers of Clubhouse 9. Following in the style of veteran television broadcaster Robert “Uncle Bob” Stewart on Channel 7, Pimentel had himself called “Tito Pepe” (Uncle Pepe), a name that endeared him to both the studio audience and those watching on television. This moniker managed to stick to Pimentel even as he hosted other shows in future years including Kuarta o Kahon and Family Kuarta o Kahon. Toward the last quarter of 1971, Clubhouse 9 acquired a right to broadcast the 1961 Japanese animated film Alakazam the Great, a 1960 Japanese musical animated film dubbed in English and narrated by American actor Sterling Holloway.

 

Most of the imported canned programs for children were animations, such as those that aired on ABS-CBN, including Atom Ant, Birdman and the Galaxy Trio, Frankenstein Jr. and the Impossibles, The Hillbilly Bears, The Pebbles and Bam-Bam Show, Space Ghost, and Squidly Diddly, all from Hanna-Barbera Productions; and Super Six from DePatie-Freleng Productions. The other American animated programs on the ABS-CBN channels were Batfink, The Famous Adventures of Mr. Magoo, Farmer Al Falfa and His Terrytoon Pals, The Woody Woodpecker Show, and Walt Disney’s Wonderful World of Color. Walt Disney’s Wonderful World of Color was not fully animated; it had live action segments featuring Disney himself. A favorite among the youngsters was the Marvel Super Heroes series featuring characters like Captain America, The Sub-Mariner, The Mighty Thor, The Incredible Hulk, and The Invincible Ironman.

 

ABC Channel 5 also imported animated programs such as The Adventures of Johnny Quest, The Flintstones, Huckleberry Hound, Peter Potamus, and Ricochet Rabbit, all from Hanna-Barbera Productions; and Mighty Mouse and Heckle and Jeckle of the Terrytoons line. The Banana Splits Adventure Show, a children’s variety and musical program combining live action sequences and animated segments, likewise from Hanna-Barbera, also aired on Channel 5. Gigantor, a black-and-white animated program, made its Philippine debut on the same station. It is the first Japanese animated robot program aired on Philippine television, beating Voltes V by 10 years. Restored episodes of Gigantor have been colorized.

 

The other stations also imported animated programs aimed at children. On RBS Channel 7 were American animated shows like Popeye (both prewar and postwar productions), Beany and Cecil the Seasick Sea Serpent, Gumby, Harveytoons, The New Three Stooges, Tales of the Genie, Sinbad the Sailor, The Dick Tracy Show, and Roger Ramjet. The animated program lineup of Channel 7 likewise included The Funny Company, a part-animated, part-live action documentary show also produced in the United States, and episodes of a dialogue-free children’s show about a nameless, costumed man with magical powers produced by Trans Tel Zeit of what was then known as West Germany. Weekday afternoons, Saturday mornings and afternoons, and a couple of hours on Sunday mornings were reserved for animated programs. KBS Channel 9 had a limited number of programs in its animation chest: The Amazing Spider-Man, Archie’s TV Funnies, Porky Pig, and Rocket Robin Hood. These shows went on the air during the late afternoons. On RMN-IBC Channel 13 were the animated programs Wally Gator and Magilla Gorilla from Hanna-Barbera Productions, and The Alvin Show.

 

In 1969, ABC Channel 5 hosted the Philippine premiere of the now classic American educational program Sesame Street. Filipinos were pleasantly surprised that the one-hour show had no commercial interruptions.

 

Movies on TV. Television during the period became an outlet for old movies that would otherwise not enjoy exposure beyond their cinema runs. On the other hand, the films helped provide TV the material to fill its airtime. ABS-CBN Channel 3 aired several local films under the labels Puting Tabing (Silver Screen) in the morning and Mga Aninong Gumagalaw (Moving Shadows) in the afternoon. On ABC Channel 5, Tagalog motion pictures aired on prime time under the banners Sinagtala (Star Beam) and Bahaghari (Rainbow). Those aired in the afternoons were under the label Aliw ng Tahanan (Joy of the Home).

 

As with the other program genres, foreign films were also on the air. ABS-CBN aired Hollywood films under the label Color Movie Greats for color films exhibited at night, Movie Greats for black-and-white films aired at night, Command Performance for afternoon films, and Repeat Performance for movie replays. During the summer months, the mid-afternoon slot was reserved for Republic Serials, which consisted of prewar and wartime black-and-white movies in serial form including Batman. On ABC Channel 5, Hollywood films were also aired under the label Million Dollar Movies, sponsored by the General Textile Company; Philippine Blooming Mills Inc, a steel manufacturing enterprise; Marvel, a detergent powder; Mikado, a Japanese brand of pomade; and Kaminomoto Oban, a Japanese brand of therapeutic plaster. Some non-American movies were also aired under this label. RBS Channel 7 aired American as well as Chinese movies, often with English subtitles, broadcast during Sunday afternoons.

 

During the early years of KBS Channel 9, almost all of its programs were canned American shows, with RBS Channel 7 as the only one that had more canned programs. Channel 9 aired numerous motion pictures, many of them horror or science fiction films and light dramas produced by American International Pictures, including House of Usher, The Pit and the Pendulum, The Raven, Tales of Terror, and Pajama Party. Hollywood films dominated Monday and Thursday evenings on KBS-TV. The movie date on Mondays was called The KBS Spectacular of the Week while the one on Thursdays was called Thursday Night at the Movies. When KBS started using the name Radio Philippines Network in 1974, The KBS Spectacular of the Week was renamed The RPN Spectacular of the Week. Night owls on Sunday evenings were treated to American horror movies under the label Sunday Suspense Theatre (SST). The first film it featured was Daughter of the Mind starring Ray Milland. After KBS ran out of American horror films for SST, the management resorted to syndicated British horror-mysteries.

 

There were also Hollywood films on RMN IBC Channel 13, shown late at night under the labels Armchair Theatre and Curtain Call. Movies about war were featured under the title War Classics. Because of the acute lack of program materials on the station, War Classics was shown twice on the night it was scheduled for broadcasting. For the same reason, the station often broadcast filler films during the afternoons.

 

Sports. The medium of television lent itself well to the spectacle of sports. Sports programs coincided with the seasonal staging of athletic events and the occasional international special sporting match. Among the memorable specials was the fight that made a boxing icon out of Gabriel “Flash” Elorde aired on ABS-CBN Channel 3. On 16 Mar 1960, the world junior lightweight boxing championship match between Elorde of the Philippines and Harold Gomes of the United States was held at the newly opened Araneta Coliseum in Cubao, Quezon City, with 36,000 spectators filling the arena. Channel 3 brought the fight to households that had television sets. The television event was the first of its kind in the Philippines. Elorde won that fight, while ABS made history. In 1972, days before Marcos put the Philippines under martial law, KBS Channel 9 provided Philippine viewers with a live coverage of the 1972 Olympic Games held in Munich, West Germany.

 

Long before the Philippine Basketball Association became famous, basketball enthusiasts in the country were loyal viewers of the games organized by the MICAA and broadcast on MBC’s radio and television stations in the early part of the 1960s. Companies that fielded teams in the MICAA basketball games include the Manila Electric Company, Crispa-Floro, San Miguel Corporation, Yutivo Motors, and E. R. Squibb Pharmaceuticals. Problems regarding the television transmitter of MBC eventually forced the transfer of the radio and television coverage of the MICAA games to other broadcasting companies toward the later part of the 1960s. In the meantime, there was also an audience among the basketball-crazy Filipinos for the prerecorded games of the National Basketball Association in the United States, which went on the air through ABS-CBN. The Boston Celtics was the dominant team back then.

 

RMN-IBC Channel 13 aired mostly canned programs because its studio was so small that it could accommodate only a news program production, but it managed to air Fistorama, because the coverage of the sporting events was done by remote broadcast rather than in a studio. Fistorama was a local primetime program featuring boxing matches between promising but unknown pugs looking for an opportunity to go big time. First aired on DZRH radio, it was annotated for Channel 13 by Joe Cantada.

 

Specials and Documentaries. By the late 1960s, local television had acquired the technological capacity to cover extraordinary events live, such as the Apollo 11 spaceship launch and its subsequent landing on the moon. On 16 Jul 1969, Channel 7, as the carrying station, broadcast the launch live via satellite simultaneously on all Philippine television channels. Stewart was chosen as the anchor of the Philippine segment annotating the long countdown to the actual space launch. The day was declared a national holiday in the Philippines to allow everybody to watch the historic space launch. A digital clock indicating the number of minutes left to actual lift-off was on the television screen. While on the air, Stewart interviewed Pres Ferdinand Marcos on the telephone a half hour prior to lift-off. During the actual conversation, Stewart was seen talking on the telephone with a photograph of Marcos inset in the corner of the screen. The Apollo 11 lunar landing on 20 Jul 1969 was also broadcast live via satellite simultaneously on all local television channels, again with Stewart as the anchor of the Philippine segment. Innumerable Filipinos watched both the space launch and the lunar landing, but the subsequent return flight of the Apollo 11 space capsule did not have the same enthusiastic viewership.

 

Prior to the Apollo 11 coverage, in 1968 ABS-CBN brought to Filipino audiences the first satellite transmission in the country—the aftermath of the assassination of Sen Robert Kennedy, a popular American political figure and younger brother of the late president John F. Kennedy, in Los Angeles, California. ABS-CBN also aired documentaries from the United States, among them the documentary anthology Appointment with Destiny. On Channel 7, an American program for dog owners, Training You to Train Your Dog, went on the air on late Saturday afternoons right before prime time.

 

Station IDs and Promos. Television stations promoted themselves by adopting logos and symbols, by having talking heads address the audience, and by producing vignettes that mixed pictures and sound and other special effects to create their respective distinctive brands. In 1963, when ABS-CBN tested the first color television transmission in the Philippines using technology imported from the United States, it also adopted a new logo—a square containing a symbolic transmitter antenna with radio waves. Three years later, in Jun 1966, the network began the commercial launch of its color television broadcasts using the same technology used by the Radio Corporation of America. Since not all local or imported programs broadcast by the network were in color, a color program was introduced by an animated sequence of the legendary sarimanok (a mythical bird with a fish in its beak) of Philippine Muslim lore formed by moving feathers and accompanied by the audio spiel, “The following program is brought to you in living color” delivered by veteran announcer Francisco “Frankie” Evangelista. Of course, the color program appeared in color only in a color television set.

 

Each primetime program on the two ABS-CBN television channels was introduced by a female talent, who interspersed her announcement with promotional spiels about a sponsor’s product, usually a bath soap, a detergent, or cleansing cream. The segment took two to three minutes. Programs outside of prime time were introduced by a title card and the disembodied voice of Evangelista. For the station identification segments of ABS-CBN Channel 3, Evangelista’s voice heralded, “You’re on Channel 3, the extra member of your family” simultaneously with a visual featuring the station identification card. This explains why ABS-CBN has been referring to itself as the Kapamilya (member of the family) network in contemporary times. As for ABS-CBN Channel 9, the promotional spiel was delivered by an unidentified female voice saying, “The viewing is fine on Channel 9.” As mentioned above, in 1969, ABS-CBN’s Channel 9 moved to Channel 4 while Channel 3 moved to Channel 2 when KBS acquired a franchise to operate Channel 9.

 

On ABC Channel 5, each program, whether on prime time or otherwise, was introduced by the disembodied voice of a female announcer. Other spiels, including those promoting other programs, were voiced by a male announcer. Only a title card with a simple illustration provided the visual component of these promotional segments.

 

In 1970, RBS Channel 7 embraced color television technology. Like he did on radio, Stewart personally promoted many products live on his television channel along with the station identification aired between programs. He appeared on a bare set, sitting on a bar stool with a product in hand. Through medium shots, close-ups, and extreme close-ups, Stewart enticed the viewer to consider, for instance, buying food products like Glendale Butter or toys from Panacraft and Toylandia, which were well-known toy stores of that time, as well as purchasing a new electronic product called the video tape recorder. Channel 7 had its fair share of loyal sponsors that placed 30-second and one-minute prerecorded advertisements within its regular programs. They included Air Manila (a competitor of Philippine Air Lines), Ultrabrite Toothpaste, Stork Margarine, Seven-Up soft drink, L&M cigarettes, Frigid-Aire refrigerators, and Suntory Whiskey.

 

Toward the end of 1971, KBS Channel 9 promoted its programs by putting a spin on the name of the month. Thus, the station came out with labels like “A September to Remember,” “Solid Gold October,” and “Sweet November.” From the start, KBS’s Channel 9 broadcasts were in color. The management used the moniker “Accucolor 9” for its station—accu from accurate. All programs on KBS-TV, whether local or canned, were introduced by a male disembodied voice saying, “the following program is brought to you in Accucolor.” Only a visual card told the audience the title of the program. Channel 9 distinguished itself from the other television stations by framing a digital clock at the lower left-hand corner of its screen. The clock had four digits to indicate the hour and the minutes. In early 1972, the station used the clock with the promotional campaign called Playtime with Television 9. At randomly selected segments, once every hour for five hours in the evening, from five to ten o’clock, Mondays to Fridays, a voice announced that “It’s playtime on Television 9!” Right after this announcement was made, an arrow pointed to the digital clock. Then the voice recited the simple instructions of the game. The viewer is urged to jot down the time displayed on the digital clock at the exact moment the arrow appeared. If the viewer was able to get all five correct time indications, he was told to write them down on a piece of paper together with his/her name, address, and signature, and to place it in a sealed envelope and either mail it to the KBS headquarters in Pasay City, or drop in any Playtime on Television 9 drop box found at designated supermarkets within the Greater Manila Area (at present the area referred to as Metro Manila). At the end of the promotion period, viewers who sent correct information participated in a raffle which entitled them to as many chances as they had correct entries. Dozens of Sony Trinitron color television sets, which were the most sought-after appliances during that time, awaited the winners. Playtime on Television 9 provided the KBS-TV management valuable demographic data for media research purposes. It also enhanced consumer desire to acquire a color television set.

 

Since KBS owner Roberto Benedicto built his business empire on sugar, a brief musical-type documentary on the importance of the sugar industry to the Philippines featuring Filipino singers Sonny Cortez and Millie Mercado was broadcast at regular intervals on KBS-TV. Cortez and Mercado sang and danced to “The Sugar Song,” a medley of songs about sugar and sweetness such as “Sugartime,” “A Spoonful of Sugar,” and “Roses Are Red, My Love.” “The Sugar Song” was produced by Vicor Records in 1971. The main sponsors of KBS-TV during the pre-martial law era were Silver Bell Ice Cream, Swedish Steak and Chicken House, Trusteeship Memorial Plans, and the Visayan Packing Corporation, which manufactured Vispac Pork and Beans. Film and television personalities Prospero Luna and Nanding Flores were the principal promoters of the Vispac brand.

 

RMN-IBC Channel 13 aired a musical spiel about what day of the week it was. The spiels went like this, “Today is Monday and Monday is unique …” At exactly 6:00 pm of every broadcast day, the station ran a segment on The Angelus, an evening prayer Roman Catholics are expected to recite on a daily basis.

 

Television Advertisements. Advertisements on television were and continue to be called commercials. During the pre-martial law period, commercials were classified as imported and local commercials, commercials in English and in Tagalog, and one-minute and 30-second commercials. Imported products relied on foreign-produced commercials, although a number of imported products were promoted using both foreign-produced and locally produced commercials. Local products relied on commercials in either English or in Tagalog and the other major languages of the Philippines depending on the target audience. Filipino film and television industry actors were often employed to endorse local products. Major advertisers had both one-minute and 30-second versions of their commercials. The advertising industry called these commercials by the technical term “spots.”

 

Politicians of the period hardly used television for their campaign propaganda. In 1967, the opposing parties placed group advertisements of their senatorial candidates on prime time. These group advertisements featured very brief footage of each of the eight candidates of the political party in a span of 30 seconds. In 1969, Pres Marcos simply exploited his continuing exposure in the television news for his television campaign. The opposition candidate for president, Sen Sergio Osmeña Jr, placed numerous campaign advertisements mostly on television channels not identified with either Marcos or Lopez. Only reelectionist senator Gil J. Puyat campaigned extensively on television. In 1971, only senatorial candidates Juan Ponce Enrile and Blas Ople campaigned using television. Their rivals from the Liberal Party did not bother to advertise on television; they simply exploited public sympathy following their having been injured when grenades exploded during their party proclamation rally at Plaza Miranda on 21 Aug 1971, and went around town in braces, plaster casts, and wheelchairs, followed by news teams from print and broadcast.

 

News and Commentary As mentioned above, news and news commentary increased in significance in the postwar years not only as a reaction to the scarcity of credible news during the Japanese occupation but also because the experience of war heightened the audience’s sense of vigilance and interest in local as well as global politics and economics. Stations allocated airtime to news and news commentary, which increased as political rivalry during the Third Republic intensified and as the nation approached another perilous period, which began with the events leading up to the declaration of martial law. These, the media, including radio and television, chronicled, analyzed, and critiqued. While accusations that there were news persons whose pen could be bought may have been warranted, many played their role as the so-called watchdogs of those who run the government and others in power. The news media was so strident in its reporting and criticism and perceived as so influential in shaping public consciousness that when Marcos signed the proclamation placing the country under martial rule, the media was among the first to be silenced—literally, in the case of radio and television.

 

Until the simultaneous declaration of Philippine Independence from the United States and the inauguration of Pres Manuel Roxas in 1946, radio coverage of political events focused only on similar ceremonial political occasions and on war reporting in connection with World War II. In 1953, the use of broadcasting for partisan politics began when radio as well as the newly inaugurated DZAQ Channel 3 was mobilized for the election campaign for the presidency. This set a pattern for subsequent political contests. Cinema was likewise mobilized for political campaigns. In the 1965 presidential elections, Ferdinand Marcos anchored his campaign on the nationwide publicity generated by Iginuhit ng Tadhana (Destined by Fate), a motion picture about his life which was a success in box offices throughout the country. In the meantime, his vice presidential running mate Fernando Lopez enjoyed free publicity from the family-owned ABS-CBN broadcast network and their newspaper, the Manila Chronicle. While political campaigns often took the form of political ads, news programs and news commentaries were significant venues for airing political issues. All radio stations allocated time for news, although music stations tended to limit such airtime to short newsbreaks. The leading stations had 15-minute newscasts that aired daily, often twice a day, in the morning and at night. Commentary programs aired daily in the MBC and ABS-CBN radio stations.

 

Perhaps the most well-remembered commentator was Rafael Yabut, who started working with MBC as an electrician in its radio station DZRH. The management saw his ambition and potential and gave him a radio program called Tayo’y Mag-aliw (Let’s Have Fun). His other programs were Ruleta Musikal (Musical Roulette), Tatlo Lamang (Only Three), and Gumising sa Pagsikat ng Araw (Wake Up at Sunrise). It was in the early morning program Gumising sa Pagsikat ng Araw where Yabut reinvented himself into a hard-hitting radio commentator by criticizing government officials. His listeners loved his tirades and he developed a loyal following and the ire of those in the receiving end of his diatribes. In 1968, he survived a gunshot wound in what appeared to be an assassination attempt, then returned to his programs until the declaration of martial law in 1972. Another outspoken radio commentator was Damian Sotto, who dished out his attacks in DZAQ radio in the program Mangatuwiran Ka (Bring to Reason). Sotto was a staunch, opinionated critic of organized religion and corrupt government officials. Other announcers and commentators who joined DZAQ during that period include Joe Taruc and Rey Langit.

 

ABS-CBN’s DZAQ Radyo Patrol (Patrol Radio), which began in 1968 after DZAQ exchanged its old 620 kHz frequency assignment for DZXL’s 960 kHz, was proof of the increasing importance of news and public affairs programs in the late 1960s. It was an expensive proposition as the station invested not only in broadcast-equipped mobile patrols roaming the city; it required the hiring of news reporters that transmitted news stories to the stations throughout the day. Radyo Patrol, the brainchild of then ABS-CBN program director for radio and television Ben Aniceto, treated its listeners to a more or less sensational reportage of the day’s news, especially fires, accidents, strikes, hostage situations, and robberies. In 1970, Radyo Patrol reported from all over what was then called Greater Manila Area and nearby provinces when Typhoon Yoling devastated Luzon. The transistor radio audience was tuned in, especially in the absence of television due to the power outages, making Radyo Patrol the model for news reporting on radio since the period. Among its first reporters were Orly Mercado, Barr Samson, Rey Langit, Emmy Arcilla, Mario Garcia, Vic Jose, Rey Pascua, Mario Crisostomo, Ysmael Reyes, Naldie Castro, Cris Daluz, Butch Gamboa, and Franklin Leocadio. They were later joined by Joe Taruc, Bobby Guanzon, Ely Aligora, Perry Alcudia, Joey Collantes, Bert Mercado, and Chat Guillermo. The studio anchors include Johnny Midnight, Eddie Ilarde, and Bessie Ocampo. The Radyo Patrol format of news reporting was actually preceded by Sound of the City on RMN’s DZHP in the early 1960s, but it was Radyo Patrol that is still remembered today.

 

Stewart had three television programs on RBS-TV. The first was The News with Uncle Bob, where he delivered the late evening news, which he often editorialized. It was the television news program of the station, which first went on the air on 30 Oct 1961, a day after RBS-TV began its television broadcast.

 

Newscasts and commentaries were also on television. MBC Channel 11 aired the first television news programs in Tagalog, Ano ang Balita (What’s News), which ran from 1962 to 1972, and Balitang Barbero (Barber’s News), which first aired in 1965. These newscasts were broadcast late at night, outside of prime time. In 1962, ABC Channel 5 produced the The Big News, which became the leading television news program of its time. The original newscasters of The Big News were Duds Rivera and Bong Lapira. Jose Ma. Velez joined the program in 1968 after Lapira moved to ABS-CBN. Rivera and Velez remained with ABC-RTV until the station was closed on the eve of the martial law era. In 1966, ABS-CBN’s Channel 9 began airing The World Tonight, an evening news program anchored by Hal Bowie, Eric Eloriaga, and Henry Halasan at 8:30. The newscasters read the news from loose sheets of bond paper. Visuals consisted of still photographs inset on the screen. The photographs were mostly of top politicians, the facades of government buildings, and famous landmarks and logos. The following year, in 1967, The World Tonight moved from Channel 9 to Channel 3 and aired at a later time, at ten o’clock. Its vacated slot in Channel 9 was filled by Newsbreak, anchored by Bong Lapira, who was pirated in 1968 from The Big News, the rival evening news program on ABC-TV Channel 5. In 1970, KBS-TV launched Newswatch, aired nightly at ten o’clock, with Harry Gasser as main anchor. Gasser used to be a newscaster of IBC Channel 13 before he joined KBS. The other newscasters in KBS-TV during this period were Babes Romualdez (now known as Babe Romualdez) and Frankie Abao. Meanwhile, on IBC Channel 13, the nightly news program was titled Vigilantes.

 

Radio Mindanao Network–Inter-island Broadcasting Company–TV Channel 13 aired mostly canned programs because its studio was so small it could accommodate only a news program production. This program was given many titles, the last and most memorable of which was Vigilantes, which aired nightly from 1970 to 1972. Its opening billboard music was lifted from the theme of the 1969 James Bond motion picture On Her Majesty’s Secret Service. Vigilantes began on RMN’s DZHP radio, which continued alongside the television counterpart until 1972.

On Sunday mornings, several newspaper columnists led by Leon O. Ty went live on Channel 7 to express their opinions on the latest events of national significance. MBC-TV was also known for the television talk show Straight from the Shoulder hosted by Luis “Louie” Beltran, a news reporter of the now-defunct The Evening News. It ran from 1970 to 1972. On ABS-CBN Channel 2, Impact was a popular talk show hosted by veteran journalist Maximo Soliven. Even the irrepressible Rafael Yabut had a brief television program on Channel 7 called The Rafael Yabut Show. As expected of him, Yabut lambasted government officials, while almost all of the other commentators were critical of the government.

 

On 14 Nov 1967, ABS-CBN Channel 3 produced Halalan ’67 (Election ’67), a 36-hour live television coverage of the results of the congressional elections nationwide. It was the first of its kind in television history, and from then on, almost all radio and television stations imitated its format of covering elections.

 

Elections for the presidency, the vice presidency, and eight seats in the Senate were held in Nov 1969. Pres Marcos and Vice Pres Lopez were running for reelection under the Nacionalista Party against Sen Sergio Osmeña Jr, and Sen Genaro Magsaysay, respectively, under the opposition Liberal Party. Being the incumbent, Pres Marcos took advantage of his regular exposure in the broadcast news, instead of placing campaign advertisements on radio and television. Pinagbuklod ng Langit (Joined by Heaven), a sequel to his earlier biographical film Iginuhit ng Tadhana (Destined by Fate), gave him nationwide publicity anew, and was even proclaimed Best Motion Picture of 1969 by the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS). Pinagbuklod ng Langit starred Luis Gonzales and Gloria Romero. As in the other election campaigns, radio campaign jingles of Lopez regularly aired on ABS-CBN radio stations all over the country. For the 1969 campaign, his radio jingle opened with the phrase, “Si Fernando Lopez, walang kapares!” (Fernando Lopez has no match) and was followed by a series of rhyming lines highlighting his achievements starting with “Binigyan niya ng lunas ang ani ng bigas” (He found a solution to the problem of the rice harvest).

 

Television was Osmeña’s choice for the bulk of his political campaign, which consisted of numerous afternoon and primetime advertisements mainly in stations that were not identified with either Marcos or Lopez. Osmeña’s propaganda focused on the shortcomings of the Marcos administration. Senator Gil J. Puyat was the only senatorial candidate in the 1969 elections who campaigned extensively on television. Puyat’s television advertisements spelled out his surname and identified him as a man of integrity. He won reelection to the Senate under the NP.

 

Marcos and Lopez were reelected that year. Their second inauguration at the Luneta was covered extensively on radio and television. Marcos also got positive reviews from KBS, which highlighted the achievements of his administration in most of its broadcast news. As mentioned above, KBS operator Roberto Benedicto was a close Marcos supporter, whose franchise to run broadcast stations gave Marcos a dependable ally in the broadcast media.

 

By 1971, popular sentiment had turned against the Marcos administration due to the public perception that despite the constitutional prohibition against a third consecutive term as president, Marcos was manipulating the 1971 Constitutional Convention to allow him to remain in office beyond 1973. Many broadcast journalists and radio commentators shared the sentiment. Moreover, student activism in the national capital and in adjoining areas was at its heyday, and military operatives from the now-defunct Philippine Constabulary often ended up in violent confrontations with student activists demonstrating near Malacañan Palace and the legislative building. These violent clashes made many broadcast journalists and radio announcers, particularly those from ABS-CBN and ABC, livid at the administration. The largely experimental DZUP radio of the University of the Philippines did not speak well of the Marcos administration either, and its broadcasts were widely noticed in spite of the limited reach of its signal.

 

In the meantime, the close political ties between Pres Marcos and Vice Pres Lopez had begun to deteriorate as a result of numerous disagreements in years past between government regulators and the Lopez-owned Manila Electric Company (Meralco) over hikes in electricity rates. Friction between Marcos and Lopez actually began during their first term. Political analysts noticed that each time government regulators refused a petition by Meralco for an increase in the electricity rates to be imposed on consumers, the Lopez-owned newspaper Manila Chronicle and some ABS-CBN radio and television programs hit the government. Readers of the newspaper began to notice that its editorial cartoons regularly put Marcos in a bad light. Its editorial section repeatedly used one and the same cartoon—an elderly male public school teacher asking his pupils a question and with all the pupils raising their hands, with the caption changing every time the cartoon is used. The caption bears the question asked by the teacher, always referring to a perceived anomaly committed by Marcos. The conflict between Marcos and Lopez became obvious when Lopez left his cabinet post as agriculture secretary in the same year, but retained his post as vice president.

 

Coincidentally, a national midterm election was set for Nov 1971, with candidates from the pro-administration NP and the opposition LP contesting eight Senate seats, and all congressional and local government positions. In the evening of 21 Aug 1971, two grenades exploded at the LP proclamation rally held at Plaza Miranda in Quiapo, Manila, causing death and injury to many, including several LP senatorial candidates. The event created huge political capital against the NP, and the film clip taken of the bombing was the best political propaganda for the LP. ABS-CBN announced that it was going to broadcast the footage. Senator Jose Roy of the NP tried to legally stop the broadcast but failed. The footage went on the air on ABS-CBN-TV Channel 3, further alienating Pres Marcos from Vice Pres Lopez and his brother Eugenio Sr. To cover the results of the 1971 election, the ABS-CBN television stations came out with Bilang ng Bayan (Nation’s Count). An instrumental rendition of “Pilipinas Kong Mahal” (My Beloved Philippines) was repeatedly played in the background in the ending segment of the live coverage. Six LP candidates and two NP candidates won in the senatorial race. Radio and television personality Eddie Ilarde won his seat in the Senate under the LP.

 

The bombing of the opposition Liberal Party proclamation rally at Plaza Miranda increased the anti-Marcos sentiment of the people and media persons, including broadcasters. Toward the end of 1971, the political allies of Pres Marcos were branded by the media, radio especially, as “mga tuta ni Marcos”—lapdogs of the president. News commentators on television were likewise critical of the administration, including Beltran on Channel 11 and Velez on Channel 5. By the middle of 1972, ABC owner Joaquin Roces was openly identified with political forces opposed to the Marcos administration. Roces was particularly close to Sen Benigno “Ninoy” Aquino Jr of the LP, the most outspoken critic and political nemesis of Pres Marcos. Before Aquino entered politics, he had started as a reporter of the Roces newspaper Manila Times, the same newspaper that continuously lambasted the Marcos administration in the years prior to the proclamation of martial law. Roces was also close to Maximo Soliven, who persistently criticized Marcos in his column in the Manila Times. Roces also openly supported his newscaster Jose Ma. Velez when the latter ran for a delegate’s seat in the 1971 Constitutional Convention. Velez was elected to represent the first district of Rizal Province. He was one of several convention delegates openly against allowing Pres Marcos to perpetuate himself in power under a new constitution (Roces 1983; Velez 1986).

 

By 1972, Soliven’s Impact had become a popular talk show on ABS-CBN-TV Channel 2 for its intense fiscalizing of the Marcos administration. Soliven, a known supporter of the political opposition, had Senator Aquino on Impact on 13 Sep 1972. Aquino had just delivered a privilege speech at the Senate where he exposed “Operation Sagittarius,” the plan of Marcos to place Metro Manila and outlying areas under the control of the Philippine Constabulary, and subsequently place the entire country under martial law. Marcos was going to use the recent bombings in the Greater Manila Area, including the one at Plaza Miranda, as a justification for his takeover and subsequent authoritarian rule. Aquino repeated his words to Soliven at his program and to a shocked audience. It seemed that, indeed, only an extraordinary measure like resorting to martial law could turn the tide in favor of the administration—and that is precisely what happened in Sep 1972.

 

It has been widely assumed that Marcos declared martial law on 21 Sep 1972. However, radio, television, and newspaper operations appeared normal until 22 Sep 1972. That evening, the convoy of defense secretary Juan Ponce Enrile was ambushed in Wack-Wack as he was going home to Dasmariñas Village in Makati before 9:00 pm. Enrile revealed in 1986 that the ambush had been staged by Marcos to justify martial law, although he subsequently retracted his statement. In the morning of 23 Sep 1972, a stunned nation woke up to a silent radio and blank TV screen. The newspapers were nowhere to be seen either. People would later find out that all television and radio stations as well as newspaper operations had been padlocked by the Constabulary, except Benedicto’s KBS Channel 9 and sister radio stations, through which Marcos announced the declaration of martial law at 7:15 in the evening of 23 Sep 1972. The following morning, the Sunday edition of Benedicto’s newspaper Philippines Daily Express bannered the headline in all capital letters, “FM DECLARES MARTIAL LAW.”

 

Marcos had Aquino and several opposition leaders jailed, as well as a number of media persons including Roces, Soliven, Velez, and Beltran. Eugenio Lopez Sr was in the United States at the time, so he escaped arrest, but his son Eugenio Jr was incarcerated. The media operations that were slowly coming back toward the end of 1972 became tame, cowed by the conditions of the authoritarian rule of Marcos and his military arm, or had changed hands, most of them to Marcos cronies. It was another dark era in the history of the Philippines. The broadcast industry, as well as the rest of the media, for the most part lost its vibrancy.Written by Victor C. Avecilla and Elizabeth L. Enriquez

article.value: Sections

Broadcasting in the Philippines in the years following World War II bore a strong imprint of American colonial broadcasting in spite of and possibly in reaction to the Japanese imposition of its culture and anti-American propaganda via radio. American music and talk as well as the new format of soap opera, fueled by advertising, filled the air. News and news commentary increased in significance as Filipinos continued to hunger for credible news that was in short supply during the war. However, the impact of the Japanese cultural policy left traces, which were evident on many cultural fronts, including radio. With both Nihongo and Tagalog proclaimed as official languages of the country, Tagalog surpassed English as the language of broadcasting during the war, even as daily on-air lessons on Nihongo were intended to supplant English. While English returned as the dominant language of broadcasting after World War II, Tagalog maintained a clear and growing presence. Other Filipino languages also flourished on the air as new radio stations began to operate outside Manila, mindful of the audience expecting broadcasters to speak their tongue. This trend extended to music played on radio and later on television as the Philippine recording industry was born and began to press records of local talent singing traditional Filipino songs and more recent local compositions as well as covers of foreign songs.

Television was born just eight years into the new Republic, in 1953. It was the second to air in Asia, only eight months behind the first, the NHK in Japan. As it was before the war, Americans as well as Filipinos invested in the rising broadcast industry, until the 1973 constitution restricted ownership of all media businesses to Filipinos. But there was a noticeable increase in the number of Filipinos staking their claim on the operation of radio and television. Not only was it profitable in the case of commercial stations; it was believed powerful not only in selling products but also in shaping tastes, captivating audiences, and molding consciousness that won elections and consolidated political power. In the postwar years, politics and economics became even more intensely intertwined with broadcasting as it became not only a profitable investment but also an arena of political power matches.
