article.value: Other shifts unfolded after the war. The call letters of broadcast stations changed soon after the inauguration of the Third Philippine Republic in 1946, which followed the end of World War II in 1945. Audiences multiplied as the number of radio stations grew phenomenally, including noncommercial stations operated by government and religious organizations. By the 1950s, the era called “golden years of radio” was underway, which lasted until the unspeakable era of martial law began in 1972.
Early Postwar Radio Broadcasts

As expected, the American military forces under Gen Douglas MacArthur were the first to operate several radio facilities in the Philippines toward the end of World War II following the silence of the Japanese-controlled PIAM at the close of 1944. MacArthur sent several of the transmitters to Japan in early 1945 with the US military takeover forces and integrated the remaining few into one station in Manila with the call letters KZFM. It was first managed by the US Department of National Defense Office of War Information, then turned over to the newly organized United States Information Service (USIS) under the US State Department. To encourage the revival of commercial broadcasting, the US Congress passed a law empowering Sergio Osmeña, who became Philippine Commonwealth president upon the death of Manuel Quezon in the United States while awaiting the end of World War II, to grant temporary radio operating permits to private citizens and groups.

article.value: Businessmen brothers Joaquin Miguel Elizalde and Manuel Elizalde were the first to take the incentive in early 1946. They purchased Samuel Gaches’s H. E. Heacock Co, which owned the KZRH of the American period, and called their new enterprise the Manila Broadcasting Company (MBC). With the help of prewar KZRH station manager Bertrand Silen, the Elizaldes imported broadcast equipment from the United States and set up its studios at the old Insular Life Building along Plaza Cervantes in Binondo, a few meters from the west end of Escolta, where KZRH used to be. Meanwhile, another station, KZPI (PI for Philippine Islands), also acquired a permit to go on test broadcast in early 1946. It was operated by the Philippine Broadcasting Corporation (PBC), the new name of the prewar Far East Broadcasting Corporation (FEBC), which used to run KZRM and KZRF. J. Amado Araneta, who owned FEBC before the war, took on new partners—Leo Prieto, Jose Avelino, Jack Preysler, and Andres Soriano—and formed PBC.

On 4 Jul 1946, the three stations, KZFM, KZRH, and KZPI, covered live the declaration of Philippine Independence and the investiture of Manuel Roxas as the first president of the Third Republic of the Philippines and his vice president, Elpidio Quirino. It also marked the end of the Commonwealth government. Three and a half months later, on 20 Oct 1946, the second anniversary of MacArthur’s landing on Leyte, the USIS turned over KZFM to the new Philippine government’s Department of Foreign Affairs, the secretary of which was Quirino. In August of the following year, Roxas moved the station to the Philippine Broadcasting Service (PBS), which he created as a unit under the Office of the President. PBS then grew into a nationwide network of government broadcast stations.

article.value: Cebu was again the site of the first radio stations outside Manila. On 21 Sep 1947, KZRC, operated by MBC affiliate Cebu Broadcasting Company (CBC), went on the air. CBC bought the station from Harry Fenton, who took over the station from the H. E. Heacock Co after the war. It is not clear, however, how the takeover took place. The following year, 1948, PBC inaugurated KZBU.

Soon after putting KZRH on the air, MBC acquired a franchise for another station, KZMB. PBC, on the other hand, put up KZOK in addition to KZPI. Not long after the inaugural broadcast of KZOK, the Elizaldes acquired PBC, which had KZPI and KZOK in Manila, and KZBU in Cebu. Araneta bowed out of broadcasting while the Elizaldes quickly became the most powerful broadcast operators from the late 1940s until television came in 1953. Notably, there was no law that regulated and limited the number of broadcast stations that any one individual, family, or company could own, and this is true until today.
In the meantime, Isaac Beck revived KZIB but it folded up after just a few months. Thus, the ownership of radio broadcasting had totally shifted before the decade of the 1940s was over.

New Call Letters. A change in call letters took effect on 1 Jan 1949 following a conference of the International Telecommunications Union (ITU) in Atlantic City in New Jersey, USA in 1947, where the fledgling Republic applied for a new set of call letters for its radio stations—PI for Philippine Islands in lieu of the American KZ. Citing bureaucratic problems, the ITU denied the request and gave the Philippines the letter series from DUA to DZZ. The entire D series was originally held by Germany (for Deutschland, which is German for Germany), but the ITU took a restrictive stance against it for Nazi Germany’s misuse of radio during the war. Thus, KZFM became DZFM, KZRH became DZRH, and so on. Later the Philippine government assigned secondary letters based on location—DZ for stations based in Luzon, DY in the Visayas, and DX in Mindanao. DW was later given to FM stations in Luzon.

With the new Republic came the restoration of many prewar laws, including Act 3846, or the Radio Control Act of 1931, which regulated radio stations and radio communications in the Philippines. Since television involves radio, this law also applied to television stations. Moreover, the law required radio stations to obtain a legislative franchise as a prerequisite to operation, thus effectively shifting the power to grant broadcast franchises from the Office of the President back to the legislature. It should be noted that the law permitted ownership of media businesses not only by Filipinos but also Americans.
The Growth of the Broadcast Industry

Wealthy families other than the Elizaldes, like the Lopezes, the Roceses, and the Sorianos, also saw a future in broadcasting after the war and eventually followed suit. However, the motive for profit was often coupled with the imperative to acquire or maintain political power through the media, which in turn protected the business interests of those who invested in media. This symbiosis led to a trend that became more transparent with the entry of television in the early 1950s. As the number of radio stations multiplied and audience numbers rose, the idea of television appeared more promising, which led to several radio stations expanding into radio-television networks. Furthermore, broadcast operations were often integrated with newspaper publishing, so newspapers and broadcasting mutually promoted and strengthened each other as well as other investments of their owners.

The early postwar stations, like KZRH and KZPI, were mostly commercial stations. Among the first of these was DXCC in Cagayan de Oro City in Mindanao. In 1948, the brothers Henry and Reuben Canoy conducted test broadcasts, which provided the blueprint of the future Radio Mindanao Network that later grew into a nationwide network that at one time involved television. Station DXCC, however, did not receive a franchise from Congress until 1952. Meanwhile, in 1949, the University of Mindanao Broadcasting Network put up radio station DXMV in Cotabato City, making it the first radio station with an orientation toward audiences living in Muslim-dominated areas in Mindanao to officially go on the air. In 1963, Ramon Jacinto, a young music enthusiast, put up radio station DZRJ under the family-owned Rajah Broadcasting Network (RBN). This AM-band station specialized in rock and roll music. RBN still operates in the country today with the controlling interest held by Ramon Jacinto Holdings Inc. It was also in 1963 when Abelardo Yabut Sr, a businessman from Mindanao, founded the Nation Broadcasting Corporation (NBC). The enterprise initially consisted of radio station DXYZ in Zamboanga City and radio station DZAM in Manila, which then grew into a nationwide network of radio stations. In the same year, the Mareco Broadcasting Network owned by the Manila Record Company began its operations. Local music found a home in this station. In 1968, the Eagle Broadcasting Corporation (EBC) began its broadcasts on DZEC. Members of the Iglesia ni Cristo religious group comprised the stockholders of EBC, which operated DZEC as a commercial station.

A number of noncommercial operations, like KZFM, went into broadcasting for reasons other than profit. In 1948, a group of Protestant evangelists established radio station KZAS, later DZAS, under the Far Eastern Broadcasting Company (FEBC), the first radio station in the country with a religious type of programming. The station was renamed DZFE, which later became an FM station, allowing FEBC to apply for a new franchise for DZAS on AM. The evangelists behind FEBC, not to be confused with the prewar Far East Broadcasting Corporation, broadcast in China beginning in 1945, but the civil war between nationalist and communist forces forced it to move its operations elsewhere. The Roman Catholic Church in the Philippines did not follow suit in using radio for evangelization until 1969 when it began operations of DWRV Radio Veritas, which had the strongest radio transmitter in Southeast Asia prior to the imposition of martial law in the Philippines in Sep 1972. While some universities operated commercial radio, the University of the Philippines (UP) in Diliman, Quezon City, started noncommercial shortwave radio experiments from its College of Engineering building under the call letters DZUP in 1958. When the station ran out of funds the following year, the UP Alumni Association raised funds to help keep the radio station operating. Later the University moved its studio to the College of Arts and Sciences and began broadcasting on the AM band. In 1964, the University of the Philippines in Los Baños, Laguna, established DZLB to provide educational programs to the rural communities surrounding the campus. In 1965, notwithstanding DZFM and the growing network of PBS stations around the country, the government’s National Media Production Center (NMPC) under the Office of the President began operating DZRP, the Voice of the Philippines (VOP), on both the AM and shortwave bands. It was the local counterpart of the Voice of America. NMPC’s head office was located along Santa Potenciana St in Intramuros, Manila.

By 1968, local and foreign manufacturers of phonographs were promoting the stereo—a large electronic appliance that had a phonograph, a radio component designed to receive both AM and FM radio transmissions, and two separate speakers, which made stereophonic listening possible. It allowed the listener to adjust bass and treble through the twist of a knob. The stereo also doubled as a piece of decorative furniture because of its polished wooden exterior. Mass production of various models made the stereo affordable. National and Radiowealth were the leading stereo brands at that time. The popularity of the stereo inevitably created an audience for FM radio transmissions, which was tried in the 1950s but did not succeed due to the absence of FM-capable radio sets. This time, broadcast companies saw an opportunity and made plans for going on the air via the FM band. The first to do so was DZFX of the Makati Broadcasting Network, which went on the air in 1968. The first successful commercial FM station in the country broadcast mood music, film soundtracks, and period pieces with high-fidelity stereophonic sound. Its studio and transmitter were located at the top of the new Insular Life Building along Ayala Ave in Makati, which was then a municipality of Rizal Province.

From five radio stations before World War II, the number grew to 33, 10 years after the end of the war. By 1968, sources put the number at more than 200, and 280 just before martial law was declared in 1972. It was an indication of the burgeoning audience, driven partly by the availability of a new radio technology—the transistor—beginning around the end of the 1950s. The new radio sets were portable and could be operated on small batteries, a stark contrast to the older radio appliance that was heavy and bulky and that required connection to an electrical outlet. Moreover, the sets, imported from the United States and Japan, were designed to receive FM transmissions. When the local manufacture of portable transistor radio receiver sets and radio-phonographs, such as those made by Avegon, brought the price of the sets down, the audience size grew exponentially. However, while radio remained the most popular mass medium of the time, television began to captivate audiences before the decade of the 1950s was over. The story of its growth cannot be divorced from the political motivations of its pioneers in the Philippines.

BEC and ABS. On 13 Jun 1946, James Lindenberg, an American entrepreneur who operated in Manila, established the Bolinao Electronics Corporation, a company that manufactured radio transmitters and similar electronic devices. The enterprise was named after Bolinao, a municipality in Pangasinan and the native town of Lindenberg’s Filipino wife. Four years later, on 14 Jun 1950, Congress granted Lindenberg a franchise to operate a radio and a television station. Supplies were difficult to acquire, however, due to strict import controls in force at the time, making it difficult for Lindenberg to operate a television facility immediately. He thus decided to focus on the radio business in the meantime.

Meanwhile, a motivation other than entrepreneurship was driving the birth of television in the country. By the middle of 1952, Pres Elpidio Quirino was eyeing reelection in the Nov 1953 polls. His administration was perceived as corrupt by many, especially the youth. Antonio Quirino, a former trial court judge and the younger brother of President Quirino, saw radio and television as means to counter public opinion and improve the chances of the reelection of the president. He had a problem to overcome though—Congress was not willing to grant him a legislative franchise. Antonio Quirino found a solution through Lindenberg. Before 1952 was over, Antonio Quirino bought 70 percent of BEC from Lindenberg, became a partner of the American businessman, and renamed the venture the Alto Broadcasting System (ABS), with DZAQ as its call letters. Alto is a combination of AL, the first two letters of the nickname of Qurino’s wife, Aleli Guzman-Quirino, and TO, the first two letters of Tony, his nickname. The letters A and Q in DZAQ are the initials of Antonio Quirino. With BEC’s television franchise, ABS obtained permission to transmit television signals on Channel 3. The original ABS radio studio was located along Florentino Torres St in the Santa Cruz district of Manila, where the newsrooms of the leading newspapers of the period were situated. Its transmitter was located at a corner lot along P. Guevarra St, right across Sitio Alto, a large estate in the district of Little Baguio in San Juan, which was then a municipality of Rizal province. Sitio Alto was where Antonio Quirino and his family resided.

To promote DZAQ-TV Channel 3, Quirino needed to import television sets into the Philippines. He obtained a loan of 60,000 pesos from Joe’s Radio and Electrical Supply, a leading electronic equipment store along Raon St in the Quiapo district of Manila, which in turn became the first to sell television sets in the country. In 1953, that amount was enough to acquire 120 bulky RCA Victor television sets manufactured by the Radio Corporation of America, then the leading brand in the United States known for its high fidelity or capability of faithfully reproducing sound. By the middle of 1953, Quirino had convinced rich families in Manila and the suburbs to buy RCA Victor television sets, with each one costing at least 1,200 pesos—the equivalent of several months of an average salary in Manila, with the minimum daily wage then set at four pesos. It was considered a status symbol to own a television set, so wealthy and prominent families bought them. Quirino invested the profit he realized from the sales of the TV sets in the business. To generate a bigger audience, Quirino published and distributed announcements inviting the general public to see the new medium at strategic areas in the commercial districts of Manila in early Oct 1953. From six to ten o’clock every evening, selected establishments located at the Quiapo, Santa Cruz, and Binondo districts of Manila opened RCA Victor television sets at their respective display areas for everyone to watch what Quirino called “the pre-inaugural telecasts of DZAQ-TV Channel 3.” The television sets were located at Poulex Department Store and Kairuz Department Store along the Escolta; Sub Bros and Francis Department Store along Dasmariñas St; 15¢ and Up Department Store and Automatic Electrical Appliances store along Rizal Ave; Joe’s Radio and Electrical Supply along Raon St (now Gonzalo Puyat St); and the Saulog Transportation ticket office along Florentino Torres St.

In Oct 1953, DZAQ began its radio and television broadcasts. While DZAQ Radio followed the typical program format of other radio stations, it was partial to news that put the administration of President Quirino in a favorable light. Meanwhile, the premiere telecast of DZAQ-TV Channel 3 finally took place on 23 Oct 1953, which showcased a garden party at Sitio Alto. Although color television technology was already available in the United States, the DZAQ telecast was in black and white. Fifty-two sponsors of this telecast actually paid for the birth of Philippine television. The event made Antonio Quirino, and not James Lindenberg or Eugenio Lopez Sr as others claim, arguably the father of the Philippine television industry.

Buoyed by the success of its premiere telecast, ABS continued its broadcasts for four hours, from six to ten o’clock every evening. Its programs consisted of feature films borrowed from foreign embassies, and religious and cultural plays organized and directed by James Reuter, the well-known Jesuit priest who began using broadcasting for evangelization in the late 1930s. His best-remembered television production was a 1953 adaptation of the classic piece Cyrano de Bergerac. From 1953 to 1956, ABS had a monopoly over the Philippine television industry. In the meantime, Filipino industrialist and civic leader Domingo M. Guevara saw a large business potential in the television industry, so in 1955, his Radiowealth company began manufacturing and selling local black-and-white television sets bearing the brand Radiowealth-Motorola. Until then, American brands like RCA Victor, Motorola, Zenith, and Admiral dominated the local market.

Although Antonio Quirino succeeded in establishing the first television station in the Philippines, he failed to get his brother reelected to the presidency in the Nov 1953 national elections. Despite this setback, Quirino went on with his radio and television enterprise. In 1956, he launched DZYL-FM, the first radio station to broadcast via frequency modulation (FM). However, it did not do well as FM was yet unheard of, with most radio receivers at the time having no provision for the reception of FM transmissions. With competition looming in the horizon in 1955, and with the death of former president Elpidio Quirino in 1956, Antonio Quirino considered retiring from the broadcast industry.

ABS-CBN. In 1955, the prominent Lopez family of Iloilo headed by Eugenio Lopez Sr obtained a legislative franchise to operate a radio and a television station under the Chronicle Broadcasting Network (CBN). The family had been in the sugar industry since the 1800s and by this time was already invested in other businesses, including the daily newspaper Manila Chronicle, the second most widely circulated newspaper in the country at the time. On 24 Sep 1956, CBN began its radio broadcasts on CBN-DZXL Radio. Its studio and transmitter were located at the CBN Building along Aduana St in Intramuros, Manila. In the weeks that followed, Eugenio Lopez Sr sent overtures to Antonio Quirino about the possible sale of ABS to the Lopez family. Antonio Quirino was open to the idea because the brother of Eugenio Lopez Sr, Fernando Lopez, was the vice president of Pres Elpidio Quirino from 1949 to 1953, even as the Quirino and Lopez families parted ways in 1953 when Fernando Lopez, instead of running for reelection as vice president under the Liberal Party with Pres Elpidio Quirino, ran for the Senate and won under a secondary opposition party. Lindenberg was also open to the idea of selling his share of the business.

On 24 Feb 1957, Eugenio Lopez Sr bought ABS from Quirino and Lindenberg. This purchase made Lopez the biggest investor in the broadcast industry of the Philippines. With his brother in the Senate, he also had very powerful political connections. By 1962, the Lopez business empire included majority ownership of the Manila Electric Company. The strong political clout of the Lopez family grew even stronger in Nov 1965 after Senators Ferdinand Marcos and Fernando Lopez were elected president and vice president of the Philippines, respectively, under the banner of the Nacionalista Party (NP). Marcos anchored his campaign on the nationwide publicity generated by Iginuhit ng Tadhana (Destined by Fate), a motion picture about his life, which was a box-office success throughout the country. Lopez, on the other hand, enjoyed the free publicity he got from the family-owned ABS-CBN broadcast network and their newspaper, the Manila Chronicle. It was the second time Fernando Lopez was elected vice president. He was also the secretary of agriculture and natural resources in the Marcos cabinet, a post he held from 1965 to 1971.

For four years, ABS radio and television stations were operated separately from CBN stations, their common ownership notwithstanding. In 1958, ABS transferred its facilities from Santa Cruz in Manila and San Juan, Rizal, to its new studio and transmitter site on Roxas Blvd in Pasay City. In the same year, on 19 Apr, CBN began its television broadcasts on CBN-DZXL-TV Channel 9 using its facilities in Intramuros. In 1961, ABS and CBN stations began using the name ABS-CBN. At the same time, on 14 Jun 1961, ABS-CBN opened its television station in Cebu City. In 1963, ABS-CBN tested the first color television transmission in the Philippines using technology imported from the United States. It was the beginning of color television broadcasting in the Philippines, and by 1966, television programs in color reached the homes of affluent Filipinos. In 1968, the Sony Trinitron color television set made its world debut, making it the leader in television technology until well into the 21st century. In the meantime, before the end of 1967, the Radiowealth Company was manufacturing and selling locally made color television sets for 2,500 pesos each, a pioneering effort that made the Philippines the third country in the world to manufacture color television sets, next to the United States and Japan. Japanese brands like National and Sony alsot made it to the Philippine market when the Precision Electronics Corporation assembled National audio and video products in Oct 1967, and when Solid Industries Inc began distributing Sony radio and television appliances in the country in 1971.

By the start of 1967, with the opening of more stations throughout the country, ABS-CBN was the Philippines’ largest network, and its stations’ identification segments proudly proclaimed its status. On 12 Feb 1967, ABS-CBN launched its iconic logo, which features an aerial transmitter and three concentric rings symbolizing broadcast waves, in the primary colors of red, green, and blue, and the letters ABS on top of the graphic and the letters CBN below it.

On 18 Dec 1968, ABS-CBN moved its radio and studio facilities to its new headquarters called Broadcast Plaza, located along Bohol Ave (now Sergeant Esguerra Ave) in Diliman, Quezon City. The following year, the old ABS studio along Roxas Blvd in Pasay City was sold to the Kanlaon Broadcasting System (KBS) owned by Roberto S. Benedicto. KBS acquired a legislative franchise in 1969 to operate a television station, which necessitated a reallocation of the VHF and UHF channel frequencies. Eventually, the government assigned Channels 2 and 4 to ABS-CBN and reassigned Channel 9 to KBS.

With the broadcast technology then still in analog format, the broadcast transmission made by one channel, which was too proximate to the transmission made by another channel, affected both transmissions as they interfered with each other. This was why, prior to the entry of KBS in the Philippine television landscape, television channel assignments were in odd numbers: 3, 5, 7, 9, 11, and 13. Although Eugenio Lopez Sr did not find the transfer to Channel 2 objectionable, he was upset about the transfer to Channel 4, which caused technical problems to both ABS-CBN-TV Channel 4 and another station, ABC-RTV Channel 5. Joaquin “Chino” Roces, the owner of the latter, shared the sentiments of Lopez.

By this time, Lopez Sr was a very powerful oligarch; Roces was a prominent critic of the Marcos administration; and Benedicto, who operated a daily newspaper and a commercial bank, was a very close friend of Pres Marcos. Political observers saw the reallocation of channels in 1969 as a strategy on the part of Pres Marcos to reduce the political power and industrial might of Lopez, to dilute the influence of Roces in the arena of public opinion, and to pave the way for Benedicto to become his powerful ally in a largely anti-Marcos media industry. Lopez Sr’s resentment in this regard was the first of many reasons that ultimately led to the deterioration of relations between him and his brother Fernando, on the one hand, and Pres Marcos on the other. When Marcos declared martial law in 1972, ABS-CBN was taken over by government and Benedicto. In 1986, after Marcos’s ouster, the Lopezes recovered one television station and a number of radio stations.

ABC Channel 5. On 19 Jun 1960, the Associated Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) began its television operations using the call letters DZMT and the Channel 5 slot. This enterprise was owned and operated by another prominent Filipino family—the Roces family—which published the Manila Times, the leading newspaper of the country in the two decades prior to the martial law period. The letters MT in DZMT stood for Manila Times. Joaquin “Chino” Roces, the helmsman of the daily, was also the top man in DZMT. ABC used to operate from its studio along Roxas Blvd in Pasay City until it moved to a new facility along Pasong Tamo Road in Makati, near Epifanio de los Santos Ave. Its transmitter tower was located at Antipolo in Rizal Province. To avoid being mistaken for the American Broadcasting Company in the United States, the ABC management identified itself first as ABC-RTV-DZMT and eventually simply as ABC-RTV. The operations of both ABC and the Manila Times ground to a halt upon the declaration of martial law in 1972, and never resumed under the Roces family even after the ouster of Marcos in 1986.

RBS Channel 7. The Republic Broadcasting System (RBS), present-day GMA 7, traces its roots to Robert “Bob” Stewart, an American war correspondent of the Mutual Broadcasting Company who arrived in the Philippines with the liberation forces of Gen MacArthur in 1944. When the war ended, Stewart remained in the country and went into the radio and television industry in the Philippines. Stewart married a Filipina, Loreto Feliciano, with whom he put up the corporation Loreto F. de Hemedes Inc on 1 Mar 1950. On 14 Jun 1950, the corporation established DZBB Radio, operating from the fourth floor of the Calvo Building on the Escolta. Stewart played an active role in the radio station, doing most of the promotional announcements himself. In 1955, the couple expanded their operation to include DZXX, an AM-band station with a music format. It was the first popular music radio station in the country. In 1957, DZBB and DZXX moved their operations from the Escolta to a new site near Kamuning in Diliman, Quezon City. On 29 Oct 1961, Stewart became part of the television landscape through DZBB-TV Channel 7. His radio and television business was now located at a building of its own along EDSA in Diliman, Quezon City, with its transmitter tower right beside the building. The tower had a triangular base, and near the top, each side bore the number 7 illuminated in green neon light. The lighted signs were like celestial lanterns dotting the evening skies, until Typhoon Yoling destroyed them in 1970.

Stewart was seen as a supporter of reelectionist president Carlos P. Garcia of the NP in the Nov 1961 elections. It may be noted that DZBB-TV obtained its franchise under the Garcia administration. When Diosdado Macapagal of the Liberal Party (LP) defeated Garcia in the 1961 presidential elections, Malacañan took steps to have Stewart deported from the country. In the meantime, Stewart’s Uncle Bob’s Lucky 7 Club, a children’s program, developed an extensive following. Stewart avoided deportation because thousands of children who regularly watched his show asked their parents to protest to President Macapagal, thus forcing the president to call off the deportation proceedings. Since then, Stewart refrained from getting personally involved in Philippine politics.

Unlike the other radio and television station operators, Stewart did not publish a newspaper, but he enjoyed substantial investments from the American Broadcasting Company of the United States. In 1963, Loreto F. de Hemedes Inc changed its name to Republic Broadcasting System (RBS). It is believed that RBS stood for Robert “Bob” Stewart. Subsequently, during the martial law period, a sale will cause another name change, this time to GMA 7.

KBS Channel 9. Roberto S. Benedicto, a lawyer and former corporate officer in the Lopez companies, invested in the radio business in 1960. On 29 Jun, he put station DZKB on the air under the Kanlaon Broadcasting System. Observers say that the letters KB in DZKB refer to the initials of his daughter, Kitchie Benedicto. By then, his commercial interests included substantial investments in the sugar industry in Negros Occidental and investments in the Traders Commercial Bank, which was later renamed Traders Royal Bank. He also owned a daily newspaper, the Philippines Daily Express. Benedicto also enjoyed the full trust and confidence of Ferdinand Marcos, a close friend in law school and college fraternity brother in the University of the Philippines, who in 1965 was elected president of the Philippines.

In 1969, Congress granted KBS a franchise to operate a television station, KBS-TV Channel 9. As previously mentioned, KBS purchased the old ABS television studio along Roxas Blvd in Pasay City for its television broadcasts following ABS-CBN’s move from its old studio to its new headquarters in Quezon City. With KBS now a part of the television industry, government regulators reallocated the frequency assignments of ABS-CBN to accommodate the newcomer. ABS-CBN’s Channel 3 and Channel 9 were replaced with Channel 2 and Channel 4, respectively. Channel 9 was assigned to KBS. Like other broadcasting companies in the country, KBS was a stock corporation. In 1970, Benedicto decided to raise investments from the public sector by listing KBS in the stock exchange. This meant that shares of stock of KBS could be purchased by the public. It subsequently changed its name to Radio Philippines Network (RPN) during the martial law period, but kept the name Kanlaon Broadcasting System in its official corporate records.

MBC Channel 11. The Manila Broadcasting Company of the brothers Federico, Joaquin Miguel (“JM”), and Manuel Elizalde, which put up KZRH, later DZRH, the first commercial station at war’s end, expanded its operations to include DZRH-TV after it was granted the corresponding franchise by Congress in 1960. Joaquin Miguel Elizalde had political connections. He served the government as foreign affairs secretary under Pres Elpidio Quirino from 1948 to 1950 and from 1952 to 1953. On 11 Apr 1962, MBC-TV Channel 11 began broadcasting. Its television studio was also located alongside its radio facilities at the old Insular Life Building at Plaza Cervantes in Binondo, Manila. Unlike the other television stations, MBC-TV did not broadcast imported programs, except for a few films to fill the airtime.

The station suffered from broadcast stoppages due to chronic problems with its transmitter. To address the problem, MBC transferred its television studio to a new location along J. P. Rizal St in the Project 4 district of Quezon City, behind the Quirino Memorial Hospital, known at that time as the Labor Hospital, in the early months of 1972. Its broadcast operations at its new location, however, were short-lived due to the proclamation of martial law in Sep 1972, which led to the closure of the television operations of all stations except KBS. Although MBC was allowed to continue its operations several weeks before the end of 1972, the management decided to abandon its television business and to focus instead on their radio broadcasts.

RMN-IBC-TV Channel 13. In 1960, the Inter-Island Broadcasting Corporation (IBC) owned by American businessman Dick Baldwin obtained from Congress a franchise to operate a television station. His station, called DZTV, was assigned television Channel 13. On 1 Mar 1960, IBC-TV 13 made its premiere telecast. In 1962, Andres Soriano Sr, a businessman with huge investments in both the A. Soriano Corporation (also known as Anscor) and the San Miguel Corporation (SMC, a giant food and manufacturing conglomerate and the Philippine franchise holder of Coca-Cola back then) bought both IBC-TV 13 from Baldwin as well as the controlling interest in Radio Mindanao Network (RMN) from the Canoy brothers, who founded the network in Cagayan de Oro City in 1952. Later that year, Soriano established DZHP Radio in Manila under the RMN banner, extending RMN’s reach to Manila, and merged his radio and television acquisitions into one entity—RMN-IBC. Soriano housed his radio and television enterprise at the old ABS transmitter site in Little Baguio, San Juan, which he renovated and improved after acquiring it from ABS-CBN. At that time, Soriano owned a daily newspaper, the Philippines Herald.

When Soriano passed away in 1964, his son Andres Soriano Jr took over the family businesses, including the media enterprises. The proclamation of martial law in Sep 1972 led to the temporary closure of the radio and television operations of RMN-IBC and to a stoppage in the publication of the Philippines Herald. Before the end of 1972, however, the radio and television facilities of RMN-IBC were operational once more since the martial law administration did not consider Soriano a threat to national security. The Philippines Herald, however, never resumed publication, even after the end of the Marcos administration.

The Canoy brothers subsequently bought back RMN during the martial law period while Soriano sold IBC to Roberto Benedicto, who was by then operating two television stations: Banahaw Broadcasting System (BBC) Channel 2 and RPN Channel 9. Benedicto renamed his newest broadcast station the Intercontinental Broadcasting Corporation, keeping the initials IBC.
The Golden Age of Philippine Radio

Veteran radio personalities and executives locate the so-called golden age of Philippine radio (also called golden years of Philippine radio) in the decades after the war, with some claiming it started as early as the late 1940s and ended with the declaration of martial law in 1972. What defined the era was the flourishing of a radio style that began to acquire what was perceived as Filipino, even if strong American influences remained. American voices stayed on but began to be edged out by Filipinos. English persisted as the gold standard of radio announcing, but Tagalog and other languages in the regions slowly but surely took over the air lanes. Western popular music endured but the development of the local recording industry introduced many songbirds whose fame on radio rivaled those of American and English music icons. The new art of the soap opera, the bodabil-inspired variety shows that included comedy skits and quizzes, and amateur singing contests hooked legions of listeners of all ages to the radio set. Advertising nourished the medium and its popularity was fanned by the new technology of the portable, battery-operated, and relatively inexpensive transistor radio. Radio was a national pastime, with more listeners than newspaper and magazine readers, even with the introduction of television in the 1950s, which took a few decades to surpass radio in audience subscription.

Music Programs and the Local Recording Industry. When the American troops returned at the end of 1944, the broadcasters among them flooded the air with American popular music, which Filipinos sorely missed as the Japanese banned them during the occupation. This had been the regular music fare on radio until a few years after the war when import restrictions limited the entry of foreign music records. The dearth encouraged the birth of the local recording industry, which pressed covers of American popular hits by Filipino singers, but also waxed contemporary local compositions as well as Filipino traditional and folk music such as the kundiman (love song) and harana (serenade). Among the first recording companies were Bataan Recording, Royal, Riego, Mater, Molave, Excelsior, and Villar Recording Company. Others were Union, Mico, Alpha, Super, Scoop, Fama, LVM, Badjao, Jessica, Imperial, Vicor, Blackgold, and Octo-Arts, few of which survived more than a few years. Acclaimed Hari ng Kundiman (King of Kundiman) Ruben Tagalog was among the first to be recorded by Riego and Mabuhay Records. Another successful singer was American-Filipino Cecil Lloyd, called The Mystery Singer, who put up his own recording studio, the Philippine Recording System (PRS) in 1948, and counted besides himself Sylvia La Torre, Pancho Magalona, and Leopoldo Silos as his first artists.

The establishment of Villar Recording Company in the Philippines in 1950 made recordings of Philippine songs and music readily available to radio stations and, more importantly, affordable to many Filipinos. Villar labels included Mareco (Manila Record Company) and Mabuhay. The company radio jingle went like this: “Remember your friends abroad, remember your friends abroad, send them lasting gifts of Philippine music on Villar records.” However, most of the radio stations were reluctant to play local music at first, mainly because of the perception that audiences preferred Western popular music and the fact that there were more American selections than there were local ones. It took some time before a few radio stations in the country picked up the trend and began including Philippine music in their regular programming, making stars out of Filipino singers, including Bimbo Danao, Phil Delfino, Belle Gonzales, and Don David in the 1950s; Pilita Corrales, Sylvia La Torre, RJ Jacinto, and teenage bands in the 1960s; and in the 1970s, Nora Aunor, Basil Valdez, Sharon Cuneta, Hajji Alejandro, Celeste Legaspi, Jose Mari Chan, Ryan Cayabyab, and the artists of the so-called Pinoy Rock and Manila Sound, the precursor of what is often called original Pilipino music (OPM).

Music records were successfully used for some political campaigns, the most memorable of which was Mambo Magsaysay. Elpidio Quirino’s opponent from the opposition Nacionalista Party when he ran for reelection in 1953 was Ramon Magsaysay, who was Quirino’s secretary of national defense. The mambo was the dance craze of the period, and so Magsaysay’s strategists came out with a likeable, danceable song they called “Mambo Magsaysay,” composed by his aide Raul Manglapus, who later became a senator, and recorded by Rosita de la Vega-Da Roza. Recordings of the song were distributed free to the different radio stations in the country and to NP provincial leaders for distribution to cities, towns, and barrios. As a result, the recording was played on the air almost everywhere in the country while people in town fiestas and similar public gatherings danced to the tune. “Mambo Magsaysay” virtually did the campaigning for Magsaysay, who won the election.

The 1960s saw Pilita Corrales, then nicknamed Asia’s Queen of Song, serenading radio audiences with her renditions of timeless local pieces, particularly Visayan songs. Helen Gamboa was also a regular singing voice on radio back then. Later in the decade and well into the early 1970s, songbird Nora Aunor, who won the Tawag ng Tanghalan (Call of the Stage) television competition in 1967 with her rendition of “Moonlight Becomes You,” and jukebox king Eddie Peregrina, who was known for “What Am I Living For” and “Together Again” were heard frequently on the AM band. Humorous ballads like “Naku Inday Bakit Mo Binigay” (Oh Inday Why Did You Give It) sung by the yodeling Fred Panopio, and Yoyoy Villame’s now famous “Magellan” were also well received by local radio audiences. Some stations allowed naughty Tagalog translations of certain songs such as the 1964 piece “A Hard Day’s Night” and “Candida,” which came out in 1970.

The 1960s was also a memorable decade for Philippine radio, which played foreign musical greats like the Beatles, the Monkees, Tom Jones, Engelbert Humperdinck, and Simon and Garfunkel. After the Beatles performed at the Rizal Memorial Stadium in Manila on 4 Jul 1966, the younger generation of Filipinos turned to the radio to listen to their singing idols, which was more practical than a vinyl record because radio programs were for free while records were not. Moreover, an unlimited access to songs was available to radio listeners while those who used phonographs could listen only to whatever vinyl records they had.

The attractiveness of musical programs to Filipino audiences bred the format amateur singing contest. Among the most popular of these was the program variously called Purico Troubadours, Purico Show, and Purico Amateur Hour. Purico is the brand of a cooking lard manufactured by the Philippine Manufacturing Company (PMC), the local licensee of Procter & Gamble. The show had its origins in prewar radio and was revived after the war. The game shows Purico Jamboree and Timpalak ng Purico (Purico Contest) on postwar KZRH were also sponsored by the brand and attained much popularity, but not as much as the amateur singing contest. It ended though when Purico in 1956 began sponsoring Tawag ng Tanghalan on DZBB, which had been on the air since 1950. The program featured aspiring singers who competed with each other in the hope of getting a crack at the professional scene. Winning contestants were allowed to finish their pieces. The losers were interrupted by the sound of a gong or a bell, which meant the contestant was eliminated. Among the contestants who emerged as singing champions and subsequently made a name for themselves were Pepe Pimentel, who later became one of the hosts of the show when it moved to television, Diomedes Maturan, Cenon Lagman, Eva Adona, Ofelia Dayrit, Novo Bono Jr, Ric Manrique Jr, Edgar Mortiz, Jonathan Potenciano, and Nora Aunor. The original hosts of the show were the comedians Rodolfo Quizon, better known as Dolphy, and his sidekick Alfonso Alba, better known as Panchito. When it went on the road, Dolphy left the show due to his movie commitments, so he and Panchito were replaced by another comedy pair, Lopito and Patsy (full name: Pastora Mateo).

Soap Operas. Radio dramas, called soaps or soap operas because the first such productions in the United States were sponsored by soap products with the Colgate-Palmolive brands, came in several formats: the melodrama, the situational comedy or sitcom, the sitcom-cum-satire, horror or fantasy and science fiction narratives, and the occasional detective drama. Ilaw ng Tahanan (Light of the Home), written by Liwayway Arceo, was the first postwar soap. It aired on DZRH in Mar 1949, followed a week later by Gulong ng Palad (Wheel of Fate) by Lina Flor, also on DZRH. Both programs, which aired daily for 15 minutes, were about the highs and lows in the life of ordinary Filipino families and their friends. DZRH enjoyed a virtual monopoly of famous radio dramas in the 1950s, a number of which carried the names of their sponsors. These programs included Gabi ng Shell (Shell’s Evening), sponsored by the Shell petroleum company and which featured the famous Lolita Rodriguez and her partner Eddie Arenas; Tang-Tarang-Tang, a sitcom about a dysfunctional Filipino family and its patriarch; the fantasy adventures Prinsipe Amante (Prince Amante), written by Clodualdo del Mundo, and Kapitan Kidlat (Captain Lightning); the detective serial Johnny Davao; another Lina Flor opus, Ginang Hukom (Madam Judge), a legal drama; Genoveva Edroza-Matute’s Aklat ng Pag-ibig (Book of Love), in which unique stories lasted only months instead of the usual years of a typical melodrama; and Gabi ng Lagim (Night of Terror), a horror drama. In 1953, Fidela Magpayo aka Tiya Dely and Dely Magpayo, who had been on radio since 1938 and, during the Japanese period, joined DZRH. She hosted a new drama format titled Ito ang Inyong Tiya Dely (This Is Your Aunt Dely) and pioneered the counseling type of radio programming, which began with the dramatization of a letter sender’s dilemma in life, followed by advice dished out by Magpayo. Her program quickly gained a huge and loyal following and became the model for counseling-and-drama programs both on radio and television.

Other memorable soaps of the period include DZPI’s child-oriented Mga Kuwento ni Lola Basyang (Stories of Grandma Basyang), based on Severino Reyes’s serial in Liwayway magazine, Clodualdo del Mundo’s Recuerdo (Memento), and the melodrama Mercedes Cruz; DZBB’s Tony Narra, which was the first detective-type of narrative on Philippine radio, Gloria Villaraza-Guzman’s love stories Mga Lihim ng Puso (Secrets of the Heart), and Camay Theater of the Air, a Sunday-night-60-minute reenactment of an upcoming Filipino movie, with the film actors coming to the studio and reenacting the movie dialogue live; and DZBC’s Panata ng Puso (Heart’s Promise) and Digmaan ng Damdamin (Battle of Emotions), both written and directed by Artemio Marquez, and the horror drama Sepulturero sa Lumang Libingan (Gravedigger in the Old Cemetery).

A most unforgettable program that combined satire with comedy-drama was Kuwentong Kutsero (Tall Tales), which first aired in 1938 before the war and went on until the 1960s, interrupted only by the Japanese occupation. It spoofed Filipino manners, politics, customs, and government, with scripts written first by Narciso Pimentel and Jesus Paredes, and later by Epifanio Matute. Conceptualized by Horacio de la Costa and James Reuter, both Jesuit priests, the show’s format was successfully replicated in the provincial stations. Other memorable postwar soaps were Fundador Soriano’s Kahapon Lamang (Just Yesterday) and Flordeluna. The latter first aired in Cebu radio and was later translated to Tagalog and produced for Manila television audiences in the late 1970s, like other popular soaps that were later reproduced on television or made into movies.

The golden years of Philippine radio were marked by the prominence of classical Tagalog—the kind associated with the great poet Balagtas. It was clearly felt in most program genres and in advertisements, but especially in drama. However, dramas in English were on the air until the 1950s, many produced by college dramatic guilds such as Cathedral Players on DZRH, managed by Ateneo de Manila’s James Reuter; Bedan Barristers on DZPI, made up of thespians of San Beda College led by Noe Nebrida; and Republic Players on DZBB, composed of several stage actors, directors, scriptwriters, and producers transitioning to radio, television, and, later, film. To the local broadcast and cinema industries they brought the literary styles and conventions of the Western stage acquired from school-based dramatic clubs.

Variety shows. The variety show, a mélange of musical performances, comic skits, and light banter among hosts and guests, was a popular genre on radio and later on television. A takeoff from the prewar bodabil and the wartime stage show, the variety show later included quizzes, games, and contests. A common feature of variety shows was the live audience in the studio, who participated in the program by joining the contests and providing live laughter and applause.

An example of the variety show that appealed to young adults was on DZXL, which scored a hit in 1958 with its innovative noontime program CBN Canteen, which was aired from the cafeteria of the CBN studio in Intramuros. CBN Canteen was hosted by Eddie Ilarde, Bobby Ledesma, and Leila Benitez. It was so popular with the student population that the CBN management decided to rename the show Student Canteen. The next year, Student Canteen became a noontime television program on DZXL-TV Channel 9. Other popular variety shows were DZXL’s Darigold Jumbo Jamboree, hosted by two of the funniest pairs of comics at the time—Dolphy and Panchito, and Leila Benitez and Eddie Ilarde; the gag-filled The Big Broadcast on DZRH, produced and hosted by Conde Ubaldo and Luz Mat Castro, featuring the brightest stars of the film studio Sampaguita Pictures; DZFM’s Edong Mapangarap (Edong the Dreamer), a string of comic skits; and the memorable Reyna ng Vicks (Queen of Vicks) on DZRH, sponsored by Vicks Vaporub vaporizing ointment, which interviewed on the air five female members of the studio audience. They all spoke about their unique experiences and the one who was applauded the loudest was declared “queen” for a day.

Variety shows that appealed to children enjoyed considerable airtime during the golden years of Philippine radio. Most of these programs consisted of quiz shows and spelling bees. Radio Schoolhouse on DZPI, hosted by Ira Davis, conducted quizzes for grade school kids, while Knowledge Unlimited on DZRH, hosted by Ray Oliver and Louie Garcia, held competitions for high school and college students. Every correctly spelled word was rewarded 50 centavos in Spell to Win, hosted by Norman Reyes and Hal Bowie. Eskuwelahang Munti (Little Schoolhouse) on DZBB, produced and hosted by Tino Lapus, featured aspiring child performers, which launched the careers of then child actors Vilma Santos, Edgar Mortiz, Esperanza Fabon, and Ike Lozada. On DZPI was Campus Capers, made up of comic skits about college life, hosted by Al Spencer with Tita Muñoz, Veronica Palileo, Arling Gonzales, and Al Wayne. Professor Quiz was a game show on DZMB that asked participants general information type of questions. Its main announcers were Hal Bowie and Don Lee while Ray Oliver, Larry Ng, Ric Tierro, Jess Fernandez, Simeon Bonzon, and Rafael Yabut took turns in selecting the contestants.

Sportscasts. The prewar stations regularly covered sporting events, especially baseball, the most popular sport in the United States, and basketball, by annotating the game to a radio audience that imagined the event they did not see. The practice continued after the war until the visual medium of television took over in the late 1950s, but not before radio made stars of sportscasters Willie Hernandez, Jake Romero, and Jack Garcia, who gave listeners play-by-play accounts of boxing, tennis, and basketball matches. The games of the basketball leagues Manila Industrial and Commercial Athletic Association (MICAA) and the National Collegiate Athletic Association or NCAA were especially popular. Ric Tierro covered baseball while Ben Francisco and Ben Hernandez joined the basketball coverage team. Henry Diy covered tennis matches while Taby Tabaniag annotated the boxing program Fistorama before it moved to television.

Old and New Formats. Interrupted by the war, a program that began to go on the air in 1934 returned on DZRH in the 1950s—the Balagtasan, a poetic joust usually about a social issue or a cultural tradition. Hosted by poet Emilio Mar Antonio every Sunday, he engaged a guest makata (poet) in a debate in Tagalog verse, with the debate topic phrased in questions like, “Should divorce be introduced in the Philippines?” or “Should the Philippines be a state of the United States of America?” (Jimenez 1996, 33B; Aniceto 2007, 508).

The absence of American programs during the war created an appetite for radio shows from the United States, which came recorded in 16-inch discs. Many of these were wartime variety productions aimed at the American soldier fighting the war in Europe and in the Pacific, such as The Lucky Strike Show with Bob Hope, The Coca-Cola Show with Giselle MacKenzie, The Perry Como Show with Jo Stafford, The Martin and Lewis Show, and the scary drama thriller Witching Hour.

In the meantime, a new format of the counseling genre, one in English, with no accompanying tearful dramatizations of listeners’ lives, went on the air in 1957. This was Father Bob and His Telephone hosted by Bob Garon, a young Roman Catholic priest. Listeners were encouraged to call up the station and seek help regarding their personal problems, without revealing their real names. The program launched the media career of Father Garon.

The PBS began airing programs that targeted farmers in the 1950s, but it was in the 1960s that the program type gained popularity and became part of regular programming of several AM stations. Usually aired in the early morning at around five o’clock, announcers discussed new ways of increasing agricultural productivity with information coming from the Department of Agriculture, UP Los Baños, the International Rice Research Institute, the Philippine Rural Reconstruction Movement, and the International Institute for Rural Reconstruction.

A program type that emerged after the war was the personality platter show in which an announcer, later called disc jockey or the DJ, played selected music records and engaged the listeners in a light chat. Several of these shows entertained requests by listeners sent by mail, with some DJs indulging their fans by dedicating the music they played to admirers. The shows boosted sales of records, particularly of popular music, while many DJs became household names. Among these programs were Cashmere Bouquet Top Tunes hosted by Larry Ng, Voice of Firestone featuring Broadway melodies and hosted by Ray Oliver, Silahis ng Pag-asa (Ray of Hope), featuring light classics and hosted by Ric Tierro, Latina Americana hosted by Louie Garcia, Roll of Honor hosted by Eddie Mercado, and the so-called request-dedication platter shows such as Request Jamboree hosted by Dick Taylor, Night Owl hosted by Lito Gorospe, All Night Stand hosted by Jo San Diego, Mailbag Jukebox hosted by Angelo and Cherrie Castro, and Platter Bungalow hosted by Bong Lapira.

Radio Advertising. In the decades following the war, almost all of the advertising aired on both radio and television was of the hard-sell type, and mostly done in Tagalog and other major Philippine languages. The products advertised consisted mainly of detergents, beauty soaps, dental creams (toothpaste), pomade, cigarettes, soft drinks, milk, instant coffee, gasoline, over-the-counter medicine, milk, beauty products, cooking oil, soy sauce, and many other consumer products. Many of these consumer products were manufactured by the Philippine Manufacturing Company, the local branch of Procter & Gamble, the biggest advertising spender at the time, which poured 90 percent of its advertising budget into radio, until television began to eat into radio’s share of the advertising pie during the martial law years. PMC’s main competitor was the Philippine Refining Company, the local licensee of Lever Brothers, present-day Unilever. Another corporate competitor of the period was Colgate-Palmolive (Philippines) Inc. The boundary then between broadcast announcers and executives, on the one hand, and advertising men, on the other, was porous. Many crossed over or did both at the same time, producing and hosting programs while writing and voicing ad copy and servicing clients. Some memorable ad lines that were initially produced for radio were later reproduced for television: “Johnson yata ’yan!;” “Say mabuhay with Tanduay;” “Kiko Baterya, Kiko Dinamo;” “I’m walking on clouds in my Camara shoes;” and “National Zippers slide up and down!” (Davis 2007, 223-26).
During election seasons, political adverttising outnumbered commercials for consumer products. Then and now, it was a significant source of income for both radio and television stations.

In the mid-1950s, television was getting increasingly popular in the country, and radio industry leaders saw a need to address a potential problem. Specialized programming was seen as a means of keeping the radio industry alive and competitive. DZXX, which began to specialize in popular music, set the trend in reinventing programming to cater to specific audience groups. Soon, other radio stations reinvented themselves. DZRJ concentrated on popular pieces and dance music, and it became a favorite among teenagers. Office workers, wage earners, and housewives became avid listeners of drama on DZAQ, DZRH, and DZXL. DWOW catered to commuters and focused on local popular music and pieces performed by local singers. Highly politicized listeners could choose from several early-morning commentators of the different AM-band radio stations. Listeners on the FM band who liked old-fashioned music and instrumentals tuned in to DZFX.

Toward the end of the decade, radio survived the competition from television by developing its own loyal following during the early morning and late evening hours. While television competed with radio in the nation’s urban areas, radio dominated the countryside and rural communities, especially those with no access to electricity.
The Age of Television

The cost of a television set was prohibitive when it was first introduced in the 1950s, so it took another decade for urban middle-class families to have it in their homes. However, as in the early years of radio, television owners invested in programming in the belief that television would eventually become a profitable business. In the meantime, programs had to be put on the air. There were two sources: American TV stations that sold canned serials and existing local radio programs transmuted into the visual medium. Buying canned shows from the United States was a practice that prevailed for decades as it was a lot less expensive to buy them than produce original shows. Moreover, it was a guaranteed investment as the Filipino audience was already conditioned to enjoy American programs. But while it was more capital-intensive to produce television programs locally, the formats and popularity of several radio shows suggested that they could be migrated to television successfully in terms of production values and audience reception. Besides, the television owners also owned the counterpart radio stations that produced the thriving programs on radio. That gamble paid off. Thus, early television programs in the country had their origins in radio. Many carried the original radio titles while others used new program titles but with the same formats. From the 1960s up to 1972, television stations in the Philippines broadcast from five o’clock in the morning and ended their broadcast day at midnight, supported and sustained by advertising. It was an indication of a growing and loyal television audience.

Variety Shows. Radio’s variety programs were the first and easiest to be replicated in television. In 1959, the variety program Student Canteen on CBN-DZXL radio became a noontime television program on then CBN-DZXL-TV Channel 9. It retained its hosts Eddie Ilarde, Leila Benitez, Bobby Ledesma, and Pepe Pimentel. It was enormously popular but in 1964, Ilarde, Benitez, and Ledesma left the show following a misunderstanding with the managers of ABS-CBN-TV Channel 9 and moved to another television program, Darigold Jamboree, on Manila Broadcasting Company’s TV Channel 11, which also had its origins as a radio program on DZRH. Pepe Pimentel remained on Student Canteen but he was unable to sustain the popularity of the show, thus leading to its termination in 1965. The management replaced Student Canteen with Stop, Look and Listen hosted by Eddie Mesa. Later, during the martial law years, Student Canteen was revived as a television program on RBS-TV Channel 7, which Ilarde and Ledesma hosted with Helen Vela.

Philippine comedy king Rodolfo V. Quizon, also known as Dolphy, made his television debut in 1964 on the weekly variety show Buhay Artista (Actor’s Life), also on Channel 3. He shared the television limelight with his cinema sidekick Alfonso Alba, also known as Panchito. Among the new television programs that went on the air on ABS-CBN-TV Channel 3 in 1965 was Magandang Tanghali (Good Afternoon), a noontime variety show hosted by Pancho Magalona. In 1967, the evening variety show Oras ng Ligaya (Happy Hour) began airing on Channel 3.

Meanwhile, ABS-CBN-TV Channel 9 is remembered for The Lucky Strike Show, an evening variety program hosted by Nelda Navarro; The Baby O’Brien Show, another variety program hosted by Baby O’Brien, and Da Best Show. All three began airing in the early 1960s. At around the same time, Everyday Holiday, a post-noontime variety program hosted by actor and singer Sylvia La Torre and comedian Doro de los Ojos, went on the air. Its opening song described the show in this manner: “Every day, holiday, oras ng kasiyahan every day!” (Every day, holiday, happy hour every day!) Some of ABS-CBN’s variety programs were hybrids of variety and musical-dance or sitcom, such as The Nida-Nestor Show, a highly popular late-evening program starring Nida Blanca and Nestor de Villa, whose dance routines were legend, and Da Pakulo (The Gimmick).

The Chiquito Show hosted by comedian Chiquito, Augusto Valdez Pangan in real life, aired on ABC-RTV Channel 5. One of the most popular local shows on Channel 5 was Seeing Stars with Joe Quirino, where host Joe Quirino interviewed international celebrities who happened to be in town. Often, Quirino got his guests to sing or perform an act, and gave them their cue with his immortal line, “Take it away,” seasoned with a thick Ilocano accent. Joe Quirino was the Philippine equivalent of America’s celebrated television showman Ed Sullivan.

On RBS TV Channel 7, Robert Stewart hosted The Bob Stewart Show, which featured guests who discussed with him almost anything of interest to television audiences. During the early years of the martial law era, this program became The Maestro and Uncle Bob, and later on, Uncle Bob and Friends. On MBC TV Channel 11, the most well-known program was Darigold Jamboree, a noontime variety show that first aired as Darigold Jumbo Jamboree on DZRH radio, hosted by veteran performers Eddie Ilarde, Bobby Ledesma, Leila Benitez, and Johnny Wilson, and sponsored by Darigold Milk, a leading American franchise brand of the day. As mentioned above, Darigold Jamboree migrated from radio after Ilarde, Ledesma, and Benitez, who were the hosts of Student Canteen on CBN-TV Channel 9, had left Student Canteen after a disagreement with CBN-TV management. Arrangements to have Pepe Pimentel and comedian Bentot (Arturo Vergara Medina in real life) join Darigold Jamboree did not materialize. For a time, Darigold Jamboree faced tough competition from The Big Show, another variety show aired on a rival television channel and sponsored by Liberty Milk, another American franchise brand. Darigold Jamboree aired from 1964 to 1972.

Musicals and Dance Programs. Derivatives of the variety show genre, programs with music and dance were popular. Coinciding with the year 1961 when ABS and CBN stations began using the name ABS-CBN, Channel 3 inaugurated Jam Session, a musical program that specialized in youth-oriented music starring Bobby Ng and a band called the Hi-Jacks. A memorable Channel 3 musical was An Evening with Pilita, hosted by Pilita Corrales, who was then dubbed Asia’s Queen of Song, and aired on prime time from 1965 to 1972. A variant of the musical show was the singing contest, which had enjoyed immense following on radio. Also on Channel 3, the television version of Tawag ng Tanghalan (Call of the Stage), hosted by Pepe Pimentel, aired also in 1965, until 1969. Tawag ng Tanghalan produced a champion in 1967 who became one of the more iconic and respected stars on the Philippine film, television, radio, and the music industries—Nora Aunor. Winning the championship on her second try, Aunor’s victory assured her of roles in other ABS-CBN television programs like the evening variety show Oras ng Ligaya (Happy Hour) on Channel 3. Another popular singing contest was Hamon sa Kampeon (Challenge to the Champion), hosted by Dely Magpayo and Pepe Pimentel. A discotheque program called Nineteeners began airing on ABS-CBN Channel 9 in 1966.

Competing with An Evening with Pilita were the evening musical programs Helen of Song, hosted by Helen Gamboa, and Carmen on Camera, featuring veteran singer Carmen Soriano on ABC RTV Channel 5, in the 1960s. On RBS TV Channel 7, Dancetime with Chito went on the air late at night, hosted by a socialite, Chito Feliciano. The program was one of the few local programs on Channel 7 broadcast live from the studio within a Spartan studio set. It was the first of its kind in the Philippines, becoming a model for subsequent dance programs on television. Feliciano and his guests demonstrated the latest dance steps to the audience. Meanwhile, on MBC TV Channel 11, DJ Dance Time and The Nite Owl Dance Party rivaled RBS TV’s highly popular Dancetime with Chito. In 1970, Channel 11 cashed in on the popularity of filmdom’s teen idol Tirso Cruz III, from the musical Cruz family, with the song-and-dance Catch Up with Tirso.

There were several imported canned musical programs in the 1960s, among them This Is … Tom Jones, which aired on ABS-CBN Channel 3, and The Engelbert Humperdinck Show on KBS TV Channel 9, both starring popular pop singers in England.

Soaps and Other Narratives. Dramatic shows on television may be loosely classified into melodramas, fantasy-horror, action-adventure, and family-oriented dramas. While there were a few daily soaps or the drama serial whose episodes continued the narrative from day to day over a period of years, many were weekly anthologies where a unique story was featured in every series. Among the most remarkable of these drama anthologies was ABC Channel 5’s Balintataw (The Mind’s Eye), which featured productions of the Philippine Educational Theater Association beginning in 1967, with Cecile Guidote, Lupita Concio, Alberto Florentino, and Nick Lizaso as producers. Its directors, who all subsequently launched careers in TV and movie directing, include Lino Brocka, Elwood Perez, and Joey Gosiengfiao. Among its most notable episodes were “Isang Gabi ng Tagsibol” (A Night in Spring), Alberto Florentino’s TV adaptation of Nick Joaquin’s May Day Eve; “Kabalyerong Tanso” (Fake Knight) an adaptation by Elizabeth Acaylar (a pseudonym) of Wilfrido Nolledo’s Rice Wine; “Pag-iisa” (Being Alone), an original teleplay by Florentino; and “Kudyapi” (Two-Stringed Lute), which Brocka adapted from Bienvenido Santos’s The Day the Dancers Came (Video 48 2008).

Salamisim (Reflections) was another of Channel 5’s drama anthologies, hosted by Marlene Dauden, which competed with ABS-CBN’s Panagimpan (Dream). Dauden subsequently also hosted the latter when she left Channel 5. Santa Zita and Mary Rose, a memorable Sunday afternoon Catholic-oriented drama about household helpers, also aired on ABC. Evolving from a radio counseling program, it was hosted by Mary Rose Jacinto and featured stage thespian Zeneida Amador under the direction of James Reuter, sponsored by the Jacinto Steel Company.

Canned dramas from American and English television aired on local TV, such as Marcus Welby, M.D. on ABS-CBN, Peyton Place on RBS Channel 7, the original hospital emergency room drama Ben Casey, and the courtroom dramas Perry Mason and Ironside on RMN-IBC Channel 13.

Locally produced but short-lived horror programs Hiwaga sa Bahay na Bato (Mystery in the House of Stone) and Limbo aired on ABS-CBN in the 1960s. Programs that imitated American and British action shows include Agent 69 and Kwatro Bidas (Four Heroes), a program considered unique because it is a serious drama that featured four known comedians—Doro de los Ojos, Teroy de Guzman, Cachupoy, and Ading Fernando—as special law enforcers who are experts in martial arts. Since it cost less for TV stations to buy canned programs from other countries than produce original shows, several imported dramas, especially the horror-fantasy and action-adventure types, aired on local TV. On ABS-CBN, there were quite a few, such as the serialized Westerns Alias Smith and Jones, Bonanza, Gunsmoke, Lancer, The High Chaparral, Wanted: Dead or Alive, and The Wild, Wild West; the adventure dramas The Rat Patrol, Route 66, Tarzan, and The Twilight Zone; a family-oriented drama, The Doris Day Show; the police and detective shows Cannon, Dan August, Hawaii Five-O, The Mod Squad, Sarge, and The NBC Mystery Movie, which was not a movie but a “wheel show” or “umbrella show” that rotated several programs within the same time period. In this case, the program rotated different detective shows including McCloud, Millan & Wife, Columbo, and Quincy, M.E., each broadcast at intervals of three to five weeks. A British-made television program, The Baron, was also on ABS-CBN.

ABC Channel 5 also aired canned American action-adventure programs, including the detective shows It Takes a Thief, Mannix, The Protectors, and Randall and Hopkirk; and the mystery anthology Alfred Hitchcock Presents. Channel 5 became known for The Samurai, a Japanese television series dubbed in English and shown in mid-morning and early evening time slots. Through his connections in the United States, especially friends from the American Broadcasting Company, Stewart obtained for RBS Channel 7 a substantial volume of the most popular American television programs of the period, dominating the station’s primetime programming up to the early 1970s. They include the war action classic Combat!; the iconic Mission: Impossible and The Fugitive; the camp program Batman; the series on the adventures of a female private investigator titled Honey West; the futuristic adventure program called The Man from U.N.C.L.E. and its spin-off The Girl from U.N.C.L.E.; Westerns such as Bat Masterson, Daniel Boone, The Rifleman, and The Virginian; the detective adventure shows The Green Hornet and The Persuaders!; mystery science fiction adventures Star Trek, Voyage to the Bottom of the Sea, Land of the Giants, The Time Tunnel, and Lost in Space; other family-oriented serials like Gilligan’s Island, Flipper, and The Patty Duke Show; action programs 77 Sunset Strip, The Untouchables, and Hawaiian Eye; and Flash Gordon, a science fiction serial produced by Universal Pictures in 1936.

RMN-IBC Channel 13, on the other hand, aired the police-detective program The FBI, a detective show based on extrasensory perception called The Sixth Sense, and One Step Beyond, a horror-thriller patterned after The Twilight Zone. There were two British productions broadcast also on prime time: The Avengers and The Saint. Both programs were about British agents who fought foreign spies and other enemies of the West.

Sitcoms and Gag Shows. A most memorable program of this genre began airing on radio in 1938, during the American colonial period, the Kuwentong Kutsero (Tall Tales). Interrupted during the Japanese occupation, the show went back on radio after the war and in the 1960s was produced by ABS-CBN Channel 3 as a television sitcom. By the middle of the 1960s, Channel 3 also had Tang-Tarang-Tang, a Saturday evening situation comedy about a dysfunctional family and its naughty patriarch. ABS-CBN produced other situational comedies such as Mrs. Milyonarya (Mrs Millionaire), starring Chichay, and Wanted Boarders, starring Pugo; and the gag show Super Laff-In. ABC RTV Channel 5, on the other hand, produced Gorio and His Jeepney and Tisoy (moniker for someone of mixed race, usually Filipino and Caucasian mix), both of which were adaptations of popular comic strips of the same respective titles in the Manila Times. Chiquito played the character of Gorio while the cast of Tisoy was composed of Jimmy Morato, Pilar Pilapil, Bert Marcelo, and Moody Diaz. In 1967, MBC-TV Channel 11 began the telecast of the sitcom Etcetera, Etcetera.

Imported canned sitcoms were numerous. ABS-CBN had The Flying Nun, Get Smart, Hogan’s Heroes, The Partners, and The Partridge Family while ABC Channel 5 aired the fantasy-comedy program Bewitched. RBS Channel 7 imported the slapstick comedy The Addams Family and the romantic comedy I Dream of Jeannie while KBS Channel 9 aired the sitcoms From a Bird’s Eye View, Hey, Landlord, My Favorite Martian, My Mother the Car, and Temperatures Rising; a slapstick comedy featuring one-liners, Rowan & Martin’s Laugh In; and the drama anthology My World … and Welcome to It. Early morning and mid-afternoon programs on RMN-IBC Channel 13 consisted of episodes of the original slapstick comedy series The Three Stooges.

Game Shows. The visual medium of television offered greater audience involvement than radio in programs that featured contests and games with prizes. Perhaps the most popular of these shows in the 1960s was Kuarta o Kahon (Cash or Box), which debuted on ABS-CBN Channel 3 in 1962, with Pepe Pimentel as host. Contestants were asked to choose between a sum of money and a mystery prize inside a randomly selected box. This show lasted until 1969, but returned to television during the martial law era via Barangay Broadcasting Corporation (later renamed Banahaw Broadcasting Corporation) Channel 2, with Pepe Pimentel as the mainstay host. Other game shows on ABS-CBN were Winner Take All and the American canned show The Game Game. ABC RTV Channel 5 meanwhile aired Kwarta Na! (Money Already!), a game show where everyone seemed to win.

A different type of game was on KBS Channel 9, the Pintakasi, a Sunday afternoon live television coverage of the Philippine betting game called sabong (cockfights) held in selected cockpits in the metropolis. Hosted by Ray Pedroche, Pintakasi afforded fans the convenience of watching a cockfight, called tupada, and the betting, too, without leaving home. Pintakasi left the air in Sep 1972. Another betting game was on Channel 11, the weekend horse races at the San Lazaro and Santa Ana hippodromes. The announcer always began his spiels with the line, “There they go … and they’re running …”

Children’s Programs and Animation. TV stations invested in programs for children more during the postwar years than the subsequent periods of Philippine broadcasting. RBS Channel 7 aired the hour before lunchtime on Sundays the children’s educational and entertainment program Eskuwelahang Munti (Little Schoolhouse). The title was taken from a Tagalog motion picture of the same title starring Luis Gonzales and Gloria Romero. Another program on Channel 7 was the Uncle Bob’s Lucky Seven Club, a weekly late afternoon television program where Bob Stewart interviewed youngsters and gave away prizes. Bespectacled and friendly, Stewart called himself everybody’s “Uncle Bob.” On ABC Channel 5 was a short-lived children’s program featuring Subas Herrero, Mr. Jumbo.

One of the few local programs KBS Channel 9 produced during the period was Clubhouse 9, the most popular local program on the station prior to the martial law period, which made its television debut in 1970. It was a late afternoon children’s live television program hosted by veteran showman Pepe Pimentel inside the KBS studio filled with children accompanied by their parents or guardians. It went on the air Mondays to Saturdays, 5:30-7:00 pm. The show opened with a young boy or girl, a bulilit announcer, introducing both the program and the host. The term “bulilit” is a Tagalog idiomatic expression which means “diminutive or extremely small.” Pauline Bonnevie, the sister of local film actress Dina Bonnevie, was one of the most famous bulilit announcers of Clubhouse 9. Following in the style of veteran television broadcaster Robert “Uncle Bob” Stewart on Channel 7, Pimentel had himself called “Tito Pepe” (Uncle Pepe), a name that endeared him to both the studio audience and those watching on television. This moniker managed to stick to Pimentel even as he hosted other shows in future years including Kuarta o Kahon and Family Kuarta o Kahon. Toward the last quarter of 1971, Clubhouse 9 acquired a right to broadcast the 1961 Japanese animated film Alakazam the Great, a 1960 Japanese musical animated film dubbed in English and narrated by American actor Sterling Holloway.

Most of the imported canned programs for children were animations, such as those that aired on ABS-CBN, including Atom Ant, Birdman and the Galaxy Trio, Frankenstein Jr. and the Impossibles, The Hillbilly Bears, The Pebbles and Bam-Bam Show, Space Ghost, and Squidly Diddly, all from Hanna-Barbera Productions; and Super Six from DePatie-Freleng Productions. The other American animated programs on the ABS-CBN channels were Batfink, The Famous Adventures of Mr. Magoo, Farmer Al Falfa and His Terrytoon Pals, The Woody Woodpecker Show, and Walt Disney’s Wonderful World of Color. Walt Disney’s Wonderful World of Color was not fully animated; it had live action segments featuring Disney himself. A favorite among the youngsters was the Marvel Super Heroes series featuring characters like Captain America, The Sub-Mariner, The Mighty Thor, The Incredible Hulk, and The Invincible Ironman.

ABC Channel 5 also imported animated programs such as The Adventures of Johnny Quest, The Flintstones, Huckleberry Hound, Peter Potamus, and Ricochet Rabbit, all from Hanna-Barbera Productions; and Mighty Mouse and Heckle and Jeckle of the Terrytoons line. The Banana Splits Adventure Show, a children’s variety and musical program combining live action sequences and animated segments, likewise from Hanna-Barbera, also aired on Channel 5. Gigantor, a black-and-white animated program, made its Philippine debut on the same station. It is the first Japanese animated robot program aired on Philippine television, beating Voltes V by 10 years. Restored episodes of Gigantor have been colorized.

The other stations also imported animated programs aimed at children. On RBS Channel 7 were American animated shows like Popeye (both prewar and postwar productions), Beany and Cecil the Seasick Sea Serpent, Gumby, Harveytoons, The New Three Stooges, Tales of the Genie, Sinbad the Sailor, The Dick Tracy Show, and Roger Ramjet. The animated program lineup of Channel 7 likewise included The Funny Company, a part-animated, part-live action documentary show also produced in the United States, and episodes of a dialogue-free children’s show about a nameless, costumed man with magical powers produced by Trans Tel Zeit of what was then known as West Germany. Weekday afternoons, Saturday mornings and afternoons, and a couple of hours on Sunday mornings were reserved for animated programs.
