KBS Channel 9 had a limited number of programs in its animation chest: The Amazing Spider-Man, Archie’s TV Funnies, Porky Pig, and Rocket Robin Hood. These shows went on the air during the late afternoons. On RMN-IBC Channel 13 were the animated programs Wally Gator and Magilla Gorilla from Hanna-Barbera Productions, and The Alvin Show.

In 1969, ABC Channel 5 hosted the Philippine premiere of the now classic American educational program Sesame Street. Filipinos were pleasantly surprised that the one-hour show had no commercial interruptions.

Movies on TV. Television during the period became an outlet for old movies that would otherwise not enjoy exposure beyond their cinema runs. On the other hand, the films helped provide TV the material to fill its airtime. ABS-CBN Channel 3 aired several local films under the labels Puting Tabing (Silver Screen) in the morning and Mga Aninong Gumagalaw (Moving Shadows) in the afternoon. On ABC Channel 5, Tagalog motion pictures aired on prime time under the banners Sinagtala (Star Beam) and Bahaghari (Rainbow). Those aired in the afternoons were under the label Aliw ng Tahanan (Joy of the Home).

As with the other program genres, foreign films were also on the air. ABS-CBN aired Hollywood films under the label Color Movie Greats for color films exhibited at night, Movie Greats for black-and-white films aired at night, Command Performance for afternoon films, and Repeat Performance for movie replays. During the summer months, the mid-afternoon slot was reserved for Republic Serials, which consisted of prewar and wartime black-and-white movies in serial form including Batman. On ABC Channel 5, Hollywood films were also aired under the label Million Dollar Movies, sponsored by the General Textile Company; Philippine Blooming Mills Inc, a steel manufacturing enterprise; Marvel, a detergent powder; Mikado, a Japanese brand of pomade; and Kaminomoto Oban, a Japanese brand of therapeutic plaster. Some non-American movies were also aired under this label. RBS Channel 7 aired American as well as Chinese movies, often with English subtitles, broadcast during Sunday afternoons.

During the early years of KBS Channel 9, almost all of its programs were canned American shows, with RBS Channel 7 as the only one that had more canned programs. Channel 9 aired numerous motion pictures, many of them horror or science fiction films and light dramas produced by American International Pictures, including House of Usher, The Pit and the Pendulum, The Raven, Tales of Terror, and Pajama Party. Hollywood films dominated Monday and Thursday evenings on KBS-TV. The movie date on Mondays was called The KBS Spectacular of the Week while the one on Thursdays was called Thursday Night at the Movies. When KBS started using the name Radio Philippines Network in 1974, The KBS Spectacular of the Week was renamed The RPN Spectacular of the Week. Night owls on Sunday evenings were treated to American horror movies under the label Sunday Suspense Theatre (SST). The first film it featured was Daughter of the Mind starring Ray Milland. After KBS ran out of American horror films for SST, the management resorted to syndicated British horror-mysteries.

There were also Hollywood films on RMN IBC Channel 13, shown late at night under the labels Armchair Theatre and Curtain Call. Movies about war were featured under the title War Classics. Because of the acute lack of program materials on the station, War Classics was shown twice on the night it was scheduled for broadcasting. For the same reason, the station often broadcast filler films during the afternoons.

Sports. The medium of television lent itself well to the spectacle of sports. Sports programs coincided with the seasonal staging of athletic events and the occasional international special sporting match. Among the memorable specials was the fight that made a boxing icon out of Gabriel “Flash” Elorde aired on ABS-CBN Channel 3. On 16 Mar 1960, the world junior lightweight boxing championship match between Elorde of the Philippines and Harold Gomes of the United States was held at the newly opened Araneta Coliseum in Cubao, Quezon City, with 36,000 spectators filling the arena. Channel 3 brought the fight to households that had television sets. The television event was the first of its kind in the Philippines. Elorde won that fight, while ABS made history. In 1972, days before Marcos put the Philippines under martial law, KBS Channel 9 provided Philippine viewers with a live coverage of the 1972 Olympic Games held in Munich, West Germany.

Long before the Philippine Basketball Association became famous, basketball enthusiasts in the country were loyal viewers of the games organized by the MICAA and broadcast on MBC’s radio and television stations in the early part of the 1960s. Companies that fielded teams in the MICAA basketball games include the Manila Electric Company, Crispa-Floro, San Miguel Corporation, Yutivo Motors, and E. R. Squibb Pharmaceuticals. Problems regarding the television transmitter of MBC eventually forced the transfer of the radio and television coverage of the MICAA games to other broadcasting companies toward the later part of the 1960s. In the meantime, there was also an audience among the basketball-crazy Filipinos for the prerecorded games of the National Basketball Association in the United States, which went on the air through ABS-CBN. The Boston Celtics was the dominant team back then.

RMN-IBC Channel 13 aired mostly canned programs because its studio was so small that it could accommodate only a news program production, but it managed to air Fistorama, because the coverage of the sporting events was done by remote broadcast rather than in a studio. Fistorama was a local primetime program featuring boxing matches between promising but unknown pugs looking for an opportunity to go big time. First aired on DZRH radio, it was annotated for Channel 13 by Joe Cantada.

Specials and Documentaries. By the late 1960s, local television had acquired the technological capacity to cover extraordinary events live, such as the Apollo 11 spaceship launch and its subsequent landing on the moon. On 16 Jul 1969, Channel 7, as the carrying station, broadcast the launch live via satellite simultaneously on all Philippine television channels. Stewart was chosen as the anchor of the Philippine segment annotating the long countdown to the actual space launch. The day was declared a national holiday in the Philippines to allow everybody to watch the historic space launch. A digital clock indicating the number of minutes left to actual lift-off was on the television screen. While on the air, Stewart interviewed Pres Ferdinand Marcos on the telephone a half hour prior to lift-off. During the actual conversation, Stewart was seen talking on the telephone with a photograph of Marcos inset in the corner of the screen. The Apollo 11 lunar landing on 20 Jul 1969 was also broadcast live via satellite simultaneously on all local television channels, again with Stewart as the anchor of the Philippine segment. Innumerable Filipinos watched both the space launch and the lunar landing, but the subsequent return flight of the Apollo 11 space capsule did not have the same enthusiastic viewership.

Prior to the Apollo 11 coverage, in 1968 ABS-CBN brought to Filipino audiences the first satellite transmission in the country—the aftermath of the assassination of Sen Robert Kennedy, a popular American political figure and younger brother of the late president John F. Kennedy, in Los Angeles, California. ABS-CBN also aired documentaries from the United States, among them the documentary anthology Appointment with Destiny. On Channel 7, an American program for dog owners, Training You to Train Your Dog, went on the air on late Saturday afternoons right before prime time.

Station IDs and Promos. Television stations promoted themselves by adopting logos and symbols, by having talking heads address the audience, and by producing vignettes that mixed pictures and sound and other special effects to create their respective distinctive brands. In 1963, when ABS-CBN tested the first color television transmission in the Philippines using technology imported from the United States, it also adopted a new logo—a square containing a symbolic transmitter antenna with radio waves. Three years later, in Jun 1966, the network began the commercial launch of its color television broadcasts using the same technology used by the Radio Corporation of America. Since not all local or imported programs broadcast by the network were in color, a color program was introduced by an animated sequence of the legendary sarimanok (a mythical bird with a fish in its beak) of Philippine Muslim lore formed by moving feathers and accompanied by the audio spiel, “The following program is brought to you in living color” delivered by veteran announcer Francisco “Frankie” Evangelista. Of course, the color program appeared in color only in a color television set.

Each primetime program on the two ABS-CBN television channels was introduced by a female talent, who interspersed her announcement with promotional spiels about a sponsor’s product, usually a bath soap, a detergent, or cleansing cream. The segment took two to three minutes. Programs outside of prime time were introduced by a title card and the disembodied voice of Evangelista. For the station identification segments of ABS-CBN Channel 3, Evangelista’s voice heralded, “You’re on Channel 3, the extra member of your family” simultaneously with a visual featuring the station identification card. This explains why ABS-CBN has been referring to itself as the Kapamilya (member of the family) network in contemporary times. As for ABS-CBN Channel 9, the promotional spiel was delivered by an unidentified female voice saying, “The viewing is fine on Channel 9.” As mentioned above, in 1969, ABS-CBN’s Channel 9 moved to Channel 4 while Channel 3 moved to Channel 2 when KBS acquired a franchise to operate Channel 9.

On ABC Channel 5, each program, whether on prime time or otherwise, was introduced by the disembodied voice of a female announcer. Other spiels, including those promoting other programs, were voiced by a male announcer. Only a title card with a simple illustration provided the visual component of these promotional segments.

In 1970, RBS Channel 7 embraced color television technology. Like he did on radio, Stewart personally promoted many products live on his television channel along with the station identification aired between programs. He appeared on a bare set, sitting on a bar stool with a product in hand. Through medium shots, close-ups, and extreme close-ups, Stewart enticed the viewer to consider, for instance, buying food products like Glendale Butter or toys from Panacraft and Toylandia, which were well-known toy stores of that time, as well as purchasing a new electronic product called the video tape recorder. Channel 7 had its fair share of loyal sponsors that placed 30-second and one-minute prerecorded advertisements within its regular programs. They included Air Manila (a competitor of Philippine Air Lines), Ultrabrite Toothpaste, Stork Margarine, Seven-Up soft drink, L&M cigarettes, Frigid-Aire refrigerators, and Suntory Whiskey.

Toward the end of 1971, KBS Channel 9 promoted its programs by putting a spin on the name of the month. Thus, the station came out with labels like “A September to Remember,” “Solid Gold October,” and “Sweet November.” From the start, KBS’s Channel 9 broadcasts were in color. The management used the moniker “Accucolor 9” for its station—accu from accurate. All programs on KBS-TV, whether local or canned, were introduced by a male disembodied voice saying, “the following program is brought to you in Accucolor.” Only a visual card told the audience the title of the program. Channel 9 distinguished itself from the other television stations by framing a digital clock at the lower left-hand corner of its screen. The clock had four digits to indicate the hour and the minutes. In early 1972, the station used the clock with the promotional campaign called Playtime with Television 9. At randomly selected segments, once every hour for five hours in the evening, from five to ten o’clock, Mondays to Fridays, a voice announced that “It’s playtime on Television 9!” Right after this announcement was made, an arrow pointed to the digital clock. Then the voice recited the simple instructions of the game. The viewer is urged to jot down the time displayed on the digital clock at the exact moment the arrow appeared. If the viewer was able to get all five correct time indications, he was told to write them down on a piece of paper together with his/her name, address, and signature, and to place it in a sealed envelope and either mail it to the KBS headquarters in Pasay City, or drop in any Playtime on Television 9 drop box found at designated supermarkets within the Greater Manila Area (at present the area referred to as Metro Manila). At the end of the promotion period, viewers who sent correct information participated in a raffle which entitled them to as many chances as they had correct entries. Dozens of Sony Trinitron color television sets, which were the most sought-after appliances during that time, awaited the winners. Playtime on Television 9 provided the KBS-TV management valuable demographic data for media research purposes. It also enhanced consumer desire to acquire a color television set.

Since KBS owner Roberto Benedicto built his business empire on sugar, a brief musical-type documentary on the importance of the sugar industry to the Philippines featuring Filipino singers Sonny Cortez and Millie Mercado was broadcast at regular intervals on KBS-TV. Cortez and Mercado sang and danced to “The Sugar Song,” a medley of songs about sugar and sweetness such as “Sugartime,” “A Spoonful of Sugar,” and “Roses Are Red, My Love.” “The Sugar Song” was produced by Vicor Records in 1971. The main sponsors of KBS-TV during the pre-martial law era were Silver Bell Ice Cream, Swedish Steak and Chicken House, Trusteeship Memorial Plans, and the Visayan Packing Corporation, which manufactured Vispac Pork and Beans. Film and television personalities Prospero Luna and Nanding Flores were the principal promoters of the Vispac brand.

RMN-IBC Channel 13 aired a musical spiel about what day of the week it was. The spiels went like this, “Today is Monday and Monday is unique …” At exactly 6:00 pm of every broadcast day, the station ran a segment on The Angelus, an evening prayer Roman Catholics are expected to recite on a daily basis.

Television Advertisements. Advertisements on television were and continue to be called commercials. During the pre-martial law period, commercials were classified as imported and local commercials, commercials in English and in Tagalog, and one-minute and 30-second commercials. Imported products relied on foreign-produced commercials, although a number of imported products were promoted using both foreign-produced and locally produced commercials. Local products relied on commercials in either English or in Tagalog and the other major languages of the Philippines depending on the target audience. Filipino film and television industry actors were often employed to endorse local products. Major advertisers had both one-minute and 30-second versions of their commercials. The advertising industry called these commercials by the technical term “spots.”

Politicians of the period hardly used television for their campaign propaganda. In 1967, the opposing parties placed group advertisements of their senatorial candidates on prime time. These group advertisements featured very brief footage of each of the eight candidates of the political party in a span of 30 seconds. In 1969, Pres Marcos simply exploited his continuing exposure in the television news for his television campaign. The opposition candidate for president, Sen Sergio Osmeña Jr, placed numerous campaign advertisements mostly on television channels not identified with either Marcos or Lopez. Only reelectionist senator Gil J. Puyat campaigned extensively on television. In 1971, only senatorial candidates Juan Ponce Enrile and Blas Ople campaigned using television. Their rivals from the Liberal Party did not bother to advertise on television; they simply exploited public sympathy following their having been injured when grenades exploded during their party proclamation rally at Plaza Miranda on 21 Aug 1971, and went around town in braces, plaster casts, and wheelchairs, followed by news teams from print and broadcast.

News and Commentary As mentioned above, news and news commentary increased in significance in the postwar years not only as a reaction to the scarcity of credible news during the Japanese occupation but also because the experience of war heightened the audience’s sense of vigilance and interest in local as well as global politics and economics. Stations allocated airtime to news and news commentary, which increased as political rivalry during the Third Republic intensified and as the nation approached another perilous period, which began with the events leading up to the declaration of martial law. These, the media, including radio and television, chronicled, analyzed, and critiqued. While accusations that there were news persons whose pen could be bought may have been warranted, many played their role as the so-called watchdogs of those who run the government and others in power. The news media was so strident in its reporting and criticism and perceived as so influential in shaping public consciousness that when Marcos signed the proclamation placing the country under martial rule, the media was among the first to be silenced—literally, in the case of radio and television.

Until the simultaneous declaration of Philippine Independence from the United States and the inauguration of Pres Manuel Roxas in 1946, radio coverage of political events focused only on similar ceremonial political occasions and on war reporting in connection with World War II. In 1953, the use of broadcasting for partisan politics began when radio as well as the newly inaugurated DZAQ Channel 3 was mobilized for the election campaign for the presidency. This set a pattern for subsequent political contests. Cinema was likewise mobilized for political campaigns. In the 1965 presidential elections, Ferdinand Marcos anchored his campaign on the nationwide publicity generated by Iginuhit ng Tadhana (Destined by Fate), a motion picture about his life which was a success in box offices throughout the country. In the meantime, his vice presidential running mate Fernando Lopez enjoyed free publicity from the family-owned ABS-CBN broadcast network and their newspaper, the Manila Chronicle. While political campaigns often took the form of political ads, news programs and news commentaries were significant venues for airing political issues. All radio stations allocated time for news, although music stations tended to limit such airtime to short newsbreaks. The leading stations had 15-minute newscasts that aired daily, often twice a day, in the morning and at night. Commentary programs aired daily in the MBC and ABS-CBN radio stations.

Perhaps the most well-remembered commentator was Rafael Yabut, who started working with MBC as an electrician in its radio station DZRH. The management saw his ambition and potential and gave him a radio program called Tayo’y Mag-aliw (Let’s Have Fun). His other programs were Ruleta Musikal (Musical Roulette), Tatlo Lamang (Only Three), and Gumising sa Pagsikat ng Araw (Wake Up at Sunrise). It was in the early morning program Gumising sa Pagsikat ng Araw where Yabut reinvented himself into a hard-hitting radio commentator by criticizing government officials. His listeners loved his tirades and he developed a loyal following and the ire of those in the receiving end of his diatribes. In 1968, he survived a gunshot wound in what appeared to be an assassination attempt, then returned to his programs until the declaration of martial law in 1972. Another outspoken radio commentator was Damian Sotto, who dished out his attacks in DZAQ radio in the program Mangatuwiran Ka (Bring to Reason). Sotto was a staunch, opinionated critic of organized religion and corrupt government officials. Other announcers and commentators who joined DZAQ during that period include Joe Taruc and Rey Langit.

ABS-CBN’s DZAQ Radyo Patrol (Patrol Radio), which began in 1968 after DZAQ exchanged its old 620 kHz frequency assignment for DZXL’s 960 kHz, was proof of the increasing importance of news and public affairs programs in the late 1960s. It was an expensive proposition as the station invested not only in broadcast-equipped mobile patrols roaming the city; it required the hiring of news reporters that transmitted news stories to the stations throughout the day. Radyo Patrol, the brainchild of then ABS-CBN program director for radio and television Ben Aniceto, treated its listeners to a more or less sensational reportage of the day’s news, especially fires, accidents, strikes, hostage situations, and robberies. In 1970, Radyo Patrol reported from all over what was then called Greater Manila Area and nearby provinces when Typhoon Yoling devastated Luzon. The transistor radio audience was tuned in, especially in the absence of television due to the power outages, making Radyo Patrol the model for news reporting on radio since the period. Among its first reporters were Orly Mercado, Barr Samson, Rey Langit, Emmy Arcilla, Mario Garcia, Vic Jose, Rey Pascua, Mario Crisostomo, Ysmael Reyes, Naldie Castro, Cris Daluz, Butch Gamboa, and Franklin Leocadio. They were later joined by Joe Taruc, Bobby Guanzon, Ely Aligora, Perry Alcudia, Joey Collantes, Bert Mercado, and Chat Guillermo. The studio anchors include Johnny Midnight, Eddie Ilarde, and Bessie Ocampo. The Radyo Patrol format of news reporting was actually preceded by Sound of the City on RMN’s DZHP in the early 1960s, but it was Radyo Patrol that is still remembered today.

Stewart had three television programs on RBS-TV. The first was The News with Uncle Bob, where he delivered the late evening news, which he often editorialized. It was the television news program of the station, which first went on the air on 30 Oct 1961, a day after RBS-TV began its television broadcast.

Newscasts and commentaries were also on television. MBC Channel 11 aired the first television news programs in Tagalog, Ano ang Balita (What’s News), which ran from 1962 to 1972, and Balitang Barbero (Barber’s News), which first aired in 1965. These newscasts were broadcast late at night, outside of prime time. In 1962, ABC Channel 5 produced the The Big News, which became the leading television news program of its time. The original newscasters of The Big News were Duds Rivera and Bong Lapira. Jose Ma. Velez joined the program in 1968 after Lapira moved to ABS-CBN. Rivera and Velez remained with ABC-RTV until the station was closed on the eve of the martial law era. In 1966, ABS-CBN’s Channel 9 began airing The World Tonight, an evening news program anchored by Hal Bowie, Eric Eloriaga, and Henry Halasan at 8:30. The newscasters read the news from loose sheets of bond paper. Visuals consisted of still photographs inset on the screen. The photographs were mostly of top politicians, the facades of government buildings, and famous landmarks and logos. The following year, in 1967, The World Tonight moved from Channel 9 to Channel 3 and aired at a later time, at ten o’clock. Its vacated slot in Channel 9 was filled by Newsbreak, anchored by Bong Lapira, who was pirated in 1968 from The Big News, the rival evening news program on ABC-TV Channel 5. In 1970, KBS-TV launched Newswatch, aired nightly at ten o’clock, with Harry Gasser as main anchor. Gasser used to be a newscaster of IBC Channel 13 before he joined KBS. The other newscasters in KBS-TV during this period were Babes Romualdez (now known as Babe Romualdez) and Frankie Abao. Meanwhile, on IBC Channel 13, the nightly news program was titled Vigilantes.

Radio Mindanao Network–Inter-island Broadcasting Company–TV Channel 13 aired mostly canned programs because its studio was so small it could accommodate only a news program production. This program was given many titles, the last and most memorable of which was Vigilantes, which aired nightly from 1970 to 1972. Its opening billboard music was lifted from the theme of the 1969 James Bond motion picture On Her Majesty’s Secret Service. Vigilantes began on RMN’s DZHP radio, which continued alongside the television counterpart until 1972.

On Sunday mornings, several newspaper columnists led by Leon O. Ty went live on Channel 7 to express their opinions on the latest events of national significance. MBC-TV was also known for the television talk show Straight from the Shoulder hosted by Luis “Louie” Beltran, a news reporter of the now-defunct The Evening News. It ran from 1970 to 1972. On ABS-CBN Channel 2, Impact was a popular talk show hosted by veteran journalist Maximo Soliven. Even the irrepressible Rafael Yabut had a brief television program on Channel 7 called The Rafael Yabut Show. As expected of him, Yabut lambasted government officials, while almost all of the other commentators were critical of the government.

On 14 Nov 1967, ABS-CBN Channel 3 produced Halalan ’67 (Election ’67), a 36-hour live television coverage of the results of the congressional elections nationwide. It was the first of its kind in television history, and from then on, almost all radio and television stations imitated its format of covering elections.

Elections for the presidency, the vice presidency, and eight seats in the Senate were held in Nov 1969. Pres Marcos and Vice Pres Lopez were running for reelection under the Nacionalista Party against Sen Sergio Osmeña Jr, and Sen Genaro Magsaysay, respectively, under the opposition Liberal Party. Being the incumbent, Pres Marcos took advantage of his regular exposure in the broadcast news, instead of placing campaign advertisements on radio and television. Pinagbuklod ng Langit (Joined by Heaven), a sequel to his earlier biographical film Iginuhit ng Tadhana (Destined by Fate), gave him nationwide publicity anew, and was even proclaimed Best Motion Picture of 1969 by the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS). Pinagbuklod ng Langit starred Luis Gonzales and Gloria Romero. As in the other election campaigns, radio campaign jingles of Lopez regularly aired on ABS-CBN radio stations all over the country. For the 1969 campaign, his radio jingle opened with the phrase, “Si Fernando Lopez, walang kapares!” (Fernando Lopez has no match) and was followed by a series of rhyming lines highlighting his achievements starting with “Binigyan niya ng lunas ang ani ng bigas” (He found a solution to the problem of the rice harvest).

Television was Osmeña’s choice for the bulk of his political campaign, which consisted of numerous afternoon and primetime advertisements mainly in stations that were not identified with either Marcos or Lopez. Osmeña’s propaganda focused on the shortcomings of the Marcos administration. Senator Gil J. Puyat was the only senatorial candidate in the 1969 elections who campaigned extensively on television. Puyat’s television advertisements spelled out his surname and identified him as a man of integrity. He won reelection to the Senate under the NP.

Marcos and Lopez were reelected that year. Their second inauguration at the Luneta was covered extensively on radio and television. Marcos also got positive reviews from KBS, which highlighted the achievements of his administration in most of its broadcast news. As mentioned above, KBS operator Roberto Benedicto was a close Marcos supporter, whose franchise to run broadcast stations gave Marcos a dependable ally in the broadcast media.

By 1971, popular sentiment had turned against the Marcos administration due to the public perception that despite the constitutional prohibition against a third consecutive term as president, Marcos was manipulating the 1971 Constitutional Convention to allow him to remain in office beyond 1973. Many broadcast journalists and radio commentators shared the sentiment. Moreover, student activism in the national capital and in adjoining areas was at its heyday, and military operatives from the now-defunct Philippine Constabulary often ended up in violent confrontations with student activists demonstrating near Malacañan Palace and the legislative building. These violent clashes made many broadcast journalists and radio announcers, particularly those from ABS-CBN and ABC, livid at the administration. The largely experimental DZUP radio of the University of the Philippines did not speak well of the Marcos administration either, and its broadcasts were widely noticed in spite of the limited reach of its signal.

In the meantime, the close political ties between Pres Marcos and Vice Pres Lopez had begun to deteriorate as a result of numerous disagreements in years past between government regulators and the Lopez-owned Manila Electric Company (Meralco) over hikes in electricity rates. Friction between Marcos and Lopez actually began during their first term. Political analysts noticed that each time government regulators refused a petition by Meralco for an increase in the electricity rates to be imposed on consumers, the Lopez-owned newspaper Manila Chronicle and some ABS-CBN radio and television programs hit the government. Readers of the newspaper began to notice that its editorial cartoons regularly put Marcos in a bad light. Its editorial section repeatedly used one and the same cartoon—an elderly male public school teacher asking his pupils a question and with all the pupils raising their hands, with the caption changing every time the cartoon is used. The caption bears the question asked by the teacher, always referring to a perceived anomaly committed by Marcos. The conflict between Marcos and Lopez became obvious when Lopez left his cabinet post as agriculture secretary in the same year, but retained his post as vice president.

Coincidentally, a national midterm election was set for Nov 1971, with candidates from the pro-administration NP and the opposition LP contesting eight Senate seats, and all congressional and local government positions. In the evening of 21 Aug 1971, two grenades exploded at the LP proclamation rally held at Plaza Miranda in Quiapo, Manila, causing death and injury to many, including several LP senatorial candidates. The event created huge political capital against the NP, and the film clip taken of the bombing was the best political propaganda for the LP. ABS-CBN announced that it was going to broadcast the footage. Senator Jose Roy of the NP tried to legally stop the broadcast but failed. The footage went on the air on ABS-CBN-TV Channel 3, further alienating Pres Marcos from Vice Pres Lopez and his brother Eugenio Sr. To cover the results of the 1971 election, the ABS-CBN television stations came out with Bilang ng Bayan (Nation’s Count). An instrumental rendition of “Pilipinas Kong Mahal” (My Beloved Philippines) was repeatedly played in the background in the ending segment of the live coverage. Six LP candidates and two NP candidates won in the senatorial race. Radio and television personality Eddie Ilarde won his seat in the Senate under the LP.

The bombing of the opposition Liberal Party proclamation rally at Plaza Miranda increased the anti-Marcos sentiment of the people and media persons, including broadcasters. Toward the end of 1971, the political allies of Pres Marcos were branded by the media, radio especially, as “mga tuta ni Marcos”—lapdogs of the president. News commentators on television were likewise critical of the administration, including Beltran on Channel 11 and Velez on Channel 5. By the middle of 1972, ABC owner Joaquin Roces was openly identified with political forces opposed to the Marcos administration. Roces was particularly close to Sen Benigno “Ninoy” Aquino Jr of the LP, the most outspoken critic and political nemesis of Pres Marcos. Before Aquino entered politics, he had started as a reporter of the Roces newspaper Manila Times, the same newspaper that continuously lambasted the Marcos administration in the years prior to the proclamation of martial law. Roces was also close to Maximo Soliven, who persistently criticized Marcos in his column in the Manila Times. Roces also openly supported his newscaster Jose Ma. Velez when the latter ran for a delegate’s seat in the 1971 Constitutional Convention. Velez was elected to represent the first district of Rizal Province. He was one of several convention delegates openly against allowing Pres Marcos to perpetuate himself in power under a new constitution (Roces 1983; Velez 1986).

By 1972, Soliven’s Impact had become a popular talk show on ABS-CBN-TV Channel 2 for its intense fiscalizing of the Marcos administration. Soliven, a known supporter of the political opposition, had Senator Aquino on Impact on 13 Sep 1972. Aquino had just delivered a privilege speech at the Senate where he exposed “Operation Sagittarius,” the plan of Marcos to place Metro Manila and outlying areas under the control of the Philippine Constabulary, and subsequently place the entire country under martial law. Marcos was going to use the recent bombings in the Greater Manila Area, including the one at Plaza Miranda, as a justification for his takeover and subsequent authoritarian rule. Aquino repeated his words to Soliven at his program and to a shocked audience. It seemed that, indeed, only an extraordinary measure like resorting to martial law could turn the tide in favor of the administration—and that is precisely what happened in Sep 1972.

It has been widely assumed that Marcos declared martial law on 21 Sep 1972. However, radio, television, and newspaper operations appeared normal until 22 Sep 1972. That evening, the convoy of defense secretary Juan Ponce Enrile was ambushed in Wack-Wack as he was going home to Dasmariñas Village in Makati before 9:00 pm. Enrile revealed in 1986 that the ambush had been staged by Marcos to justify martial law, although he subsequently retracted his statement. In the morning of 23 Sep 1972, a stunned nation woke up to a silent radio and blank TV screen. The newspapers were nowhere to be seen either. People would later find out that all television and radio stations as well as newspaper operations had been padlocked by the Constabulary, except Benedicto’s KBS Channel 9 and sister radio stations, through which Marcos announced the declaration of martial law at 7:15 in the evening of 23 Sep 1972. The following morning, the Sunday edition of Benedicto’s newspaper Philippines Daily Express bannered the headline in all capital letters, “FM DECLARES MARTIAL LAW.”

Marcos had Aquino and several opposition leaders jailed, as well as a number of media persons including Roces, Soliven, Velez, and Beltran. Eugenio Lopez Sr was in the United States at the time, so he escaped arrest, but his son Eugenio Jr was incarcerated. The media operations that were slowly coming back toward the end of 1972 became tame, cowed by the conditions of the authoritarian rule of Marcos and his military arm, or had changed hands, most of them to Marcos cronies. It was another dark era in the history of the Philippines. The broadcast industry, as well as the rest of the media, for the most part lost its vibrancy.Written by Victor C. Avecilla and Elizabeth L. Enriquez

The Imposition of Martial Law

Broadcast Media and the 1986 EDSA Revolt

 

Strictly speaking, the martial law regime under Pres Ferdinand E. Marcos, through Proclamation 1081, lasted from 21 Sep 1972 until 17 Jan 1981 when Marcos officially lifted it by way of Proclamation 2045. The latter proclamation notwithstanding, authoritarian government remained, as seen in the power of Marcos to continue to legislate concurrently with the Batasang Pambansa, the legislative assembly under the 1973 Constitution. From 1981 up to early 1986, the military could still order the arrest and detention of citizens, media personnel included, and shut down any periodical or broadcast station for virtually any reason. It is from this perspective that martial law in the Philippines is seen as the period covering 21 Sep 1972 up to the downfall of the Marcos administration on 25 Feb 1986.

The Imposition of Law

The start of the 1970s was a period of political unrest in the Philippines, especially in the national capital and its suburbs. A communist insurgency was threatening the country, an armed secessionist movement was creating trouble in Mindanao, and student activism was at its apex. By the middle of 1972, Marcos was more than halfway into his second term as president and his political enemies were getting ready for the Nov 1973 presidential elections. The 1935 Constitution, the charter then in force, denied Marcos a third term. Other events that marked the period were the infamous Plaza Miranda bombing in Quiapo, Manila, on 21 Aug 1971 and the staged assassination attempt on then defense secretary Juan Ponce Enrile hours before the declaration of martial law.

 
 

The political scenario literally changed overnight when Marcos signed Proclamation 1081 on 21 Sep 1972, placing the entire country under martial law, a prerogative granted to him by the Constitution. Marcos coordinated the seizure of power during the night of the implementation of martial law through the national military telephone alert system of the country, which was installed by the United States Agency for International Development in the late 1960s. The proclamation, however, was made public two days later on 23 Sep 1972.

 

Closure of Media Companies. A major step in the execution of martial law was the closure of the media companies that was specified in Letter of Instruction 1. Newspapers and magazines expected at the news stands and from delivery personnel never made it to their destinations in the early morning of 23 Sep 1972. There were no programs on radio or television either. Hours before daybreak, all print and media facilities were closed down by armed soldiers from the Philippine Constabulary following orders from the secretary of the Department of National Defense (DND) and then secretary of the Department of Public Information (DPI) Francisco Tatad. Gen Fidel Ramos was the chief of the Philippine Constabulary, a unit of the Armed Forces of the Philippines responsible for maintaining order in the country.

 

 

Upon the proclamation of martial law, the government shut down 15 of the 16 daily newspapers, six of the seven TV stations, and all radio services. The major radio and television facilities shut down by the government included ABS-CBN of Eugenio “Kapitan” Lopez Sr, which operated two TV channels and the daily newspaper Manila Chronicle; the Associated Broadcasting Corporation (ABC-RTV-DZMT) of Joaquin “Chino” Roces, who owned the newspaper Manila Times; the Republic Broadcasting System (RBS-DZBB) of American war correspondent Robert “Uncle Bob” Stewart; the Manila Broadcasting Company (MBC-DZRH) of the Elizalde brothers Maestro Federico, former ambassador Joaquin Miguel “JM,” and Manuel “Don Manolo” Sr; and the Radio Mindanao Network–Inter-island Broadcasting Corporation (RMN-IBC) of Andres Soriano Sr, the brothers Don Henry and Atty Reuben Canoy of Cagayan de Oro City, Robin Cui, and Vicente Rivera. Classes at all levels were suspended indefinitely.

 

In some instances, the military takeover of broadcast stations was violent. Fr James Reuter, SJ, one of the early producer-directors on Philippine radio and television, narrates in an interview that the radio transmitters of Radio Veritas in Malolos, Bulacan, were smashed with clubs by a truckload of goons. Radio station DZUP in the Engineering Building and in the Arts and Sciences Building of the University of the Philippines in Diliman, Quezon City, was raided and its equipment completely destroyed. All other radio stations in Metro Manila were also raided, with guards posted on the premises.

 

 

Everyone in the media who were known or even suspected to be critics of the Marcos administration were also detained at the stockades, mostly in Camp Crame in Quezon City. Among those in the broadcast media who were detained when martial law was proclaimed were Eugenio “Geny” Lopez Jr, the son of the owner of ABS-CBN; Joaquin Roces; Jose Mari Velez, news anchorman of ABC-RTV-DZMT; and talk show hosts Maximo Soliven and Luis Beltran.

 

Two incumbent senators who were immediately detained upon the proclamation of martial law were Benigno Aquino Jr and Jose W. Diokno.

 

Exempted from the military clampdown were the Philippines Daily Express, a nationwide daily newspaper; the radio and television facilities of the Kanlaon Broadcasting System–Radio Philippines Network (KBS-RPN TV Channel 9); the government-owned radio station Voice of the Philippines; and the personnel of these media groups. The Philippines Daily Express and KBS-RPN were owned and operated by Roberto S. Benedicto, a sugar baron from the south, a staunch ally and fraternity brother of Pres Marcos. Both were explicitly allowed by Pres Marcos to operate on 23 Sep 1972 and onward.

 

 

The 23 Sep 1972 issue of the Philippines Daily Express revealed that Pres Marcos resorted to martial law to “save the Republic” from, among others, the communist insurgency. Appearing on KBS-RPN TV Channel 9 that day, the secretary of the DPI confirmed that the Philippines had been placed under martial law by the president. Subsequent announcements from Malacañan Palace were also aired at irregular and largely unpredictable hours of the day. Before nightfall, Marcos himself appeared live on the same TV channel confirming what everybody had already known. In that same appearance, Marcos answered questions from a panel of three journalists from abroad in an interview conducted live via satellite. He assured his audience, and the world for that matter, that martial law was not a military takeover of the country.

 

In between announcements from Malacañan Palace, KBS-RPN 9 broadcast an endless array of animation programs. There were no commercial advertisements on the air until regular programming resumed before the end of Sep 1972.

 

Legality of Marcos Edicts. The proclamation of martial law was scheduled in a way that Pres Marcos could institutionalize one-man rule legally. When Pres Marcos proclaimed martial law, Congress was not in session. Leaders of Congress could not convene the legislature because soldiers had closed down the legislative building. Moreover, numerous leaders of the political opposition party were thrown in the stockades, and those who managed to escape the dragnet fled abroad. Since the martial law government had no qualms about imprisoning incumbent members of Congress, the idea of convening the legislature to undo martial law seemed unthinkable.

 

 

In Sep 1972, the 1971 Constitutional Convention had not yet finished its task of drafting a new charter for the country. Many of its delegates who were perceived as enemies of the state were likewise detained in military camps. Those who were not arrested were mostly pro-Marcos people who finished the charter toward the end of 1972. The draft charter gave Marcos unbridled power under its transitory provisions.

 

Pres Marcos submitted the draft charter for ratification by the people not through a plebiscite as mandated by the 1935 Constitution then in force, but through so-called citizens assemblies purportedly created all over the country. In Jan 1973, Marcos announced that the 1973 Constitution was approved by the people. Three months later, the Supreme Court agreed and ruled that the new charter was in force and effect (Javellana v. The Executive Secretary, 50 SCRA 30, 1973). That ruling was followed by an equally controversial pronouncement declaring that all orders and decrees issued by Pres Marcos have the force and effect of law (Aquino, Jr. v. Commission on Elections, 62 SCRA 275, 1975).

 

 

The Laws. With the proclamation of martial law came a series of edicts from Pres Marcos: general orders, letters of instruction, and presidential decrees. Through these issuances, Marcos did anything he pleased, including ordering the detention of suspected enemies of the state, and enforcing a nationwide curfew. The original curfew was from midnight to 4:00 am. Later on, this was shortened to 1:00-4:00 am. Beginning 1975, the curfew was temporarily lifted every yuletide season. By 1976, the curfew was lifted completely.

 

Overnight, the military establishment became very powerful. Freedom took the back seat to authoritarian government. Congress could not do anything about the situation because it was not in session, and the legislative building had been shut down by soldiers.

 

The closure of all print and broadcast media, with the exception of the Philippines Daily Express and the KBS-RPN broadcast facilities, was undertaken pursuant to Letter of Instruction 1, which directed the secretaries of the DND and the DPI to take over and control all media in the country. The Philippine Constabulary carried out their directives.

 

 

On 2 Nov 1972, Pres Marcos issued Presidential Decree (PD) No. 36 which cancelled all legislative franchises issued by Congress to radio and television stations prior to the proclamation of martial law. All broadcast stations before martial law were required to obtain a legislative franchise from Congress as a prerequisite to its operations. A legislative franchise was in the form of a Republic Act duly approved by Congress and signed into law by the president. PD 36 further mandated that no radio or television station may resume broadcast operations without obtaining a prior clearance from the Mass Media Council (MMC) created by the president. Most of the members of the MMC were military officers.

 

Marcos also made it unconstitutional for foreigners to own and operate the media, including broadcast networks, effectively Filipinizing ownership of Philippine media for the first time. To many, the change was revolutionary. The expressed objective was to decolonize the media and balance the flow, estimated at 90 percent, of media output from the West that dominated the media environment in the Third World. The downside was that the ownership of Philippine media was relegated by Marcos to family and friends, and those owned by political rivals remained padlocked or were taken over by his cronies.

 

PD 191, issued by Pres Marcos on 11 May 1973, replaced the MMC with the Mass Media Advisory Council (MMAC). Unlike the MMC, the MMAC had more civilians among its members. This was apparently necessary to erase the impression that the military was in charge of the regulation of the media under martial law. Thus, the MMAC was given the power to issue permits for the operation of mass media in the Philippines, subject to the approval of the president.

 

On 9 Nov 1974, Pres Marcos issued PD 576, which abolished the MMAC and transferred its powers to two distinct bodies—namely, the Philippine Council for Print Media (PCPM) and the Broadcast Media Council (BMC). Some sources erroneously state that the Kapisanan ng mga Brodkaster sa Pilipinas (KBP), not the Broadcast Media Council, was the agency created under PD 576. The KBP is a private, nonstock, nonprofit corporation.

 

The individuals composing the PCPM and the BMC were mostly from the media sector themselves. By creating these bodies, the government wanted to convey the message that under martial law, the media in the Philippines were subject to self-regulation, instead of state regulation. Nonetheless, both agencies continued to operate under the strict policy of the government against printing or broadcasting materials that go against the New Society.

 

The KBP represented the broadcasters themselves, mostly from the private sector. However, the independence of the KBP was questionable, as could be expected under a martial law regime, because the head of the KBP and the BMC was one and the same person, well-known columnist Teodoro Valencia.

 

To ensure its tight grip on the broadcast media, all the foregoing regulatory councils exclusively issued permits with a limited duration, some lasting for just one month. As a result, permit renewal was periodically required. This arrangement forced broadcast stations to stay on good terms with the government. After all, the broadcast media industry is capital intensive and it cannot afford to miss even a day of broadcast operations.

 

The BMC and KBP produced some resolutions that would have some beneficial effects. One of these guidelines was regarding commercial loads. To address charges of overcommercialization of the air, the BMC imposed a limit of 13 minutes of advertising per clock-hour on radio. Other guidelines included those regarding the number of OPM or original Pilipino music to be played every broadcast hour, tax exemptions for imported broadcast equipment, and the establishment of broadcast stations in neglected areas, albeit a strategy by the government to expand its influence via the airwaves.

 

Regulation of Technical Matters. In Sep 1972, the technical aspects of broadcast media operations, such as transmitter strength and frequency assignments, were regulated by the Radio Control Office (RCO) created by law in 1962. The RCO was replaced by the Telecommunications Control Bureau in 1974. On 23 Jul 1979, Pres Marcos issued Executive Order 546 vesting in the National Telecommunications Commission (NTC) regulatory powers regarding technical matters over the broadcast media. The NTC had this responsibility for the remaining years of the Marcos administration, and continues to maintain such regulatory power in the country.

 

Martial Law Propaganda. Right after proclaiming martial law, Marcos heralded that he replaced the old, discredited political order with “the New Society” or “Ang Bagong Lipunan.” Government propaganda about the New Society was everywhere. The words “Ang Bagong Lipunan” appeared on money bills and coins. People were bombarded with announcements in the print and broadcast media, and on street posts as well, all bearing the slogan “Sa ikauunlad ng bayan, disiplina ang kailangan” (For the country to progress, discipline is necessary). Other auxillary slogans, likewise set to rhyme, were also disseminated.

 

All these slogans were promoted by the Mabuhay ang Pilipino Movement (Long Live the Filipino Movement), a group of private citizens who were willing to give the New Society a chance to succeed. The “Mabuhay ang Pilipino” song, which was set to a marching tempo, was regularly played on radio and television, and before every screening in all cinema houses in the country. Two other government-sponsored songs were regular features on broadcast media and in movie theaters as well. The first was the “Bagong Lipunan Hymn” (New Society Hymn), which had a slow beat, and the second was “Bagong Pagsilang” (New Birth), which sounded more inspiring. Later, “Bagong Pagsilang” was renamed the “Bagong Lipunan March” (New Society March). Music legends Felipe Padilla de Leon and Levi Celerio wrote these pieces.

 

For several weeks following the proclamation of martial law, all television stations were required to broadcast a film featuring elementary school pupils reciting the juvenile limerick “Sampung Palaka” (Ten Frogs) in class:

 

Sampung palaka na lumalangoy

Pataas, pababa, at paikot pa.

Ang sabi ng nanay, “Matulog na kayo.”

Ang sabi ng palaka, “Ayaw ko, ayaw ko, ayaw ko!”

 

(Ten frogs swimming

Up, down, and even around a circle.

Mother says, “Go to sleep now.”

Each frog says, “I don’t want to, I don’t want to,

I don’t want to!”)

 

Ostensibly, the film was to illustrate the obedient nature of young schoolchildren. Somebody probably noticed that the negative line at the end of the limerick seemed to encourage dissent and rebellion and so the film remained on television but its audio was removed.

 

To show to the world that the martial law government meant business, the execution by musketry of Lim Seng, a drug lord convicted by a military tribunal in Dec 1972, was broadcast on television in Jan 1973.

 

Not all government propaganda was outrightly political in character. In 1983, the government launched a campaign on radio and television to convince the public to shift from the English system of measurement to the metric system. Its theme was “the system of metric is better.”

 

Reopening the Networks. By the end of Sep 1972, Marcos allowed the pre-martial law Manila Bulletin to reoperate under a new name, Bulletin Today. Another newspaper, the Times Journal, came out the following year. It was operated by a brother-in-law of Pres Marcos, Benjamin “Kokoy” Romualdez. In 1986, Bulletin Today reverted to its original name.

 

Marcos also allowed the broadcast stations to go back on the air, provided that they did not broadcast anything that may be considered anti-government in character. Stewart’s Republic Broadcasting System was broadcasting anew via radio station DZBB and television Channel 7. Stewart was forced to sell RBS when the 1973 Constitution took effect. Under the new charter, foreigners were disallowed from owning mass media in the Philippines. Marcos presidential aide Gilberto M. Duavit Sr, Stewart’s lawyer Felipe L. Gozon, and accountant Menardo R. Jimenez later bought the controlling interest in RBS-DZBB. It was renamed Greater Manila Area–Radio Television Arts (GMA-RTV), later shortened to GMA. Stewart, however, continued to host programs on the station until 1986.

 

Next to reopen was the Radio Mindanao Network–Inter-island Broadcasting Corporation, through RMN radio stations and television Channel 13. At that time, the RMN-IBC studios and broadcast facilities were located at Little Baguio, San Juan, Rizal (now part of Metropolitan Manila). In 1975, Benedicto, a Marcos crony, bought the controlling interest in RMN-IBC and renamed it the Intercontinental Broadcasting Corporation (IBC).

 

The Manila Broadcasting Company of the Elizaldes did not resume its television operations but it was allowed to reopen its DZRH radio facilities. ABS-CBN and ABC-RTV-DZMT of the Lopezes were never allowed to reoperate any of its radio or television facilities for the duration of the authoritarian government of Pres Marcos.

 

In Jun 1973, a fire that destroyed the KBS-RPN studios on Roxas Blvd in Pasay City forced its transfer to the already closed ABS-CBN operations center in Quezon City. A year later, KBS-RPN began using the call letters RPN in its station identification segments.

 

Another broadcast facility, the Barangay Broadcasting Corporation (BBC), opened in Nov 1973. Like KBS-RPN and IBC, BBC was owned by Marcos crony Benedicto. Like RPN, BBC used the facilities of the shuttered ABS-CBN studios in Quezon City. It operated DWWX radio and BBC Channel 2. The letters “BBC” also stood for “Big, Beautiful Country,” a description then First Lady Imelda Romualdez Marcos gave to Metropolitan Manila, which she called “the city of man.” Songwriter Jose Mari Chan was commissioned to write the station’s theme song. More than two years later, BBC changed its name to Banahaw Broadcasting Corporation after Pres Marcos announced that the terms “barangay” (kin-based village during the pre-Spanish and Spanish colonial periods) and “maharlika” (nobility) were for the exclusive use of the government. In 1980, BBC was renamed City 2. It reverted to BBC in 1984.

 

By Aug 1973, Benedicto’s companies were broadcasting on all the ABS-CBN TV and radio frequencies, and operating nearly all the ABS-CBN provincial stations, except for the Iloilo radio station which was adjacent to the house of Fernando Lopez. By 1974, Benedicto had a virtual monopoly of Philippine television, owning three of five existing TV stations then.

 

In 1974, Channel 3 Cebu and Channel 4 Bacolod were reopened and changed their call signs to DYCW-TV Cebu and DYBW-TV Bacolod. Also in 1974, the administration established the Government Television Network or GTV, which operated TV Channel 4. GTV’s airtime was initially shared by the Department of Public Information (DPI), the National Media Production Center (NMPC), and RPN 9. NMPC, whose original headquarters for its TV operations were on Santa Potenciana St in Intramuros, Manila, used the facilities of ABS-CBN in Quezon City when it gained full control of Channel 4 in 1980. By this time, the ABS-CBN facilities in Quezon City were given a new name: Broadcast Plaza.

 

Two years later, in 1976, BBC 2, KBS-RPN 9, and IBC 13 moved to a new site at Old Balara in Quezon City called Broadcast City. Thus, GTV, supervised by George Viduya and Emil Jurado, had the old ABS-CBN facilities to itself. GTV 4 would gain the notoriety of being the propaganda station of the regime. Joe Jalandoon supervised IBC, Salvador “Buddy” Tan was the general manager of KBS, Jun Medina was the operations manager of RPN, and Kitchie Benedicto ran BBC.

 

By 1976, Benedicto’s Channels 9, 2, and 13 cornered about 85 percent of total airtime sales of the four major networks, equivalent to 102.1 million pesos. The highest earner was RPN 9 with total TV sales recorded at 67.4 million pesos, followed by BBC 2 with 29.5 million pesos. Third was GMA 7, which took 19.4 million pesos, and last was IBC 13 with 9.1 million pesos. In 1977, RPN enjoyed a whopping 50 percent audience market share. By 1978, RPN had 13 TV stations and at least 31 radio stations. During this period, airtime cost increased from 200-300 pesos for a 30-second spot to 2,400-3,600 pesos, simultaneous with a significant rise in television production costs, with the hit comedy John en Marsha (John and Marsha) and the top-rating musical program Superstar receiving the highest investment in terms of amount poured into each episode.

 

In 1980, GTV 4 was renamed the Maharlika Broadcasting System (MBS), headed by Gregorio Cendaña, who sought the help of former Manila Times reporter Rod Reyes to run the government station. Reyes just came from a three-year stint reorganizing GMA. At the government station, he “poured his energy into mounting highly professional coverage of the President’s activities, such as the Marcos trip to Japan in 1977 and to Washington in 1982” (Sioson-San Juan 1999, 105).

 

In 1981, there was an attempt on the part of a Christian group to open television Channel 11. Although a studio was constructed for it at the Strata building at the Ortigas business center in Pasig, the plans did not materialize.

 

In 1984, presidential daughter Imee Marcos attempted to take over GMA 7, but was resisted by Jimenez and Gozon. Stewart did not leave the country until after 1986. He was heartbroken because he did not get GMA back which he thought he would when Pres Corazon Aquino came to power (Sioson-San Juan 1999, 105).

 

Reopened Radio Stations. The martial law government was hot on the heels of AM radio stations, particularly those that had news commentaries hosted by hard-hitting announcers who took potshots at Marcos and his government. FM radio, though operational, remained unaffected, since its programming was mainly music and did not pose any potential threat to the administration. At the onset of martial law, FM was not really a bandwidth to which people listened, since most programs were concentrated on AM. The FM band during the early days of martial law was used merely as a link to connect an AM station to its transmitter, usually located at the outskirts of the city. The government also did not seem to be too strict on privately owned, nonpolitical radio stations, and those operated by established religious groups.

 

Within a few weeks from the proclamation of martial law, popular AM radio stations like DZBM and DZRJ, which had music for its programming, were allowed back on the air. As mentioned earlier, DZRH of Elizalde’s Manila Broadcasting Company was allowed to reopen its radio and TV facilities, but discontinued airing on TV following technical difficulties. The radio stations owned by religious groups that resumed operations soon enough were DZRV-Radio Veritas of the Roman Catholic Church, the Far East Broadcasting Company (FEBC) owned by a Christian organization, and the Eagle Broadcasting Corporation (EBC) of the Iglesia ni Cristo group. DZRV-Radio Veritas started operating in the Philippines on 11 Apr 1969. Maintaining good relations with established religions made it easier for Pres Marcos to run the nation under an authoritarian regime.

 

In 1975, two pioneering Cebu radio stations, DYRC of the Cebu Broadcasting Company and DYBU of the Philippine Broadcasting Corporation, reopened, this time under the ownership of the Elizaldes. In 1976, the government established DWIM-FM, which operated at the Philippine Communications Center tower along Ortigas Ave in Pasig. It had the strongest radio transmitter in the country and the latest digital broadcast equipment. The letters IM and FM in its call letters are believed to stand for the initials of Imelda Marcos and Ferdinand Marcos.

 

The station with the most powerful concentration during the period was the Voice of America (1000 kw), followed by RPN, Radio Veritas, FEBC, and the government’s National Media Production Center, each operating at 50 kw. The US Armed Forces station, which operated in the Subic Naval Base, ran on a frequency of 25 kw. Sussman (1981) reports that of the 257 radio stations in 1978, 86 percent were commercial. Eighty-three of the radio stations were owned by only five people, the largest owner of whom was Benedicto who owned RPN.

 

Advertising was mainly from affiliates of transnational corporations (TNCs). Seventy-five percent of the 123 members of the Philippine Association of National Advertisers who used the airwaves were TNCs.

 

The Return of Entertainment Programs. The return of entertainment on broadcast and other media would be used to signal the return to a sense of normalcy. Local television programs of the pre-martial law period had to find slots in the other stations which were allowed to continue operations after Sep 1972. These programs were allowed on the air again by Oct 1972, provided that they changed their titles to reflect a shift from the old order to the New Society. These programs, mainly comedy and humorous shows, used to air on the ABS-CBN television channels. Si Tatang Kasi (Blame It on Father), which featured the tandem of Pugo and Bentot, reemerged on RPN 9 as Naku Po, Tatang (Oh No, Father). Mrs. Milyonarya (Mrs Millionaire), which starred Chichay, became Ginang Milyonarya (Madame Millionaire) on RPN 9. Wanted: Boarders, which starred Patsy, became Boarding House on GMA 7. Super Laff-In, led by Ramon Zamora, Tange, Balot, Babalu, June Keithley, and Maya (Mitch) Valdez, was renamed Laughing Stock on GMA 7. The classic game show Kuarta o Kahon (Cash or Box), hosted by Pepe Pimentel, was reborn on BBC 2, which later became Family Kuarta o Kahon on RPN 9. Oras ng Ligaya (Happy Hour) became Oras ng Saya (Happy Hour) on IBC 13. Buhay Artista (Actor’s Life) retained its title when it transferred to IBC 13. The talk program Two for the Road, hosted by socialite Elvira Manahan and Joey Lardizabal, the latter subsequently replaced by Eddie Mercado, reappeared on Channel 4, then moved to GMA 7 with Nestor Torre as co-host. Gone forever were Oh My Love, Kuwentong Kutsero (Tall Tales), Santa Zita and Mary Rose, My Family Three, The Nida-Nestor Show, and Tomodatsi.

 

There were hardly any visible changes in the feature programs on radio in the aftermath of the proclamation of martial law. The dramas remained, and Dear Tiya Dely (Dear Aunt Dely) still prevailed on afternoon radio. Popular broadcasters Johnny de Leon and Joe Taruc moved to KBS’s station DWWW. Veteran broadcaster Kuya Eddie Ilarde still entertained his listeners on Kahapon Lamang (Just Yesterday), which moved from DZXL to DZBB in 1975, and ended his broadcasts with the usual “Give my regards to the family, mabalos!” (short for the Bicolano expression dios mabalos, thank you). The old radio program Tang-Tarang-Tang, again starring Pugo and Bentot, was reborn on television via BBC 2. Conspicuously missing from Philippine radio was the horror program Gabi ng Lagim (Night of Terror).

 

Radio AM programming during the period was predominantly entertainment, consisting of soap dramas, personality programs, and music, which was mainly foreign. Music was either interspersed between programs or was part of counseling and showbiz programs. The AM band catered primarily to audiences of the lower socioeconomic class.

 

FM programming during the early days of the martial law period was in its infancy stage, but would blossom during the period. Among different sectors of the broadcast industry, FM radio was the least affected by the political situation of the country mainly because it concentrated on music programming that aired politically safe music pieces.

 

Imported Programs. The usual array of pre-martial law American television programs was back on the airwaves after Sep 1972. These shows include Hawaii Five-O on RPN 9, and Lost in Space and the camp Batman series on GMA 7. As expected, new shows from the United States filled the gap, such as The Six Million Dollar Man, Policewoman, SEARCH, The Price is Right, and Family Feud, on RPN 9; and The Bionic Woman, Kolchak: The Night Stalker, Charlie’s Angels, The Muppet Show, Mork & Mindy, James at 15, Little House on the Prairie, The Paul Lynde Show, Love Boat, Three’s Company, CHiPS, Starsky & Hutch, and How the West Was Won on GMA 7. BBC 2 aired the afternoon soap The Young and the Restless. There were programs from England as well, like Tales of the Unexpected and The Benny Hill Show, both aired on GMA 7. A hit program was Dance Fever, GMA 7, hosted by Deney Terio, an American disco dance competition.

 

Imported religious programs found their way into Sunday programming. These programs include The 700 Club and The Rev. Ernest Angley Hour, both on GMA 7; Rex Humbard World Outreach Ministry, Jimmy Swaggart, and The Baptist Hour, on IBC 13; and Gospel Crusade on GTV 4, which also aired the local program The Sunday Mass. The 700 Club would also later gain the late evening daily time slot of GMA and would eventually have a Philippine version of the program.

 

Aside from American, Japanese, and British broadcast productions entering the Philippine market, imported Chinese-language programs found a dent in the Sunday morning programming of television, which catered to the Chinese language-speaking sector of the population. Examples include Beautiful Sunday, IBC 13; Ring of Love, GMA 7; and several programs featuring old Chinese movies. Chinese Weekend Musicals, IBC 13, gained a Saturday late evening programming in the late 1970s.

 

Undoubtedly the most popular imported show was the educational program Sesame Street, 1974, produced by the Children’s Television Workshop, which featured Jim Henson muppets Big Bird and Cookie Monster. Significant about the program was the absence of commercials within the show, which was in accordance with the instructions of the American producers of the show. Each episode of the program cost only 50 dollars, but the use of a special tape to record each episode was so prohibitive that its distributor had to tap season sponsorships from large corporations such as Delta, Cocobank, and the Philippine National Bank, and had to periodically transfer to different channels to survive.

 

New animated programs of the period include Wait Till Your Father Gets Home and Yogi’s Ark Lark from Hanna-Barbera Productions, and Arnie Barkley and The Houndcats from DePatie-Freleng Productions. By 1978, the iconic Voltes V, a Japanese show about the saga of a family and their robot that went on the air every Friday afternoon on GMA 7, dominated juvenile television programming. Its phenomenal success could be seen in the fact that schoolchildren actually sang its Japanese-language theme song without understanding what the words meant. After about a year, an English version of the song replaced the original one in the program. Locally sold Voltes V toys and stationery generated tremendous sales. The success of Voltes V prompted GMA 7 management to bring in other robot-type Japanese animated programs like Mazinger Z and Mekanda Robot.

 

Although each episode of Voltes V was a complete story in itself, all the episodes were part of a bigger story with an anticipated end. Sadly, Voltes V fans were unable to watch the last four or five episodes of the show because Pres Marcos ordered a ban on robot animation programs on television, because parents were ostensibly complaining of violence shown to children. Many, however, were of the opinion that the cancellation of the program was because its content reflected the repression of the Marcos government. There were no digital video disks and no cyber technology available in 1978. Moreover, the country was still under martial law and what Marcos wanted, Marcos got. The disappointed viewers had to wait until about 15 years later when GMA ran the entire gamut of Voltes V episodes over a fixed period.

 

In 1974, over 75 percent of television broadcast time was imported, the broadcast of which was supported by big advertisers, mostly from US transnational corporations. By the late 1970s, almost 58 percent of the average of 573.5 hours of weekly broadcasting was foreign, largely canned programs from the United States, the United Kingdom, and Japan (Ministry of Public Information 1979).

 

The importation of syndicated programs was partly due to the high cost of producing a local TV production. It was more expensive to produce shows than to buy shows from foreign suppliers. A local network in the 1970s needed about 6,000-18,000 pesos (800-2,400 US dollars at exchange rates of the period) to produce a single episode, while it needed practically the same cost (8,000-20,000 pesos or 1,000-2,600 US dollars) to import a complete series of a highly rated program (Mercado 1983).

 

Censorship

 

The times were not normal in spite of the return of entertainment in the broadcast media. The government and its military arm exerted control over the media through both coercive and persuasive methods: prior censorship, threats of legal sanctions, bribery, detention, physical intimidation, and the ultimate method of death when nothing else worked. The climate of suppression corrupted many and broke the spirit of others. The government’s Board of Censors monitored all broadcast programs. The board did not allow programs or parts of programs that were considered politically or morally unfit for broadcast. The Lumauig Bill threatened to limit the free expression of artists.

 

For example, during the first few years of the Marcos dictatorship, drama programs were required to submit their scripts to the military prior to airing to root out what was deemed subversive content. This departed from the previous practice of writing the scripts literally minutes before the radio program was either aired or recorded. Some programs were asked to revise or retape parts that were considered politically or morally unfit for broadcast. Perhaps one of the worst forms of censorship, which became a practice under a climate of fear, was self-censorship.

 

Broadcast news, accountable to Marcos, was monitored and censored by the Office of Civil Affairs. “You write the news and then it goes to Civil Affairs and then it goes back to you censored” (Freddie Garcia, quoted in Rodrigo 2006, 261). “The networks maintained a tightlipped silence about inconvenient truths. The de facto news policy was ‘see no evil’” (Rodrigo 2006, 260). The public affairs program Kapwa Ko, Mahal Ko (My Dear Fellowman), GMA 7, which featured poor people in desperate need of assistance, was ordered to momentarily stop its airing in 1975 when the Marcos government was sprucing up Manila and Quezon City for the visit of an official of the International Monetary Fund–World Bank. Pasig Mayor Emiliano Caruncho Jr and his henchmen mauled Radio Veritas reporter Salvador F. Reyes on 16 Jun 1981, an election day. Reyes asked the mayor about a voter who had not been allowed by the Commission on Election to vote because of a certification concern, which irritated the mayor. GMA cameraperson Boy Sonza captured on camera the mayor and his aide pulling the reporter’s hair, strangling him, and hitting him on different parts of his body, which GMA aired on News at Seven. Ronnie Nathanielsz of GTV 4 attempted to squelch the controversy by casting doubt on the credibility and integrity of Reyes and Sonza. The mayor was eventually suspended though, but Radio Veritas station manager Fr Sonny Ramirez had to fire Reyes and publicly condemn him for signing an affidavit of desistance from his civil, criminal, and administrative charges against the mayor. Also censored was news about the collapse on 17 Nov 1981 of the fourth floor of Imelda Marcos’s pet project, the seven-level Manila Film Center or “film palace,” killing 64 workers, including an engineer, and wounding 168 construction workers, who were rushing its construction for the 18 Jan 1982 opening of the First Manila International Film Festival. A government news crew was suspended by Malacañan when he inadvertently showed footage of Marcos, at a time when he was rumored to be ill with lupus, looking weak during a cabinet meeting and being fanned by aides (Rodrigo 2006, 260).

 

Lupita Aquino-Concio (now Aquino-Kashiwahara) said in an interview that there was an “unwritten blacklisting” in the broadcast media. In the early 1970s, Concio was handling RPN’s music variety program Superstar and the weekly drama anthology Ang Makulay na Daigdig ni Nora (The Colorful World of Nora), which offered some competition to top-rating programs John en Marsha and Hawaii Five-O. Concio’s programs were rating high and winning awards, but management informed her that Superstar needed reformatting, which meant tapping several directors taking turns doing the show. Concio accepted this arrangement for the good of the show. She learned later, however, that the same would be done with Makulay na Daigdig. She knew then that she was being eased out of the two top-rated shows. Concio believed that her connection to Benigno Aquino Jr, her brother, who was a staunch critic of the Marcos regime, was the reason behind this plan by the management. Concio did not resign from the network, but stayed on until she was fired. The broadcast industry’s loss was the movie world’s gain. Concio moved on to direct films like Minsa’y Isang Gamu-Gamo (Once a Moth), a sociopolitical critique of the American bases in the country.

 

Ms. Ellaneous hosts Ma-an Hontiveros, Tina Revilla, and Yogi Dominguez-Zaragoza also found themselves gradually eased out of their program after they tried to have opposition lawyer Jose Diokno as a guest (Sioson-San Juan 1999, 161).

 

In 1981, the National Bureau of Investigation (NBI) had to cancel even the government-produced program Metro Magazine, which aired at different days and time on all Metro Manila channels, because it found one of its episodes, “Awit, Tula, at Kasaysayan,” seditious and inciting to rebellion. The 30-minute episode featured the theater group Tambisan ng Sining singing fervently patriotic songs, such as “Babaeng Walang Kibo” (The Tight-lipped Woman), “Palasyong Alipin” (Enslaved Palace), “Republikang Basahan” (Tattered Republic), “Awit ng Rebolusyonaryo” (Song of the Revolutionary), “Ang Masa” (The Masses), and “Bayan Ko” (My Country). The episode was seen on RPN 9’s 26 Apr airing and on GMA 7’s 28 Apr airing by members of a government agency that was regularly monitoring on-air programs. The NBI invited producer and scriptwriter Willie Virtucio, host Jaime Fabregas, camerapersons Jean Velasquez and Ricky Ligon, production assistant Joey Gamara, and Tambisan officers Lourdes Marquez, Joel Saracho, Jun de los Reyes, Philip Obligacion, and Nena Gajudo to submit themselves for a “conference.” Scheduled airings of the same episode on GTV 4 and IBC 13 were cancelled.

 

Some programs, mainly of GMA 7, continued to test the boundaries of censorship. For example, the late-night talk show Two for the Road featured and interviewed activists and opposition leaders in some of its episodes, which prompted the Board of Censors under Maria Kalaw Katigbak to make moves, although unsuccessfully, to require the program to tape all their episodes so it could cut out the parts that it deemed radical, incendiary, and unfit for TV. Orly Mercado’s GMA exclusive on the Marcoses' hidden wealth; Ricardo “Dong” Puno’s interview with newly widowed Corazon Aquino on his talk program Viewpoint, 1984-94; Tina Monzon Palma’s outfit of black or yellow, the symbols of the opposition, on News at Seven, or the expressions on her face that would reveal her distrust of the news stories she was reading; and GMA news reporters or anchorpersons rolling their eyes as they talked about the accomplishments of the dictator—all this prompted Malacañan and its cronies to reprimand or admonish the owners of the network.

 

Rod Reyes, who was running the government television station MBS 4, objected to instructions from Malacañan to downplay the funeral of Ninoy Aquino. He eventually resigned from MBS at the end of 1983 (Sioson-San Juan 1999).

 

However, in spite of some headway, many broadcast workers, as well as listeners and viewers, resented the tight rein in which the Marcos government kept broadcasting. As in the time of the Japanese occupation, the climate of suppression produced a heightened consciousness not only among broadcast workers but also among their viewers and listeners. Once again, the people longed for the lively, irreverent, and liberal programming, particularly that of radio, of a previous era, which was perceived to be free and credible. This consciousness would very soon lead to the forging of protest broadcast, which was part of the alternative media—alternative to the crony media, that is—of the early 1980s.

 

By late 1980, Pres Marcos announced that martial law was no longer necessary because all the problems that had triggered its proclamation were virtually solved. On 17 Jan 1981, Marcos issued Proclamation 2045 lifting martial law throughout the Philippines. Despite this proclamation, he kept his authoritarian government intact by retaining his power to legislate under the 1973 Constitution.

 

Pres Marcos also announced that the lifting of martial law carried with it the abolition of the PCPM and the BMC. Thus, permits to operate broadcast media in the Philippines, like before, would require a legislative franchise, either a Batas Pambansa (Republic Act) from the Batasang Pambansa, which was dominated by the pro-administration party, or a presidential decree issued by Marcos himself. Simply put, it became more difficult to get such a permit.

 

The abolition of the BMC and the PCPM in 1981 did not automatically mean full freedom for the broadcast media. Any broadcaster who created trouble could be charged with subversion and detained indefinitely. Marcos already had his cronies running the media. Roberto Benedicto was in charge of ABS-CBN and the Kanlaon Broadcasting System networks and the Philippines Daily Express. Benjamin Romualdez, the brother of the First Lady Imelda, controlled the Times Journal. Hans Menzi, a former military aide of the president, owned the Manila Bulletin.
