Presidential assistant Juan Tuvera and Imelda’s official biographer Kerima P. Tuvera had Focus, Evening Post, and Orient Express. Leon O. Ty, a Marcos-appointed governor of the Development Bank of the Philippines, and Ralph Nubla, a Marcos organizer in Chinatown, were publishers of the Weekly Examiner and the United Daily News. The government media, including the broadcast networks, were naturally in the service of the Marcos regime.

 

Programming Developments

 

Development Communication and Renaissance Programming. Development communication, a concept that originated from agricultural extension, was stressed during the martial law years. Educational programs were produced to push the concept of development communication, such as Ating Alamin (Let Us Find Out), 1974-91, hosted by Gerry Geronimo, and Tele-Aralan ng Kakayahan (Knowledge Educational TV), hosted by theater artist CB Garrucho (Cecilia Bulaong-Garrucho), both aired on weekends on KBS-RPN 9. Even shows like the top-rating comedy program John en Marsha had to develop and send “developmental” messages about health, family planning, discipline, good citizenship, and family morals across its audience (Sioson-San Juan 1999). On radio, a classic example is the hour-long program Lingap ng Pangulo sa Barangay (The President’s Care for the Barangay), a nonformal educational series that all KBP member stations were required by the government to broadcast. School-on-the-air types of programs, which targeted rural audiences to send across the development programs of the government, became one of the trends, a forerunner of which is DZLB of the University of the Philippines at Los Baños (Flor 1994).

 

The concept of development communication extends to the government’s effort to usher in what it termed as “renaissance programming” in Philippine broadcasting, which meant bringing “culture” closer to the people by airing educational and cultural programs during prime time—that is, 7:30-8:00 pm and preceded by the news at 7:00 pm. That was how KBS general manager Buddy Tan was able “to air an entire library of Encyclopedia Britannica documentaries, and to transfer Armida Siguion-Reyna’s late-night musical Aawitan Kita to prime time” (Sioson-San Juan 1999, 117).

 

The idea of renaissance television, unfortunately, was not commercially viable and it was soon forgotten. In various seminars and workshops organized by the BMC and the KBP, development communication was always presented as a vision. However, it was virtually impossible to realize since the mass communication system remained commercial.

 

Original Pilipino Music. On 27 Apr 1973, leaders of the broadcast media industry organized themselves as the Kapisanan ng mga Brodkaster sa Pilipinas (KBP, Organization of Broadcasters in the Philippines), later changed during the Corazon Aquino administration to Kapisanan ng mga Brodkaster ng Pilipinas (Organization of Broadcasters of the Philippines), to encourage more professionalism among radio and television broadcasters. All radio and television stations were required to be members of the KBP, which was a private, nonstock, nonprofit corporation.

 

Perhaps the biggest positive impact of the KBP-BMC regulation of radio broadcasting was the tremendous growth attained by the local recording industry as a result of the rule that all radio stations play what were called Original Pilipino Music (OPM) on the air, which referred to a song or piece composed by a Filipino, or any song or piece performed by a Filipino, or a song or piece composed by a Filipino but performed by a foreigner. The move challenged the dominance of foreign music and talents. Beginning with one song per program hour in 1975, the requirement was brought up to four in 1982. From the mid-1970s until the middle of the 1980s, local composers, singers, and musicians enjoyed unprecedented exposure on radio and achieved a measure of maturity in their craft.

 

Before martial law, popular Filipino music referred primarily to folk songs and the kundiman (love songs). OPM during martial law took on a more distinctively younger sound, incorporating elements of Filipino culture with pop, jazz, folk, and rock music. This paved the way for the birth of the “Manila Sound.” Music from bands became the vogue. The most popular band of the period was Hotdog, creator and performer of such hits as “Ikaw ang Miss Universe ng Buhay Ko” (You Are the Miss Universe of My Life) and the iconic “Manila.” Other popular bands were The Ambivalent Crowd, The New Minstrels, The Circus Band, Juan de la Cruz Band, Maria Cafra, Heber Bartolome’s Banyuhay, and VST & Company. Among the artists who became stars as a result of the KBP-BMC rule on OPM were Freddie Aguilar, Sampaguita, Joey “Pepe” Smith, Florante, Mike Hanopol, Asin, Leah Navarro, Jose Mari Chan, Basil Valdez, Celeste Legaspi, Sharon Cuneta, the Apo Hiking Society, Rico J. Puno, Hajji Alejandro, Rey Valera, Imelda Papin, Claire de la Fuente, Eva Eugenio, and Vernie Varga. Composers George Canseco, Willy Cruz, Ryan Cayabyab, Nonong Pedero, and the Garcia brothers Rene and Dennis of Hotdog, whose compositions would later become classics, ushered in a vibrant period of Filipino popular music.

 

The Florescence of FM Radio Programming. FM radio stations with a music orientation began to flourish during the martial law period. Benedicto-run BBC renamed DZYK to DWWK 101.9 in 1972, which aired pop vocal and instrumental jazz, then labeled as jazz fusion. DWLL 94.7 “The Mellow Touch,” owned by FBS Radio Network Inc and which adopted the adult Top 40 format, started airing in 1973. The taped voice of Butch Gonzalez became the signature voice of the station.

 

Midway through the decade, Fred J. Elizalde’s MBC migrated to FM by establishing 90.7 DZMB “Love Radio,” which went on the air during Valentine’s Day of 1975. The station took on an adult contemporary easy listening format, which included love songs, oldies, country music, and later OPM. This was in keeping with the band’s predominantly laid-back sound. Also in 1975, IBC operated DWKB 89.1, a pop music-format station. It was also around this time that RMN’s DZHP migrated to FM, occupying the frequency 93.9 MHz. It took on the middle-of-the-road format (music with general appeal or something not too current, not too old, and neither too loud nor too soft), combining disco hits with oldies from the 1950s, 1960s, and 1970s. RBS relaunched DZXX as DWLS in the FM band in 1976, with LS standing for Loreto Stewart, the wife of owner Robert La Rue Stewart, more popularly known as Uncle Bob; it played oldies and pop music. Trans-Radio Broadcasting Company, which owned DZTR Radyo Pilipino on AM, acquired a license in 1976 to broadcast on FM, enabling it to migrate to FM under the call letters DWRT, aka 99.5 RT, owned by Emilio R. Tuason and Andre S. Khan, who were considered then the young turks of the industry whose innovations would alter FM programming of the period.

 

Easy listening station DWIM-FM 104.3, which went on the air in 1976, was owned and operated by the Philippine Broadcasting Service (PBS) under the Office of the Press Secretary. In 1978, Radio Mindanao Network, after having DZHP migrate to FM in the mid-1970s, reformatted the station and renamed it DWKC 93.9, making it the network’s flagship station in Metro Manila. It took on pop music programming aimed at targeting a mass audience. DWKC was among several FM radio stations that RMN launched nationwide as part of the network’s expansion efforts during the period.

 

Philippine FM’s radio programming became synonymous with the so-called contemporary sound, a supposedly high-brow alternative to the otherwise mass-based AM type of programming. This was characterized primarily by classical, easy listening (ballads and instrumentals), or middle-of-the-road formats, which were meant to target mature audiences. During the late 1970s, the FM band opened its doors to younger-sounding formats, like contemporary hit radio or the Top 40 format.

 

“Less talk, more music” was the mantra during Philippine FM’s early years during the martial law period, or at least until radio stations like DWRT came into the picture and broke the mold by highlighting its programming with deejay (DJ) chatter. Although music programs on AM had disc jockeys manning the airwaves, FM’s music programs consisted of prerecorded voices ensuring continuity or the smooth transition from music sweep to commercial break and vice versa. Voices of such talents as Butch Gonzalez of DWLL 94.7 “The Mellow Touch,” Suzette Arboleda of DWFM 92.3 “MRS (Most Requested Song) Radio,” and Jess Decolongon of DWIM-FM 104.3, now known as “Business Radio,” complemented the flow of their respective station’s programming.

 

DWFM introduced “seamless programming” as an alternative to the already existing album-oriented programming. FM stations initially played the entire music album and stopped only to accommodate time checks. It was DWFM that started playing a variety of tunes segued one after the other, and complemented by prerecorded announcer spiels delivered by Arboleda, DWFM’s official voice-over announcer after her stint with DXIR in Iligan, a provincial station of NBC.

 

The entrance of DWRT 99.5 into the scene, which went on the air in 1976 using a five-kilowatt Sparta transmitter accompanied by a JamPro penetrator antenna, set industry standards that consequently compelled the other stations to eventually run on five kilowatt-powered transmitters. FM radio stations used to broadcast using only one kilowatt-powered transmitters. DWRT 99.5 is said to have become the radio technology showcase for Asia. Everything was state of the art. Audio equipment brand Philips even approached Tuason, one of the station’s owners, to tie in with them in launching compact discs (CDs) and laser discs through the station. The dawn of the digital age arrived on Philippine radio as early as 1981. Among DWRT’s innovations are the introduction of the contemporary hit radio format, a mix of pop, rhythm and blues, and rock ’n’ roll; the syndicated American Top 40; and niche programming, a type of programming meant to target specific audiences. Legendary deejays of DWRT include Joppy Gutierrez, Al Torres (aka Al W. Leader), Eric Eloriaga (aka Eric Caine), a certain Dr John Madness, Ramon Cruz (aka Adam Kite and Joey Pizza), Gerry Magnaye (aka Jeremiah Junior), Bob Kishore Bhavnani (aka Bob Curry), Vince de Guzman (aka Vince Saint Price), Sonny Zarate (aka Sonny Z), Jigs Ona (aka Jiggy), Dikie Aragama (aka Dick Reese), station manager Mike Pedero, and Tuason himself.

 

DZFX, DWFM, DWWK, and DWLL targeted mature audiences, albeit through contrasting musical genres, while DWRT aimed for the younger demographics. RMN’s DWKC catered to a more low-end segment of listeners, and one of its innovations was the incorporation of jokes by its deejays into its pop music programming. DWKC’s deejays included Bobby Ante (aka The Nutty Professor), Mike Enriquez (aka Baby Michael), Willy Inong (aka Hillbilly Willy), Louie Ansaldo (aka Happy Louie), Brian Bhavnani (aka Dr Buddy Brian), Reginald Francisco, and Butch Gonzalez, who were all from AM radio station DWBL. The idea to implement a mass-based approach to FM programming on DWKC started when the announcers saw the success of DZHP when it was still on AM, particularly the music program of one of its announcers, the Taglish-speaking (a mash-up of Tagalog and English) deejay Nick Mendoza (aka Friendly Nick). This led them to experiment on implementing the so-called bakya (mass appeal) concept of programming, but with English as their medium of expression. English was the language that prevailed on FM at the time. Having a steady supply of jokes was a major concern. Deejays read jokes verbatim on air, lifted from published joke books, which were based on American humor, resulting in a rather toned-down version of mass-based program formats of the 1990s on through the 2000s. Surprisingly, DWKC managed to capture part of the high-end market, gaining a huge following among high school students from exclusive schools and elevating the station’s deejays to celebrity status. The station even had some joke books published as a result, which they gave away to listeners during on-air promotions. The novelty of the concept wore off through time, since people’s listening habits, wants, and likes often shifted.

 

The 1980s may well be considered the heyday of the Philippine FM radio history as more radio stations started mushrooming, more so since FM radio remained unaffected by the regime. At the same time, it was also a period of transition for some, since a handful of stations underwent programming changes mainly due to station acquisitions.

 

In 1982, DWXB 102.7, owned by the National Council of Churches in the Philippines, a coalition of Protestant churches, forged a management contract with programming expert Freddie Dandan and marketing man Ciro Songco, who would handle sales for Radyo Inquirer in the 2000s, and renamed it Magic Disco 102, bringing an exclusively disco programming to the airwaves. It was later on sold to Marcos crony Danding Cojuangco, and its programming shifted to new wave and alternative rock, under the helm of program director Jesse Gonzalez. This went on until the time of the EDSA Revolt, after which Bombo Radyo Philippines purchased the station from Cojuangco and renamed it DWSM 102.7.

 

In 1983, DWEI 93.1 of Liberty Broadcasting Company was acquired by Audiovisual Communicators Inc, then owned by Rene Lacson and Freddie Garcia, and became DWRX 93.1 or Music City RX 93, which featured pop music. The call letters “RX” are said to stand for prescription music, just what the doctor ordered, and “Rated eXcellent.” The station was later acquired by Antonio Barreiro Sr, a founding member of the KBP, which would later be owned by his sons Chito, Rafael, and Antonio Jr, under its new monicker Monster Radio RX 93.1.

 

In 1984, Mabuhay Broadcasting Company, owned by Edgar Ragasa and wife Cynthia, went on the air via DWKY 91.5, which took on a contemporary hit radio format combined with OPMs.

During the same year, Banahaw Broadcasting Company changed DWWK’s format to pop, and went by the call name DWOK 101.9. Several format-based radio stations followed suit in 1985, and these were mellow rock station DWRK 96.3 Real Radio for Real People owned and operated by ACWS–United Broadcasting Network Inc led by Benny Rebueno Hodreal Sr, who was also a founding member of the KBP.

 

DWBM 105.1 of Mareco Broadcasting Network Inc, owned and operated by Manuel P. Villar Sr, also began operations, after proving successful on AM via DZBM. It must be remembered that in 1950 Villar founded Villar Records, which was famous for recording Philippine folk songs, kundiman, balitaw (courtship song), and other love songs from the different regions of the country. For this, Villar earned the title as the “Father of Philippine Recording” for his pioneering work in recording original Filipino music. DWBM took on a new wave format, which eventually changed to adult contemporary format toward the 1990s.

 

During the end of the martial law period, niche programming became the prevailing pattern, as FM radio stations targeted specific audiences. With DWRT trailblazing the trend, a number of other format-oriented radio stations soon followed suit and eventually made a mark in Philippine FM radio history.

 

Regional Expansion and the Telecommunications Industry

 

Before the proclamation of martial law, television did not reach many parts of the archipelago. Most television broadcasts could only reach northern and southern Luzon. Developments in telecommunications technology after 1972 made it possible to transmit television programs to key cities in the Visayas and Mindanao by relay stations. Satellite technology, which improved immensely in the middle of the 1970s, also contributed to the wider reach of television during this period, simultaneous with the continuing hold of transnational corporations on the telecommunications industry of the country, which became one of the most concentrated areas of business ownership and one of the primary generators of foreign investments in the country, specifically in so-called growth centers although mainly carried out in Manila and in export processing zones. The industry had interlocking interests with large transnational corporations and also became associated with military security. The telecommunications industry provided the conduit for transnational advertising, the system that brought together the separated regions of the country, and the infrastructure that integrated the nation into the globalized world system.

 

The Benedicto group, having drawn loans from the government-owned Philippine National Bank, expanded the operation of its network, RPN, to 12 regions of the country. On 21 Sep 1977, the fifth anniversary of the declaration of martial law, Benedicto inaugurated domestic satellite communications or DOMSAT, with RPN serving as its transmitting network of 11 satellite earth stations nationwide and for all special broadcasts from the Office of the President. RPN also served as the relay station of IBC’s 12 television and 18 radio stations, as well as those of KBS, BBC, and GTV. DOMSAT went full blast in its operation in Jan 1980 in preparation for the provincial and municipal elections during the same year, which made possible the national coverage of candidates under Marcos’s political party, the Kilusang Bagong Lipunan (KBL). It also made possible the influx into the network of many foreign entertainment programs and specials. Through DOMSAT, the daily noon variety program Eat Bulaga! (Lunchtime Peek-a-Boo!) of RPN was able to expand its viewership, enabling the program to dislodge from the top spot its rival program Student Canteen of RBS-GMA. RPN also attracted top transnational corporations (TNC) for its advertisements—namely, Unilever’s Philippine Refining Company, Procter & Gamble, Colgate-Palmolive, Consolidated Foods Corporation, Nestle’s Filipro, San Miguel, Pepsi Corporation, Radiowealth, and Johnson & Johnson. The lone fully domestic corporation advertiser it had was Banco Filipino.

 

In 1978, Marcos secured control of the television industry to RPN by overturning a law that encouraged domestic production of TV receivers and, through Letter of Instruction 640, gave Nivico, a Japanese-Benedicto joint TV manufacturing venture, sole tax- and duty-free component import rights. Nivico’s principal foreign partner was the Japanese transnational conglomerate Marubeni, a television manufacturer, which became the major supplier of RPN and DOMSAT. Other major television manufacturers protested the decree, but nothing came out of the protest.

 

Also in 1978, Benedicto, by then the undisputed media mogul in the Philippines, ventured into cable television. He operated Sining Makulay Inc from the old RMN-IBC studio facilities, the ancestral Quirino house by KBS, in Little Baguio in San Juan, Metropolitan Manila. Subscribers to the service received programs from two channels—namely, 5 and 11—on their regular television dial. The subscription fee was rather expensive, and the service was available only to the plush subdivisions in Makati, San Juan, Pasig, and Quezon City. Benedicto’s cable TV was considered by critics “a political animal” operated by the Marcos administration to “monopolize all the channels of VHF and close the airwaves to other bidders” so much so that “aside from the commercial channels, cable Channels 5, 6, 8, 10, and 12 were now also under government control” (Sioson-San Juan 1999, 105). Although Benedicto had monopoly of cable TV, “illegal” operations were widespread in the provinces, mainly to bring via cable broadcast signals that could not reach certain areas. It was a response to a demand that could not be met by broadcasting via the air. Cable subscription was 60 pesos per month. Benedicto’s cable TV enterprise proved not to be very successful, and its operations were overtaken by the political events of 1983. It stopped its operations soon thereafter.

 

Another player in the telecommunications industry was Eastern Telecommunications Philippines Inc (ETPI), one of three major international record carriers that handled telegraph, telex, and data transmission, which had cooperation with Cable & Wireless, a British international communication giant, and Oceanic Wireless Inc, an international tropospheric scatter (troposcatter) radio communication system. ETPI had Benedicto as one of its principal partners. The Marcos government granted ETPI the exclusive rights to the communications market of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) that consequently made it possible for ETPI to corner other Asian cable markets, and the sole permit to operate institutional circuits from the Bataan export processing zone, which attracted multinational communications and electronics industries to invest in the Philippines. ETPI’s top user was the US military.

 

Another key figure in the telecommunications industry was the Philippine Long Distance Telephone Company (PLDT) of Ramon Cojuangco, the pro-Marcos wing of the landed Cojuangco family. He was also a major stockholder in DOMSAT. PLDT provided domestic terrestrial connections to and from every DOMSAT ground station in voice, video, record, and data communications. PLDT was dependent on the cable of ETPI for its traffic to and through Asia. It had million-dollar contracts with General Telephone and Electronics (GTE) Corporation of the United States and Siemens Corporation of the Federal Republic of Germany for electronic switching equipment. PLDT competed with 67 smaller telephone companies all over the country, but it cornered 85 percent of the country’s telephone services. PLDT’s principal international toll users were hotels, while the largest domestic users were Coca Cola, Pepsi Cola, Colgate-Palmolive, Unilever’s Philippine Refining Company, Procter & Gamble, the Philippine National Bank, and foreign oil companies.

 

Both Benedicto and Cojuangco, together with Marcos defense minister Enrile, were principal partners in another major player in the telecommunications industry, the Philippine Communications Satellite (Philcomsat), which had the US military as its largest and single-end user. Another major player was Philippine Communications Corporation (Philcom) of Radio Communication of America (RCA), nominally headed by former ambassador to the United States Ernesto V. Lagdameo, with Enrile and energy minister Geronimo Z. Velasco as one of its major stockholders. Among Philcom’s largest wideband users were the US military, Pan Am, and IBM, while its narrowband users were US and Japanese transnational corporations, such as Caltex, IBM, Xerox, Getz Bros., Seatrain, General Electric, General Instrument, Cummins Engine, Timex, and Hitachi-Union. Globe-Mackay Radio Corporation of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, which had the Ayalas and the Zobels for its major business partners, operated the telephone and communications systems of the Bataan export processing zone, the Philippine National Assembly, the Philippine Navy, the Philippine National Bank, the Bank of the Philippine Islands, the Consolidated Bank and Trust Company, Puerto Azul, the Westinghouse Bataan Nuclear Power Plant, the Philippine International Convention Center, and the convention centers in Baguio City and Olongapo City.

 

The growth of the telecommunications industry, with satellite transmission in previously inaccessible areas, made significant headway for various industries, mostly transnational corporations, and linked the so-called offshore operations that foreign investments established in the Philippines to the centers of these operations, which were mainly in industrialized countries. The industry, with interlocking local and global interests, made it possible for these investors to market their products and services under the full protection and support of the Marcos government. The expansion of international capital informed the transnationalization of media, which, in turn, fed into the strategic development goals of the military government of Marcos that favored the concentration of capital among friendly members of the elite, which would later be termed as crony capitalism. Indeed, the broadcast media industry, both as part of the bigger telecommunications industry and as a conduit of transnational capital, is one classic example of the operations of crony capitalism during the martial law period.

 

News and Public Affairs Programs

 

A few days after the proclamation of martial law was announced to the public, regular news programs began airing on KBS-RPN 9 and its radio counterpart. When RBS-DZBB and RMN-IBC resumed operations, they carried regular news programs as well.

 

Radio news programs consisted of a series of announcements aired either every half-hour or every hour. Toward the evening, the news of the day was discussed by some panelists over a longer talk show-type of program. The broadcast news had to be approved by the DPI, and the discussions always had to end on an optimistic note about the New Society. Television news programs were just as restricted, especially during the early months of martial law.

 

When the news programs returned to the air in Oct 1972, a number of radio commentators like Rey Langit resumed their broadcast activities. DWWW, a crony-owned AM station of KBS, began to air in 1974, which had new recruits Johnny de Leon, Rod Navarro, Noli de Castro, and Vic Morales.

 

The first of the regular evening television news programs was The DPI Reports, hosted by Bong Lapira. As its title suggested, the news announced on this program were provided by the DPI itself. Aired right after The DPI Reports was Pulong-Pulong sa Kaunlaran (Public Forum for Development), a discussion about the accomplishments of the New Society. The panelists spoke positively about the government and its officials. Both programs, however, were eventually scrapped, and the DPI concentrated its dissemination of the news through the regular news programs of the radio and television stations currently operating.

 

When RBS-DZBB Channel 7 and RMN-IBC Channel 13 were allowed to resume broadcasting, they were required, together with KBS-RPN, to broadcast The DPI Reports and Pulong-Pulong sa Kaunlaran. This simulcast compelled television audiences to watch these programs, there being no other shows at those hours. In due time, KBS-RPN was allowed to resume its pre-martial law era news program NewsWatch with veteran news anchor Harry Gasser as its principal newscaster, assisted by newscasters Babes Romualdez and Frankie Abao. Ninez Cacho-Olivarez later joined the group. Gasser used to be the news anchor on the RMN-IBC evening news program Vigilantes before he joined KBS-RPN. Babes Romualdez later went by the name Babe Romualdez. RBS-DZBB Channel 7 and RMN-IBC 13 were also allowed to broadcast their own news programs. Antonio Zorilla was the principal newscaster of News at Seven on Channel 7, later anchored by Bong Lapira, Jose Mari Velez, Tina Monzon-Palma, and weatherman Amado Pineda, with Jun Bautista as one of its most reliable field reporters. The newscasters at News at Seven tried to copy the trend of some television news anchors in the United States to “personalize” the news by adding some commentaries. The practice was discontinued soon afterward. Francisco “Frankie” Evangelista Jr and Bingo Lacson were the news anchors of Newsday on IBC 13.

 

When BBC went on the air in 1973, it introduced BBC Balita, the first primetime news program in Filipino after the declaration of martial law, anchored by Lee Andres and Paul Lacanilao; it would later be given a new title, Balita Ngayon (News Today), which would become the only news program in Filipino until the launch of TV Patrol, ABS-CBN, in 1987 following the ouster of Marcos. MBS Channel 4 came out with Newscenter 4. Its opening theme was lifted from the Hollywood motion picture Battlestar Galactica. Veteran broadcast journalist Lito Gorospe was the news anchor. Another GTV 4 news program was News Today with Joe Sobrino, Romy Sager, and Betsy Enriquez, later joined by other hosts, including Bon Vibar. By that time, KBS-RPN 9 came out with an innovation and decided to broadcast two editions of NewsWatch: the evening edition at 7:00 pm and the final edition at 10:00 pm, hosted in pair and alternately by Harry Gasser, Caloy Prieto, Ernie Fresnido, Pat Lazaro, Cielo Villaluna, Cathy Santillan, and Eric Eloriaga. NewsWatch made innovations by adding in to its programming the weekly NewsWatch: Junior Edition, 1976-93, with children reading the news or talking about the issues of the day in a freewheeling discussion portion presided over by producer Agnes Caballa. Children newscasters of the early versions of the program included Janice de Belen and Cathy Babao.

 

The old pre-martial law era television talk show Meet the Press, produced by the National Press Club, was likewise back in business. Its main competitor was Face the Nation, which went on the air via MBS Channel 4. Public affairs news programs of similar orientation came out, such as Julie Yap Daza’s Tell the People on KBS-RPN 9 and Ricardo “Dong” Puno Jr’s Viewpoint on GMA 7.

 

To state the obvious, the news on all broadcast channels was subjected to strict censorship. As expected, they were not allowed to criticize the Marcos administration. The stations concerned broadcast stories provided by the DPI itself, or air stories from their own news department provided that the stories were first cleared by a representative of the DPI who held office inside the station itself. All news about the activities of the political opposition was absolutely forbidden on the air. Paid advertisements or announcements relating to their activities were likewise prohibited. Media personalities who dared disobey these prohibitions faced indefinite detention in a military stockade.

 

Personalities identified with the political opposition were not allowed to go on the air. To avoid incurring the anger of the government, broadcasters refrained from inviting personalities from the political opposition to their programs. One sure way of avoiding trouble was to focus on what Mrs Marcos referred to as “the true, the good and the beautiful” in the sense that the martial law government perceived these to be.

 

In 1978, many radio and television personalities did just that. They went out of their way to openly support the administration candidates who were running for seats in the interim Batasang Pambansa under the Kilusang Bagong Lipunan ticket.

 

Like every general rule, there were a few noted exceptions. In Apr 1978, Rosario “Charito” Planas, a sworn Marcos foe, denounced, on live radio, the fraud allegedly committed by Marcos supporters in the elections for seats in the interim Batasang Pambansa in the national capital region. Planas was one of those who ran with political opposition leader Benigno “Ninoy” Aquino Jr under the Lakas ng Bayan (Laban) ticket in that ill-fated election.

 

Sometime toward the end of 1985, Ricardo “Dong” Puno Jr interviewed Salvador “Doy” Laurel, a former senator and Marcos critic who announced that he was ready to run against Marcos if a special election were to be called in 1986. Although Laurel refrained from using below-the-belt lines against Marcos while on television, Laurel criticized Marcos in categorical terms. Fortunately for Puno, his program was not axed either by the station’s management or by Malacañan. Perhaps, with a presidential election in the horizon, it would not have looked good for the administration to order the closure of a television program simply because its host interviewed a potential opponent of Pres Marcos in that election.

 

Charity shows were the trend in public service programs, which were aired in the late afternoon. The most popular were Mr. Public Service, hosted by Tony Santos Sr; Damayan (Helping One Another), revived in 1976, GTV 4, with film actor Rosal Rosal calling on various organizations to help alleviate the plight of indigent people going to the program to seek help; and Kapwa Ko, Mahal Ko (My Dear Fellow), 1974, GMA 7, with Orly Mercado, Boots Anson-Roa, Cielito del Mundo, and kidney specialist Dr Antonio Talusan helping those who need medical attention, reuniting estranged siblings, and mending broken families. Kapwa Ko, Mahal Ko is the first program to feature volunteer sign-language interpreters from the Philippine School for the Deaf on a portion of the TV monitor. On radio, DZRH launched the program Operation Tulong (Operation Assistance), 1979, which aired from midnight until 2:00 am and hosted by Manny Calpito, who conducted interviews on air and assisted the homeless, taxi drivers, people in need of medical care, and those who needed all sorts of immediate help. Financial and other forms of support came from the listeners, not from government and corporations.

 

Sometime in the late 1970s, GTV 4 aired Sambayanan (The Nation), a government-produced morning talk show aired every day from 11:00 am to 1:00 pm, hosted by Ed Tipton. The program’s significance lay not in its content, which obviously carried government’s point of view on several issues discussed in the program, but in its attempt to introduce a talk program in a time slot dominated by soap and variety programs. The 11:00-11:30 am programming during the period was mainly devoted to daily drama soaps, the 11:30-12:00 noon programming to news or variety programs, and the 12:00-1:00 pm schedule to variety programs. Sambayanan’s airing on this time slot would serve as a precursor of later light talk shows in the same time slot during the post-Marcos period.

 

Television stations in Cebu in the Visayas during the late 1970s and early 1980s were anchored on Manila stations. The programming was “made in Manila,” as Cebuanos put it. Features and news followed the slant of the Office of Media Affairs. Radio stations on both the AM and FM bands include DYRC, DYHP, DYGB, DYFM, and DYBU. These stations were financed reportedly by businessmen from Manila. DYLA is owned by the Associated Labor Union of the Trade Union Congress of the Philippines. Blocktimers on radio were a potent presence during the period, the most popular of which was DYLA’s talk and public affairs program Saksak Sinagol (Pound, Push, and Mix), hosted by lawyers Miguel “Migs” Enriquez and Vic Villordon, with a huge listenership base in Cebu, Bohol, Samar, Leyte, Northern and Western Mindanao, Negros Oriental, and the Cebuano-speaking areas of Negros Occidental (Espina-Moore 1983).

Civil society organizations began creeping into mainstream broadcast during the latter days of the Marcos dictatorship. Radyo Womanwatch (Womanwatch on Radio), produced by activist women belonging to Women in Media Now, began airing in 1985 on DZSR Sports Radio, and became one of the launching pads of discussions of women’s issues. A television version was produced after the ouster of Marcos, and the radio version moved to different stations.

 

The extent of television news censorship under martial law was realized by the people in two milestones in Philippine broadcast media history—namely, the Mar 1978 televised interview of political opposition leader Benigno “Ninoy” Aquino Jr and the coverage of his assassination and funeral in Aug 1983.

 

To repeat, elections for seats in the interim Batasang Pambansa were set for Apr 1978. Aquino, a former senator incarcerated at Fort Bonifacio and the nemesis of martial law, declared his intention to run. He lamented that while he was allowed to go home to Quezon City for a few days, he was not given enough freedom to reach out to the people. The government responded with an offer to get Aquino interviewed by a panel of journalists on the evening talk show program Face the Nation on GTV 4. Aquino agreed, provided that the interview would be broadcast live. The government took a chance, and Aquino was interviewed live at Fort Bonifacio on the evening of 10 Mar 1978. It was a decision the government regretted. Aquino mesmerized the audience and underscored the faults and abuses of the Marcos administration. For the first time in years, somebody was openly criticizing Pres Marcos and his martial law regime. People who had never even heard of Aquino, much less heard him speak, experienced a televised ringside seat to a litany of the sins of the dictatorship.

The government tried to take remedial measures by airing an edited version of the interview the next day. To those who were able to watch the interview live on television, the edited version only reminded them of the freedom of expression the martial law administration had been denying them since Sep 1972.

 

The coverage of the Aquino assassination is another sad chapter in the history of press freedom in the Philippines. After a three-year exile abroad, the most famous political opposition leader of the country arrived at the Manila International Airport on 21 Aug 1983. Right after touchdown, Aquino was escorted out of the plane by a squad of soldiers assigned to protect him. Seconds after leaving the plane, Aquino was shot in the head at the tarmac, in broad daylight. His funeral was a national event, and the funeral procession was a pilgrimage joined by millions. The last time a funeral procession attracted multitudes of grieving Filipinos was that of Pres Ramon Magsaysay, who died in a plane crash in 1957.

 

Despite the national significance of the event, no radio or television station gave detailed coverage of the assassination, its aftermath, and the funeral procession. No actual footage of the shooting of Aquino while descending from the plane was ever made public; either there was none taken or any footage taken was not made available to or by the media. Horacio Paredes reports in a Mr. & Ms. article: “Fifteen maintenance men, 106 co-passengers, 10 AVSECOM (Aviation Security Command) soldiers on the ground, four soldiers coming down the ramp and at least two plainclothesmen on the upper landing of the ramp, a television camera crew, all are in positions to see a lot yet not one says he saw anything. Perhaps, now that it is established that the civilians saw nothing, the public awaits the testimony of the military witnesses” (Espina-Moore 1983, 9). Fifteen media men covered Aquino’s trip home. Among them were reporters of Time and Asiaweek, and radio and TV crew of the American Broadcasting Corporation (ABC), the Nippon Hoso Kyokai (NHK)–Japan Broadcasting Network, and the Tokyo Broadcasting System (TBS). Aquino’s brother-in-law Ken Kashiwahara of ABC, then on leave, was traveling with Aquino.

 

With no available footage of the actual shooting, people resorted to reproducing NHK, JBS, and TBS Betamax tapes of the assassination and other sources of photographs and TV footage, which were distributed and circulated clandestinely. Local commercial media, especially the broadcast networks, were no longer considered the site of reliable news. The search for the truth was played out elsewhere, this time mainly on Betamax units at home and in offices. The duplication and circulation in domestic private spaces of any available footage published or broadcast in foreign media networks proved to be the most reliable source of news about the Aquino assassination. The people found creative ways to feed their thirst for the truth in spaces that they had managed to keep from the reach or radar of the government and the military. Interestingly, Betamax video tapes in the late 1970s were mainly used by the gossip mill in circulating footage of men and women actors engaged in unseemly acts. The Betamax, however, also proved to be the most accessible and effective route in circulating images, mostly from international sources, of the assassination of Ninoy.

 

A few networks dared to cover the event. DZRV-Radio Veritas was the only radio station that provided a blow-by-blow account of Ninoy Aquino’s arrival, with its correspondent annotating the events through a pay phone. Radio Veritas and other radio stations attempted to cover the 10-hour funeral procession of the slain senator, attended by two million sympathizers, but their frequencies were jammed. GMA 7 was just daring enough to devote a limited time of its primetime news to the funeral procession; testimonies state that the on-air coverage ran for only eight seconds. The talk show Two for the Road, known for glamour and glitz, also had the courage to feature a 15-minute tribute to the slain hero, including footage of the funeral.

Many citizens in the predominantly Catholic nation took DZRV’s stance as indicative of the Catholic clergy’s increasing displeasure with Marcos. For many, it was also their cue to begin taking an oppositional stand.

 

The changed situation encouraged radio commentators in several AM stations to view more critically the unfolding events that would lead to the end of Marcos’s rule. As the political opposition mounted street protests and launched civil disobedience campaigns that had the public boycott the crony press among other things, some radio stations braved the government restrictions that were still in effect and covered and commented on the escalating opposition to Marcos.

Provincial radio was also beginning to stir. One of the feistiest commentators in Cebu, for example, Inday Nita Cortes-Daluz, was detained by the military for covering a march staged by the political opposition in Cebu, but resumed her political commentary on the air as soon as she was released.

 

Variety Programs and Game Shows

Variety programs were plentiful during the martial law period, which were a mix of musical numbers and interviews with personalities; some had segments on games or contests usually promoted by commercial sponsors.

 

Many AM radio stations were also programmed for music, aside from news and drama. One of the top AM music stations during the period was DWBL, which had Rudolph Rivera, Willy Inong, and Mike Enriquez, who would become a popular news anchor on GMA 7 in the 1990s. DWKW had Bambi Fonacier, Bingo Lacson, Helen Vela, Vic Salta, Howard Medina (aka Long Tall Howard), and Robert D’Lion. DZRJ-AM “Boss Radio,” owned by Ramon Jacinto and which would become Radyo Bandido during the EDSA Revolt, focused on rock music, which earned for the station its monicker “The Rock of Manila.” Popular DZRJ programs included the daily show Pinoy Rock ’n’ Rhythm, hosted by Bob Posas (aka Bob Magoo) and later by Dante David (aka Howlin’ Dave). The show featured the early vinyl releases of pioneering Filipino rock music groups, such as RJ and the Riots, Juan de la Cruz Band, Anak Bayan, Maria Cafra, Petrified Anthem, and Destiny. Its midnight show, The Rock ’n’ Roll Machine, followed the cross-genre, album-oriented format. Its early morning program opened with Howlin’ Dave’s voice announcing “Gising na, RJ na!” (Wake up, it’s RJ time!).

 

On television, the noontime show Student Canteen, with mainstays Eddie Ilarde, Bobby Ledesma, minus Pepe Pimentel, but with new addition Helen Vela and later Coney Reyes, was relaunched on GMA 7 in 1975. “IQ Seven,” a quiz show for university students, was one of Student Canteen’s most popular Saturday segments. Independent company Television and Production Exponents (TAPE), headed by Romy Jalosjos, launched Eat Bulaga! (Lunchtime Peek-a-Boo!) on RPN 9 in Jul 1979, with Tito, Vic, and Joey, who were formerly provided employment by Ledesma through GMA’s weekly dance show Discorama. Eat Bulaga! would eventually unseat Student Canteen from its hold of the daily noontime programming, particularly when RPN 9 switched to domestic satellite (DOMSAT) broadcast, which provided nationwide live coverage of the program, highlighted by the transfer of Coney Reyes to Eat Bulaga! in 1982. Eat Bulaga! launched the career of many child stars, such as Aiza Seguerra, a runner-up in the program’s “Miss Little Philippines” in the 1980s, and Ryzza Mae Dizon, a winner of the same child beauty contest in the 2010s.

 

A phenomenon of the variety program genre of the period was advertising personality Ariel Ureta. He captured the hearts of the Filipino audience as the witty and well-dressed host. The mustached funnyman started with a noontime show called 12 O’Clock High on BBC 2, then moved from one station to another. From Noontime Matinee and For the Boys on IBC 13, Ureta moved back to BBC 2 with Ariel con Tina, which ended when co-host Tina Revilla started disappearing to do movies. He conceptualized and hosted the early-evening variety show Ariel & Co. After Six, BBC 2, with a child co-host, then child superstar Niño Muhlach, and guest appearances by pretty female co-hosts. Ureta also had The Morning Show, GTV 4, co-hosted by Merce Henares, which was a pioneer of daily morning talk-magazine programs. There is an account of Ureta supposedly mocking the New Society slogan “Sa ikauunlad ng bayan, disiplina ang kailangan” with his own “Sa ikauunlad ng bayan, bisikleta ang kailangan” (For the country to progress, bicycle is necessary). Rumors at that time had it that Ureta was arrested, taken to Camp Crame, and ordered to ride a bicycle around the camp while shouting the government slogan in its correct text. In recent years, Ureta denied having made that comical version of the New Society slogan.

 

Nora Aunor thrilled her fans with the weekly musical show Superstar, 1971-89, RPN 9. The Salvador family, led by Lou Salvador Sr, was all over the place in Showbiz with the Salvadors, with one of his sons, Leroy, heading the program. Joe Quirino, considered the Ed Sullivan of the Philippines, hosted the musical variety-talk show Seeing Stars with JQ, 1975-86, IBC 13.

 

Entertainment variety programs that focused more on featuring upcoming teen stars include Big Ike’s Happening, BBC 2, by star manager Ike Lozada, and Germside, 1978, GMA 7, later retitled Germspesyal, then GMA Supershow by star builder German Moreno. The teen variety show Apat na Sikat (The Famous Four), RPN 9, featured popular young stars Arnold Gamboa, Maribel Aunor, Dondon Nakar, and Winnie Santos. These programs were the precursor of teen variety shows that were produced after the fall of Marcos that capitalized on young stars’ ambition to make it big in show business but eventually became a sort of training school for these young talents, such as That’s Entertainment, 1986-96, by German Moreno on GMA, and Ang TV (The TV), 1992-97, and Flames, 1996-2002, on ABS-CBN.

 

A new game show patterned after the American was developed into Spin-a-Win, RPN 9, with Jeanne Young. A matchmaking game show, Rhoda and Me, 1975-78, GTV 4, hosted by Joey Lardizabal, later replaced by Ronald Remy, and a charming female computer called Rhoda, gained popularity among audiences and critics alike, and which became the model for the 1990s show It’s a Date by Plinky Recto. Pepe Pimentel’s Kuarta o Kahon, revived on BBC 2, was one of the most popular in its genre. Also on BBC 2 were Game na Game (Really Game), which had kiddie host Janice de Belen and adult co-hosts Bambi Arambulo, Willie Nepomuceno, and George Javier, and Everybody Wins, hosted by Inday Badiday, Eddie Ilagan, Ike Lozada, Elizabeth Ramsey, Oscar Obligacion, Sylvia La Torre, Ed Finlan, Jeanne Young, and rock star Sampaguita. GMA 7 had Suerte sa Siete (Lucky at Seven), with Eddie Ilarde and Helen Vela. IBC 13 had The New Lucky 13 Show, hosted by Ronald Remy. GTV 4 had the quiz show Pamantayan ng Talino (Standard of Intelligence).

 

Talent search shows, which can be classified as a mix of game and variety show, reemerged, such as the singing competition program Ang Bagong Kampeon (The New Champion), 1985-88, hosted by Pilita Corrales and Bert “Tawa” Marcelo, which discovered the likes of Regine Velasquez and Donna Cruz; the program was a remake of Tawag ng Tanghalan (Call of the Stage) of the 1960s. The search for musical talents was also the aim of Tanghalan ng Musika (Musical Stage), 1979, IBC 13, hosted by Eddie Mercado, Emma Yuhuico, and Gary Bautista.

 

Dance and Music Programs

 

Dance programs were similarly remade, such as The Nida-Lita Show on RPN 9, featuring Nida Blanca and Lita Gutierrez, patterned after The Nestor-Nida Show of the 1960s. GMA 7 produced Discorama, hosted by Bobby Ledesma and the Apo Hiking Society, with a DJ segment for Loren Legarda, who was still then a broadcast communication student; they were later joined by the comedic trio of Tito, Vic, and Joey, and Penthouse Seven, a remake of the pre-martial law Dancetime with Chito, with new host Archie Lacson and dancers Mike Monserrat, Joannie Feliciano, Ray-An Fuentes, Sandy Hontiveros, Ida Ramos, and Poncy Quirino. The Penthouse Seven sequel, Penthouse Live, GMA 7, brought together young star Pops Fernandez and balladeer Martin Nievera. Other dance variety programs were 2-Night, hosted by Mike Monserrat and Becca Godinez, and Oddysey 2, hosted by Bambi Fonacier, both on BBC 2.

 

These shows and other entertainment programs that strove for quality production, while very good or excellent in terms of broadcast production values, have often been criticized for their promotion of a kind of entertainment that glorifies the fads and frills of an opulent life in a time of political decadence. The programs, critics argue, tended to deflect attention from the poverty and the stark social realities of the period.

 

Music programs that were more oriented toward the classics and the so-called traditional music include Concert at the Park, the regular Sunday concert at the Luneta Park open air auditorium hosted by Tina Monzon-Palma; Rondalla sa Telebisyon, hosted by Bert Buena, and Return Engagement, both on GTV 4. Another important program, Sunday, Sweet Sunday, which began airing in 1969, was revived after the declaration of martial law, and ran until 1974. The program, which brought opera and Broadway musicals to a wider audience, featured and was hosted by librettist and coloratura soprano Fides Cuyugan-Asensio. Major accomplishments in independent broadcast production were Aawitan Kita (I Shall Sing for You), produced by Armida Siguion-Reyna, which began airing in 1970 and was occasionally broadcast until 2005, and the musical special At Long Last, Celeste!, produced by Circus Band member Richard Tan and directed by Fritz Ynfante.

 

Aawitan Kita, which moved from one television network to another in its 35 years of broadcast existence, showcases the rich musical tradition and heritage of the Philippines, specifically Filipino classic love songs, such as the Tagalog kundiman, the Visayan balitaw, and Filipino music from different regions of the country. The program, hosted by Siguion-Reyna herself, featured singers Robert Natividad, Ric Manrique Jr, Diomedes Maturan, Ruben Tagalog, the Mabuhay Singers, and later Lirio Vital, Leo Valdez, Bimbo Cerrudo, Richard Reynoso, Carla Martinez, and Cris Villongco. Siguion-Reyna, the sister of martial law defense minister Enrile, also sings popular kundiman in the program. The program used to air on late nights, but was transferred to an earlier time slot following a directive by then KBP chair Teodoro Valencia to air cultural and educational programs in the 7:30-8:00 pm time slot immediately after the news programs, which were programmed at 7:00 pm. Critics remarked that on the one hand the episodes are “gloriously photographed, the music lushly orchestrated,” but on the other, that the show is “simply an exercise in vanity” (Sioson-San Juan 1999, 139). Ultimately, however, Aawitan Kita undoubtedly promoted an aspect of Philippine culture through the broadcast medium that has always been described as a vast wasteland.

 

At Long Last, Celeste! starred singer Celeste Legaspi, then the young lead of the singing group The Ambivalent Crowd. Ynfante, who was then making a name as a director of music programs on television, developed a concept for Celeste. He said that “the musical is a story of a new star on her concert night” (del Mundo 2003, 23). The show includes backstage scenes with Joonee Gamboa as a reporter, hounding the new star for an interview. Ryan Cayabyab, then a rising young music composer, was tapped to do the musical direction. The special was taped over a three-day period at the Meralco Theater with all the huge and unwieldy camera equipment. Celeste did mostly American tunes, like a medley of Cole Porter, and capped the show with “A Corner of the Sky.” Ballet Philippines, with choreographer Alice Reyes, provided the dance numbers.

 

Noteworthy directors of musical variety programs were Mitos Villareal, choreographer Al Quinn, and Fritz Ynfante. Villareal’s TV productions became synonymous with elegance “in which the music and the songs were the stars” (Sioson-San Juan 1999, 132). Quinn’s productions were visually stunning but the extravagance never upstages the stars. Ynfante’s works were “marked by an extravagance that draws inspiration from Broadway and the world of big musicals” and “a party where only the most beautiful people got invited” (Sioson-San Juan 1999, 138).

 

The rise in the number of entertainment programs and cultural shows on television reflected the ironies and contradictions of the times. From the point of view of propaganda, perhaps it was cunning of the Marcos regime to allow the development of cultural programs, even of some that bordered on the political, which was more obvious in Philippine cinema. This openness announced to the world that the regime was also supportive of cultural programs that were independently produced and innovative in approach.

 

Comedy Shows

 

New locally produced television programs appeared during the martial law period. These include situation comedies that focused on family life, like My Son, My Son, which starred Chichay, Jay Ilagan, Patsy, and Tange, RPN 9; Problema Mo Na ’Yan (That’s Your Problem), which starred Leopoldo Salcedo and Bentot; Ang Biyenan Kong Mangkukulam (My Witch In-Law), a local version of the US television program Bewitched and which featured Pancho Magalona; ’Yan ang Misis Ko (That’s My Wife), with Ronald Remy and Rosal Rosal as mainstays; Wala Kang Paki (None of Your Business), with Nida Blanca; Mommy Ko si Mayor (The Mayor Is My Mom), featuring Gloria Sevilla, Amado Cortez, and the Ranillo siblings Suzette, Mat, Dandin, and Lilibeth; and Apartment 153-A, written and directed by Ading Fernando and which starred Panchito as an oldie bachelor who always gets into funny situations. In spite of the relatively high number of comedy programs, the plot of these comedies is practically the same: someone makes a mistake, the error puts the characters in unexpected situations, the mistake is discovered at the end, and the characters patch things up. Others resorted to making fun of physical attributes, peppered with a dose of gay bashing or sexist jokes, like Chicks to Chicks, 1984, IBC 13, written by Ipe Pelino, directed by Johnny Manahan, with mainstays Nova Villa, Freddie Webb, Chuchi, Chito Arceo, Strawberry, Sammy Lagmay, and sexy women characters played by Carmi Martin and beauty queens Lorraine Schuck, Bong Dimayacyac, and Maria Teresa Carlson, who would become famous for her “Si ikaw, si ako” (You, me) lines. Duplex, 1982-84, RPN 9, stands out among the sitcoms, which is about a dysfunctional family, written and directed by Ading Fernando and starring Fernando himself, Marissa Delgado, Dely Atay-atayan, Al Tantay, Bernardo Bernardo, Soxy Topacio, beauty queen Anna Lorraine Kier, and Janice Jurado whose character “Liweng” as the beautiful yet dumb house helper became popular. Duplex had good narratives but would sometimes poke fun at people’s deformities.

 

Relevant sitcoms were produced in the mid-1970s and early 1980s. Baltic & Co., 1974-76, GMA 7, based on the comic strip created by Roni Santiago, is about a hot-headed boss named Baltic and the daily concerns of his employees. Nanding Flores, the original Mr Baltic, was replaced by Prospero Luna when Flores passed away in 1975, and later played by Bert Tawa Marcelo. The classic pre-martial law Juan Tamad character was resurrected on TV as Juan Tamad (Lazy Juan), 1979, GTV 4, and starred Manuel Conde as the legendary lazybone hero who is a caricature of the Filipino, with Gloria Romero and Aurora Salve. Prinsipe Abante (Prince Abante), 1979, GMA 7, directed by Ading Fernando and featuring Bert Marcelo, Tina Revilla, Dely Atay-atayan, Gene Palomo, and Prospero Luna, is a modern spoof of Prinsipe Amante (Prince Amante), a komiks serial by Mario del Mar in the 1950s and adapted into a radio play by Clodualdo del Mundo Sr. Two Plus Two, 1982, BBC 2, with Vic Sotto, Dina Bonnevie, their daughter Danica who was then a toddler, Chichay, Maricel Soriano, William Martinez, Gary Lising, and Herbert Bautista, whose character “Bistek” originated from this show, deals with the daily concerns of a young middle-class couple. The daily sitcom Cafeteria Aroma, 1982, GMA 7, is about a job placement bureau and a talent agency operated by Apeng Daldal and the different characters’ search for ideals shattered by the difficulties of landing the right job. It was conceptualized and starred by Apeng Daldal, produced by Ben S. Fernandez, written by Naning Estrella, aka Lukas Pakaskas of Balitang Kutsero (Coachman’s News) during pre-martial law, directed by Arjel Joseph, and featuring comedians Brother Manok, Miniong Villegas, and a former Cultural Center of the Philippines dancer named Johnson. An interesting sitcom produced during the waning years of the Marcos administration until the early years of the post-EDSA period was U.F.O.: Urbana, Felisa, and Others, 1984-89, GMA 7, directed by Jose Javier Reyes and featuring Mitch Valdes, Ariel Ureta, Francis Magalona, and Lou Veloso, whose character Mang Truman was introduced in the program.

 

Two sitcoms became extremely popular during the period. Iskul Bukol (School Bumps), 1977-90, IBC 13, written by Bibeth Orteza, spoofed a bunch of lazy, ambition-less students making fun of people around them. The slapstick featured the comedic trio of Tito, Vic, and Joey whose triumvirate would become a phenomenon during the martial law years and a powerful launching pad for the political career of Tito Sotto. A rival program was put up by RPN, Coed Fever, premiered in 1979, scripted and directed by Rico Flores and starring the Apo Hiking Society and Maya (now Mitch) Valdez, about zany situations in a boarding house of college students, but the effort failed to dent the audience share of Iskul Bukol.

 

The sitcom that ruled the ratings and became one of the longest-running comedy programs was the weekly John en Marsha, 1973-90, RPN 9, created by musician-writer-director Ading Fernando. It featured the poor man John Puruntong (played by Dolphy), his rich wife Marsha (Nida Blanca), their children Shirley (Maricel Soriano) and Rolly (Rolly Quizon), Shirley’s suitor Isko (Isko Salvador), the overweight, very rich mother-in-law of John, Doña Delilah (Dely Atay-atayan), and Delilah’s helper and sidekick Matutina (Evelyn Bontogon). Each episode of the program ended with Doña Delilah screaming her advice to her financially challenged son-in-law, “Kaya ikaw, John, magsumikap ka!” (So you, John, try even harder!), which became a household catchphrase.

 

Lumbera (1975) comments that the caricature of economically poor Filipinos as lazy or not industrious enough to make both ends meet, particularly in the case of John Puruntong, discounts institutional and structural deficiencies in Philippine society that render them poor in the first place, almost always barred from opportunities to rise above their conditions, and only shifts the blame on fate and the individual rather than on the responsibility of the government to provide the citizens with basic social services.

 

Three gag shows also became popular. T.O.D.A.S., 1977-89, IBC 13, starring Joey de Leon, Val Sotto, Richie D’Horsey, Maribeth Bichara, Frieda Fonda, and Jimmy Santos, made fun of popular personalities, spoofed commercial advertisements, and popularized the “knock-knock” and “use in a sentence” jokes, but was highly criticized for its toilet humor and sexual innuendos. The show that attracted the higher end of TV audiences was the social commentary-cum-gag show Champoy, 1975-85, first on GTV 4 then moved to RPN 9 only after a few weeks. It was conceptualized by advertising men Noel Trinidad and Subas Herrero. Inspired by the Oliver Hardy and Stan Laurel image on the champoy wrapper, “fat” Herrero and “thin” Trinidad worked with a new group composed of Peque Gallaga, Gary Lising, Tessie Tomas, and Mitch Valdes, who would soon make their respective marks on television, film, and theater. Another relevant comedy is “Doña Buding,” a stand-up gag segment of the live weekly musical variety program Penthouse Live, GMA 7, which featured members, or imaged as members, of the middle class or those aspiring middle-class status. The program’s audiences cut across all social classes. “Doña Buding,” played by Nanette Inventor, ridicules the sensibilities, illusions, and delusions of the middle class, the high society, and the filthy rich.

 

Some comedy programs portray women as sex objects or as stupid and silly persons, like the women characters of Chicks to Chicks and the character of “Liweng” in Duplex, who are often seen wearing clothes with plunging necklines, or in shorts, bikinis, or micromini skirts to highlight their physical charms and delectable body, or unable to comprehend the simple situations in which they find themselves. Being an unmarried woman is a source of laughter for the character Miss Tapia in Iskul Bukol, or being a loud mouth, like that of Matutina in John en Marsha. Sexist jokes permeate Chicks to Chicks and most gag skits in T.O.D.A.S. Physical attributes of men and women, like the shape of one’s body, the color of one’s skin, or any physical deformity, are the butt of jokes in Duplex and T.O.D.A.S., even in family-oriented comedies like My Son, My Son, John en Marsha, and Cafeteria Aroma.

 

Programs for Children

Local children’s shows were more entertainment in orientation, and had themes that revolved around discipline, cooperation, and the nationalism of the New Society. Imee Marcos produced Kaluskos Musmos (Kiddie Noise), 1979-89, RPN 9, about children’s fantasies and pranks and kiddie newscasts, directed by Johnny Manahan, with a cast of children headed by Maricel Soriano, Herbert Bautista, Dranreb Belleza, Princess Aquino, Maila Gumila, Siegfried Garcia, and Sharon Manabat, with adult mainstays Bert Marcelo, Gary Lising, Chichay, and Estrella Kuenzler. Its writers, considered the best in the genre, included Ading Fernando, George Javier, Gary Lising, and later cartoonist Nonoy Marcelo and theater and film director Dindo Angeles. BBC 2 produced Kuskos Balungos (Just Making Noise), 1980-82, and absorbed the senior children in the cast of Kaluskos who “graduated” from the show, such as Soriano, Bautista, Gumila, Garcia, and Manabat, and added children Jose Mari Samson and Ronald Daguio, and later teen idol William Martinez. Kuskos Balungos, written by Raffy Oyales, Domingo Landicho, Rowie Morales, and Ed Morales, followed the format of Kaluskos. RPN 9 also produced The New Raffle Gang, 1979, hosted by Rina Reyes, Michael Uytengsu, Dolly Carvajal, who would become a movie columnist like mother Inday Badiday, and Andre Castillo, who would become part of the music group The Company. GMA 7 had Uncle Bob’s Lucky 7 Club, 1976-92, and Telebong, Telebong, Telebong, 1979, hosted by Willie Nepomuceno. GTV 4 had Aliwan ng mga Bata (Children’s Pastime) in the 1970s, produced by the Bureau of Public Schools. IBC 13 had Communicating with Wilma, also in the 1970s, hosted by Wilma Cruz Tapalla, on learning with kids, and Kulit Bulilit (Curious Children), 1982-88, another program produced by Imee Marcos similar to Kuskos and Kaluskos, written by Edna Mae Landicho and Ed Morales. In 1984, the Philippine Sesame Street Project came up with the educational show Sesame, 30 minutes of which is from the original Sesame Street and the remaining 30 minutes a Filipinized version, which introduced local muppets Kiko Matsing and Pong Pagong.

 

Magazine Programs and Entertainment Talk Shows

 

Magazine programs and talk shows of the period, even if promoted as informative, served more as entertainment than a platform for serious discussions. A pioneer of the daily morning talk show was the pre-martial law news-magazine program The Morning Show, which was revived during martial law as Good Morning, Manila, GTV 4, hosted by Ariel Ureta and Merce Henares, later replaced by Baby O’Brien, and introduced Bibeth Orteza, who took advantage, in a positive note, of her heavy Ilonggo accent for her character in the program named Bibeth Bisaya. The show featured personalities, the weather, sports, and other cultural facts, but less news. Another pioneer of the daily early morning talk show was Coffee with Lee, 1976, BBC 2, 8:00-9:00 am, hosted by Lee Andres and Noel Trinidad.

 

An excellent magazine program beginning in the mid-1970s was Metro Magazine, a combination of talk, travelogue, and mini-documentaries, produced by Imelda Marcos’s Metro Manila Commission. An episode was broadcast daily, each on a different day and time on each of all the five Metro Manila TV channels. Early hosts were Ariel Ureta and Jaime Fabregas.

 

A popular late-night talk program that was revived during martial law was Two for the Road, GMA 7, hosted by Elvira Manahan, co-hosted this time by Nestor Torre, and directed by Maria Montelibano. Ms. Ellaneous, 1977, GMA 7, a talk magazine show with Ma-an Hontiveros, Tina Revilla, and Yogi Dominguez, presented a new image of the Filipina. Other talk programs were The Late Hour with June and Johnny, GMA 7, with June Keithley and Johnny Litton; Something with Pilita, 1978, IBC 13, directed by Manolo Brion, where hosts Pilita Corrales and Eddie Mercado roast the program’s guests, with pro-Marcos newspaper columnist Teodoro Valencia as one of their first “victims;” and Celebrity, 1979, GTV 4, hosted by basketball star Robert Jaworski and theater artist Joy Virata.

 

A prominent but often maligned television entertainment program host was Inday Badiday, whose movie talk shows on television Nothing but the Truth, 1976, followed by Would You Believe?, 1978, both on BBC 2, then See-True, 1979-87, on IBC 13 then on GMA, followed by two more shows after the EDSA Revolt, Eye-to-Eye, 1988, and The Truth and Nothing but the Truth, 2000, both on GMA, focused on showbiz gossips and controversies and featured a panel of movie reporters who queried invited stars who often lied in their answers. Guests were mostly superstars, soft-core porn actors, aging starlets, vulnerable young actors, and showbiz personalities eyeing public office. Her shows put on camera movie reporters who were then considered taboo on the air. These showbiz reporters include Lolit Solis, Cristy Fermin, Nap Gutierrez, Lulubelle Lam Ramos, Anselle Beluso, Aster Amoyo, Jun Nardo, and Eugene Asis, some of whom would later have their own radio and television talk shows or segments in popular broadcast entertainment programs. To acknowledge Nothing but the Truth’s sponsors, Inday would say, “Pasok, Noli” (Your turn, Noli), and the voice-over of Noli would enumerate the show’s sponsors; the voice was that of Noli de Castro, who would become vice president of the country. Inday Badiday simultaneously hosted the daily radio showbiz talk and counseling program Inday ng Buhay Ko (The Woman of My Life), DWWA, which she regularly ended with a piece of advice that referred to the insincere and hypocritical relationships common in the entertainment industry: “Bye for now. Mag-ingat sa mga taong hindi mo kilala; mas lalo kang mag-ingat sa mga taong kilala mo.” (Bye for now. Beware of people you don’t know, more so with people you already know.)

 

See-True was the most prominent movie talk show on television during the martial law period, gaining national prominence at a time when public affairs talk show on television was gaining ground, buoyed up by the political events of the period as a result of the 1983 assassination of Ninoy Aquino. Talk programs, specifically public affairs programs, before Aquino’s assassination were those sanctioned by the regime. After Aquino’s assassination, political talk programs began to go on the air, such as Viewpoint, 1984-94, GMA 7, hosted by Ricardo “Dong” Puno. It tackled national issues that captured the imagination of the restless middle class. These programs, according to Capino, became “a public ritual of interrogation and discussion, denial and confession” (2003, 263). Capino contends that Inday Badiday’s See-True reflected, unintentionally, the conduct of public affairs on television that relied on the spectacular and the lachrymose, and capitalized on the blurred distinctions between the public and the private, the vulgar and the sacred, the vicious and the virtuous, the political and the showbiz, the real and the fake, the truth and the lie. Both showbiz and politics lie. But, says Inday Badiday in an interview, “truth in showbiz is different from truth in politics. In showbiz, when a movie star tells a lie, it is entertaining. In politics, when a politician tells a lie, no matter how small, it can ruin the nation” (HRC 2005).

 

 

Drama Programs

 

Radio dramas during the martial law period were melodrama and fantasy stories. Most radio melodrama serials were produced by MBC’s DZRH, RPN’s DWWW, and RMN’s DZXL. Themes on radio dramas were usually about suffering as God’s test of individual faith, as reflected in Maja Vida (Pleasant Life) on DWWW; the poor are always blessed by God, as shown in Kasaysayan ni Aida Nuñez (Story of Aida Nuñez) and True Confessions on DZRH; the poor are always happy, as depicted in Pinagpala (Blessed) on DZRH; love is powerful, as exemplified in Kapantay ay Langit (As Hight as Heaven) on DWWW, Love Story on DZRH, and Di Ko Malilimot (I Will Never Forget), Alaala ng Isang Awit (Memory of a Song), and Hibik ng Puso (Lamentations of the Heart), all on DZXL; and happy endings await a faith-filled character, such as the return of the prodigal child, the return of the unfaithful husband, the punishment of the culprit, the spiritual rebirth of a bad character, and the reward of the faithful, as dramatized in Lumipas na Madaling Araw (Forgotten Morn) on DZXL, and Bukang-Liwayway sa Takipsilim (Dawn at Dusk) on DZRH.

 

One of the most popular radio productions was the fantasy-adventure drama serial Zimatar, written by Pedro Tiangco, which started its run in the 1970s and went on the air for two decades on DZRH. It is about a young prince searching for his lost mother and whose kingdom is threatened by a rival kingdom. The characters of Zimatar and his assistant Eng-eng were voiced by Eloisa Cruz-Canlas, while the character of Tagani was performed by Mike Perez, who replaced Ben David’s voice-over for the horror drama Gabi ng Lagim (Night of Terror). A hit melodrama that came out in 1973 and is still airing on DZRH is the daily soap Ito ang Palad Ko (This Is My Fate), directed by the husband-and-wife team of Jun Soler, aka Virgilio Garcia Jr, and Raquel Monteza, which features one complete story per day. Stories are usually above love and domestic issues. Some voice talents of the anthology are Rosanna Villegas, Leonel Benjamin, and Rashida Elba Abanco.

 

Prominent radio voice drama talents of the period are Tani Cruz, Greg Arnaldo, Luz Fernandez, and Mely Tagasa, the last two becoming popular on television and film. Other voice talents, some of whom also alternated as radio drama directors and most of whom are still active, are Tony Angeles, Vilma Borromeo, Nick de Guzman, Chiquit del Carmen-Amor, Jun Legaspi, and Susan Lemon. Sound designers include Froilan Malimban, Bobby Salonga, Eric Lucero, Manny Salas, and Froilan Villegas.

 

Philippine drama programs on television during the martial law period were weekly one-hour melodrama anthologies, followed later on by daily serials. Weekly dramas during the period relied less on good narrative than on the audience-drawing power of stars. The titles alone of weekly drama anthologies beginning in 1974 provide an indication of this phenomenon: Tina Revilla’s Christina, Vilma Santos’s Dulambuhay ni Rosa Vilma (Life Story of Rosa Vilma) directed by Mitos Villareal and Marcial Sanson, and Pinky de Leon’s Ito Ako, Pinky (This Is Me, Pinky) directed by Sanson, all on BBC 2; Tirso Cruz III’s Sila sa Buhay ni Tirso (They Who Are Part of Tirso’s Life) and Chat Silayan Drama Studio, 1981-86, both on GMA 7; Nora Aunor’s Ang Makulay na Daigdig ni Nora (The Colorful World of Nora), directed by Lupita Concio, on KBS-RPN 9; and Coney Reyes-Mumar Drama Studio, 1977-81 on GMA 7, then 1984-89 on RPN 9, directed by Mario O’Hara and Argel Joseph. Ang Makulay na Daigdig ni Nora and Coney Reyes-Mumar Drama Studio showed gems in some of their episodes. The heavy reliance on women actors in drama programs continued on to the post-EDSA years, this time with investments on the stars’ commercial packaging that included spinning drama on the real lives of the stars themselves to compensate for the lack of dramaturgy in their television drama programs.

 

The daily serialized drama on television during the martial law period was introduced in 1977, the first of which was Gulong ng Palad (Wheel of Fate), 1977-85, on BBC 2, followed by Mga Kuwento ng Pag-ibig (Stories of Love), RPN 9. Gulong ng Palad, reincarnated from the daily radio soap of the same title created by writer Lina Flor that aired on DZRH from 1949 to 1956, is a family drama that focuses on the travails of a young couple: Carding (Ronald Courveau), a loving yet philandering husband who comes from a rich family, and Luisa (Marianne de la Riva), a suffering and martyr wife who comes from a poor family and is always emotionally tormented by her cruel mother-in-law (Tita de Villa). The TV series was directed by Marcial Sanson and written by Lina Flor’s sister, Loida Viriña. It launched the career of child actor Romnick Sarmenta who played Peping in the program, and also starred Caridad Sanchez, Beth Bautista, Metring David, and Augusto Victa. In a 1978 survey, it garnered a 63.1 percent audience share, a feat rarely accomplished by any broadcast program.

 

The period also witnessed the stiff competition of two daily late afternoon soaps that each featured children. Flordeluna, 1979-84, RPN 9, also written by Loida Viriña, and alternately directed by Mario O’Hara, Leo Martinez, Benny Rivera, Orlando Nadres, Lorli Villanueva, and Tony Santos Sr, introduced child actor Janice de Belen who played the title role. Anna Liza, 1980-85, GMA 7, directed by Gil Soriano, starred Julie Vega.

Flordeluna, based on a radio drama written by Marcos Navarro Sacol, is about an 11-year-old girl from a middle-class family who tries to keep her family intact in the face of several trials they face, one of which is the meanness of her stepmother, played by Laurice Guillen. Flor’s father is a military man, played by Dindo Fernando. Flor is also tormented by her cruel stepgrandmother, Nyora Agueda, played by Carmen Enriquez. Anna Liza, on the other hand, is about the trials and tribulations of a poor young girl. Anna Liza is an abused child yet is civil and caring toward people whose lives she touches and changes in a positive way. The series ended when Vega died in 1985.

 

Some daily drama serials were aired in the morning, such as Damdamin (Feelings) and Nang Dahil sa Pag-ibig (Because of Love), both in the late 1970s and on GMA.

 

Many weekly television drama programs featured real-life stories of viewers who sent in their narratives to popular counseling programs, such as Kahapon Lamang (Just Yesterday), 1976-86, hosted by Eddie Ilarde, and Lovingly Yours, Helen, 1980-96, hosted by Helen Vela, both on GMA 7. The stories were mostly about domestic concerns, especially issues revolving around marital issues and relationships between lovers, but there were also true stories of orphaned children in Ulila (Orphan), hosted by Rosal Rosal, 1978-79, on BBC 2. Dramas with children were popular. Child actor Romnick Sarmenta appeared in four weekly drama anthologies: Peping: Ang Munting Anghel (Peping: The Little Angel), 1976; Bata (Child); True Story; and Señor Santo Niño.

 

Some fiction drama programs made use of action as a main vehicle to discuss love, oppression, and revenge, such as Bertong Dragon (Berto the Dragon), starring Ramon Zamora, on GTV 4, which was patterned after Bruce Lee karate movies, or horror to exemplify the battle between good and evil, such as Guni-guni (Imagination), 1979, on GMA 7, or fantasy to highlight moral values, such as Ora Engkantada (Enchanted Hour), 1973, on GTV 4, then on BBC 2 in the late 1970s.

 

Weekly television drama anthologies that followed the social realist tradition started by the pre-martial law Balintataw (The Mind’s Eye), 1968-71, ABC-RTV5, were Maskara (Mask), 1979, on BBC 2, a critique of the entertainment industry; Rosas (Rose), 1979, on Channel 4, about women’s social issues; and Ilaw ng Tahanan (Light of the Home), 1979, on BBC 2, about the family trials of a mother, all produced by Armida Siguion-Reyna. Other drama anthologies were Eliza, 1973, with Boots Anson-Roa, Nagmamahal, Amalia (Lovingly Yours, Amalia), 1973, with Amalia Fuentes, Babae (Woman), 1979-80, Maria Morena, 1979-80, Panata (Vow), 1979-80, all on BBC 2; Anino (Shadow), 1974, Huwaran (Model), 1974-80, Brocka Presents, 1977-80, Tipanan (Rendezvous), 1979, and Neneng Magtanggol, 1979, all on GTV 4; Alindog (Allure), 1978-79, Mga Kuwento ng Pag-ibig (Stories of Love), 1978-80, and Katha (Stories), 1978, all on GMA; Tanghalan (Stage), 1974, on GMA, then 1975 on GTV 4; and Anak (Child), 1979, and Hiyas (Gem), 1986, on IBC 13. RPN 9 aired Malayo Pa ang Umaga (The Morn Is Yet So Far), 1979, based on the 1947 novel Without Seeing the Dawn, 1947, by Stevan Javellana and produced by Armida Siguion-Reyna. This could be considered the first miniseries on Philippine television, later to be called telenovela in the 2000s. RPN 9 produced the drama special Alab ng Lahi (Ardor of the Race). The weekly anthology Dahong Ginto (Golden Leaf), 1973, on IBC 13, and Mario O’Hara’s TV adaptation of a Spanish novel, Marcelino, Pan y Vino: Alamat o Himala? (Marcelino, Bread and Wine: Legend or Miracle?), 1979, on BBC 2, followed the initial efforts by Fr James Reuter of adapting literary classics to television in the mid-1960s. The weekly drama anthology Obra Maestra, ABS-CBN, which starred Charito Solis, also featured adaptations in the late 1960s. Some of the directors of these television drama programs were Lino Brocka, Mario O’Hara, Maryo J. de los Reyes, Romy Suzara, Elwood Perez, Joey Gosengfiao, Nick Lizaso, and Tony Santos Sr.

 

Both radio and television dramas are often trapped in delineating female stereotypes: “the woman as martyr, as femme fatale, as sacrificial lamb, as the faithful shadow, as the manipulator” (Reyes 1991, 188). Most situations depict them mostly in the confined spaces of the household, in which their characters are unable to relate their domestic concerns to pertinent social issues. Their situations are often “the conflict between mother and daughter, the struggle between two sisters for their parents’ attention, and coping with delinquent children” (Reyes 1991, 189).
