Now, you will get the truth from this channel,” it was very clear that ousting the dictatorship necessitated capturing the very medium of its propagation. Punzalan’s statement was both a critique of the media of lies that was the convention during the time of Marcos and a reaffirmation of the responsibility to truth of the broadcast media. It was the ultimate successor to a series of memorable mass media audiovisual moments: Marcos’s announcement of the imposition of martial law on television, radio, and print on 23 Sep 1972; the announcement of the breakaway from Marcos by Enrile and Ramos; and the four-day EDSA Revolt, which, in its climax, witnessed the TV blackout during Marcos’s press conference and the near-simultaneous oath-taking of Marcos and Aquino as the country’s president, and culminated on 25 Feb 1986 with Marcos, his family, and cronies fleeing the country.

 

In the Aftermath of the 1986 EDSA Revolt

 

Closure, Sequestration, Reopening, and Ownership of Media Networks. TV stations were taken off the air on the day Enrile and Ramos broke away from Marcos. GMA 7 was the first to resume broadcasting on 26 Feb 1986, a day after the EDSA Revolt.

 

One of the first acts of Corazon Aquino as president of what was called a “revolutionary government” was to sequester several radio and television stations, which worked under the assumption that the media outlets were illegally acquired by Marcos cronies and relatives. Tussles between the government and private media companies ensued when the Aquino administration sequestered the broadcast companies Marcos snipped for his cronies. The new government took over broadcast networks RPN 9, IBC 13, and BBC 2, which dominated the industry in terms of local entertainment productions and was considered the top networks during the martial law years (Tolentino 1987). IBC 13 suffered the most from complicated legal matters; it became a 100 percent government-owned station in the 1990s by virtue of a compromise agreement between former owner Roberto Benedicto and the Presidential Commission on Good Government. Marcos’s Maharlika Broadcasting System was renamed People’s Television Network Channel 4, which, like Channel 9, continued operations but later suffered from the intensely competitive field of commercial broadcasting. The Lopezes recovered one station, Channel 2, and relaunched ABS-CBN. The company held a show, Pagbabalik ng mga Bituin (Return of the Stars), in Mar 1987 to signal its return to the media industry. ABS-CBN resumed broadcasting on 14 Sep 1986. The network, however, continued to struggle with the new government for nearly a decade over ownership of the station. GMA’s triumvirate owners Gilberto M. Duavit Sr, Felipe L. Gozon, and Menardo R. Jimenez changed the network’s name from Greater Manila Area Radio Television Arts to Global Media Arts, with the same acronym. Both ABS-CBN and GMA would lord it over in the ratings game, which defined the character of commercial broadcasting of the post-EDSA period. The Elizaldes continued the broadcast of their radio network, the Manila Broadcasting Company.

 

The Aquino administration also sequestered the major newspapers that were considered loyal to Marcos: Bulletin Today, the Philippines Daily Express, and the Journal Group of publications. These pro-Marcos newspapers either retreated or closed shop, while the so-called alternative press, composed mainly of the Philippine Daily Inquirer and Malaya, became the mainstream media. Pre-martial law newspapers were revived: the Roceses’ Manila Times, the Lopezes’ Manila Chronicle, and the Elizaldes’ Manila Standard.

 

Because of the capital-intensive nature of media and the low return on investments of newspapers and broadcast networks, media ownership remained in the hands of individuals and families engaged in diverse business interests. Ownership of revived newspapers changed hands either due to economic reasons or the new policy that prohibited cross-media ownership. The new owners include the Prietos of the Philippine Daily Inquirer, Yap of Bulletin Corporation, the Gokongweis of the Manila Times, Go-Belmonte of the Star Group of Publications, Coyiuto of the Manila Chronicle, Cabangon Chua of the Philippines Graphic, and the Locsins of the Philippines Free Press. Ownership of the new free TV network, VHF (very high frequency) station Channel 11, was contested by two religious charismatic groups: the Jesus Is Lord Movement of Brother Eddie Villanueva and the El Shaddai of Brother Mike Velarde.

 
 

Broadcast Media and Coup Attempts. The Aquino administration and the broadcast networks during this tenuous period of political transition became easy targets of military coup attempts. Rightist or disgruntled members of the AFP, either coming from Marcos loyalists or Honasan’s Reform the Armed Forces Movement (RAM), launched six coup plots to topple the Corazon Aquino administration from 1986 to 1989. Three of these coup attempts involved the seizure of broadcast networks to bring down the new government.

 

Marcos’s losing vice-presidential running mate Arturo Tolentino led the Manila Hotel plot on 6-8 Jul 1986. Defense Secretary Enrile and the RAM masterminded and led the God Save the Queen plot on 22 Nov 1986. Pro-Marcos military loyalists seized GMA 7 and the Sangley Point Airport Base in Cavite on 27-29 Jan 1987. Fifty-six rebel soldiers raided Fort Bonifacio on 18 Apr 1987, an event that came to be known as the Black Saturday incident. Some military members took over the Manila International Airport in Jul 1987. The 28-29 Aug 1987 coup, one of the most serious destabilizing attacks by the military against the Aquino government, was led by Honasan, whose forces attacked Malacañan Palace, seized portions of Camp Aguinaldo, including the headquarters of the Department of National Defense, Villamor Air Base, military camps in Pampanga and Cebu, the airport in Legaspi City, and took ABS-CBN, GMA, and the government-owned PTV 4, under siege, in which 40 GMA employees were held hostage by Col Oscar Canlas.

 

 

The Aug 1987 coup attempt left 53 dead and more than 200 wounded. The Jan 1989 plot was led by renegade policeman Rizal Alih, who seized Camp Cawa-Cawa in Zamboanga City. The deadly 1-6 Dec 1989 coup, led again by Honasan, is considered the biggest coup attempt on Corazon Aquino’s presidency, which involved nearly 3,000 military officers and men staging multiple attacks on Malacañan Palace, Villamor Air Base, Fort Bonifacio, Camp Crame, Mactan Air Base in Cebu, and Sangley Point in Cavite. The Dec 1989 coup once again targeted television networks ABS-CBN, GMA, and PTV. Ninety people died and 570 were wounded in the December coup attempt. The Dec 1989 coup was also staged in the business center of Makati. Radio directly played a key role during the event: it helped secure the safety of civilians and foreign tourists caught in the cross fire. On DZRH, reporter Rey Langit negotiated on the air with the rebels, who had stationed snipers on top of several high-rise buildings in Makati, for a ceasefire to allow tourism secretary Rafael Alunan to escort hostaged local and foreign tourists out of the battle zone. On 4 Mar 1990, suspended Cagayan governor Rodolfo Albano and his armed men of 200 seized a hotel in Tuguegarao on 4 Mar 1990, killing a general and 12 men on both sides of the gunfire that ensued. Finally, soldier mutineers, led by Brig Gen Danilo Lim, raided and seized an army base in Mindanao on 4-6 Oct 1990.

 

Media and the Constitution. The adoption of the 1987 Philippine Constitution was the most significant development during the Aquino administration. Some members of the constitutional commission were from the media: Florangel Rosario-Braid, journalists Napoleon Rama and Vic Foz, both of the Bulletin group, and film director Lino Brocka.

 

The new constitution contained an unprecedented 13 communication-related provisions, foremost of which is the flagship provision, which is contained in the Declaration of Principles and State Policies: “The State recognizes the vital role of communication and information in nation building.” It strengthened the critical role of media and communication in creating self-reliant communities, redressing imbalances in the distribution of wealth, and promoting peace and national identity, which were concerns not directly mentioned about media in the 1973 Constitution. The new constitution also improved on the coverage of press freedom, which now included “expression” as an expansion of the more conventional freedom of speech and the press. The right to information found in the 1973 Charter was also expanded with the inclusion of the phrase “as well as government research data used as basis for policy development.”

 

 

The 1987 Constitution also institutionalized the Filipinization of mass media, mainly in terms of media ownership. The new constitution retained the provision on 100 percent ownership of mass media by Filipinos, one of the legacies of Marcos. Article XVI, Section 11, Article 1 of the new constitution explicitly states that “the ownership and management of mass media shall be limited to citizens of the Philippines, or to corporations, cooperatives or associations, wholly-owned and managed by such citizens.” It allowed, however, foreign equity in advertising entities, defined by law as part of mass media, through its 70:30 provision. Telecommunications and the cable industries fall under the 60:40 equity ratio, in favor of Filipinos. Present ownership of telecommunication and the new information technology, however, consists of joint ventures between local owners and transnational corporations.

 

Several mass media-related bills and resolutions were filed in the reconvened Philippine Congress starting in 1987. These covered freedom of information, public access, public broadcasting system, support for community media, privatization of sequestered media, and the transnationalization of telecommunication. Media legislation was slow, mainly because legislators were cautious in introducing media-related bills, some of which were perceived by some sectors as a curtailment of freedom of expression. A few of the bills passed into law were Republic Act (RA) 7306 granting PTV a charter, RA 7925 or the Public Telecommunications Policy Act, RA 8370 or the Children’s Television Act, and RA 8293 or the Intellectual Property Code. Among the more active media policy advocates in the upper house were Senators Agapito Aquino, Leticia Shahani, Nikki Coseteng, and Heherson Alvarez; in the House of Representatives, these advocates included Michael Mastura, Ramon Bagatsing, Leandro Verceles Jr, Romeo Candazo, and Andrea Domingo.

 

 

Regulation of the Broadcast Media. Regulation of the broadcast media in the Philippines emanates from three sources: the State, the broadcast industry itself, and the internal mechanisms of the stations themselves.

 

Philippine laws that regulate broadcasting companies are Act 3846, approved in 1931 and amended by Commonwealth Acts 365 and 571, and RA 584, approved in 1950. Both require the approval of a broadcasting franchise by the Congress of the Philippines. Memorandum Circular 7-3-93 stipulates that once a franchise has been obtained, the company is required to secure a certificate of public convenience from the National Telecommunications Commission (NTC), a government agency established in 1979 under the Department of Transportation and Communication. Executive Order 205, issued on 30 Jun 1987, governs the regulation of cable antenna television (CATV) and requires a network to obtain a certificate of authority to operate for not more than 15 years, which can be renewed for a similar period. By the 2000s, broadcasting firms have saturated the VHF and UHF (ultra-high frequency) bandwidths in Metro Manila. Programs aired on these bandwidths are the main sources of advertising revenues for the networks, so much so that networks tended to overload these programs with commercials, an issue that has generated a lot of debate among members of the broadcast industry, the government, and the public.

 

 

Two important state agencies that continue to regulate broadcast media content were the Movie and Television Review and Classification Board (MTRCB) and the Presidential Appeals Board. The MTRCB, created through Presidential Decree 1986, screens television programs, commercials, and publicity materials. It classifies programs according to audiences: G for general patronage, PG for parental guidance, and SPG for strict parental guidance. The MTRCB bans shows that depict lewd, offensive or demeaning content; contain attacks against any race, creed, or religion; condone and encourage the use of illegal drugs; undermine faith and confidence in government; glorify criminals or condone crimes; are libelous or defamatory; or constitute contempt of court. The Presidential Appeals Board addresses issues raised by parties pertaining to decisions made by the MTRCB. It submits recommendations to the president of the Philippines, who makes the final decision.

 

The MTRCB made decisions that shaped the nature of broadcast regulation. In 1991, the MTRCB decided it has jurisdiction to review episodes of documentaries before they get aired on national television. The decision stemmed from complaints by officials of the Philippine Women’s University (PWU) about “Prosti-tuition,” an episode of The Inside Story, 1991, ABS-CBN, hosted by Loren Legarda, that featured PWU female students allegedly engaging in prostitution to finance their studies. In 2005, the Supreme Court decided in favor of PWU, citing that a public affairs program such as that by Legarda is not exempt from review by the MTRCB. A number of episodes in 1992 of the weekly TV program Iglesia ni Cristo (INC, Church of Christ), produced by the INC, received an X rating from the MTRCB because of the program’s criticisms of the veneration by Roman Catholics of the Virgin Mary. In 1994, the Supreme Court held MTRCB’s X rating as a prior restraint on the freedom of religious speech. The MTRCB slapped several suspensions of varying durations on Willie Revillame, Randy Santiago, and John Estrada, hosts of the daily noontime show Magandang Tanghali, Bayan (Good Afternoon, Nation), 1998-2005, ABS-CBN, because of their sexist remarks and jokes. The show itself was suspended for one week in 2001 because of a similar offense, which led to the ouster of Revillame as host of the program. Eli Soriano’s Ang Dating Daan (The Old Road) went off the air in 2004 when MTRCB suspended it for three months following complaints by INC ministers, who were the target of invectives by Soriano on national television. The Supreme Court affirmed MTRCB’s decision, explaining that personal attacks on persons cannot be considered part of freedom of religious speech. The MTRCB also suspended the television documentary i-Witness for two weeks in 2006 because of its airing of the episode “Lukayo: Hindi Ito Bastos” (Lukayo: This Is Not Obscene), which is about lukayo, a wedding ritual involving old women dancing with wooden phalluses in the town of Kalayaan in Laguna. In 1996, the MTRCB also ordered the withdrawal of three sexy liquor commercials that featured Amanda Page, Sunshine Cruz, and Glydel Mercado.

 

 

Self-regulation by the broadcast industry has become more responsive during the post-martial law period. The Kapisanan ng mga Brodkaster ng Pilipinas (KBP), which was established in 1973, continues to regulate the broadcast industry after the martial law period. This time, the KBP has functioned as a truly self-regulatory organization of broadcasters, unlike its role during the Marcos martial law period. It continues to coordinate with government regulators; lobby important laws, policies, and regulations with state legislators; police its own ranks; impose sanctions for violations committed by its members; and promulgate and regularly review its broadcast code of ethics. The KBP also works actively with the Advertising Board or AdBoard, the umbrella organization of advertisers that formulates and enforces standards in both print and broadcast media advertising.

 

Individual networks and stations also internally regulate themselves, but only ABS-CBN and GMA and the online platform Rappler, have full-time ombudspersons in charge of monitoring and regulating their programs, especially against their journalists and staff engaged in so-called envelopmental journalism, receiving grease money from politicians and interest groups or providing these individuals and groups with unfair access to media exposure.

 

AM Radio

 

AM radio after the 1986 EDSA Revolt continued to be providers mainly of news and information, while FM radio continued to be oriented toward music and entertainment. The gradual shift of some AM radio stations from entertainment to news was recognizable beginning with the assassination of Ninoy Aquino in 1983. However, much caution was exercised by broadcast journalists as the country was still under a climate of censorship and control despite Marcos’s lifting of martial law in 1981. After 1986, the people’s demand for news became seemingly insatiable, following the long years of being saturated with propaganda by the Marcos regime.

 

 

Such developments, plus the restoration of freedom and democracy, emboldened AM radio stations to reformat. Most stations either strengthened their news programming or completely shifted from entertainment to news and public affairs. For example, DZRH, acknowledged as the pioneer of radio dramas and musical variety shows since its founding in 1939 until the fall of the Marcos dictatorship in 1986, began focusing on news and public affairs. GMA’s DZBB, which started as news, public affairs, and entertainment during its early broadcasts beginning in 1955 and focused on music and personality-oriented programs during the martial law period, reoriented its programming to news after the ouster of Marcos, relaunching DZBB as “Radyo Bisig Bayan” (Radio with the People) in 1989, then recast it as “Super Radyo” (Super Radio). ABS-CBN’s DZMM brought back its pre-martial law type of news programming, revived Radyo Patrol (Patrol Radio), which would dominate the airwaves during the early years of the Corazon Aquino administration. These stations expanded the running time of their major newscast programs both in the morning and in the early evening slots. Unlike in the 1960s until the early 1970s when announcers read news straight from newspaper articles, wire copies from local and foreign news agencies, and syndicated reports coming from the government-owned Philippine News Agency, the post-EDSA newscasts were enhanced with more voice clips, spot reports, and live or phone-patched interviews. Even the stations’ weather reports, which also used to be read from newspapers, were now coming straight from the weather agency Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration (PAGASA). Stations would call and put on-air interviews with PAGASA personnel for the weather updates, with some of the meteorologists eventually becoming regular announcers for these programs, such as Amado Pineda in the 1970s and the 1980s and Nathaniel “Mang Tani” Cruz in the 1990s and the 2000s for GMA’s news programs. This procedure also applied when getting traffic updates, information on water service interruption, and brownout schedules.

 

Reports from the field were aired not only during the news and public affairs programs, but also in other programs, including entertainment shows, all throughout a station’s broadcast hours. Marked changes in the 1990s included improvements in electronic news-gathering technologies, such as portable transmitters and more convenient mobile communication gadgets and monitoring equipment. Present technologies that enhanced the news programming of AM radio stations include cable television and computers with Internet services, digital recording units, and editing software.

 

Stations that shifted to news and public affairs required the setting up of a separate news department. With most stations creating their respective news departments, increasing the number of news personnel, and purchasing more efficient and convenient technologies and transportation units, news production beginning in the late 1980s became more systematic, eventually developing full productions. The format, however, remained mainly news and talk. Documentaries would see their full potential on television.

 

A significant development during the post-EDSA period was the entry of civil society groups into the broadcast scene, first on radio, then on TV. The Citizens’ Alliance for Consumer Protection continued airing its weekly radio drama-talk program Pintig ng Konsyumer (Pulse of the Consumer) on DWXI. The peasant organization Kilusang Magbubukid ng Pilipinas produced regular audio materials for its campaigns about palay production subsidy for peasants, genuine agrarian reform, and the politics of grains trading on DZRH, 1988-2000. The Philippine Peasant Institute, a nongovernment organization (NGO) that focused its advocacy on agrarian reform and related peasant issues, produced the daily radio commentary program Punlaan sa Himpapawid (Seedling Plots on Air), which premiered on DWBC, 1987, then went weekly as an early evening one-hour drama and talk program on DWAN, 1988-90, until its final run in the late 1990s. Tambuyog Development Center, one of the earlier NGOs that advocated for a community-based coastal resource management, produced the weekly early evening one-hour drama and talk program Radyo Lundayan (Lundayan Radio), DZEC, 1991-95. The Arts Research and Training Institute in Southern Tagalog, an artists’ group based in provinces south of Manila, produced the magazine program Kalinangang Bayan (National Culture), DZLB, 1989-91, which featured critical analyses of social issues that find expression on the region’s local cultures. The Development Education Media Services, a progressive media training group, produced radio drama productions, such as Salaminagway, 1991-92, which tackled issues of workers, farmers, urban poor, indigenous peoples, internal refugees, and the human rights situation of the country. The underground Communist Party of the Philippines–National Democratic Front produced Radyo Sierra Madre (Sierra Madre Radio), an occasional talk radio commentary program in the early 1990s, surreptitiously tapping bandwidths from where it could clandestinely broadcast for an hour or two.

 

In the late 1990s until the early 2000s, radio continued to be one of the main avenues of programs for the advocacy of civil society groups. Pathways Productions, under the management of Garth Noel Tolentino and the creative direction of Tet Maceda, produced the daily drama serial-public forum program Pitlag! Kuwento ng Buhay, Isyu ng Bayan (Jolt! Narratives of Life, Issues of Community and Nation), which first aired on Radio Veritas, 2000-2001, as part of the movement to oust Pres Joseph Estrada, and relaunched in 2002 and aired until 2006 on the 25 stations all over the country of Radio Mindanao Network. The relaunched program maintained its original format, but the new series covered a wider range of topics, some of which included the social cost of war in Mindanao, the struggles of indigenous peoples, the death penalty, and child labor. Radio programs and public service announcements produced by civil society groups critical of the administrations of Aquino, Ramos, Estrada, and Arroyo would not have been permitted airtime during the Marcos martial law period.

 

The change in programming of AM radio stations, from an entertainment to a more news-oriented approach, was born out of the stations’ interaction with the social environment. Influences on programming shifts can be classified as external and internal. Externally, the reprogramming to news was shaped by historical events, political regulation, new technologies, and the competitive environment under which the stations operated. Internally, management played a significant role in the improvement of the radio stations’ news productions.

 

FM Radio

 

Programming. Niche programming, also called format radio or modern radio programming, a specialized programming with a specific market segment as an intended target audience, became the prevailing pattern in FM radio broadcast. In niche programming, the station, through its program or station manager, and not its deejays, created the image of the station through a well-planned music playlist. Deejays had to strictly adhere to the principles and aesthetics of the station’s projected identity.

 

DWRT 99.5, aka “RT 99.5,” was the trailblazer of the trend since it went on the air in 1976. More stations adopted niche programming during the post-EDSA years. DWDM 95.5, under Eagle Broadcasting Co., carried the adult contemporary/OPM format; OPM refers to original Pilipino music, which became a major trend in Philippine radio broadcasting in the 1970s. DWTM “Magic 89.9” under Quest Broadcasting Inc, owned by Jose Luis Vera, was one of the top-rating format radio stations in Metro Manila. It featured deejays like Nelson “Sgt. Pepper” Capulso and Adel “Little David” Gabot, both formerly with 96.3 WRock, Ken Fortun, Paul “Paul Reno” Alejandrino, Vince “Rockin’ V” Faner, and Roland “Joe D’ Mango” Sulit, who became a household name through his “Love Notes” segment where he read letters sent by avid listeners pertaining to love problems. DWKS 101.1 Kiss FM’s Top Ten at Ten and Top 20 at 12 music countdowns generated a huge following among its young listeners throughout its three-year existence, prior to reformatting to jazz, then to a more mass-based format after it was acquired by the Manila Broadcasting Company and has since become 101.1 Yes FM. Kiss FM’s main newscasters include Marinela “Pinky” M. Aseron, Lindy Pellicer, and Bernadette Sta. Maria. Its on-air staff was composed of former 99.5 RT deejays Gerry “Jeremiah Junior” Magnaye, Eric “Eric Caine” Eloriaga, Vince “Vince St. Price” de Guzman, Sonny “Sonny Z” Zarate, Jigs “Jiggy” Ona, and Dickie “Dick Reese” Aracama. “Manila’s Intelligent Alternative” City Lite 88.3, owned and operated by Raven Broadcasting Co and which began operations in 1987, was composed of former marketing executive Francis Lumen, businessman Alexander Limjuco, Guam-based real estate developer Gerry Geronimo, lawyer Steve Salonga, engineer Francisco “Kit” Ravina, and programming expert Joselito “Mike” Pedero. Featuring a playlist consisting primarily of vocal and instrumental jazz, rhythm and blues, New Age music, and genre-specific musical programs, its announcers included Marinela “Pinky” Aseron, who also served as the station’s manager, Mike “Adam Kite” Taylor, Ramon “Joey Pizza” Cruz, Pancho “Pancho” Alvarez, and Jay “J Latin” Zorilla, with newscasters Armie Jarin-Bennett, Karen Wu, Carissa Tiongson-Palanca, and Marie Anjanette Fernandez. It catered to a high-end market, including the expatriate community. After 16 years, it changed format in 2003 and had since become Jam 88.3. DWNU NU 107.5, “The Home of New Rock,” which began operations in 1987, was owned and operated by Progressive Broadcasting Company led by banker and businessman Atom Henares and telecommunications executive Orlando “Doy” Vea, with Mike Pedero as partner and programming head. It introduced modern rock and incorporated cutting-edge programming with events that became popular such as the annual NU107 Rock Awards, with local rock icon Joey “Pepe” Smith, the Eraserheads, Bamboo, Jun Lopito, Jingle Magazine, and the Rock Jocks of DZRJ as some of its awardees. NU’s announcers included Tom “Major Tom” Lupton, Gerry Dris, GJ Torres, Gerry Why, Charlie “Charlie Y” Ysmael, Claire Miranda, Russ Davis, and musicians Francis “Francis Brew” Reyes of the rock band The Dawn, and Myrene Academia of the rock band Sandwich. Ramon “RJ” Jacinto’s Rajah Broadcasting Company migrated its DZRJ 180 AM to FM via DZRJ 100.3 in 1987. Considered one of the industry’s more enduring stations, DZRJ “RJ FM” took on the adult contemporary/classic hits format, combining four decades of pop music from the 1960s to the 1990s, gaining for RJ the label “pied piper of retro/revival music.” Other stations that adopted format radio were DWRock, KY 91.5, DYNY-FM Cebu, and Y101 Cebu.

 

Radio stations that followed an easy listening format, playing mellow standards, include DWAD 97.9, owned and operated by the Crusaders Broadcasting Co., GMA Network’s “The Giant” DWLS 97.1 FM, and DWCD 103.5 of the Global Broadcasting Co. These stations began operations in 1986.

 

The Top 40 format, also known as contemporary hit radio, which was a major trend in the 1970s, began to lose its appeal to radio audiences during the post-EDSA period, mainly due to the innovations in programming introduced by many stations that preferred niche programming. From 1986 to 1988, some FM radio stations reformatted to meet the challenges posed by niche programming. DWXB 102.7 changed its format from new wave to easy listening via “Gentle Wind” DWSM 102.7, under the management of Bombo Radyo Philippines. DWKB 89.1, which had already been part of the sequestered Intercontinental Broadcasting Corporation, became DZMZ or DMZ “Dance Muzik Zone” and featured dance and club music. DWKS 101.1 became Kiss Jazz, taking on the adult contemporary/jazz format. DWRK 96.3 became lite rock station 96.3 WRock. English was still the main language used in most FM radio stations. Lately, however, there has been a rise in the number of bilingual FM stations, appealing to a broader market.

 

Provincial radio programming is usually “chop suey,” a hodgepodge of musical programs, the reason being that niche stations rarely click in these areas. Provincial stations subsist mainly on blocktimers, specifically politicians who wish to maintain their “visibility” to their constituents. For marketing, some stations in the provinces affiliated with large Manila-based networks, which proved to be a viable option, such as the case with the Canoys’ Radio Mindanao Network affiliating with GMA. Metro Manila–based broadcast stations had their regional counterparts, with the most number coming from ABS-CBN and GMA. Southern Broadcasting Network (SBN) had FM stations DWSN 97.9 Laoag, DZRB 95.9 Naga, DYCP 90.3 Bacolod, DYAP 88.3 Cebu, DYJP 101.5 Tacloban, DXJP 101.9 Zamboanga, DXCS 92.7 Cagayan de Oro, and DXSS 97.9 Davao.

 

Branding. Niche programming, in which music on the playlist featured by deejays depended on the station’s image, gained a strong foothold among FM radio stations. Beginning in the 1990s, branding became an apparent trend. In 1991, Mareco Broadcasting Network Inc changed Power 105’s new wave format into easy listening, using “World-Class Music” as its catchphrase, which later became 105.1 “Crossover.” In 1992, “The Giant” 97.1 DWLS of GMA Network tweaked its programming to target the youth via “Campus Radio 97.1 LS FM.” Also in 1991, Fred Elizalde of Manila Broadcasting Company acquired DWKS of Makati Broadcasting Company, transforming 101.1 Kiss Jazz into DWST “Showbiz Tsismis,” which centered on showbiz news and talk. In 1995, the Crusaders Broadcasting Company sold DWAD 97.9 to Aliw Broadcasting Company owned by Antonio Cabangon-Chua Sr, who changed its call letters to DWQZ and went by the moniker “97dot9 Home Radio.” The Barreiros’ DWRX 93.1 was rebranded as “Monster Radio” RX 93 and went by the slogan “Metro Manila’s first creative radio station.” Ramon Florete of Bombo Radyo Philippines acquired 102.7 “Gentle Wind” and renamed it “Star FM 102.7.” Radio Partners Inc, a medium-scale network of Metro Manila and provincial radio stations led by lawyer Jose Luis Vera, acquired DWCD 103.5 and repackaged it as 103.5 “K-Lite.” In 1996, Far East Broadcasting Company reinforced the positioning of its classical and Christian music format radio station DZFE 98.7 via the slogan “Christ for the world by radio.” In 1998, ABS-CBN switched the programming of DWRR 101.9 from adult contemporary easy listening to a mass-based format and went by the slogan “101.9 for life!” UR 105, a sister station of DZRJ 100 FM, labeled itself “Underground Radio.”

 

More Talk Programs. By the mid-1990s, talk-oriented programs slowly crept into the FM programming scene. Early talk-oriented format programs include RX 93.1’s Morning Rush, hosted every early morning by the deejay tandem of Chico and Delamar; 103.5 K-Lite’s Talk Back, an early evening program that encouraged listeners to phone in their views and opinions on a given topic; and NU 107’s Twisted, hosted by Jessica Zafra every Sunday, which was a radio version of her column of the same title. Toward 1996, K-Lite came out with another talk-oriented program called Nite Lite, which replaced Talk Back but carried its same format, hosted by Mano “Monica” Figueras, Adel “Little David” Gabot, and Jess “The Blade” Reyes.

 

More transitions took place, specifically in Metro Manila’s FM radio stations, at the turn of the new century. In 2001, TRPI added DZMZ 89.1 to its stable of FM radio stations, repackaged it as Wave 89.1 under the network name Blockbuster Broadcasting Company, and took on an easy listening R & B format. In 2003, after 16 years of broadcasting as an adult contemporary radio station, DWCT “City Lite 88.3” shifted to light pop and alternative music and repackaged as Jam 88.3. Magic 89.9 added more talk-oriented programs during its primetime programming, including Good Times with Mo Twister, which dominated the airwaves during the 6:00-9:00 am drive time, and Boys’ Night Out, with Sam YG, Slick Rick, and Tony Toni, which took the evening drive-time shift.

 

Masa Programming. The shift by most FM radio stations to talk-oriented programs ushered in a new trend, caused primarily by the need to get more listeners, particularly the so-called masa (mass) group composed of the C, D, and E economic classes, which comprise the bulk of the radio-listening public. FM radio during its early years in the 1960s until the 2000s mainly catered to the A and B markets. Those from the lower economic groups started to gain more access to new technological gadgets during the post-EDSA period, while the A and B markets began shifting to more high-end electronic equipment. These developments altered the listening habits of audiences. Some from the A-B crowd abandoned radio listening in favor of music downloadable onto their new mobile devices without the need for an FM radio station. The C-D-E market, on the other hand, began tuning in to FM.

 

New talk-oriented programs adopted mass-based programming to reach the masa. In the 1990s and on to the 2010s, among the radio stations that took on the masa bandwagon were DWYS 101.1 “Yes FM”; DWRR 101.9 “For Life”; DWLS 97.1 “Barangay LS”; DWKY 91.5 Energy FM; DWOW 103.5, which used to be Max FM; DWET 106.7, formerly jazz and easy listening station Dream FM; and DWNU 107.5, from modern rock to masa programming and renamed Win Radio 107.5. In 2011, Progressive Broadcasting Company acquired the frequency franchise of 91.5 and repackaged it as Big Radio. Energy FM moved to 106.7, which used to be adult contemporary radio station Dream 106 FM.

 

A milestone in the history of Philippine FM radio was the entry of Media Quest Holdings Inc, led by telecommunications mogul Manuel “MVP” Pangilinan, into FM radio on 28 Nov 2010. Pangilinan’s group took over the frequency 92.3 after Francis Lumen’s All-Youth Channel’s lease expired, and converted the station into 92.3 News Radio, aka Radyo Singko, a news and talk-oriented radio component of TV5 of the Associated Broadcasting Company. It positioned itself as “Ang Bagong Tunog ng FM” (The New Sound of FM). Its entry into the medium may be considered a milestone in the history of Philippine FM radio in the sense that a network has ventured into migrating what is traditionally an AM format into a predominantly music-oriented medium.

 

With the emergence of more stations scrambling to attract a huge mass-based audience, music programming took a back seat as a radio station’s main marketing tool. Listeners have come to know a station not by the music it plays nor by its frequency and call letters, but by its catchy slogan. Examples are 90.7 DZMB Love Radio’s “Kailangan pa bang i-memorize ’yan?” (Do you need to memorize that?), 106.7 Energy FM’s “Hi, Pangga!” (Hi, Love!), and Magic 89.9’s “Today’s best music!” Talk entertainment, characterized by high-energy banter, jokes, and canned laughter, became the order of the day. Music in these programs comprised less than 40 percent of its hourly programming. As of 2011, almost half of the total 25 FM radio stations in Metro Manila have already adopted the mass-based programming format.

 

Programming Developments

 

Development Communication and Educational Media. Whereas Marcos used the framework of development communication to usher in the so-called development projects of international lending institutions and its concept of renaissance programming during the martial law period to mask and justify propaganda, development communication as a programming concept took on a different turn in the aftermath of the EDSA Revolt. It shifted to distance education using broadcast. The advent of new information and communication technologies provided greater opportunities to use these technologies as alternative learning delivery schemes. Digital classrooms started to become sites of the active interaction of teachers and students mediated by multimedia technology. Communication specialists active in development communication and educational broadcasting include Alexander Flor, Rebecca Pestaño-Smith, Louie Tabing, Teresa H. Stuart, Mary Ebitha Y. Dy, Felix Librero, Carlos Arnaldo, Cesar Mercado, Nora C. Quebral, Juan Jamias, Juan Mercado, Frankie Llaguno, Delia Barcelona, Benjamin Lozare, Paulina Bautista, Zenaida Domingo, and Grace J. Alfonso.

 

Blocktime Programming. The early years following the EDSA Revolt saw broadcast television programming by the networks mainly relying on blocktimers. Friends of network owners filled in the airtime. Broadcast Marketing, owned by Jun Sison, put up new drama shows for the new ABS-CBN, such as Ina (Mother), 1986, directed by Lino Brocka, and Parak (Police), 1986, directed by Lamberto Avellana and starring Anthony Alonzo and Robin Padilla, then a young, emerging actor. ABS-CBN initially had popular canned shows from abroad, such as The Golden Girls and The Cosby Show.

 

Movie outfits Regal Films, owned by Lily Monteverde, and Viva Films, owned by Vic del Rosario, co-produced weekly primetime shows. For ABS-CBN, Regal produced the sitcom Palibhasa Lalake (Because They Are Guys), 1987-98, starring Richard Gomez, Joey Marquez, Gloria Romero, and Cynthia Patag; the weekly drama anthologies Regal Drama Presents, 1986-89, featuring the studio’s popular stars; Maricel Regal Drama Special, 1987-90, starring Maricel Soriano; and Regal Presents, 1986, a show featuring the studio’s hit movies. For GMA, Regal produced the weekly drama anthology Mother Studio Presents, 1986-96, and the weekly horror serial Regal Shockers, 1985-91. In 1988, Viva pulled out of IBC 13 and transferred to GMA to produce Viva Box Office Hits, 1988-90, renamed Viva Sinerama, 1990-91, then MVP: Monday Viva Presentations, 1994, a weekly program for the rerun of the studio’s latest movies on national television. Viva Television continued to produce more programs for GMA in the 1990s, such as the weekly drama anthologies Spotlight, 1993-98, and Mikee, 1999; the daily soap operas Villa Quintana, 1995-96, Anna Karenina, 1996-2002, Ganyan Kita Kamahal (That’s How I Love You), 1998, Ikaw na Sana (I Hope It’s You at Last), 1997-98, and Halik sa Apoy (Kiss the Fire), 1998-99; the comedy shows Ober da Bakod (Over the Fence), 1992-96, Haybol Rambol (Rumble in the House), 1993-95, and Si Manoy at si Mokong (Manoy and Mokong), 1997-98; and the youth-oriented shows T.G.I.S., 1995-99, and Growing Up, 1997-98. GMA launched FPJ sa GMA (FPJ on GMA), 1987-92, a weekly series of movies by action and box-office king Fernando Poe Jr, who was reportedly paid 10 million pesos by GMA for the first-run rights to his movies.

 

Loca-Lobo Productions of Lourdes Carvajal, aka Inday Badiday, moved from IBC 13 to GMA, where she produced the entertainment talk shows See True, 1987-93; Eye to Eye, 1989-96; and Face to Face, 1990-95. Television and Production Exponents (TAPE) by Tony Tuviera began airing the noontime variety show Eat Bulaga! (Lunchtime Peek-a-Boo!) on RPN 9, 1979-89, then transferred to ABS-CBN, 1989-94, before settling to GMA beginning in 1994. TAPE produced top-rating afternoon soaps. For RPN 9, it produced Heredero (Heir), 1984-87, and Agila (Eagle), 1987-89, which later moved to ABS-CBN until its run in 1992. For ABS-CBN, it produced Valiente, 1992-95, before it moved the drama soap to GMA until its end in 1997. For GMA, TAPE produced Del Tierro, 1997-99; Rio del Mar, 1999-2001; and Kirara: Ano ang Kulay ng Pag-ibig? (Kirara: What Is the Color of Love?), 1999-2001.

 

Cheche Lazaro’s Probe Productions produced intelligent TV programs covering different types of formats: The Probe Team, 1988-2010, the first Filipino investigative news magazine on local TV; 5 & Up, 1992-2002, a children’s program; AgriLink, 1993-99, an agricultural-entrepreneurial magazine show; Game Plan, 1995-2008, a sports and leisure program; and Cheche Lazaro Presents, started in 1999, a travel show that developed into a one-hour documentary program.

 

Network-Produced Programs. Beginning in the 1990s, the VHF channels of free television started coming up with more station-produced programs. When networks began filling in the evening primetime slots with their entertainment programs, which were mainly drama series, the public affairs programs of blocktimers were moved to the late-night shift. The VHF channels also migrated their foreign canned programs to their respective UHF channels. Local programming on the VHF channels, particularly the network giants ABS-CBN and GMA, thus began to dominate over foreign programs.

 

Networks started filling in the late morning and afternoon prime time with more entertainment programs to reach a wider audience, mainly the so-called masa. ABS-CBN attempted to rival the dominance of Eat Bulaga!, which has been with GMA since 1994, with noontime shows like ‘Sang Linggo nAPO Sila (APO Now Runs for a Week), 1995-98, and Masayang Tanghali, Bayan (Happy Afternoon, Nation), 1998-2005.

 

News and public affairs programs, including entertainment news, on VHF adopted a combination of information and entertainment in their format, but were, and continues to be, tabloid in character, filled with stories of crime, violence, and mundane celebrity trivia that bordered on sensationalism, all in the rush for scoops. The line separating news from entertainment has become indistinct. Many cases were exploited to the fullest, an example of which includes the Bishop Bacani sexual harassment case. Trivia about the Taiwanese F4 band of Meteor Garden fame got equal treatment in national news programs. Celebrity Ruffa Gutierrez’s wedding, and later divorce, and all the controversies of Kris Aquino that involved her relationships were headline news as much as the war on terrorism. Considered an all-time low in Philippine broadcast journalism is the coverage of the death of matinee idol Rico Yan. The news was exploited in primetime news programs and talk shows. The networks covered the actor’s death from every possible angle, without due regard to the proper sensibilities required of the situation. The practice, undoubtedly, had its precedent in the 1980s with the exploitation of the death of Julie Vega, the young star of the daily serial Anna Liza, 1980-85, GMA, when Vega’s funeral was seamlessly incorporated into the story of her own soap opera.

 

Reality TV programs would proliferate beginning in the 1990s in varying formats, as in the cinema verité recording of contestants’ daily routines, and were viewed on national television at different times of the day, or those in the form of game shows and talent search programs. Real-life narratives of participants and contestants permeated these new programs, some of which were apparently scripted. Some of these narratives focused on the lachrymose, very much like the melodrama of the daily soaps.

 

Indecency and insensitivity seemed to have become the practice by popular hosts and even by broadcast journalists. Similar incidents include the coverage of natural disasters, crisis situations, crime, and children, such as the case of a male ABS-CBN reporter who shoved the microphone into a small opening to interview a young girl, who was trapped under a debris of boulders of a four-story school building in Cabanatuan City which collapsed during the 7.7-magnitude earthquake that struck northern Luzon in Jul 1990—and who would later die of her injuries—and insensitively asked how she was feeling; the Rizal Park crisis where several Chinese tourists were taken hostage by a policeman on 23 Aug 2010; and the Janjan macho dance controversy on TV5’s program Willing Willie on 12 Mar 2011. Real life and TV soap, and a dose of incompetent and unethical reporting, were fused into a spectacle in the name of commerce.

 

In the stiff competition to capture a wider audience reach and increase ratings and profits, the networks employed younger news anchors and reporters, which was a welcome development, except that they seemed to be more concerned with appearances than professional practice. They were made up and made over like any other television performer. In general, younger newscasters and reporters became more valued than ever, with the older newscasters relegated to the UHF or cable channels, including Frankie Evangelista and Tina Monzon-Palma. The younger ones, like Korina Sanchez, Karen Davila, Vicky Morales, and their male counterparts like Julius Babao, Henry Omaga Diaz, and Tony Velasquez, are all cast and glamorized for the news programs’ VHF channels. Senior newscasters like Mike Enriquez, Noli de Castro, and Mel Tiangco are more the exception than the rule, although their personas are manufactured for the medium. Enriquez and de Castro are packaged and imaged as the no-nonsense critics of all forms of abuses and defenders of the downtrodden, while Tiangco is the motherly friend, the kapuso (close to the heart) of every Filipino.

 

The mix of entertainment and news seemed to have gained traction in the packaging of broadcast journalists. News anchors cross over to entertainment programs, such as Mel Tiangco of GMA who anchors Frontpage and hosts Magpakailanman (Forever), 2002-8, then revived in 2012, a melodramatic anthology based on the lives of celebrities and, later, of ordinary people. Vicky Morales, who anchors GMA’s news program Saksi, does the same with her weekly wish-granting program Wish Ko Lang! (Just My Wish!), premiered 2002. Korina Sanchez of ABS-CBN anchors the news program TV Patrol and co-hosted the entertainment talk show Morning Girls, 2002-4, with Kris Aquino.

 

More local soaps, derived from real-life stories, would deluge TV primetime programming. New soaps from abroad would also enter into the picture, particularly drama serials, first from Mexico and Latin American countries, which were called telenovelas, which are limited-run drama serials, then from Taiwan, which Filipinos called chinovelas (Chinese telenovelas), and from Korea, which were termed koreanovelas. All these new drama serials, together with Japanese anime programs, which also started to flood local primetime programming in the 2000s, were dubbed in Filipino.

 

Telenovelas, Chinovelas, and Koreanovelas. The phenomenal program that significantly altered local television programming was Marimar, 1996, which came not from the giant commercial networks ABS-CBN and GMA but from RPN, which at that time was under contestation between Marcos crony Benedicto and the government’s Presidential Commission on Good Governance. Marimar was a Mexican telenovela produced by Televisa, a Mexican broadcast production group. It was brought to the Philippines by Procter & Gamble, which sold Televisa soaps into the country in exchange for free spots within the programs. The Latin American soap was dubbed in Filipino. RPN had earlier aired a Latin American telenovela, La Traidora (The Lady Traitor), 1994, but it was Marimar that ultimately changed the landscape of the late afternoon and evening primetime programming.

 

Marimar had a fast-paced narrative. Thalia, the star of the series, became a household name, and the program became a monster hit, which seriously threatened to dislodge the newscast TV Patrol of ABS-CBN from its number one ranking in the ratings game. Marimar was broadcast from Monday to Friday on prime time, at a time slot opposite the second half of TV Patrol and GMA’s early evening newscast. This horizontal programming showed the other networks that there was economic sense in scheduling a program five days a week on the same hour. Once the program clicked with the audience, like Marimar, the station would have control of that hour five days a week. ABS-CBN and GMA seriously considered vertical programming and learned many lessons from the hit telenovela, one of which was that a daily soap can beat stable news programs.

 

The success of Marimar provided the impetus for broadcast networks to produce daily drama serials in the early evening primetime programming, the first of which were the back-to-back tandem of ABS-CBN’s 30-minute drama series Mula sa Puso (From the Heart), and Esperanza, both from 1997 to 1999. Mara Clara, ABS-CBN’s popular daily series in the afternoon slot, was also moved to the early evening programming. By the late 1990s, the daily drama serials, either locally produced or imported, had started to flood the airwaves, with Latin American telenovelas dominating the evening programming.

 

With the phenomenal popularity of Marimar, RPN offered more Mexican telenovelas, some of which include Maria la del Barrio (Maria of the Slums), 1996; Luz Clarita, 1996; Acapulco: Cuerpo y Alma (Acapulco: Body and Soul), 1996; Esmeralda, 1996; and Sin Ti (Without You), 1997. ABS-CBN also got hold of Mexican telenovelas, like Maria Mercedes, 1996, Rosalinda, 2000, both Thalia starrer, and Rubi, 2005, while GMA acquired Agujetas de Color de Rosa (Pink Shoe Laces), 1996, and ABC 5 got Morena Clara, 1996.

 

Telenovelas also came from other countries, and were dubbed in Filipino. From Colombia, RPN 9 had La Viuda de Blanco (The Widow of Blanco), 1997; ABS-CBN had Pasion de Amor (Passion of Love), 2005-6; and GMA had Betty La Fea (Ugly Betty), 2007, and Lola, 2013. From Venezuela, ABS-CBN aired Ilusiones (Illusions) and Maria Mercedes, both from 1996 to 1997, Kassandra, 1997-98, Solita Mi Amor (Solita, My Love), 2003, and Gata Salvaje (Wild Cat), 2003-5; and GMA aired Mis Tres Hermanas (All My Love), 2002. ABS-CBN showed Ana Manuela, 2014, from Brazil and El Cuerpo de Deseo (Body of Desire), 2008, from Florida in the United States. From Argentina, GMA showed Muñeca Brava (aka Monica Brava), 2001, and from Peru, Girasoles para Lucia (Sunflowers for Lucia), 2002.

 

Beginning in the 2000s, when telenovelas dubbed from Spanish to Filipino were waning in popularity, new drama series from Asia began airing on Philippine VHF channels. Chinovelas from Taiwan became popular. IBC 13 started the trend with its airing of Amazing Twins, 2002, but it was Meteor Garden, 2003, ABS-CBN, which starred the Taiwanese boy band F4 over which young Filipino audiences went crazy, that became a huge hit almost on the same level as that attained by Marimar. Other chinovelas aired on ABS-CBN that also became successful were its sequels Meteor Rain and Meteor Garden II, both in 2003, and 101st Proposal aka My Perfect Girl, 2008. TV5 showed Easy Fortune, Happy Life, 2010.

 

Simultaneous with chinovelas was the entry of telenovelas from South Korea into Philippine primetime TV, most of which were aired on GMA. The most popular was Full House, 2005, and Dae Jang Geum aka Jewel in the Palace, 2006. Other koreanovela hits aired on GMA were Bright Girl, 2003; Autumn in My Heart, 2003; Winter Sonata, 2004; Stairway to Heaven, 2005; Frog Prince, 2005; My Name Is Kim Sam-soon, 2006; Coffee Prince, 2008; Love Story in Harvard, 2008; Queen Seon Deok, 2010; Shining Inheritance aka Brilliant Legacy, 2010; Dong Yi, 2011-12; and My Love from the Star, 2014. ABS-CBN aired Lovers in Paris, 2003; Green Rose, 2005; Memories of Bali, 2005; Only You, 2005-6; A Love to Kill, 2006; Jumong, 2007; Marrying a Millionnaire, 2007; and Boys over Flowers, 2009-10. By the late 2000s and on to the 2010s, other networks joined the bandwagon, like TV5, which aired Golden Bride, Oh Su Jung vs. Karl, Hero, and My Wife Is a Superwoman, and Net25 showed The Snow Queen, 2013, Level 7 Civil Servant, 2014, and Hidden Identity, 2015. QTV and Studio 23 had reruns of koreanovelas that were initially broadcast on their sister stations GMA and ABS-CBN, respectively. The government channel PTV 4 began airing koreanovelas in 2014, starting with Oh, Ja Ryong Is Coming.

 

By the mid-2000s, these imported telenovelas and locally produced drama serials dominated afternoon and evening primetime programming. Entertainment talk and variety programs took the late morning and early afternoon time slots. Documentaries and public affairs programs were relegated to the late evening block, some of which were canceled, moved to weekend programming, or transferred to free UHF channels. Major networks ABS-CBN and GMA virtually broadcast all day with local programming and have practically deserted foreign shows in their VHF channels, while TV5, Net 25, Solar, PTV 4, and the rest continue to mix foreign programs because it is generally cheaper to import.

 

Regional Expansion and the Telecommunications Industry

 

Three important developments contributed to the growth of Philippine broadcasting beginning in the 1990s. These were the move toward decentralization, resulting in the growth of provincial media; the rapid revolution in communication technology; and the liberalization and deregulation of the telecommunications sector. These developments coincided with the return and expansion of the democratic space after the EDSA Revolt and the promotion and protection of the free enterprise system.

 

Before the turn of the 21st century, the 1998 KBP Broadcast Media Factbook estimated the number of television stations nationwide at 137. Of this number, 63 were originating stations, 50 were relay, and 24 were on UHF. In terms of distribution of TV stations by island groups, 12 TV stations were in Metro Manila, 53 in Luzon, 28 in the Visayas, and 44 in Mindanao. The number increased by the early 2000s. There were 952 radio stations scattered throughout the archipelago, 369 of which were AM and 583 FM. The number of television stations in the country was estimated at 225, all of which had access to 1,373 community antenna television networks. Beginning in 2005, Cebu had more FM radio stations than AM. The FMs numbered 23, while the AMs were only 16. Of the 10 television stations operating in Cebu, the most prominent are ABS-CBN, GMA, RPN 9, ABC 21, PTV 11, Channel 23, Channel 27, and SBN 6. A newcomer then was the Cebu Catholic Television Network (CCTN 47), which had started reaching out to audiences in Eastern Visayas and Northern Mindanao. There was only one cable TV, the Sky Cable, which was servicing the Cebu public during this period. As in Manila, the battle for the mass television audience was between the two most aggressive protagonists, network giants ABS-CBN and GMA.

 

The phenomenal growth was in cable television beginning in the 1990s. President Aquino abolished a Marcos decree that granted exclusive franchise to ally Roberto Benedicto to install and operate cable TV nationwide. Geny Lopez of ABS-CBN Corporation put up SKYVision on 25 Mar 1991, under the trade name SKY Cable. Beginning operations in Feb 1992, SKY Cable has since become the country’s leading cable TV operator. Included in its initial programming lineup were programs from CNN, HBO, Starworld, Discovery Channel, and ESPN, and local cable TV programs Cinema One, ABS-CBN News Channel (ANC), and the Lifestyle Channel. SKY Cable merged with competitor Home Cable in 2000 to increase its dominance of its market in Metro Manila and the regions.

 

To get a dose of foreign programs, one has to switch to cable where one can get a smorgasbord of international programs: news at CNN, BBC, NHK, ANC, and other networks; shows for the young in Nickelodeon; cartoons on the Cartoon Network; nature documentaries on the National Geographic channel; foreign movies on HBO, Showtime, AXN, and Star Movies; local movies on Cinema One and Pinoy Box Office; sports on ESPN, Star Sports, and Solar Sports; music on MTV and Myx; and many more in various languages from various continents.

 

By the turn of the 21st century, there were about 753 cable TV operators nationwide owned by more than 500 companies, reaching about 430,000 households all over the country.

 

UHF channels in Metro Manila became popular in the 1990s, which mainly served as an alternative to cable television. UHF broadcasting offered free programming for households in the target markets. Similarly, pay services were also introduced in 1992, when DWBC-TV Channel 68 began initial transmissions as a paid UHF station, and commenced regular service in Jan 1993. It offered foreign programs not shown on local TV, but eventually folded up due to intense competition from Sky Cable.

 

The first commercial station to broadcast on the UHF channel in Metro Manila was the Southern Broadcasting Network (SBN) DWCP-TV on Channel 21, which aired in May 1992 featuring programs from World TV. Owned by Chinese-Filipino business tycoon Lucio Co, the founder of the supermarket chain Puregold, SBN is both a radio and television network. It was then known as Word TV 21 before it changed its name to SBN Channel 21 in 1995. SBN was originally a radio station based in Davao City, which started broadcasting in 1970. SBN Channel 21’s programming was patterned after FEN Channel 17 of the former Clark US air base before it was abandoned in 1992 because of the eruption of Mount Pinatubo in that year and the non-extension of the bases agreement. SBN entered into an agreement with Solar Entertainment, which leased airtime on SBN beginning in Jan 2008. Solar aired programs from its entertainment channel ETC or Entertainment TV Channel. SBN renewed its partnership with Solar in 2011 to create the news network Talk TV, which became known as Solar News Network (SNN), a 24-hour English news channel on free-to-air TV, beginning on 30 Oct 2012. SNN moved to RPN 9 in 2013, renamed it 9TV, then CNN Philippines in 2014.

 

On 31 Oct 1992, the Radio Mindanao Network became the second radio-based network to launch a TV station called DWKC-TV on Channel 31 and the first UHF station to carry the format of a cable movie channel. It was renamed CTV 31, also in 1992. In 1997, it started broadcasting shows from E! Channel, a US cable TV channel. It stopped broadcasting in Aug 2000, but returned on 3 Jul 2011 as Beam Channel 31, but has since then undergone various programming changes, from the Game Channel to a new programming called CHASE, to Jack City, then Vision TV Shopping followed by Tagalog-dubbed telenovelas from the Telenovela Channel beginning in 2015.

 

In 1993, the third channel to go on UHF was the Rajah Broadcasting RJTV 29 of Ramon “RJ” Jacinto. An all-female and lifestyle TV station and the first local UHF channel to feature a home TV shopping program, it went into niche programming, showing infomercials, foreign shows, and cartoons, which all catered to kids during the day and baby boomers at night. It ended its operations in 2012.

 

After the initial success of these stations, other channels went to UHF. DWDB-TV Channel 27 of GMA Network was launched on 27 Aug 1995. Popularly known as CityNet Television from 1995 to 1999, Entertainment Music Channel (EMC) from 1999 to 2001, and resumed as CityTV in 2005, it was GMA’s main outlet for imported programs, freeing up slots in GMA 7’s programming for more domestic productions. DWAC-TV Channel 23, a UHF station of ABS-CBN Corporation, was launched on 12 Oct 1996. It originally carried music TV of MTV Asia from Hong Kong’s Star TV. News 23, produced by ABS-CBN News and Current Affairs over Channel 23, premiered on 14 Oct 1996. On the same year, it was renamed Studio 23, and carried the slogan “The Premium Network.” Studio 23’s programming catered to the upscale youth sector. Strong programs included the basketball games of the University Athletic Association of the Philippines (UAAP) and the National Collegiate Athletic Association (NCAA), and supplemental programming for programs originally shown on ABS-CBN 2, such as the reality programs Pinoy Dream Academy and Pinoy Big Brother. Originally an all-English station, it switched to Taglish, a combination of English and Tagalog, in 2004. In 2011, it severed ties with MTV Asia. Studio 23 stopped operations in 2014. It has since then been replaced by ABS-CBN Sports+Action. ABS-CBN also launched its music channel Myx on UHF in 2000. Early VJs and hosts of Myx TV were Sally Acupan, Rico Blanco, Heart Evangelista, Franco Mabanta, Luis Manzano, Karel Marquez, Bernard Palanca, Ala Paredes, Michi Valeriano, Lourd de Veyra, and Iya Villania.

 

Other UHF channels followed suit. In 1998, Delta Broadcasting System launched DBS TV Channel 35. In 1999, the Eagle Broadcasting Company launched Net 25, the Progressive Broadcasting Company (PBC) launched NTV 37 as a television counterpart for its NU 107 radio station by airing rock-related music videos, the Associated Broadcasting Company (ABC) ran its UHF station DWDZ Channel 47, and Channel 7 started carrying Channel V Philippines. In 2000, MTV Philippines launched Channel 41. In 2001, Channel 45 ran 3ABN or 3 Angels Broadcasting Network. In 2005, the Philippine Independent Church started operating Channel 49 GEM TV. In 2006, Sonshine Media Network International launched SMNI TV 39. In 2008, ZOE Broadcasting Network ran its UHD station ZOE TV-33. In 2011, the Nation Broadcasting Corporation of MediaQuest Holdings launched Aksyon TV Channel 41.

 

Many of these UHF stations either closed shop after a few years of broadcasting or reformatted or rebranded their identities. Those who folded up or became inactive include ABC’s DWDZ in 2003, RMN CTV 31 in 2003, Channel 47 and DBS Channel 35, both in 2004, and MTV Philippines in 2007. Those that changed programming formats were PBC, which replaced NUTV with UNTV in 2001; GMA CityNet changed to QTV or Quality Television in 2005, later replaced with GMA News TV Channel 27 in 2011; ZOE was renamed Light TV 33 in 2011; Solar Entertainment replaced Talk TV Channel 21 with Solar News Channel in 2012; and GEM TV Channel 49 was replaced by INC TV in 2012.

 

From 2001 to the present, UHF channels were also established in the regions. These provincial UHF broadcasts specialize in news, public service, and other types of shows as part of their free programming. A good example of UHF broadcasting from the regions is Beam Channel 26 DWHB-TV Baguio, owned by Broadcast Enterprises and Affiliated Media. Formerly affiliated with Solar Entertainment, Beam started its broadcast on 15 Aug 2011, carrying The Game Channel. Its main blocktimers are Essential Broadcasting Network, owned by the Greg Durante Ministries, and the CJ Group of Korea. It reaches the provinces of La Union, Pangasinan, Isabela, Cagayan Valley, the rest of the Ilocos, and the northern parts of Central Luzon. Another significant UHF station is the Cebu Catholic Television Network (CCTN) Channel 47. Founded by Nonito Limchua in 2002, it reaches out to audiences throughout the Visayas and Northern Mindanao. It mainly features religious programs, but it is keeping up with trends in mass-based programming by offering locally produced television drama series, absorbing media artists of the radio dramas that have been discontinued by some stations. In Mindanao, Hope Channel Philippines, first seen on UHF Channel 25 in Davao, was launched on 26 Sep 2011 by the religious network of the Seventh-Day Adventist Church and Gateway UHF Broadcasting. It shares a network with 3ABN International and is aired on Channel 45 in Manila.

 

Meanwhile, the emerging UHF channels experimented on niche programming, which targeted specific markets for the different types of programming they employed. These UHF channels, especially those owned by or affiliated with local VHF channels, favored programming that featured canned programs.

 

News and Public Affairs Programs

 

News became the most valued program after the 1986 EDSA Revolt as it was deemed that with the Marcos propaganda machine out, people could expect the “true news,” even if it was not pleasant, as opposed to the conjugal dictatorship’s ironic and obsessive promotion of “the true, the good, and the beautiful.” ABS-CBN jumpstarted newscast in the Filipino language with the revival of the pre-martial law Balita Ngayon (News Today), 1986-87. It ran for only a year, but since then newscasts in Filipino underwent a series of reformatting.

 

ABS-CBN was vigorous in its recruitment of anchors and staffers into its news and public affairs department, including those that were identified with the Marcoses, among whom were Frankie Evangelista of IBC 13; Noli de Castro from Benedicto’s DWWW; and Mel Tiangco, Ces Drilon, Doris Bigornia, and Korina Sanchez from MBS 4 (Rodrigo 2006).

 

GMA Headline News, 1986-92, aired almost coterminous with the Corazon Aquino administration, while GMA Balita (GMA News), 1986-97, covered the Aquino and Ramos administrations. GMA’s news anchors, like Tina Monzon-Palma and Randy David, and journalists, like Jessica Soho and Alex Tinsay, delivered a more sober reportage than ABS-CBN’s news that tended toward the loud barker-type newscasting for its entertainment-filled, sometimes shocking, reportage. News programs lived up to its social responsibility of informing the public. However, with the preponderance of popular genre programs since 1986, primetime news served to hook the viewing public to profitable shows afterward, creatively forming the symbiosis of news-as-service and comedy/drama/action-for-profit programming.

 

The most significant development in Philippine media programming was the institutionalization of Filipino as the language of news and public affairs. The establishment used to propagate the idea that English is the medium of delivery for newscast to be believable. With the euphoria over people empowerment, democratization of media space occasioned communication with the widest audience possible, and Tagalog-based Filipino became the standard. From Balita Ngayon (News Today), ABS-CBN produced TV Patrol, 1987-present, led by broadcast journalists Noli de Castro, Mel Tiangco, Frankie Evangelista, and Angelique Lazo. New team members, such as Korina Sanchez, Ted Failon, and Julius Babao, either joined or replaced the original members of the news team. The Filipino viewing audience listened to the news anchors and reporters of ABS-CBN in colloquial Tagalog, which was entirely different from the formal Tagalog rendering of the news by Lee Andres and Paul Lacanilao of BBC Balita (BBC News), BBC 2, and Dell Villanueva, Ismael Reyes, and Betsy Enriquez of Balita (News), Channel 4, and its reformatted evening news in Filipino during the martial law period, then by Andres on Headline Trese (Headline on 13), IBC 13, or by Helen Vela, Mike Lacanilao, Bobby Guanzon, Rene Jose, Rey Pacheco, and Amado Pineda on GMA Balita (GMA News), 1986-98. It was still sometime after that GMA adapted to the changing language of broadcast media. Saksi: GMA Headline Balita (Eyewitness: GMA News Headline), 1995-present, made headway when it kicked off savvier news reporting from its anchors Mike Enriquez, who came from GMA’s FM radio, and newcomer Karen Davila, with reporters Jessica Soho, Arnold Clavio, and Susan Enriquez. Mel Tiangco and Jay Sonza, who had issues with ABS-CBN over product endorsement deals on TV, joined GMA’s news team in 1996, and Vicky Morales joined Saksi from GMA’s late-night English news program, while Davila moved to ABS-CBN. The early evening newscast in Filipino changed formats, bannered by Frontpage: Ulat ni Mel Tiangco (Frontpage: News Report by Mel Tiangco), 1999-2004, then to 24 Oras (24 Hours), 2004-present, to rival ABS-CBN’s TV Patrol, which led the ratings game during the period.

 

English newscasts continued to be relegated to the late-night time slot, but all shifted to Filipino in the late 1990s. ABS-CBN produced The World Tonight, 1986-99, anchored by Angelo Castro, Loren Legarda, and Larry Ng, who were joined by segment reporters Ces Oreña-Drilon, Cathy Yap-Yang, and Dyan Castillejo. It lost to GMA’s Filipino late-night newscast Frontpage. ABS-CBN replaced the show with Pulso: Aksyon Balita (Pulse: News in Action), 1999-2000, hosted by Sanchez and Failon, who were later replaced by Gel Santos-Relos and Erwin Tulfo, then reformatted several times using the Filipino language. GMA had GMA Headline News, 1986-92, with Monzon Palma, Jose Mari Velez, Morales, and Pineda, which changed to GMA Network News, 1992-98, this time anchored, at different years, by Leslie Espino, Morales, Jessica Soho, Marga Ortigas, Mari Kaimo, and Risa Hontiveros-Baraquel. It was later reformatted to a full Filipino newscast via Saksi, which premiered as the network’s early evening newscast in 1995 until it was moved to the late evening shift in 2002, this time anchored by Clavio and Pia Arcangel.

 

RPN 9 continued its flagship programs until 2008 when the network was acquired by Solar Entertainment. The early evening news program NewsWatch: Evening Cast was anchored by Harry Gasser, then by Cielo Villaluna and Cristina Pecson, and the late evening edition, NewsWatch Prime Cast, by Cathy Santillan and Gasser, who was later replaced by Eric Eloriaga. The early evening edition was replaced by RPN Aksyon News (RPN News in Action), later by NewsWatch Aksyon Balita (NewsWatch News in Action), 2004-6, first anchored by Erwin Tulfo, Connie Sison, Aljo Bendijo, Jake Morales, Vikki Sambilay, and Bobby Yan.

 

English newscasts moved to the networks’ free UHF channels. Those that were retained on VHF (very high frequency) channels had to face the stiff competition posed by newscasts in the national language.

 

News programming beginning in the 1990s was highly marked by a rigodon of anchors and reporters, a highly flexible movement of primetime slots, and what critics would call the tabloidization of news that skewed the content, format, and style of reporting toward entertainment, all in the rush to attract more viewers, particularly the C-D-E markets, and increase each station’s ratings, which spelled the life and death of the programs. The broadcast industry was then becoming the game for the big conglomerates, with news and public affairs programs giving the mass audience the television equivalents of sensational material found in the tabloids. The “war of the broadcast networks,” mainly between ABS-CBN and GMA, turned fiercer, each trying to outdo the other in selling news and entertainment that favored the bizarre, the absurd, the sexy, the violent, the taboo, and the macabre.

 

In spite of the trend toward sensationalism, serious news reporting also significantly developed beginning in the late 1990s and onward the 2000s with the war coverage of leading broadcast media companies. Both GMA and ABS-CBN sent teams of journalists to cover the US invasion of Iraq in 2003, following the 11 Sep 2001 attacks, for which the American government blamed terrorists coming from the Middle East. The networks faced the arduous process of visa applications, securing permits for coverage, transporting equipment, and protecting their crew, all done in fulfillment of a reporter’s dream to do “real journalism.” It has since become imperative for Philippine media to achieve coverage of several events happening outside the country, present the geopolitical implications of worldwide developments, and analyze the impact of such events on Filipinos scattered all over the globe.

 

Asia’s freest media returned with a vengeance after toppling the Marcos dictatorship. With the viewing public eager to know the different facets of the nation’s life, documentary and investigative programs multiplied in the post-EDSA period.

 

A few significant documentaries were produced on radio. Examples are Kalinangang Pilipino (Filipino Heritage), 1994, DZRM Radyo Manila, written by Norma Balaoro-Remo, which showcased the different artistic expressions and cultural heritage of Filipinos; Sa Likod ng Balita (Behind the News), 1991-95, DXND-Kidapawan, Cotabato, produced by Notre Dame Broadcasting Corporation, written and hosted by Malu Maphytte Roa Cadelina, which critically assessed both local and national political issues through the lens of culture; Bulawanon nga Kagawasan (Golden Liberty), 1994, DYVL-AM Tacloban, which featured the voices of ordinary people about the significance of the 50th anniversary of the historic Leyte landing of Gen Douglas MacArthur; and Yaman ng Lahi (Bounty of the Race), 1992, DWLC Philippine Broadcasting System, written by Carmencita C. Bodino and hosted by Josie A. Gonzalez and Edgardo M. Driz, which focused on the relevance of regional culture. DYFM Radyo Bombo Iloilo City came out with a series of magazine and public affairs documentaries in the 1990s that tackled issues about history, current events, and art activities of the region.

 

The most politically significant television documentaries during the early years of the Corazon Aquino administration were those produced by IBC 13, which at that time was suffering from legal battles with Marcos loyalists resisting the Aquino government’s sequestration of the network. IBC 13 hardly had any public information show before 1986, except for its news programs. People Power: The Philippine Experience, 1986, was about the February EDSA Revolt. Ceasefire, 1986, was the first documentary that looked into the possibility of a ceasefire between the military and the leftist National Democratic Front–New People’s Army. Keithley Report: The US Bases, 1986, presented the different views about the presence of military bases of the United States in the country at a time when the US bases provision was under deliberation by the Constitutional Commission, which was tasked by the Aquino administration to draft the new Philippine constitution. Ramut: The Roots of Revolution in the Cordillera, 1986, traced the history of the struggle of the people of the Cordillera in northern Philippines. Tiempo Muerto: Crisis and Poverty in Negros (Downtime: Crisis and Poverty in Negros), 1986, looked into the situation of the sugar workers in central Philippines and the struggle for emancipation from hunger and feudal values. Autonomy: No Shortcut to Peace, 1987, addressed the question of autonomy and the perception of several minority groups about the issue. Hamon sa Pamahalaan, Hamon sa Taumbayan (Challenge to the Government, Challenge for the People), 1987, considered the first documentary that used the Filipino language, analyzed the meaning of the plebiscite results in the context of the various crises that have rocked the Aquino administration.

 

During the early years of the post-martial law period, it seemed that everybody wanted to talk, and talk people did, almost unhampered. Among public affairs talk programs, the game changer was Truth Forum, 1986, IBC 13’s first weekly public affairs program and the first talk show that used Filipino as a language of serious discussion about current issues of the country. The show was conceptualized by a team of University of the Philippines (UP) scholars, such as literature professor Teresita G. Maceda, hosted by UP sociology professor Randy David, and directed by filmmaker Marilou Diaz-Abaya, with guests that formed the panel of discussants and a live audience of 15, representing different views and sectors. The program was the television equivalent of the parliament of the streets. Truth Forum proved that Filipino can be a powerful language for intelligent discourse on television. The program switched networks and changed titles to Public Forum, IBC, to Randy David sa Public Forum (Randy David on Public Forum), ABC 5, then to Public Life with Randy David, GMA, and shifted time slots when entertainment programs began easing public affairs programs out of primetime programming and moving them to the late-night shift. These programming moves compromised the viewership of the show. More public affairs talk shows dealing with political, social, economic, and religious issues that tested the limits of Aquino’s democratic space, without fear of repression, came into the picture. GMA and ABS-CBN programs dominated the programming of the genre. Lawyer Ricardo “Dong” Puno continued with Viewpoint, which started in 1984, GMA, until his ambition to run for the Senate in 1998 got in the way. He returned to television via Dong Puno Live, 1995-2000, and Insider, 2005-6, both on ABS-CBN, Viewpoints, 2006-7, ABS-CBN News Channel, then moved to Aksyon TV for programs like Dong Puno de Kalibre (Quality Dong Puno), 2011-14, and News5 Debates: Hamon sa Pagbabago (News5 Debates: Challenge for Change), which premiered in 2011. Veteran print journalists had their talk shows on TV. Luis Beltran voiced out his opinion on the state of the nation in Straight from the Shoulder, 1987-94, GMA, which was a revival of his pre-martial TV program of the same title on MBC Channel 11. Teddy Benigno interviewed local and international newsmakers, including Henry Kissinger and Margaret Thatcher, in Firing Line, 1992-99, GMA, co-hosted first by Oscar Orbos then by Solita Monsod. Both Orbos and Monsod had their Debate with Mare at Pare (Debate with Mare and Pare), 1998-2006, GMA, an open debate program that discussed various political issues.

 

Another game changer was Cheche Lazaro’s The Probe Team, 1987-2010, which had initially aired on ABS-CBN, before it moved to different networks. It can be considered the most critically acclaimed weekly public affairs magazine program. It pioneered investigative broadcast journalism in the country and raised Philippine broadcast journalism several notches higher than the prevailing standards of “envelopmental” journalism of the period when many journalists in both print and broadcast media were reportedly paid cash in envelopes by individuals and institutions in exchange for good publicity. Lazaro’s team of young broadcast journalists, such as Maria Ressa, Luchi Cruz-Valdes, Tony Velasquez, Judy Torres, and Angie Ramos, critically examined the deeper aspects and dimensions of various socially important subjects, such as corruption in public office or profiles of ordinary people or famous personalities.

 

Another game changer was ABS-CBN’s Magandang Gabi, Bayan (Good Evening, Nation), 1988-2005, which utilized the full, authoritative voice of Noli de Castro, the kabayan (fellow countryman) of the mass audience, speaking in crisp Tagalog and exposing government anomalies. Through investigative reports, he taunted officials of the land for their neglect of the masses, which made him highly popular.
