The program functioned as the critical fourth estate, but toward the mid-1990s, the program tended to focus more on de Castro’s image as a mediator between the masses and those in power than the ability of the program’s masa audience to rely on their own agency to challenge government ineptness. The program’s popularity catapulted de Castro to the vice presidency during Gloria Macapagal Arroyo’s administration.

 

The most important public affairs programs of the period came from the giants ABS-CBN and GMA. The Correspondents, 1998-2010, ABS-CBN, was a documentary program that utilized a number of the network’s stable of young journalists in bringing out exciting facets of certain topics. Imbestigador (Investigator), which premiered in 2000, GMA, hosted by Mike Enriquez, is a documentary-investigative show known for dangerously pursuing hot cases of drugs, arms, and prostitution but has also extended into other investigative issues such as poverty, health, and education. Similarly, XXX: Exklusibo, Explosibo, Exposé (XXX: Exclusive, Explosive, Exposé), 2006-13, ABS-CBN, was a crime-investigative show hosted by Julius Babao, Pinky Webb, and Anthony Taberna. Imbestigador and XXX received severe criticisms for baiting suspected malfeasants in order for the crime they are supposed to document to happen and for possibly violating several human rights in the process of the commission, investigation, prosecution, and judgment of cases. Che Che Lazaro Presents, 1999-2003, GMA, then 2010-present, ABS-CBN, continues the investigative and documentary mission of Probe Productions by tackling complex social and political issues. It later expanded to three- to five-hour broadcast on ABS-CBN, starting past midnight of Sunday up to the early hours of Monday morning. Another important program in this tradition is Investigative Documentaries, premiered 2011, GMA News TV Channel 11, hosted by print journalist Malou Mangahas, who provides an in-depth analysis of current issues.

 

Of the investigative-documentary genre, two programs stand out the most: i-Witness, which premiered in 1999, and Reporter’s Notebook, beginning in 2004, both of GMA. Presented by Howie Severino, Kara David, Sandra Aguinaldo, and Jay Taruc, i-Witness selects topics not usually tackled in other shows, embedding their journalists in excruciating and life-threatening scenarios which are the everyday world of their subjects. Broadcast journalists Jiggy Manicad and Maki Pulido deal with difficult issues of government neglect and public accountability in child labor, migration, education, and a host of other concerns in Reporter’s Notebook. The two programs received dozens of awards from academic and civic organizations in the country and several recognitions in the New York Festivals for Television, with i-Witness having already won two medals from the George Foster Peabody Awards, said to be the Pulitzer Prize in broadcast journalism.

Recent welcome developments in the documentary genre are Reel Time and Front Row, which both premiered in 2011 on GMA News TV Channel 11. These documentaries challenged broadcast conventions by following a more cinematic approach to broadcast documentaries that cover a wide range of social issues. Unlike most documentaries in which the hosts tended to be the central figure in the analysis of topics covered by the programs, Reel Time and Front Row presented and dissected the struggles and triumphs of Filipinos in the context of the country’s social and political realities without a host or a narrator. Their episodes have won the Peabody and several other awards from local and international groups.

 

Single-airing documentaries were also produced during the period. People-Powered Presidency, 1987, traced the roots of the EDSA Revolt that catapulted Corazon Aquino to power and examined her first 10 months in office. Inside Congress, 1987, examined the legislative history of the Philippines from the time it was convened in 1946, its closure in 1972, and its return in 1986. Dear Sam … Sumasaiyo, Juan (Dear Sam …Yours, Juan), 1989, directed by Joel Lamangan, written by Rosalie Matilac, and produced by the Ateneo Center for Social Policy and Public Affairs, highlighted the protest movement and the art forms that critiqued the presence of US military bases in the country. Pilipino Ako: Namumuhay sa Europa (I Am a Filipino: Living in Europe), 1992, produced by Cheche Lazaro, reported by Luchi Cruz-Valdes, and hosted by Danny Javier, tackled the push and pull factors, through case studies, that bring about the migration of Filipino workers to Europe. Anatomy of Rape, 1993, GMA, written and hosted by Jessica Soho, intelligently examined the issue of rape at a time when people felt there was a need to bring the issue into the open; Kids with Kids, 1996, produced by Cheche Lazaro’s Probe Productions, hosted by Yas Mapua and Francis M, discussed sex and relationships among teens; Jose Rizal: Ang Buhay ng Isang Bayani (Jose Rizal: The Life of a Hero), 1996, produced by Bookmark and the History Department of Ateneo de Manila University, directed by Butch Nolasco and narrated by Joonee Gamboa, was about the life of national hero Jose Rizal; Batas Militar (Martial Law), 1997, written by Lito Tiongson and Pete Lacaba, produced by the Foundation for Worldwide People Power, was a documentary about martial law in the Philippines; and Minsan Lang Sila Bata (Children Only Once), 1997, written and directed by Ditsi Carolino and Sadhana Buxani, produced by the Ateneo Center for Social Policy and Public Affairs, featured children working as laborers in select regions of the country.

 

A significant progress was the entry of women in news and public affairs, which have long been dominated by men. The roster of broadcast personalities today counts women, now in fact ubiquitous, who have earned as much stature and credibility. Although much more needs to be done, the female perspective has seeped into many broadcast programs that deal with traditionally male subjects, such as politics and foreign relations.

 

Broadcast journalism in the Philippines is inextricably linked with the country's national and local politics. Politicians enter the broadcast industry either in the spirit of public service or to help push forward their career in politics. News and public affairs programs have often been the launching pad for an individual’s political career. The most glaring examples of broadcast personalities who were successful in their entry into politics are Noli de Castro, who became senator, then vice president of the country mainly on the merit of his programs on ABS-CBN, especially Magandang Gabi, Bayan (Good Evening, Nation), 1988-2005, and the segment “Hoy, Gising!” (Hey, Wake Up!) of the daily newscast TV Patrol, which premiered in 1987; Loren Legarda, whose career as a senator was partly propelled by her public affairs and magazine programs on ABS-CBN, like The World Tonight, 1986-97, Pep Talk, 1988-90, and The Inside Story, 1990-98; and Orlando “Orly” Mercado, a communication expert whose career in broadcast journalism spanning from the late 1960s to the martial law period, particularly with the popularity of his program on GMA, Kapwa Ko, Mahal Ko (I Love My Fellowman), which premiered in 1974 and continued on air after martial law, largely contributed to his political career as a senator and defense secretary during the post-EDSA period. Some news reporters also tried to enter local politics; some of them, like Gilbert Remulla, who also comes from a clan of politicians, and Ted Failon, gained the trust of audiences, while others failed in their bid to hold political office.

 

Entertainment programs also significantly helped in increasing the chances of gaining political seats. Joseph “Erap” E. Estrada, who rose from the ranks of local politics during the martial law period, became president of the country from 1998 to 2001 mainly on account of his popularity as a movie actor whose films were also shown on local broadcasting networks. Fernando Poe Jr, considered the king of Philippine movies and whose films continued to be shown on television, treaded on the political path taken by his friend Estrada to embolden him to run for the presidency, but failed allegedly because of massive cheating committed by his political opponents. The political career of Vicente “Tito” Sotto depended on the huge popularity of the long-running noontime show Eat Bulaga! (Lunchtime Peek-a-boo!), which has consistently topped the ratings since 1979. Some popular movie stars whose presence has also been conspicuously felt on television and went into politics are Vilma Santos, Herbert Bautista, Ramon Revilla, Jinggoy Estrada, Roderick Paulate, Lou Veloso, Cita Astals, Daniel Fernando, Alfred Vargas, Joey Marquez, and Alma Moreno. Some who originated in broadcast, including the advertising and the recording industries, or those more associated with broadcast than other media platforms, and made it into politics are Connie Angeles, Ted Failon, Isko Moreno, Lucy Torres, Teri Onor, Anjo Yllana, Kring Kring Gonzales, and Imelda Papin.

 

Clearly, not only do the broadcast genres of public affairs and entertainment mix or their boundaries blurred; so do the personae of celebrity stars and politicians whose identities swing in the pendulum of the real and the imagined during the uncertainties of the post-EDSA Revolt up to today, which is highly marked by the virtualities of transmedia, the ubiquity of social media, and the heterogeneity of the transnationalization of media ownership and practices.

 

Variety Programs and Talk Entertainment Programs

 

Variety programs continued to be popular among viewers. The format remained a hodgepodge of music, games or contests, and special segments usually sponsored by a product. Unlike in the martial law period when variety shows were aired in the noontime, evening, and weekend programming, variety shows during the post-EDSA period were mainly programmed in the afternoon and broadcast daily until Saturdays. Sunday variety programs also took the noontime slot. Entertainment talk programs, mainly about showbiz personalities, were broadcast during late afternoon weekends.

 

The noontime variety program is an anchor on which the network establishes its ascendancy in the ratings game. Pioneer noontime show Student Canteen was revived for a year, 1989-90, RPN 9, with original hosts Eddie Ilarde and Bobby Ledesma, joined by Malu Maglutac, Jean Garcia, Cherry Pie Picache, basketball player Atoy Co, and Ramon Lorenzo, a perennial winner in the program’s quiz segment “IQ VII” during its run during the martial law period.

 

ABS-CBN revived in 1987 the noontime show Kalatog Pinggan (Clattering Plates), hosted by Bert “Tawa” Marcelo, Herbert Bautista, and Joey Marquez. It was with BBC 2 from 1985 to 1986, then moved to ABC 5 in 1989, this time hosted by Randy Santiago, John Estrada, and Bayani Agbayani. Kalatog Pinggan was replaced by Eat Bulaga! (Lunchtime Peek-a-boo!) when the latter moved from RPN 9 to ABS-CBN in 1989. GMA had Lunch Date, 1986-93, where Willie Revillame started as a host, and Salo-Salo Together (Lunch Together), 1993-95. Student Canteen finally bowed to rival Eat Bulaga! Student Canteen host Eddie Ilarde resurfaced in the noontime show Alas Dose sa Trese (Twelve at Thirteen), 1998-99, IBC 13, with former Student Canteen host Boots Anson-Roa and PTV newscaster Chiqui Roa-Puno.

 

Eat Bulaga! dominated noontime programming and continues to be the most popular noontime variety show, which first aired on RPN 9, 1979-1989, then with ABS-CBN from 1989 to 1994, and finally with GMA from 1995 onward. The program was perhaps at the apex of its popularity in the late 1980s until the 1990s with the hilarious cast graced by the cute and witty Aiza Seguerra, a 1987 runner-up in the program’s segment “Little Miss Philippines.” Eat Bulaga! pioneered numerous talent search and game segments that have become the template for the industry, the most popular of which is the guessing game “Pinoy Henyo” (Filipino Genius), 2004. For the longest time, ABS-CBN tried to beat the show with a succession of programs, to no avail: ’Sang Linggo nAPO Sila (APO Now Runs for a Week), 1995-98, which was expanded from a Sunday to a weeklong program hosted by the rather uppity Apo Hiking Society, followed by Magandang Tanghali, Bayan, 1998-2003, later renamed Masayang Tanghali, Bayan, 2003-4, and MTB: Ang Saya-Saya (MTB: So Happy), 2004-5, which carried on the challenge and generated income for the network.

 

It was not until Wowowee in 2005 that ABS-CBN finally found the formula to evenly rival Eat Bulaga!, with an engaging combination of surprising game segments, dramatic stories by contestants, and sexy dancers driven to scandalous proportion by host Willie Revillame. The show became known for the heart-wrenching stories contestants tell to the public as they compete for prizes and the tremendous talents they exhibit on the worldwide stage. On 4 Feb 2006, a stampede unfortunately happened during its first anniversary celebration at the PhilSports Arena (formerly Ultra) in Pasig City. Seventy-three people died and 700 were injured in the fanatical gathering incited by the show itself. The network and the host were severely criticized for profiting millions through encouraging mendicancy. It ran until 2010 when it had serious conflicts with the public, shareholders, and the management after Revillame criticized the zealous coverage of the funeral of former president Corazon Aquino to the detriment of his show. The show resurrected as Wil Time Big Time on TV5 from Oct 2010 to Jan 2013 and as Willing Willie (That’s So Willy) from Jan to Oct 2013 when it suffered from poor ratings and eventually ceased programming, until GMA revived the show as Wowowin, 2015, in its Sunday late afternoon program slot. ABS-CBN made a few programs to fill the slot vacated by Wowowee, first with Pilipinas Win na Win (Philippines On the Win), 2010, hosted by Kris Aquino and Robin Padilla, and Happy Yipee Yehey!, 2011-12, emceed by Randy Santiago, John Estrada, Rico Puno, Toni Gonzaga, and Pokwang. The network moved It’s Showtime from its prelunch time slot to challenge Eat Bulaga!’s supremacy and offered serious challenge because of its more extensive talent search, fantastic production numbers, and the presence of more popular young personalities. Sometimes It’s Showtime beats Eat Bulaga! in the ratings game with the popularity of its hosts and contests, although it remains to be proven whether a different variety show will be able to topple Eat Bulaga!, which has been durable in terms of holding on to the Filipino audience worldwide. Eat Bulaga! also continues to innovate, with hit segments like “Pinoy Henyo” (Filipino Genius), “All for Juan, Juan for All,” and “Kalye Serye with AlDub” (Street Series with AlDub). AlDub stands for the split-screen love team of young star Alden Richards and dubsmash sensation Maine Mendoza.

 

Sex became a come-on, particularly for noontime shows. The Sex Bomb Girls, who gyrate, grind, and push their pelvis forward while egging on contestants of “Laban o Bawi” (Fight or Withdraw), have become a regular fixture in Eat Bulaga! The sexual innuendos by the male hosts of Magandang Tanghali, Bayan, later renamed Masayang Tanghali, Bayan, crossed the line separating naughtiness from indecency. In sitcoms, comedy is not measured by the wit of the actors but by the plunging necklines that have become the common practice among the female actors. One can easily and rightfully criticize these incidents as exploitation of women whose bodies are used in the economy of television entertainment, but the irony is that women have occupied the networks’ top positions. For example, Charo Santos was the head of the entertainment division of ABS-CBN and Wilma Galvante was her counterpart in GMA when these variety shows were encouraged.

 

Late-night talk entertainment shows during the early post-EDSA period targeted mainly the AB crowd. Edu Manzano’s Not So Late Night with Edu, which premiered in 1985, GMA, an evening talk entertainment show, continued airing until 1987 before it moved to ABS-CBN, 1987-93. Aside from becoming a popular game show host, Manzano later hosted similar programs such as Late Night with Edu, 1992-94, and What’s Up, Doods?, 2013, both on ABC/TV5. Oh No, It’s Johnny, 1987-99, ABS-CBN, hosted by Johnny Litton, is considered a classy late-night talk show that combined wit, elitism, and old-school rambunctiousness. Singer Martin Nievera put his gift of gab to good use by hosting Martin After Dark (aka MAD), 1988-93, GMA, then 1993-98, ABS-CBN, featuring known personalities and with segments of special features. Journalist Jullie Yap-Daza continued hosting the late-night talk entertainment–public affairs show Tell the People, 1981-97, RPN 9. The show was an original BBC 2 production called Tell the City, 1980-81, and would become Tell the People Now when it moved to ANC in 2001 and stayed in the network until 2004. Mel Tiangco and Jay Sonza’s Mel & Jay, 1988-96, ABS-CBN, tackled the most mundane and most social of subjects, from governmental inefficiencies to cultural peculiarities of people. It migrated to GMA after the hosts had a legal tussle with ABS-CBN over commercial rights and was retitled Partners Mel & Jay, 1996-2004. Tiangco would later on be partnered with Joey de Leon in Mel & Joey, 2004-11, GMA.

 

Daily and weekend variety shows were focused on celebrities, mainly young and upcoming stars. German Moreno’s shows on GMA had a spike during the period, which include the daily late afternoon program That’s Entertainment, 1986-96, which featured Moreno’s stable of young stars, and the weekend programs Saturday Entertainment, 1986-95, GMA Supershow, 1984-97, and Master Showman, which debuted in 1997, later renamed Walang Tulugan with the Master Showman (Awake All Night with the Master Showman), a late-night Saturday program that ends on Sunday morning. ABS-CBN had the daily afternoon show Ang TV (The TV), which showcased the network’s crop of young talents. A curious practice in most variety shows is that of tasking young stars to sing even if they lack the talent or the training to render a musical performance. It has become a staple component in local broadcast programs to the point of marginalizing professional singers, pitting more popular personalities against the more qualified and better-trained artists.

 

The heated rivalry between the networks ABS-CBN and GMA showed in the entertainment programs they pitted against each other. ABS-CBN had the weekly variety musical program ASAP, aka All-Star Sunday Afternoon Party, which premiered in 1995; the entertainment talk shows on weekday mornings, such as Teysi ng Tahanan (Tessie of the Home), 1991-97, and Morning Girls with Kris and Korina, 2002-4; the weekend celebrity talk shows Showbiz Lingo, 1992-99, and The Buzz, 1999-2015; the weekend entertainment talk show Sharon, 1998-2010; and the weekend variety dance program Loveli-ness, 1987. GMA’s equivalent of these programs were SOP, aka Sobrang Okay, Pare! (Super Okay, Dude!), 1997-2010; Sis: Janice and Gelli (Sisters: Janice and Gelli), 2001-10; Star Talk, which premiered in 1995; S-Files, 1998-2007; and Vilma!, 1986-95. IBC produced Maricel Live!, 1986-89, The Sharon Cuneta Show, 1986-88, and Lovely Ness, 1988-89.

 

Showbiz talk shows had a heyday in the late 1980s up to the 1990s. Inday Badiday’s See True, GMA, ended its run in 1987, but followed it up with Eye to Eye, 1988-97, and The Truth and Nothing but the Truth, 2000, both on GMA. Presidential daughter Kris Aquino, at age 15, first appeared as a guest on See True in 1986 immediately following the ascendancy of mother Corazon Aquino to the presidency. Scoop, 1988, IBC 13, introduced movie talk show hosts Boy C. de Guia and Lolit Solis. Audiences welcomed weekend celebrity talk shows, such as Showbiz Lingo, 1992-97, then renamed Showbiz Lingo Plus, 1997-99, ABS-CBN, hosted by Butch Francisco, Cristy Fermin, Ogie Diaz, and John Lapus, and Startalk, which premiered in 1995, GMA, and had Kris Aquino and Boy Abunda as initial hosts of the program before they left for ABS-CBN, and later hosted by Lolit Solis, Joey de Leon, Butch Francisco after he left ABS-CBN, and Ricky Lo. Startalk became notorious when it got bold star Rosanna Roces as one of its hosts. Another show hosted by Boy Abunda and Kris Aquino, The Buzz, 1999-2015, ABS-CBN, inherited the mantle of Showbiz Lingo by featuring the latest news on showbiz personalities and having exclusive features of the latest scandals.

 

These celebrity talk programs earned both popularity and criticisms when they featured the latest news on showbiz personalities, peered into the most private aspects of actors’ lives, offered exclusive features of the latest scandals and controversies, particularly those involving breakups, marital infidelity, gender identity, and sex, and created, maneuvered, or provoked confrontations. Sexual innuendos have also become the trademark of these programs. For example, Rosanna Roces did a song number in her program while suggestively caressing the shaft of the microphone. Also, these tabloid talk shows have virtually become confessional booths for many stars, opening themselves up on national television, making a public revelation, often in tears, of deep personal secrets. Private Conversations with Boy Abunda, premiered 2001, ANC 21, and The Bottom Line with Boy Abunda, premiered 2009, ABS-CBN, paved the way for the host’s respectability by having a more punching yet empathic and more intimate talk program.

 

Game Shows and Talent Search Contests

 

Game shows continued to gain popularity as they served to entice people who wanted to prove their knowledge and skills combined with mettle. Pepe Pimentel’s Family Kuarta o Kahon (Family Cash or Box), 1987-2000, RPN 9, was held every Sunday noontime at SM City North EDSA and broadcast live on Channel 9. It was a hilarious show of parlor games and chances, oftentimes ending with ludicrous prizes—like street food, for instance—for those who failed in their wager.

 

A few educational quiz shows were produced during this period. The most popular was Battle of the Brains, 1992-99, RPN 9, then 1999-2001, PTV 4, hosted by David Celdran. It was a quiz competition open to students in the primary to tertiary levels. Participants battle with one another from the easy to average and then to the difficult round in weekly, monthly, quarterly, and annual tournaments, bagging institutional prestige and personal glory. Viewers elsewhere become contestants themselves as they try to answer the questions for the studio contestants. The show received tremendous support from the public and sponsors. When it folded up, Digital LG Quiz, 1999-2005, GMA, tried to resurrect the school “brain tournament” genre but did not last long. The nearest successor to Battle of the Brains is the segment “Pinoy Henyo” of Eat Bulaga!, though the contest, while testing the analytical and encyclopedic knowledge of contestants, is non-academic in nature and is open to everyone. Who Wants to Be a Millionaire?, 2000-2002, IBC 13, hosted by Christopher de Leon, was based on the original British game show of the same format and title. It became very popular with a top prize of two million pesos to be bagged by a contestant who passed the ever-increasing level of difficult questions with higher risks. The show was revived on TV5 in 2009 with Vic Sotto as host. ABS-CBN produced interesting quiz game shows with high production value, such as Kapamilya: Deal or No Deal (Family Member: Deal or No Deal), 2006-9 and 2012-13; Ready, Get Set, Go!, 1992-97; and the Game Ka Na Ba? (Are You Ready to Play) series: Game KNB?, 2001-2; Milyon-Milyon Na: Game KNB? (It’s Running in the Millions: Are You Ready to Play?), 2002-3; Next Level Na: Game KNB? (Onto the Next Level: Are You Ready to Play?), 2003-4; and Pilipinas, Game KNB? (Philippines, Are You Ready to Play?), 2001-9, hosted by Kris Aquino, 2001-7, then by Edu Manzano, 2007-9. GMA produced the quiz-game show GoBingo!, 1996-99, hosted by Arnel Ignacio. The music-game show K: The 1-Million-Peso Videoke Challenge, 2002-4, hosted also by Ignacio, and later reformatted as All-Star K: The 1-Million-Peso Videoke Challenge, 2004-9, hosted by singer Jaya and comedian Allan K, rode on the popularity of videoke music among Filipinos. Also on GMA, Celebrity Bluff, which premiered in 2013, with Eugene Domingo as host and comedians Boobay, Jose Manalo, and Brod Pete as bluffers, tests celebrity contenders’ knowledge in all fields, giving sometimes seemingly preposterous explanations for answers that are revealed to be the correct ones in the end.

 

The most important sports program that came out during the post-EDSA period was Probe Productions’ Game Plan, 1995-2008, first on GMA, then on Studio 23, and finally on Solar Sports. Some of its hosts over the years included Paolo Abrera, Paolo Bediones, Suzi Entrata, Akiko Thompson, Rovilson Fernandez, and Paulo Soler. Its hosts did stories of many sports across the country, featuring mainly nonprofessional athletes. It was publicly relaunched in 2012 as an online healthy lifestyle sports show. Another interesting show was Sports Unlimited, 1997-2015, ABS-CBN, hosted by Dyan Castillejo and Marc Nelson, which featured different kinds of sports and ordinary and prominent sports figures. Sports programs appearing in the 2000s started adopting the reality TV format, such as Extra Challenge, 2003-6, 2012-13, GMA, and The Amazing Race Philippines, which premiered in 2012, TV5.

 

The Philippine entertainment industry has become insatiable in its quest for new and younger talents. Starstruck, 2003-7, 2009-10, 2015, GMA, reinvigorated the field of talent search when it started in 2003, becoming the launching pad of some promising actors like Jennylyn Mercado, Rocco Nacino, Paulo Avelino, and the Philippines’ first Miss World title holder Megan Young. Not to be outdone, ABS-CBN launched its Star Circle Quest, 2004-11, with seasonal editions for kids.

 

Singing contests have become a staple part of television programming, and every year tens of thousands join the open call. GMA produced Ang Bagong Kampeon (The New Champion), 1985-88, Search for a Star, 2003-4, and Pinoy Pop Superstar, 2004-7, while ABS-CBN came out with Tanghalan ng Kampeon (Stage of Champions), 1987-93, Search for the Star in a Million, 2003-6, The Singing Bee, premiered 2008, X-Factor Philippines, premiered 2012, and The Voice of the Philippines, premiered 2013. These shows churned out admirable singers whose longevity in the music industry will be decided not only by their talent but by market agility. In a nation known for musical prowess, singing contests continue to attract the young and ambitious, though it remains a challenge to impart “Filipino” musicality and to outgrow the imitation of the “foreign” style of singing. Filipinos may be known to produce excellent singers, as displayed in contests in other countries where those with Filipino pedigree win the competition, but it is disappointing that the country has simply become a mini or second-rate Hollywood in this part of the Third World.

 

Dance shows, which were mainly contest programs, were Shall We Dance?, 2005-10, and Celebrity Dance Challenge, which premiered in 2014, both on ABC/TV5 and both hosted by former Lux shampoo commercial model Lucy Torres. Multi-category talent contests were also produced during the period, which stations intended as a venue to hire diverse entertainers for the networks’ various programs. Singers, dancers, tricksters, ventriloquists, and jack-of-all-trades performers joined programs such as Talentadong Pinoy (Talented Filipino), 2008-14, TV5, and Pilipinas Got Talent (Philippines Got Talent), 2010-15, ABS-CBN, of the British Got Talent franchise. The Filipino shadow play group El Gamma Penumbra won in the 2015 Pilipinas Got Talent and later emerged the grand winner in Asia’s Got Talent’s first season, also in 2015.

 

Comedy Shows

 

Comedy programs that were avowedly political in subject matter had become prominent in the early post-EDSA years. Satire became the means of expression of intellectuals and cultural workers who seized the renewed freedom of expression. Sic O’Clock News, 1987-89, IBC 13, a gag show that parodies social issues in the format of a news program, was the most biting in its criticisms of government graft and corruption, foreign domination of the economy and politics, and the character of the nation and its people. The show anchored itself on the previously neglected but critical mass audience but later suffered from the boycott of advertisers because of the show’s hard-edged criticism and spoof on current local and international sociopolitical events, even attacking American imperialism. The boycott extended to the other shows of one of the program’s actors, Jaime Fabregas.

 

Political satire, mainly in the form of spoofs in various program formats, continued in spite of occasional threats coming from advertisers. During the early years of the Corazon Aquino administration, these shows mainly came from the reinvigorated IBC 13, under the management of Noel Tolentino, while in the midst of long-drawn-out legal battles against Marcos loyalists who wanted to maintain their hold on sequestered broadcast networks. Barrio Balimbing (A Barrio of Turncoats), 1986, IBC 13, then 1987-88 when it moved to ABS-CBN, made fun of personalities, lambasted politicians, and conveyed the ordinary people’s perception of political and social issues, which the characters spoofed in the show. Mongolian Barbecue, 1990-91, then 1993-95, RPN, featured writer-director Jun Urbano’s fictional character of Mr Shooli, based on the film Genghis Khan, 1952, by his father filmmaker and National Artist Manuel Conde. With sidekick Kuhol, played by Philip Supnet, Mr Shooli took potshots at politicians and personalities through his “grill-and-roast” type of interviewing while seated on the mouth of a Buddha statue. Similar to other comedies, Mongolian featured song-and-dance satirical performances, spoofs of TV advertisements, and “laugh-in” segments. Urbano resurfaced on Mongolian Barbecue in 2014 on UHF free cable TV Global News Network (GNN).

 

Similar satirical spoofs were produced in the 2000s. Real-life friends Maveric Relova and Ariel Villasanta anchored ABC 5’s pseudo-investigative news-documentary Totoo TV: Walang Kinatatakutan, Walang Kinikilingan, Walang Hiya (Real TV: Fearless, Balanced, Shameless), 2005, an alliteration of claims of balanced reporting by national broadsheets and broadcast news programs. A recent welcome development in the genre is Kontrabando (Smuggled), 2015, ABC/TV5, a news satire show hosted by Ramon Bautista, Lourd de Veyra, Jun Sabayton, and RA Rivera.

 

Gag shows continued to be the popular format of many comedy programs. T.O.D.A.S., IBC 13, a program that started during the martial law period, continued to air until 1989. ABS-CBN revived its pre-martial law gag show Super Laff-In, 1996-99. Goin’ Bananas, 1986, BBC 2, 1986-87, IBC 13, then 1988-91, ABS-CBN, starred acclaimed movie actors Christopher de Leon, Jay Ilagan, Johnny Delgado, and Edgar Marquez playing out macho fantasies about women. The mid-1990s was the heyday of gag shows, marked by the entry of the very popular Tropang Trumpo (Troop of Tops), 1994-99, ABC 5, with its signature parodies of songs, dances, and segments, such as the memorable “Battle of the Brainless” where nobody wins while contestants state the most stupid and non sequitur answers to questions posed by the segment’s quiz master. The program’s lead stars, Michael V. and Ogie Alcasid, were pirated by GMA and led the cast of the sketch comedy show Bubble Gang, which premiered in 1995. The duo’s comedic genius and its cast were utilized well in their new show as they made a succession of hilarious segments. Because it subjects almost anything popular to parody, the show has received criticisms on a number of issues such as its portrayal of women, rape, and the insensitive depiction of a special child. With 19 years and counting, Bubble Gang has surpassed the 10-year run of T.O.D.A.S. and the 17-year airing of John en Marsha (John and Marsha), and ranks along with Eat Bulaga! (36 years counting) as one of the longest-running shows on Philippine television. A gag show that employed a cast of children, with the exception of the oldest and only adult in the show Dagul, was Goin’ Bulilit (Goin’ Kiddie), 2005-15, ABS-CBN, directed by Edgar Mortiz. Patterned after Goin’ Bananas, in which Mortiz appeared as a mainstay, the show was not for children, with kids playing adult roles in various funny, but often not-fit-for-children, situations.

 

An important sketch comedy show was Comedy Central Market, 2007, GMA, hosted by Arnel Ignacio. It pioneered stand-up comedy on television, but with inoffensive, nondiscriminatory, fairer, and more respectable humor than contemporary variety programs that insensitively and callously make fun of people. The show featured stand-up acts by Romnick Sarmenta, Eugene Domingo, Ai-Ai delas Alas, Ruby Rodriguez, and Vice Ganda.

 

Perhaps one of the best gag shows that ran from the 1990s to the 2000s was Ispup (Spoof), 1999-2004, ABC/TV5. It parodied television shows in its program segments, some of which included “Alam Morena Clara” from the telenovela Morena Clara, “The Cheapest Link” from the British game show The Weakest Link, “Gay KNB?” (Are You Now Gay?) from the game show Game KNB?, and “Pangako sa ’Yo sa Puso Ko Iibigin Ka Hanggang sa Dulo ng Walang Hanggan” (I Promise to Love You from the Bottom of My Heart Forever and Ever) from three popular local soaps. The show’s cast, which include Leo Martinez, Willie Nepomuceno, Candy Pangilinan, Madeleine Nicolas, Ruffa Mae Quinto, Jon Santos, Caloy Alde, Joy Viado, Ramon Bautista, Pekto Nacua, and Ate Gay, impersonated political and popular personalities like politicians such as Joseph Estrada, Gloria Macapagal Arroyo, and Loren Legarda; church leaders such as Jaime Cardinal Sin; showbiz stars such as Sharon Cuneta and Nora Aunor; and broadcasters and network personalities such as Korina Sanchez, Mel Tiangco, Mike Enriquez, Charo Santos-Concio, the Tulfo brothers, and Ernie Baron.

 

Spoof comedy in the mid-1990s and on through the 2000s combined some elements of reality television. Examples are Wow Mali (Oh No, It’s a Mistake), 1996-2006, 2009-15, ABC 5, directed by Robert Quebral and hosted by Joey de Leon, a candid-camera-type show that features practical jokes on people on the streets, the funny situations in which some of these people are caught on camera, and video footage of bloopers and bizarre incidents; The Misadventures of Maverick and Ariel, 2003-5, ABC 5, which blurs the line between fiction and reality as the camera follows the lives of hosts Maverick Relova and Ariel Villasanta as they go about their everyday lives and get into a series of real-life and fictional “misadventures” to pursue their elusive dream of making it big in showbiz; Mommy Elvie’s Problematic Show, 2007-8, ABC 5, a spoof-reality TV program of Mommy Elvie, Ariel Villasanta’s real-life mother who regularly had cameo appearances as her wacky self in The Misadventures of Maverick and Ariel.

 

Family-oriented and situational comedies dominated primetime programming of the major networks immediately following the post-EDSA Revolt and on to the 1990s. Interesting situational comedies that had political commentaries include Sitak ni Jack (Jack’s Taxicab), 1987, IBC 13, starring Cachupoy and Junix Inocian, which featured characters of a taxi company undergoing all kinds of mishaps and utilized the taxi as a venue for political and social commentaries; Kwentong Barbero (Barber’s Story), 1987, IBC 13, directed by Naning Estrella and starring Lou Veloso, Oly de Guzman, Marco Sison, Encar Benedicto, Hero Bautista, and Sabatini Fernandez, which cast a critical eye on the local political scene; and Tambayan (Hangout), 1993, ABS-CBN, where characters loiter at the neighborhood store, drinking liquor and talking about political topics in the language of the everyday. John en Marsha, which started in 1973, continued airing on RPN 9 until 1990. Audiences, however, did not receive well its sequel, John en Shirley, 2006-7, ABS-CBN, which featured two of the show’s original cast, Dolphy and Maricel Soriano. Dolphy made his presence felt further on TV in Home along da Riles (Home along the Railroad), 1992-2003, ABS-CBN, a title ripped off from the popular American movie Home Alone. The sitcom depicted a poor family of informal settlers living alongside the railway tracks. Along with his son Vandolph; grandson Boy 2 Quizon; teen stars Claudine Barretto, Gio Alvarez, Smokey Manaloto, and Bamba; and veteran stars Nova Villa, Babalu, Bernardo Bernardo, and Cita Astals. Dolphy solidified his hold on Philippine primetime comedy playing Kevin Cosme. Nova Villa made her mark as the sister of Kevin’s deceased wife, devoting herself to helping Kevin’s family while also making advances on him. Also noticeable in the program was the continuation of the presence of the kasambahay (housemaid) character as one of the show’s lead stars, sometimes being bossy to the real boss only to be put back to her place and always providing a comic relief of her own as chief gossiper and villain-heroine. Okay Ka, Fairy Ko! (You’re Okay, My Fairy!), 1987-89, IBC 13, 1989-95, ABS-CBN, and 1995-97, GMA, entertained TV audiences with its fantastic premise of a marriage between a human being, Enteng Kabisote, portrayed by Vic Sotto, and a supernatural, Faye, played by Alice Dixson. Veteran actor Charito Solis and dancer-comedian Bayani Casimiro performed their more memorable roles on TV in this program in the twilight of their careers. Okay Ka followed John en Marsha’s format of the perennial fight between a man and his nagging and biased mother-in-law.

 

Three popular yet contrasting situational comedy shows became highly popular during the period, all of which were produced by ABS-CBN. Palibhasa Lalake, 1987-98, Chika Chika Chicks (Chatty Chicks), 1987-91, and Abangan ang Susunod na Kabanata (Watch for the Next Chapter), 1991-97, led the ratings and cemented the dominance of ABS-CBN just a few years after it was given back to the Lopez family by the Aquino administration. Directed by Johnny Manahan, written by Jose Javier Reyes, and starring Joey Marquez, Richard Gomez, Miguel Rodriguez, Gloria Romero, Amy Perez, Carmina Villaroel, Arlene Muhlach, and Cynthia Patag, Palibhasa showed the naughty foibles of guys out to play tricks on their family, girls, and the rest of the gang. It was known for showing veteran actor Romero as a neighborhood drunkard, the glass-breaking scream of singer Patag, the presence of sexy women as guests, mysterious hands outside the camera frame intruding into the scene, camera shots taken from unconventional angles, and the water douse at the end of the show. It was also one of the pioneers in modeling clothes that are worn by its stars and the guesting of public officials and media showbiz personalities. One memorable moment was the interview made by Korina Sanchez with agrarian reform secretary and presidential candidate Miriam Defensor-Santiago in the heady days of the 1992 presidential campaign. Santiago rebutted from the television studio Joey Marquez’s simplistic view of women which he uttered while watching the Santiago interview. Santiago later on entered the program’s studio “house” and mouthed her advocacies to the rest of the cast. The episode was considered one of the first forays of electoral candidates into the TV medium, which was also exploited by actor Marquez when he ran for a public post, and both the show and the politician-guest were criticized for using the broadcast media for electioneering. Prior to Palibhasa was Chika Chika Chicks, featuring the husband-and-wife characters of Freddie Webb and Nova Villa. Pirated from IBC 13’s Chicks to Chicks, 1980-86, Chika Chika Chicks thematized the insecurities of an overweight wife who always rescues her husband from his shenanigans with sexy women. On the other hand, Abangan ang Susunod na Kabanata, also from the director-writer tandem of Manahan and Javier Reyes, would be etched in Filipino popular memory for having Anjo Yllana play Dino Tengco, a gun-toting special child of corrupt politician Congressman Tengco (Noel Trinidad) and his pill-popping Imeldific wife Barbara (Tessie Tomas). The show revolved around the peccadilloes of a morally depraved elite family foisting their whims on the rest of society as other people imitate, repel, fight, praise, and hobnob with them.

 

Situational comedy programs that maintained the old-school, clean comedy and clearly avoided the vulgar were Hapi House (Happy House), 1987-88, IBC 13, written by Bibeth Orteza, directed by Bert de Leon, and starring Tito Sotto, Helen Gamboa, Aga Muhlach, Isabel Granada, Chuckie Dreyfuss, and Laura Hermosa, which showed the oddities, ironies, and awkward moments of a typical Filipino family life; Buddy en Sol (Buddy and Sol), 1991-93, RPN 9, written by Jose Bartolome, Divino Reyes, and Herman Salvador, directed by Leo Martinez, which portrayed friendships and loyalties in the midst of conflicts; Ober da Bakod (Over the Fence), 1992-97, GMA, starring Janno Gibbs, Anjo Yllana, Leo Martinez, Malou de Guzman, Gelli de Belen, and Donita Rose, which is about two families divided by economic class yet their children managed to develop good personal relations; Pepito Manaloto, which premiered in 2010, GMA, created by Michael V., starring Michael V., Manilyn Reynes, Nova Villa, Jessa Zaragosa, Ronnie Henares, Jake Vargas, Angel Satsumi, John Feir, Janna Dominguez, Arthur Solinap, and Mosang, about the funny daily experiences of an instant-millionnaire family, their helpers and drivers who are treated as members of its household, and their old-rich and quick-rich neighbors in their gated village; and Vampire ang Daddy Ko (My Daddy is a Vampire), which premiered in 2013, GMA, written and directed by Bibeth Orteza, starring Vic Sotto, Oyo Boy Sotto, Pilita Corrales, Jimmy Santos, Anjo Yllana, Sef Cadayona, Bea Binene, Barbie Forteza, Derrick Monasterio, Glaiza de Castro, Ryzza Mae Dizon, and Jacque Oda, about the classic battle between good and evil around which love, honesty, and fairness serve as key to overcome suspicions, mistrust, and paranoia.

 

Programs for Children and Teens (and Adults)

 

A few programs for children were produced by local radio networks. A noteworthy production was Daigdig ng mga Bata (World of Children), 1994, DZRB Radyo ng Bayan, written by Miles Donguines-Cruz, which emphasized the importance of local culture in the contemporary life of Filipino children. DWRK-FM produced in 1994 dramatized radio plugs in its series called Tayong mga Pinoy (We, Filipinos) and Hoy Bata (Hey, Kid), which reminded audiences of decency in everyday life and nationalism among children.

 

A more aggressive programming addressed to kids was initiated by TV networks after the restoration of media companies to their private owners. Some children’s programs during the martial law period that continued airing during the post-EDSA Revolt were Uncle Bob’s Lucky 7 Club, 1961-92, RBS-GMA; Kaluskos Musmos (Kiddie Noise), 1979-89, RPN 9; and Kulit Bulilit (Curious Children), 1982-88. Batibot, which means small but strong, continued to gain popularity since its first airing in 1984 to its last broadcast in 2012. It aired on one channel after another, from RPN 9, PTV 4, ABS-CBN to GMA. Its radio version, Radyo Batibot (Batibot Radio), was broadcast beginning in the 1980s on DZAM, later called DZAR. Created by the Philippine Children’s Television Foundation, Batibot was created to ground Filipino children in the Filipino language, culture, and heritage. It became known for clear and entertaining discussions of a wide range of topics, mostly on literacy, numeracy, interpersonal communication, and basic lessons on good manners and right conduct. It received numerous awards for its pro-Filipino programming and memorable cultural and artistic creations of puppets, songs, and stories. Better-funded and technologically savvier children’s TV shows eclipsed Batibot in the mid-1990s.

 

A Batibot-type of program, titled Pin-Pin, 1990-94, PTV 4, ABC 5, RPN 9, ABS-CBN, and GMA, propagated Chinese-Filipino culture in the Philippines, especially addressing the decline of Hokkien (Fukienese) among Filipinos with Chinese roots in the Philippines. Probe Productions Inc created 5 & Up, 1992-2002, GMA, for a relatively more mature kid audience by featuring young children and teens, such as Atom Araullo, Chynna Ortaleza, Maxene Magalona, and Rayver Cruz, reporting on a whole gamut of topics that interest children, and Art Is Kool (Art Is Cool), 2002-4, GMA, hosted by Robert Alejandro, an art workshop program that teaches children how to create artworks using recycled materials.

 

ABS-CBN Foundation produced many educational programs for children and teens—namely, Sineskwela (School on Air), 1994-2001, co-produced with the Science Education Institute of the Department of Science and Technology, a daily, curriculum-based science program for grade school children; Bayani (Hero), 1995-2000, a history program for young people, which disseminates a nationalist consciousness through the stories of Philippine national heroes and characters from precolonial Philippines; Hiraya Manawari (Reaching One’s Dreams), 1995-2003, a fairy tale series of journeys to magical places with a focus on values formation; Mathtinik (Math Wiz), 1997-2003, teaching elementary mathematics to schoolchildren; Epol/Apple, 1999-2003, teaching basic literacy in the English and Filipino languages; Pahina (Pages), 2000-2001, a weekly drama anthology, starring Carlo Aquino, that features and dramatizes noted Filipino literary works that promote values necessary in the character development of the youth; and Salam (Peace), 2006-7, directed by Jon Red and written by Ian Victoriano, a drama series about Muslim and Christian children and peace issues in Mindanao. For radio, ABS-CBN Foundation aired the science and technology weekly discussion program Bago ’Yan, Ah! (That’s New!), 1997-2013, DZMM, mainly for teens and young adults; it was initially anchored by Marie Reyes and Eli Guieb III, who, after a year of broadcast, were both replaced by Angelo Palmones.

 

The succession of programs made by ABS-CBN ultimately became hits, and gained recognition as the network partnered with educational institutions and private companies for the transmission, distribution, and integration of their programs into the curriculum of partner schools. Other important educational children’s programs aired on ABS-CBN include Children’s Hour, 1986-88; Star Smile Factory, 1987-92; It Bulinggit (Itty-Bitty It), 1990-91; Eh Kasi Bata! (Because They Are Children), 1991-95; ATBP: Awit, Titik, at Bilang na Pambata (ETC: Songs, Letters, and Numbers for Children), 1994-98, which introduced the young Piolo Pascual and created unforgettable characters like Bb Karunungan(Miss Knowledge) andKapitan Bilang (Captain Count); For Kids Only, 1994-2000; Detek Kids (Kid Investigators), 2003-4; Silip: Sining sa Lipunan (Peep: A Look at Society), 2004; Art Jam, 2004-6; Basta Sports (As Long as It’s Sports), 2006; Kabataan Xpress (Youth Express), 2006-7; Sirit (I Give Up), 2007; and Kulilits (Inquisitive Kids), 2009-10. The last, along with ATBP, Hiraya Manawari, Mathtinik, and Epol/Apple, was later reissued on Knowledge Channel.

 

Among the children’s educational programs shown on GMA, the following stood out: Koko Kwik Kwak, 1999-2000, which featured a Batibot character generated in computer animation, with other Batibot characters remaining as puppets; Lovely Day, 2004-9, a magazine show, hosted by Love Añover, with kids Jacob Raterta, Bea Binene, and Gabriel Roxas, which allows children to immerse themselves in various experiences that teach them social, cultural, and life lessons; Art Angel, 2004-11, hosted by Pia Arcangel and Tonipet Gaba, which specializes in presenting doable arts and crafts by and for kids; Ang Mahiwagang Baul (The Enchanted Chest), 2005-7, a weekly dramatized anthology of Philippine myths, legends, and folklore, starring Eissen Bayubay, Sandy Talag, and Carme Sanchez; Mga Kuwento ni Lola Basyang (Stories of Grandma Basyang), 2007, about Lola Basyang’s strong-willed granddaughter, played by Manilyn Reynes, who drives to numerous places in a rolling library van packed with Lola Basyang’s books and shares her grandmother’s classic tales with everyone; Batang Bibbo! (Bibbo Kid!), 2008-10, a puppet show, with Roxanne Barcelo, that teaches children language, songs, stories, and social skills; Ka-Blog! (Blogmate), 2008-10, a teen-oriented show, hosted by Andrea Torres, Mico Aytona, and Monica Verallo, which tackles anything and everything about adolescent life and its challenges; Happy Land, 2009-10, a narrative series, starring Love Añover, Patricia Gayod, and Jermaine Ulgasan, which combines animation, digital technology, and live-action photography in telling stories that inspire young viewers to discover happiness despite the bad things in life; and One Day, Isang Araw (One Day, One Day), 2013, a weekly anthology of stories shared by the four characters of the series, played by Jillian Ward, Milkcah Wynne Nacion, Marc Justin Alvarez, and Joshua Uy, who hang out in a tree house.

 

The Communication Foundation for Asia (CFA) produced or co-produced with broadcast networks noteworthy radio and television programs for children, among which were Chikiting Patrol (Kiddie Patrol), 1988-90, ABS-CBN, then 1990-2002, GMA, and 2004-6, ABC 5, which featured children Maricor Jabolin, Raffy Ticson, Caling Velez, and Lionel Yumoll as reporters; Gospel Komiks: The TV Series, 2006, TV Maria: The Catholic Channel, a 20-episode, half-hour animation TV series based on CFA’s comics magazine that dramatizes the Gospel followed by a discussion of its themes and lessons; and Vote 4 U, 2007, TV Maria and Destiny Cable, written and directed by Clodualdo del Mundo Jr, a three-part TV reality game show designed to show young voters the importance of choosing the right candidates during elections.

 

Other noteworthy children’s programs were Pen Pen de Sarapen, 1987-2001, RPN 9, whose title was taken from a Filipino folk song, hosted by Connie Angeles, Caselyn Francisco, Fred Moore de los Santos, and Camille Velasco, a game and storytelling show; Yan ang Bata (That’s the Kid), 1990-93, GMA, then 1993-95, ABS-CBN, hosted by Encar Benedicto; Ang Galing Mo, Bata (You’re Great, Kid), 1992-93, IBC 13, hosted by Sunshine Dizon and Atong Redillas; Friends of the Earth, 1993, RPN 9, the first children’s program about the environment, directed by Manni Coloma; and Tropang Potchi (Potchi’s Gang), 2009-11, QTV 11, then 2011, GMA, a magazine show that featured games of reasoning, children-produced videos, short stories in which the characters are played by the children hosts and a strawberry-colored mascot called Potchi, and a problem-solving scenario about any of the hosts’ experiences. PTV 4 aired in the 1990s three telecourses for teachers of elementary science, chemistry, and physics under the Continuing Education Program for Science via Television, a project of the Department of Education, Culture, and Sports, the UP Institute of Science and Math Education, and the Philippine Normal University.

 

ABS-CBN established the Sky Foundation, later known as Knowledge Channel, in 1991 to help public primary and secondary school education in the country. It produces language, mathematics, science, and values education programs which serve as supplement to the school curriculum. The Knowledge Channel Foundation Inc cooperates with the private sector for the sponsorship of facilities (television units and satellite disks), conducts teacher training workshops, and performs assessments on the efficacy of its shows. It launched Educational Television or ETV in 1994, a project that uses audiovisual equipment and materials, such as television sets, video players, and access to educational videos, to help selected public schools in the Philippines.

 

Parents and numerous citizens have voiced their concerns about several children’s shows exhibiting aggression using the most astonishing techniques. In response, GMA started the “Worry-Free Kid TV” programming, which promised child-friendly shows devoid of bad language, sex, and violence.

 

Magazine, Cultural, Musical, Lifestyle, Travel, and Related Programs

 

A renewed mobility of people both within the country and abroad, surging purchasing power for some segments of the population, a growing number of Filipinos getting more information from various sources, and the ever-changing and complex socioeconomic development provided grounds for the proliferation of magazine shows in the last 30 years. These magazine shows covered a wide range of concerns, either focusing on one topic or theme as the main feature or a combination of several topics featured under different formats in one show.

 

Magandang Umaga Po (Good Morning), which premiered in 1986, ABS-CBN, was the morning counterpart of evening news with a lighter mode of delivery and was dotted with commentary, hosted by Noli de Castro and Korina Sanchez. The show was reformatted in 1992 and given a new name, Alas Singko y Medya (Five-Thirty), featuring a big cabal of personalities including Julius Babao, Claudine Trillo, Erwin Tulfo, Cheryl Cosim, Bobby Yan, Pia Guanio, Kat de Castro, and Aljo Bendijo. The program’s title was changed to Magandang Umaga, Bayan (Good Morning, Nation) in 2002, and renamed in 2005 as Magandang Umaga, Pilipinas (Good Morning, Philippines) until its final run in 2007.

 

The late morning program was also dominated by daily lifestyle talk shows, mainly targeting women audiences. Tessie Tomas hosted Teysi ng Tahanan, 1991-97, and Teysi, 2003-4, both on ABS-CBN, and Joey & Teysi, 2013, IBC 13. One of the more memorable segments of Teysi ng Tahanan was “Kung Maibabalik Ko Lang” (If I Could Bring Back) in which women letter senders shared moments of their lives that they regretted.

 

The period also saw an increase in the production of magazine documentaries. Apple Pie, Patis, Pâté, Atbp. (Apple Pie, Fish Sauce, Pâté, Etc.), 1986-89, RPN 9, presented the multifaceted lives of Filipinos abroad and comically hosted by Joey de Leon. Café Bravo, 1989-90, ABS-CBN, was a talk magazine show, set in a modern café, that featured artists and personalities of the local art and culture scene. Tatak Pilipino (Filipino Trademark), 1990-94, ABS-CBN, showcased Filipino customs and traditions with the main aim of appreciating diversity and instilling love of country. Pep Talk, 1986-90, and The Inside Story, 1990-98, both on ABS-CBN and both presented by Loren Legarda, toured the whole country to feature sundry interesting people and places. News magazine shows Balitang K (K News), 1996-2001, and Rated K, premiered in 2004, both ABS-CBN and both hosted by Korina Sanchez, showcased a variety of interesting topics with regular features on the supernatural and bizarre human traits. Pipol (People), 1999-2006, ABS-CBN, then on ANC beginning in 2011, is a show focusing on profiles of remarkable people in society, politics, business, sports, and many other fields. Kapuso Mo, Jessica Soho (One with You at Heart, Jessica Soho), which began in 2004, GMA, is a news and lifestyle magazine show famous for its take on trends and research on different cuisines. Storyline, 2008-13, ANC, was a feature on different stories of interest. A different kind of public service program was initiated by GMA in Wish Ko Lang!, premiered in 2002, a wish-granting program that features ordinary and popular individuals whom the program would shower with gifts and incentives, such as an educational scholarship, a small business enterprise, or meeting a favorite celebrity or long-lost family member or friend, all in the spirit of inspiring confidence, hope, and optimism about the future.

 

Music programs of the martial law period continued to be produced during the post-EDSA Revolt. Coverage of weekly live concerts of classical and traditional Filipino music and dance was broadcast on regular weekly TV programs of the government station PTV 4. In the 2000s, however, these programs were no longer part of the station’s regular programming, but the station continues to present these programs as occasional features. These shows are Concert at the Park, which began in 1978, broadcast live from Luneta; Paco Park Presents, beginning in 1980, from the Paco Cemetery; and Puerta Real Evenings, beginning in the 1980s, from Intramuros.

 

Armida Siguion-Reyna carried on with her noteworthy musical program Aawitan Kita (I Shall Sing for You), this time as monthly specials on RPN 9. Fides Cuyugan-Asensio and John Lesaca provided audiences with both classical and contemporary music in A Little Night of Music, 1989-2001, GMA. Kuh Ledesma had Kuh by Special Arrangement, 1986-87, IBC 13. Martin Nievera and Pops Fernandez had Martin and Pops Twogether, 1987-89, ABS-CBN. Composer Ryan Cayabyab, who has become well-known in the industry, appeared in a weekly show with his guests in Ryan, Ryan Musikahan (Music with Ryan), ABS-CBN. An interesting religious musical program for the youth that deviated from the dry and didactic tone of most religious programs was Mag-Smile Club Na (Join the Smile Club), 1996, IBC 13, starring PY Nakar.

 

Excellent television music specials were Serenata ng Shell (Serenade of Shell), 1989, which combined classical artists and popular singers in a special concert; Tinig ng Tagumpay (Voice of Success), 1990, GMA, which paid tribute to the Filipino singers working abroad as overseas contract workers; and Paano Kita Mapasasalamatan: A Tribute to George Canseco (How Can I Thank You: A Tribute to George Canseco), 2005 and 2006, ABS-CBN, singer Kuh Ledesma’s tribute to composer George Canseco.

 

Exceptional music programs on radio, especially in the late 1980s until the 1990s, that focused on Philippine music include Kulay at Anyo (Color and Form), DZRB Philippine Broadcasting Service, which featured the music and folk stories of different indigenous groups and regions of the country; Cancionan on the Air (Debate in Verse and Music on Air), DWDW International Broadcasting Corporation, which featured on-the-spot composing of music; Pagmahal sa Bisaya (Love in Visayan), DYSS Republic Broadcasting Corporation, which promoted Visayan music; Turbaan Ilokano (Ilocano Music), DWMC-AM Pangasinan, which presented on-the-spot composing of songs in the Ilocano-speaking areas of Pangasinan; Hawiran Ta ang Kagab-ihon (Let Us Hold the Night), DYKC-AM Cebu, a musical magazine program that focused on the Cebuano balak (poetry) and music; and Yukbo sa Kagahapon (Salutations of Yesteryears), DYRF Word Broadcasting Corporation–Cebu, which featured budding Cebuano music composers and artists whose works reflect current issues of the country. DYFM Radyo Bombo Iloilo maintained producing programs that promoted Hiligaynon music. DZUP’s Tuti: Tunog at Tinig (Tuti: Sound and Voice) is a production of the UP College of Music that features stories of Filipino music and music makers, and shows the aspects of musical creation, transmission, and performance to engage listeners to more ways of thinking about music expression.

Educational programs in agriculture, entrepreneurship, and business that began during martial law were sustained. Tele-Aralan ng Kakayahan (Knowledge Educational TV), 1983-94, PTV 4, hosted by Cecille B. Garucho, kept simple its style of presenting local livelihood entrepreneurship. Ating Alamin (Let Us Find Out), 1974-91, KBS-RPN 9 and IBC 13, hosted by Gerry Geronimo, continues to have special features on agriculture on ABS-CBN’s The Filipino Channel. Relevant programs of this type that first appeared after martial law were Negosiyete (Business on Seven), 1990-98, GMA, hosted by German Moreno; Agrisiyete (Agriculture on Seven), 1992-98, GMA, hosted by Bert “Tawa” Marcelo; Agrilink (Agricultural Link), 1994-2001, ABC 5, hosted by Luchi Cruz-Valdes; and Negosyo Atbp. (Business, Etc.), NBN 4, hosted by Nikka Cleofe Alejar. Business magazine programs were Business Today, 1990-97, GMA, an interview talk-magazine program hosted by Cecile Carlos, Karen Davila, Rico Hizon, Mon Isberto, and Florence Tabug, which featured various economic and business news contextualized in the local setting; and Usapang Business (Business Talk), 1996-98, ABS-CBN, hosted by Ces Oreña-Drilon, David Celdran, and Cathy Yap Yang, which featured the lives of ordinary people going into business. Motoring Today, 1991, PTV 4, directed by Jennifer Bleza, written by Elmo Valera, hosted by Butch Gamboa and Pocholo Ramirez, tackled issues about road safety. On radio, important programs that emerged in the 2000s that promoted the entrepreneurial spirit among the general public were Radyo Negosyo (Radio Business), beginning in 2001, DZMM, hosted by Dr Carl Balita, and That’s Entreptainment (That’s Entrepreneurship Entertainment), 2013, DZUP 1602, hosted by Daisy Cayos.

 

Many magazine lifestyle shows carry a particular focus. Important culinary shows were Cooking It Up with Nora, 1986-95, ABS-CBN, and Kusina at Iba Pa (Kitchen, Etc.), 1996-98, PTV 4. Health programs that stood out are Kapwa Ko, Mahal Ko (I Love My Fellowman), which began in 1975 and continues to run as a public service health program on GMA; Salamat, Dok (Thank You, Doctor), premiered in 2004, ABS-CBN, which incorporates public service, medical health information, alternative medicine, and practical home remedy tips; Talk to Doc, 2010, ABS-CBN News Channel, which tackles specific medical cases and their corresponding treatment programs, discussed from the perspective of patients and their doctors; and Pinoy MD: Mga Doktor ng Bayan (Filipino MD: Public Doctors), which began in 2010, GMA, a weekly magazine program that offers viewers practical tips on how to deal with different medical issues and how to practice a healthy lifestyle. On AM radio, excellent health shows are Doctors on Line, began in early 2000s, DZAS 702 and DZXI 1062, which integrates physical and mental health with spiritual health; Doctor’s Orders, DWWW 774, hosted by Dr Jaime Galvez Tan, which highlights local indigenous knowledge and practices on medicine; and Health Matters, DZUP 1602, hosted by Jun Austria, which discusses with experts from the UP Philippine General Hospital the social aspects of medicine. A pioneer in environmental magazine shows on television are Born to Be Wild, premiered in 2007, GMA, which presents the wildlife in its natural state, and Hamon ng Kalikasan (The Challenge of Nature), 2012, GMA, the first broadcast meteorology program in the Philippines.

 

Significant travel magazine programs were Travel Time, 1986-2013, IBC 13, then GMA, then Studio 23, a pioneer in travel shows, hosted by Susan Calo Medina; Sa Sariling Lupa: Cultural Tourism Destinations (On One’s Own Soil: Cultural Tourism Destinations), 1999, IBC 13, which promoted the seven major cultural destinations under the program of the Department of Tourism, the National Historical Commission of the Philippines, the National Museum, and the National Commission for Culture and the Arts—namely, Rizal-Laguna, Davao, Cebu, Baguio-Banaue, Laoag-Vigan, Bohol, and Palawan; Lakbay TV (Travel TV), 2003, IBC 13, which featured local customs in the context of community-based tourism; and What I See, 2012, GMA News TV, then 2013, Talk TV, and 2015, CNN Philippines, a travel photography documentary that focused on people, places, treasures, and cultures of the Philippines from the lens of photographer Francisco “Paco” Guerrero.

 

Art magazine programs include For Art’s Sake, 1990, PTV 4, hosted by Susan Africa, about Philippine culture and the arts; By Design, 1993-94, ABC 5, written and directed by Monette E. Alfon and hosted by Tina Revilla-Valencia, which focused on the science and art of architecture; Tipong Pinoy (Filipino Style), 1998, IBC 13, hosted by Susan Calo Medina and Wency Cornejo, which showed unique Filipino practices, art, ideologies, faith, and traditions; Cooltura (Cool Culture), 2011-14, IBC 13, hosted by Cathy Eigenmann and Patricia Natividad, which presented the art, music, food, practices, dances, and festivals of a province or city, with a brief discussion of the history of the art forms presented; Art Republik, 2012, Knowledge Channel, which featured contemporary Filipino artists from various fields; and Arttalk, 2012-13, Net25, hosted by Gemma Cruz-Araneta, which featured 21st-century Filipino Moro, lumad, and Christian artists, art experts, and cultural workers and their significant role in contemporary Philippine society.

 

 

Drama Programs

 

Along with comedy, drama continued to be the staple of most broadcast networks. The genre is conventionally thought as the litmus test of thespian potential. Drama programs during the early years of the post-martial law period were mainly in the format of a one-hour anthology, aired in one of the days of the week. Locally produced daily drama soaps, with no end in sight, also continued during the period. The entry in the 1990s of telenovelas from Latin America, Taiwan, and Korea completely altered not only the design of television programming but also the format of local dramas, which by then had adapted limited-run narratives that lasted for a season of three to four months instead of the never-ending soap serials or the weekly celebrity-focused anthologies that characterized most drama programs of the period.

 

Radio dramas continued their popularity during the post-martial law period, such as Ito ang Palad Ko (This Is My Fate), which began in 1973, DZRH. Radio Mindanao Network, particularly its network in the regions, continued to produce drama programs that reached Visayan-speaking audiences in the Visayas and Mindanao: DYHP Cebu, DXDC Davao, DXCC Cagayan de Oro, DXBC Butuan, DXIC Iligan, DXMD General Santos, DXPR Pagadian, DXRZ Zamboanga, DXMY Cotabato, DXRS Surigao, DXPR Dipolog, and DXMB Malaybalay. Its network also reaches Ilonggo-speaking areas through its stations DZHB Bacolod, DYRI Iloilo, DYVR Roxas, DYKR Kalibo, and DXKR Marbel. Its drama programs have dominated the programming of the genre for over 20 years. Kun Ako ang Pasultihon (If I Were to Speak), written and directed by Julian “Teban” Daan, co-hosted by Pricilla Raganas, is an advice comedy drama about ordinary problems of ordinary people. One of its hit segments is “Mga Asoy ni Teban ug Goliat” (The Comedy of Teban and Goliat), which presents short sitcoms and fantasy stories. Kini ang Akong Suliran (This Is My Problem) dramatizes legal and medical issues sent by listeners, who are given pieces of advice by medical doctor Randolph Rosaroso and lawyer Elaine Bathan. Handumanan sa Usa ka Awit (Memories of a Song) are stories of love based on a song sent in by listeners. What’s d’ Style highlights the usual problems of adults, which are often about sex and related stories.

 

Remarkable drama anthologies were also produced by other radio stations. Drama Filipina, 1990, DZEC Eagle Broadcasting Corporation, featured in drama form classic Filipino works by writers such as Pedro Bukaneg, Francisco Baltazar, Nick Joaquin, and contemporary works by popular writer Mars Ravelo. Tukmo kag Punay (Spotted Doves and Turtledoves), which began its run in the 1970s and continued airing up to the 1990s, produced by DYRP Radyo Tagring of the Allied Broadcasting Center in Iloilo City, employed the ambahan (poetry) and other local literary forms, to dramatize social and political issues in Panay. Salaminagway, 1991-92, written by Vita Moral-Bangon, directed by Don Pagusara, produced by the Development Education Media Services, critically examined national political issues and how such impinge on local politics through radio dramas aired on more accommodating radio stations than those affiliated with the commercial networks.

 

On television, one of the pioneers of the letter-sending anthology format was Lovingly Yours, Helen, which started in 1980, GMA, and continued airing from 1992 to 1996, written by Gina Marissa Tagasa, directed by Mario O’Hara and Argel Joseph. Vela was replaced as host by daughter Princess Punzalan when Vela died in 1992. Other TV drama programs showcasing the stories of the letter-sending audience include Napakasakit, Kuya Eddie (It Hurts, Brother Eddie), 1986-88, ABS-CBN, which, like Lovingly Yours, originated from radio, and Maalaala Mo Kaya (Will You Remember), premiered 1991, ABS-CBN, hosted by Charo Santos-Concio. These programs featured the lives of ordinary people facing different challenges in life. The programs would end with the host giving advice to the letter sender, usually in a positive note to inspire confidence and hope, and often citing inspirational lines from local proverbs or quotes from the Bible. A similar format that draws from real lives and incidents are the crime investigative show Calvento Files, 1995-98, ABS-CBN, and legal drama program Ipaglaban Mo (Fight for It), 1989-92 on IBC13, 1992-99 on ABS-CBN, 2003-4 on RPN 9, and 2012-13 on GMA News TV.

 

Film companies Regal, Seiko, and Viva and, later, television networks ABS-CBN, through Star Studio and Star Magic, and GMA, through GMA Films, produced numerous drama programs featuring either the popular female actors in their roster or new ones they are building up. On ABS-CBN, some of the versions of the studio system on television were Regal Drama Presents, 1986-99; Seiko TV Presents, 1989-90; and Star Drama Theatre, 1993-2001. On GMA, these were Mother Studio Presents, 1986-96; GMA Telesine Specials, 1993-99, 2001; and GMA Love Stories, 1999-2001. Viva’s popular daily soap operas were Villa Quintana, 1995-96, and Anna Karenina, 1996-2002, both on GMA. Coney Reyes on Camera, 1984-99, RPN 9 and then ABS-CBN, was the longest-running drama anthology. It was a reformat of her earlier drama anthologies Coney Reyes-Mumar Drama Studio, 1977-81, and Coney Reyes-Mumar on the Set, 1981-83, both on GMA. Maricel Soriano had two weekly anthologies, totaling 10 years: Maricel Regal Drama Special, 1987-90, and Maricel Drama Special, 1990-97, both on ABS-CBN.

 

Personality-focused daily drama soap serials continued to dominate the format of the drama in broadcast, this time starring a younger generation of performers. The most popular were those in which teen actor Judy Ann Santos appeared. She played the title role of Mara in Mara Clara, 1992-97, ABS-CBN, a story of two sisters who were switched at birth with one being raised by affluent doting parents while the rich parents’ real daughter is being abused by poor parents. Mara Clara was notorious for its unbelievable and unduly long plot of the crucial diary that contained the secret, which was lost for years, and the overly dramatic scenes of incredible physical, verbal, and psychological abuse. Santos also played the title role in Esperanza, 1997-99, ABS-CBN, about a child’s search for her biological family. Written by Dado Lumibao, Wali Ching, and Reggie Amigo, directed by Jerry Lopez Sineneng, Rory B. Quintos, and Don Miguel Cuaresma, the soap posted very high ratings and catapulted young actor Judy Ann Santos to superstar status. Other members of the cast include young performers Wowie de Guzman, Piolo Pascual, Angelika Dela Cruz, and Marvin Agustin. Another young performer who dominated the drama soap serial was Claudine Barretto for her lead roles in consistent top-raters like Mula sa Puso (From the Heart), 1997-99, Saan Ka Man Naroroon (Wherever You Are), 1999-2001, Sa Dulo ng Walang Hanggan (At Eternity’s End), 2001-3, Marina, 2004, and Iisa Pa Lamang (Just One), 2008, all on ABS-CBN. Jolina Magdangal was typecast in light drama-comedy serials, such as Labs Ko si Babe (I Love Babe), 1999-2000, with love team partner Marvin Agustin.

 

To this day, the story line of a young boy or girl separated from parents and raised amiably by kind adoptive relatives or strangers is exploited to the hilt by ABS-CBN as seen in Pangako sa ’Yo (The Promise), 2000, a hit series that catapulted Jericho Rosales and Kristine Hermosa into superstardom and made them famous in Asia and Africa, and would be remade in 2015 to showcase the career transition of Daniel Padilla and Kathryn Bernardo; Minsan Lang Kita Iibigin (I Will Love You Only Once), 2011, which showed the promise of actor Coco Martin, who appeared in many independent films, as a mainstream star; Walang Hanggan (My Eternal), 2012, a recreation of the blockbuster film Hihintayin Kita sa Langit (I Will Wait for You in Heaven), which itself is based on Emily Bronte’s Wuthering Heights topbilled by Richard Gomez and Dawn Zulueta; Ina, Kapatid, Anak (Mother, Sister, Daughter), 2012-13, which starred young sensation Kim Chiu; Juan de la Cruz, 2013, an action-fantasy drama that sealed Martin’s domination of the drama teleserye commonly achieved in the past by women actors; and Ikaw Lamang (No Greater Love), 2014, which featured the already popular television actors Martin and Chiu.

 

Telenovelas from Mexico and Spanish-speaking countries, chinovelas from Taiwan, and koreanovelas from Korea began flooding television programming beginning in the mid-1990s, local drama productions significantly shifted to the teleserye, a limited-run drama series. Major teleseryes came from ABS-CBN, GMA, and ABC 5. ABS-CBN produced teleseryes that became huge hits, like Sana’y Wala Nang Wakas (I Wish This Were Forever), 2003-4, about two star-crossed lovers who suffer from their parents’ long-forgotten sins; Sa Piling Mo (With You), 2006, about childhood friends who fall in love with each other; Maging Sino Ka Man (Whoever You May Be), 2006-7, about filial relationships among the elite and the poor; Tayong Dalawa (The Two of Us), 2009, about two brothers who joined the military; and Be Careful with My Heart, 2012-14, a daytime family-romantic comedy. Important GMA teleseryes include Kung Mawawala Ka (A World Without You), 2002-3, an epic political thriller and love story; Amaya, 2011-12, an epic series about precolonial Philippines; and My Husband’s Lover, 2013, about gay relationships in contemporary Philippine society.

 

Today, the Philippines has become a major producer of teleseryes, some of which have gained recognition from international award-giving bodies. Lobo (Werewolf), 2008, ABS-CBN, won the Rockie Award for the Telenovela in the BANFF World Television Festival in Canada in 2009. Teleseryes that were nominated in the International Emmy for the telenovela category were ABS-CBN’s Kahit Isang Saglit (A Time for Us), 2008, and Dahil May Isang Ikaw (Destined Hearts), 2009-10, and GMA’s Magdusa Ka (You Suffer), 2008, and My Husband’s Lover, 2013. Eva Fonda, 2008-9, ABS-CBN, was nominated as Best Drama Series at the Seoul International Drama Awards in 2009.

 

Most of these local drama soaps, serials, anthologies, and teleseryes, either for general audiences or geared toward the youth, exploited female stereotypes: “the woman, martyr, femme fatale, as sacrificial lamb, as the faithful shadow, as the manipulator” (Reyes 1991, 188). Their world revolves around the confines of the family. The themes lack the social context in which to situate their private and personal concerns, such as mother-daughter conflicts, sibling rivalry, extramarital affairs, teen delinquency, which all convey conventional images and orthodox representations of women.

 

TV dramas also drew critical attention from an observant public. Some praise the excitement in their ever-twisting narrative, saying that shows have become addictive and that to miss an episode would derail a viewer from the story’s development. On the other hand, the confusing and convoluted plot is also a cause of irritation, with many chastising the implausibility of both turn of events and character transformation. Suspension of disbelief is not anymore reserved for fantasy but also applies to television dramas in which the bida (protagonist) possesses unusual kindness, even to the degree of stupidity, while the kontrabida (antagonist) demonstrates an incredible capacity to evade punishment and death. Drama shows also usually end with the spectacular kill-all-the-evil-antagonists that are the vehicle for the costly action genre.

 

In the first few years of the post-martial law period, however, progressive cultural workers engaged in television drama productions on top of their involvement with other media and art forms. Cecile Guidote-Alvarez resurrected the social realist drama anthology Balintataw (The Mind’s Eye) on PTV 4 beginning in 1987 and continues to this day with occasional runs of new episodes. Its stable of writers included Rolando Tinio, Dodi Anzures, Ronaldo Tumbokon, Lualhati Bautista, Lito Casaje, Henry Nadong, and Mars Cavestany, while its pool of directors included Nick Lizaso, Jose Mari Avellana, Jose Gruta, Maryo J. de los Reyes, Orlando Nadres, and Lupita Aquino-Kashiwahara. Radyo Balintataw (Radio Balintataw) continues to air daily on DZRH under a new format: a combination of drama, poetry, music, storytelling, and reports and commentaries on sociocultural issues. The Philippine Educational Theater Association (PETA) created Handog ng PETA (An Offering of PETA), 1990-92, alternately directed by Ishmael Bernal, Soxy Topacio, Joel Lamangan, Beth Mondragon, Beth Quindara, and Ellen Ongkeko. The anthology examined relevant sociopolitical issues that most drama programs of the period rarely or were afraid to tackle. From PETA also came PETA-bisyon (PETA Vision), 1993, PTV 4, then RPN 9 and ABC 5, which portrayed social issues that depicted the agency of characters and provided solutions that were grounded more realistically than the conventions of escapism that characterize the genre. Dear Teacher, 1991, Islands TV 13, presented the lives of teachers by not romanticizing their situation. Episodes of the weekly anthology were written by Chris B. Millado, Lualhati Bautista, Soxy Topacio, and Amado Lacuesta Jr, and directed by Ishmael Bernal, Gil Portes, and Rey Bato. Activist filmmaker Lino Brocka had his own Lino Brocka Presents, 1986, IBC 13, and Sa Direksiyon ni Lino Brocka (Under the Direction of Lino Brocka), 1990, GTV 4. Mario O’Hara had Hilda, 1989, RPN 9, with co-director Soxy Topacio and writer Rusty Sangalang, and Mama, IBC 13, with scriptwriter Lualhati Bautista. Joel Lamangan directed Spotlight, 1990-98, GMA, written by Armando Lao and Frank Rivera. Armida Siguion-Reyna produced the drama special Taghoy ng Dagat (Lament of the Sea), 1993, written by Bibeth Orteza and directed by Jose Mari Avellana. The Task Force Detainees of the Philippines produced Melinda, 1995, GMA, directed by Joel Lamangan, written by Ricky Lee, about the rape of young student activists by the military.

 

These drama productions by progressive groups and individuals interrogated the status quo, presented more realistic and contextualized nuances of national social and political issues, conveyed clearly delineated personas of characters, introduced innovative narrative plots that either enriched or deviated from the conventions of the genre, critically examined networks of human relations, and offered progressive alternatives and potentials for a just and humane society.
