Tele-Aralan ng Kakayahan (Knowledge Educational TV), 1983-94, PTV 4, hosted by Cecille B. Garucho, kept simple its style of presenting local livelihood entrepreneurship. Ating Alamin (Let Us Find Out), 1974-91, KBS-RPN 9 and IBC 13, hosted by Gerry Geronimo, continues to have special features on agriculture on ABS-CBN’s The Filipino Channel. Relevant programs of this type that first appeared after martial law were Negosiyete (Business on Seven), 1990-98, GMA, hosted by German Moreno; Agrisiyete (Agriculture on Seven), 1992-98, GMA, hosted by Bert “Tawa” Marcelo; Agrilink (Agricultural Link), 1994-2001, ABC 5, hosted by Luchi Cruz-Valdes; and Negosyo Atbp. (Business, Etc.), NBN 4, hosted by Nikka Cleofe Alejar. Business magazine programs were Business Today, 1990-97, GMA, an interview talk-magazine program hosted by Cecile Carlos, Karen Davila, Rico Hizon, Mon Isberto, and Florence Tabug, which featured various economic and business news contextualized in the local setting; and Usapang Business (Business Talk), 1996-98, ABS-CBN, hosted by Ces Oreña-Drilon, David Celdran, and Cathy Yap Yang, which featured the lives of ordinary people going into business. Motoring Today, 1991, PTV 4, directed by Jennifer Bleza, written by Elmo Valera, hosted by Butch Gamboa and Pocholo Ramirez, tackled issues about road safety. On radio, important programs that emerged in the 2000s that promoted the entrepreneurial spirit among the general public were Radyo Negosyo (Radio Business), beginning in 2001, DZMM, hosted by Dr Carl Balita, and That’s Entreptainment (That’s Entrepreneurship Entertainment), 2013, DZUP 1602, hosted by Daisy Cayos.

Many magazine lifestyle shows carry a particular focus. Important culinary shows were Cooking It Up with Nora, 1986-95, ABS-CBN, and Kusina at Iba Pa (Kitchen, Etc.), 1996-98, PTV 4. Health programs that stood out are Kapwa Ko, Mahal Ko (I Love My Fellowman), which began in 1975 and continues to run as a public service health program on GMA; Salamat, Dok (Thank You, Doctor), premiered in 2004, ABS-CBN, which incorporates public service, medical health information, alternative medicine, and practical home remedy tips; Talk to Doc, 2010, ABS-CBN News Channel, which tackles specific medical cases and their corresponding treatment programs, discussed from the perspective of patients and their doctors; and Pinoy MD: Mga Doktor ng Bayan (Filipino MD: Public Doctors), which began in 2010, GMA, a weekly magazine program that offers viewers practical tips on how to deal with different medical issues and how to practice a healthy lifestyle. On AM radio, excellent health shows are Doctors on Line, began in early 2000s, DZAS 702 and DZXI 1062, which integrates physical and mental health with spiritual health; Doctor’s Orders, DWWW 774, hosted by Dr Jaime Galvez Tan, which highlights local indigenous knowledge and practices on medicine; and Health Matters, DZUP 1602, hosted by Jun Austria, which discusses with experts from the UP Philippine General Hospital the social aspects of medicine. A pioneer in environmental magazine shows on television are Born to Be Wild, premiered in 2007, GMA, which presents the wildlife in its natural state, and Hamon ng Kalikasan (The Challenge of Nature), 2012, GMA, the first broadcast meteorology program in the Philippines.

Significant travel magazine programs were Travel Time, 1986-2013, IBC 13, then GMA, then Studio 23, a pioneer in travel shows, hosted by Susan Calo Medina; Sa Sariling Lupa: Cultural Tourism Destinations (On One’s Own Soil: Cultural Tourism Destinations), 1999, IBC 13, which promoted the seven major cultural destinations under the program of the Department of Tourism, the National Historical Commission of the Philippines, the National Museum, and the National Commission for Culture and the Arts—namely, Rizal-Laguna, Davao, Cebu, Baguio-Banaue, Laoag-Vigan, Bohol, and Palawan; Lakbay TV (Travel TV), 2003, IBC 13, which featured local customs in the context of community-based tourism; and What I See, 2012, GMA News TV, then 2013, Talk TV, and 2015, CNN Philippines, a travel photography documentary that focused on people, places, treasures, and cultures of the Philippines from the lens of photographer Francisco “Paco” Guerrero.

Art magazine programs include For Art’s Sake, 1990, PTV 4, hosted by Susan Africa, about Philippine culture and the arts; By Design, 1993-94, ABC 5, written and directed by Monette E. Alfon and hosted by Tina Revilla-Valencia, which focused on the science and art of architecture; Tipong Pinoy (Filipino Style), 1998, IBC 13, hosted by Susan Calo Medina and Wency Cornejo, which showed unique Filipino practices, art, ideologies, faith, and traditions; Cooltura (Cool Culture), 2011-14, IBC 13, hosted by Cathy Eigenmann and Patricia Natividad, which presented the art, music, food, practices, dances, and festivals of a province or city, with a brief discussion of the history of the art forms presented; Art Republik, 2012, Knowledge Channel, which featured contemporary Filipino artists from various fields; and Arttalk, 2012-13, Net25, hosted by Gemma Cruz-Araneta, which featured 21st-century Filipino Moro, lumad, and Christian artists, art experts, and cultural workers and their significant role in contemporary Philippine society.
Drama Programs

Along with comedy, drama continued to be the staple of most broadcast networks. The genre is conventionally thought as the litmus test of thespian potential. Drama programs during the early years of the post-martial law period were mainly in the format of a one-hour anthology, aired in one of the days of the week. Locally produced daily drama soaps, with no end in sight, also continued during the period. The entry in the 1990s of telenovelas from Latin America, Taiwan, and Korea completely altered not only the design of television programming but also the format of local dramas, which by then had adapted limited-run narratives that lasted for a season of three to four months instead of the never-ending soap serials or the weekly celebrity-focused anthologies that characterized most drama programs of the period.

Radio dramas continued their popularity during the post-martial law period, such as Ito ang Palad Ko (This Is My Fate), which began in 1973, DZRH. Radio Mindanao Network, particularly its network in the regions, continued to produce drama programs that reached Visayan-speaking audiences in the Visayas and Mindanao: DYHP Cebu, DXDC Davao, DXCC Cagayan de Oro, DXBC Butuan, DXIC Iligan, DXMD General Santos, DXPR Pagadian, DXRZ Zamboanga, DXMY Cotabato, DXRS Surigao, DXPR Dipolog, and DXMB Malaybalay. Its network also reaches Ilonggo-speaking areas through its stations DZHB Bacolod, DYRI Iloilo, DYVR Roxas, DYKR Kalibo, and DXKR Marbel. Its drama programs have dominated the programming of the genre for over 20 years. Kun Ako ang Pasultihon (If I Were to Speak), written and directed by Julian “Teban” Daan, co-hosted by Pricilla Raganas, is an advice comedy drama about ordinary problems of ordinary people. One of its hit segments is “Mga Asoy ni Teban ug Goliat” (The Comedy of Teban and Goliat), which presents short sitcoms and fantasy stories. Kini ang Akong Suliran (This Is My Problem) dramatizes legal and medical issues sent by listeners, who are given pieces of advice by medical doctor Randolph Rosaroso and lawyer Elaine Bathan. Handumanan sa Usa ka Awit (Memories of a Song) are stories of love based on a song sent in by listeners. What’s d’ Style highlights the usual problems of adults, which are often about sex and related stories.

Remarkable drama anthologies were also produced by other radio stations. Drama Filipina, 1990, DZEC Eagle Broadcasting Corporation, featured in drama form classic Filipino works by writers such as Pedro Bukaneg, Francisco Baltazar, Nick Joaquin, and contemporary works by popular writer Mars Ravelo. Tukmo kag Punay (Spotted Doves and Turtledoves), which began its run in the 1970s and continued airing up to the 1990s, produced by DYRP Radyo Tagring of the Allied Broadcasting Center in Iloilo City, employed the ambahan (poetry) and other local literary forms, to dramatize social and political issues in Panay. Salaminagway, 1991-92, written by Vita Moral-Bangon, directed by Don Pagusara, produced by the Development Education Media Services, critically examined national political issues and how such impinge on local politics through radio dramas aired on more accommodating radio stations than those affiliated with the commercial networks.

On television, one of the pioneers of the letter-sending anthology format was Lovingly Yours, Helen, which started in 1980, GMA, and continued airing from 1992 to 1996, written by Gina Marissa Tagasa, directed by Mario O’Hara and Argel Joseph. Vela was replaced as host by daughter Princess Punzalan when Vela died in 1992. Other TV drama programs showcasing the stories of the letter-sending audience include Napakasakit, Kuya Eddie (It Hurts, Brother Eddie), 1986-88, ABS-CBN, which, like Lovingly Yours, originated from radio, and Maalaala Mo Kaya (Will You Remember), premiered 1991, ABS-CBN, hosted by Charo Santos-Concio. These programs featured the lives of ordinary people facing different challenges in life. The programs would end with the host giving advice to the letter sender, usually in a positive note to inspire confidence and hope, and often citing inspirational lines from local proverbs or quotes from the Bible. A similar format that draws from real lives and incidents are the crime investigative show Calvento Files, 1995-98, ABS-CBN, and legal drama program Ipaglaban Mo (Fight for It), 1989-92 on IBC13, 1992-99 on ABS-CBN, 2003-4 on RPN 9, and 2012-13 on GMA News TV.

Film companies Regal, Seiko, and Viva and, later, television networks ABS-CBN, through Star Studio and Star Magic, and GMA, through GMA Films, produced numerous drama programs featuring either the popular female actors in their roster or new ones they are building up. On ABS-CBN, some of the versions of the studio system on television were Regal Drama Presents, 1986-99; Seiko TV Presents, 1989-90; and Star Drama Theatre, 1993-2001. On GMA, these were Mother Studio Presents, 1986-96; GMA Telesine Specials, 1993-99, 2001; and GMA Love Stories, 1999-2001. Viva’s popular daily soap operas were Villa Quintana, 1995-96, and Anna Karenina, 1996-2002, both on GMA. Coney Reyes on Camera, 1984-99, RPN 9 and then ABS-CBN, was the longest-running drama anthology. It was a reformat of her earlier drama anthologies Coney Reyes-Mumar Drama Studio, 1977-81, and Coney Reyes-Mumar on the Set, 1981-83, both on GMA. Maricel Soriano had two weekly anthologies, totaling 10 years: Maricel Regal Drama Special, 1987-90, and Maricel Drama Special, 1990-97, both on ABS-CBN.

Personality-focused daily drama soap serials continued to dominate the format of the drama in broadcast, this time starring a younger generation of performers. The most popular were those in which teen actor Judy Ann Santos appeared. She played the title role of Mara in Mara Clara, 1992-97, ABS-CBN, a story of two sisters who were switched at birth with one being raised by affluent doting parents while the rich parents’ real daughter is being abused by poor parents. Mara Clara was notorious for its unbelievable and unduly long plot of the crucial diary that contained the secret, which was lost for years, and the overly dramatic scenes of incredible physical, verbal, and psychological abuse. Santos also played the title role in Esperanza, 1997-99, ABS-CBN, about a child’s search for her biological family. Written by Dado Lumibao, Wali Ching, and Reggie Amigo, directed by Jerry Lopez Sineneng, Rory B. Quintos, and Don Miguel Cuaresma, the soap posted very high ratings and catapulted young actor Judy Ann Santos to superstar status. Other members of the cast include young performers Wowie de Guzman, Piolo Pascual, Angelika Dela Cruz, and Marvin Agustin. Another young performer who dominated the drama soap serial was Claudine Barretto for her lead roles in consistent top-raters like Mula sa Puso (From the Heart), 1997-99, Saan Ka Man Naroroon (Wherever You Are), 1999-2001, Sa Dulo ng Walang Hanggan (At Eternity’s End), 2001-3, Marina, 2004, and Iisa Pa Lamang (Just One), 2008, all on ABS-CBN. Jolina Magdangal was typecast in light drama-comedy serials, such as Labs Ko si Babe (I Love Babe), 1999-2000, with love team partner Marvin Agustin.

To this day, the story line of a young boy or girl separated from parents and raised amiably by kind adoptive relatives or strangers is exploited to the hilt by ABS-CBN as seen in Pangako sa ’Yo (The Promise), 2000, a hit series that catapulted Jericho Rosales and Kristine Hermosa into superstardom and made them famous in Asia and Africa, and would be remade in 2015 to showcase the career transition of Daniel Padilla and Kathryn Bernardo; Minsan Lang Kita Iibigin (I Will Love You Only Once), 2011, which showed the promise of actor Coco Martin, who appeared in many independent films, as a mainstream star; Walang Hanggan (My Eternal), 2012, a recreation of the blockbuster film Hihintayin Kita sa Langit (I Will Wait for You in Heaven), which itself is based on Emily Bronte’s Wuthering Heights topbilled by Richard Gomez and Dawn Zulueta; Ina, Kapatid, Anak (Mother, Sister, Daughter), 2012-13, which starred young sensation Kim Chiu; Juan de la Cruz, 2013, an action-fantasy drama that sealed Martin’s domination of the drama teleserye commonly achieved in the past by women actors; and Ikaw Lamang (No Greater Love), 2014, which featured the already popular television actors Martin and Chiu.

Telenovelas from Mexico and Spanish-speaking countries, chinovelas from Taiwan, and koreanovelas from Korea began flooding television programming beginning in the mid-1990s, local drama productions significantly shifted to the teleserye, a limited-run drama series. Major teleseryes came from ABS-CBN, GMA, and ABC 5. ABS-CBN produced teleseryes that became huge hits, like Sana’y Wala Nang Wakas (I Wish This Were Forever), 2003-4, about two star-crossed lovers who suffer from their parents’ long-forgotten sins; Sa Piling Mo (With You), 2006, about childhood friends who fall in love with each other; Maging Sino Ka Man (Whoever You May Be), 2006-7, about filial relationships among the elite and the poor; Tayong Dalawa (The Two of Us), 2009, about two brothers who joined the military; and Be Careful with My Heart, 2012-14, a daytime family-romantic comedy. Important GMA teleseryes include Kung Mawawala Ka (A World Without You), 2002-3, an epic political thriller and love story; Amaya, 2011-12, an epic series about precolonial Philippines; and My Husband’s Lover, 2013, about gay relationships in contemporary Philippine society.

Today, the Philippines has become a major producer of teleseryes, some of which have gained recognition from international award-giving bodies. Lobo (Werewolf), 2008, ABS-CBN, won the Rockie Award for the Telenovela in the BANFF World Television Festival in Canada in 2009. Teleseryes that were nominated in the International Emmy for the telenovela category were ABS-CBN’s Kahit Isang Saglit (A Time for Us), 2008, and Dahil May Isang Ikaw (Destined Hearts), 2009-10, and GMA’s Magdusa Ka (You Suffer), 2008, and My Husband’s Lover, 2013. Eva Fonda, 2008-9, ABS-CBN, was nominated as Best Drama Series at the Seoul International Drama Awards in 2009.

Most of these local drama soaps, serials, anthologies, and teleseryes, either for general audiences or geared toward the youth, exploited female stereotypes: “the woman, martyr, femme fatale, as sacrificial lamb, as the faithful shadow, as the manipulator” (Reyes 1991, 188). Their world revolves around the confines of the family. The themes lack the social context in which to situate their private and personal concerns, such as mother-daughter conflicts, sibling rivalry, extramarital affairs, teen delinquency, which all convey conventional images and orthodox representations of women.

TV dramas also drew critical attention from an observant public. Some praise the excitement in their ever-twisting narrative, saying that shows have become addictive and that to miss an episode would derail a viewer from the story’s development. On the other hand, the confusing and convoluted plot is also a cause of irritation, with many chastising the implausibility of both turn of events and character transformation. Suspension of disbelief is not anymore reserved for fantasy but also applies to television dramas in which the bida (protagonist) possesses unusual kindness, even to the degree of stupidity, while the kontrabida (antagonist) demonstrates an incredible capacity to evade punishment and death. Drama shows also usually end with the spectacular kill-all-the-evil-antagonists that are the vehicle for the costly action genre.

In the first few years of the post-martial law period, however, progressive cultural workers engaged in television drama productions on top of their involvement with other media and art forms. Cecile Guidote-Alvarez resurrected the social realist drama anthology Balintataw (The Mind’s Eye) on PTV 4 beginning in 1987 and continues to this day with occasional runs of new episodes. Its stable of writers included Rolando Tinio, Dodi Anzures, Ronaldo Tumbokon, Lualhati Bautista, Lito Casaje, Henry Nadong, and Mars Cavestany, while its pool of directors included Nick Lizaso, Jose Mari Avellana, Jose Gruta, Maryo J. de los Reyes, Orlando Nadres, and Lupita Aquino-Kashiwahara. Radyo Balintataw (Radio Balintataw) continues to air daily on DZRH under a new format: a combination of drama, poetry, music, storytelling, and reports and commentaries on sociocultural issues. The Philippine Educational Theater Association (PETA) created Handog ng PETA (An Offering of PETA), 1990-92, alternately directed by Ishmael Bernal, Soxy Topacio, Joel Lamangan, Beth Mondragon, Beth Quindara, and Ellen Ongkeko. The anthology examined relevant sociopolitical issues that most drama programs of the period rarely or were afraid to tackle. From PETA also came PETA-bisyon (PETA Vision), 1993, PTV 4, then RPN 9 and ABC 5, which portrayed social issues that depicted the agency of characters and provided solutions that were grounded more realistically than the conventions of escapism that characterize the genre. Dear Teacher, 1991, Islands TV 13, presented the lives of teachers by not romanticizing their situation. Episodes of the weekly anthology were written by Chris B. Millado, Lualhati Bautista, Soxy Topacio, and Amado Lacuesta Jr, and directed by Ishmael Bernal, Gil Portes, and Rey Bato. Activist filmmaker Lino Brocka had his own Lino Brocka Presents, 1986, IBC 13, and Sa Direksiyon ni Lino Brocka (Under the Direction of Lino Brocka), 1990, GTV 4. Mario O’Hara had Hilda, 1989, RPN 9, with co-director Soxy Topacio and writer Rusty Sangalang, and Mama, IBC 13, with scriptwriter Lualhati Bautista. Joel Lamangan directed Spotlight, 1990-98, GMA, written by Armando Lao and Frank Rivera. Armida Siguion-Reyna produced the drama special Taghoy ng Dagat (Lament of the Sea), 1993, written by Bibeth Orteza and directed by Jose Mari Avellana. The Task Force Detainees of the Philippines produced Melinda, 1995, GMA, directed by Joel Lamangan, written by Ricky Lee, about the rape of young student activists by the military.

These drama productions by progressive groups and individuals interrogated the status quo, presented more realistic and contextualized nuances of national social and political issues, conveyed clearly delineated personas of characters, introduced innovative narrative plots that either enriched or deviated from the conventions of the genre, critically examined networks of human relations, and offered progressive alternatives and potentials for a just and humane society.

Significant socially oriented drama anthologies were also produced by commercial networks beginning in the 1990s. ABS-CBN came out with Japayuki, 1992-96, detailing the lives of Filipina entertainers in Japan, and Mga Lihim ng Ermita (The Secrets of Ermita), 1992-96, which explored the salacious nooks and crannies of an old district in an old city. The drama serial Angkan (Clan), 1986-89, ABS-CBN, was epic in scope as it sought to dramatize in microcosm the lives of people in a sugar hacienda. GMA News TV came out with important drama serials like Bayan Ko (The Politician), 2013, a drama about politicians in a Philippine town; Titser (Teacher), 2013, a drama about the state of public education in the Philippines; and Katipunan, 2014, about the lives of ordinary Filipinos during the Philippine Revolution of 1896.
Commercials

A longtime component of programming and a crucial requirement of any successful show that has received significant popular and critical attention since the late 1980s are commercial advertisements. Commercials are the primary source of income that sustains TV and radio programs and also the measure of success of any show, with top-rating shows receiving more ads than less popular ones. In 1988, a San Miguel Corporation advertisement titled Bilmoko (contraction of “ibili mo ako” or “buy it for me”) was criticized for portraying a materialistic woman who always asks her man so many things for herself. A Pepsi raffle of winning numbers written on the bottle cap once ignited public outrage and faced legal and governmental battles when it once picked a set of numbers which was placed in countless bottle caps.

Many ads received commendations, such as those of McDonald’s which have continually featured specially or differently abled people tendering affectionate gestures to their loved ones. It has become a template of food and beverage advertisements in which happy moments are shared with the product as the indispensable element, from noodles to soda to fastfood. One lotion commercial funnily yet affirmatively portrayed two men in a relationship.
Emerging Programs, Digital Technology, and Convergence
New program types evolved during the post-martial law period, with some programs branching out to other media platforms or fusing multiple formats.

As early as the mid-1980s, some television programs had radio counterparts. The popular children’s program Batibot (Small but Strong), 1984-2000, produced by the Philippine Children’s Television Foundation headed by Lyca Benitez-Brown and Feny de los Angeles-Bautista, had Radyo Batibot (Radio Batibot), a 30-minute daily radio version which began to air in the late 1980s until 2000 on DZAM, later called DZAR. Woman Watch, produced by the Women’s Media Circle, 1986-94, PTV 4, hosted by Nikki Coseteng, also aired on DZSR Sports Radio, 1985-86; PTV 4’s Radyo ng Bayan, 1986-88; DWWW, 1988-90; and DWIZ, 1990-93.

The mid-1980s and the 1990s saw radio stations utilizing programming software that simplified and hastened the creation of the radio station’s daily playlist. For example, City Lite 88.3 utilized Selector, an imported software that enabled programmers to input pertinent data of certain songs into the computer, including their pace, tempo, and sound texture. The computer, in turn, took care of sorting out the songs and matching them based on their similarities. The result is a smooth flow in the transition of the songs contained in each playlist.

The 1990s also signaled the advent of the Internet, which served as source for news, information, and updates on new music. Developments during the period include the use of mobile phones, which later took on functions to accommodate more media platforms. With these came free music-sharing sites, such as Napster and Limewire, as well as the iPod and MP3 players which enabled music enthusiasts to download music from the Web for free and input them into their gadgets for their personal consumption. This proved to be more of a threat to radio than a helpful tool, as FM radio was suddenly relegated to being a mere source of information for new music. This applies particularly to the young segment of the listening market, who are said to have switched to other music media. Apparently, music lost its place as the unique selling product of FM radio stations. Advertisers started looking for more innovative concepts in which they could invest their money, and were no longer settling for basic spot buys. Stations turned to events as their primary product, while radio spots became mere add-ons to publicize events.

Some radio stations have started to embrace the Internet and use it to their advantage by linking their company profiles into the Web and making them accessible not just to listeners but to their potential advertisers as well. These websites have links that grant access to the station’s webcasts, and are used as add-ons in radio station sales departments’ advertising packages. Others took matters to the extreme by adopting unconventional program concepts or by completely overhauling their station’s format.

The turn of the 21st century witnessed advancements in technology and telecommunication facilities that facilitated the combination of media platforms. A new development is teleradyo (television radio), the merging of radio and television. A radio or a television program is simultaneously broadcast on radio and television. Broadcast stations also began tapping emerging technologies for their media platforms. They tapped into the Internet for more interactivity in their programs, allowing live streaming of some, if not yet all, of their terrestrial programs. Broadcast stations linked up with print organizations, sharing websites, and interactive platforms.

The most prominent genre of the period was reality television. The most popular reality show is the local franchise of the TV hit Big Brother of Dutch company Endemol, titled Pinoy Big Brother (Filipino Big Brother), which premiered in 2002 and continues to run to this day, ABS-CBN. It presents the day-to-day life of individuals from different walks of life put together inside an Orwellian house. Each “housemate,” as a contestant is called, is expected to obey house rules and perform household chores and special tasks as instructed by Kuya, the unseen Big Brother who commands their attention. Housemates, either picked from auditions held all over the archipelago and from some parts of the world or handpicked by management, vie for their housemates’ acceptance and public approval as they vote who should remain inside the house. Nominations by Big Brother and the housemates are decided upon by viewers through text votes. The show had several editions, including ones with teens as housemates and one that housed already-known personalities. It received countless criticisms from televiewers concerning the proper conduct of its participants and has been meted disciplinary actions by the MTRCB.

Since the 2000s, reality television has become the approach in both game and talent search programs. It is a format that puts contestants in real-life situations, awaiting their “real” reactions to challenges. Adventure series Extra Challenge, 2003-6, 2012-13, GMA, and The Amazing Race Philippines, 2012 and 2014, ABC 5, test the participants’ physical and psychological strength and endurance, from swimming to running and from haggling with vendors to knowing the local culture, in a variety of challenges held in different parts of the archipelago. A whole gamut of contests has also emerged in recent years. Pinoy Fear Factor, 2008-9, and I Dare You, 2011 and 2013, both on ABS-CBN, focus on participants overcoming their fears and inhibitions. Junior Master Chef, 2011-12, and MasterChef Pinoy Edition, 2012, both on ABS-CBN, test culinary skills and are also promoted to develop the food industry in the country. The Biggest Loser, 2011 and 2014, ABS-CBN, was launched to challenge the growing number of overweight people to lose weight and take care of their health.
Televisual Power and Politics

A corollary of tabloidization is the phenomenon of entertainment becoming news and news becoming entertainment or what others call “infotainment” where information is inextricably packaged with entertainment. Media becomes king and now sets the agenda in government policy and public discourse as public officials are forced to react and bow to what is reported and commented upon by big conglomerate media. Aggrieved persons report their grievances to television and radio stations in order to draw attention to their plight, testifying to the breakdown of governmental accountability and the haughty power of celebrated media personalities, themselves taking up certain causes against government officials. In this case, media, meant to be a neutral provider of information and arbiter of truth, becomes a political weapon.

Since the mid-1980s, when media freedom was restored and there was an exponential growth in TV and radio appliance ownership, broadcast media’s power has tremendously increased in the sociopolitical field. Programs formatted as complaints desk fortified the media’s bargaining power. “Hoy Gising!” (Hey, Wake Up!), 1992-2001, a segment of ABS-CBN’s flagship news program TV Patrol, and Isumbong Mo kay Tulfo (Report It to Tulfo), 1991-2006 and 2012 to present, DWIZ, which also aired in 2010-12 on DZIQ, were two popular shows that helpless citizens approached for a range of problems, from erring government officials to public infrastructure. Their prodding and investigation of concerned public and private institutions compelled higher-ups to address the people’s complaints, knowing that their actions would not be left unreported, thereby giving the public some form of welfare protection. But the way the programs’ hosts lambasted authorities without prior check on the nature of the complaint and the high-handed, even personal, treatment of each and every issue was rightly criticized. A more important concern not highlighted in the often sensational treatment of grievances is that institutional corrective mechanisms are not harnessed, reaching the hopeless point of begging the media to broadcast what should have been basic matters of citizen and consumer rights. Aptly described as “media as messiah,” mass media’s image points come at the expense of the reputation of public institutions and amicable civic relations. Popular programs that followed this format are Imbestigador (Investigator), which has been running on GMA since 2000, hosted by Mike Enriquez, and T3, which premiered in 2011 on ABC 5, hosted by Tulfo brothers Ben, Raffy, and Erwin.

Perhaps the most notable manifestation of mass media’s power is the electoral success of some of its most notable personalities. The phenomenon is a testament to the drawing power of the television medium and has been taken as formula by a growing number of media personalities for their political ambitions. Regardless of whether they were thinking of a political career when they first set into jobs as reporters and hosts, it has made the broadcast media profession suspect as the media audience-citizen voters realize that those they watch and listen to are only out to exploit what used to be a respectable industry as a platform for political candidacy. Appallingly, media have been gradually used as a revolving door from and to politics. This puts into question the ethical practices of broadcast media personnel.

A remarkable development in the operation of mass media is the coverage of impeachment trials of the country’s leaders, most popularly Estrada in 2000-2001 and Chief Justice Renato Corona in 2012, and legislative hearings on the scandalous corruption and violence perpetrated by top government officials. It has become regular for media networks to air their coverage of such procedures, with the viewing public avidly following the progress of those cases. Media have also become an effective and staple vehicle for citizen mobilization during times of emergency. Coverage of investigative proceedings and philanthropic crusades has, in turn, been criticized for focusing on simplistic issues of personalities, weakness in the explanation of technical and legal processes and their wider social and historical implications, waning reportage when the issues drag on, and the opportunistic use of natural disasters for the station and its roster of reporters and showbiz stars’ popularity.

The status of political reporting in the country is still reprehensible as it remains personality-based and is made more problematic by the personal ties of newspersons with government officials, if not being involved themselves in the bureaucracy prior to or after their service in the industry.
Language

The ascendancy of Tagalog-based Filipino in news broadcasting demonstrates the necessity of using a language more comprehensible to the widest audience possible in order to inform, to be patronized, and to earn. It also shows that English remains the language of the more educated and the upper class, a still tiny segment of the viewing and listening public. Serious and uppity business, global politics, talk, lifestyle, and investigative shows in English migrate to the networks’ secondary and/or cable channels catering to small niches of the Filipino audience. In spite of the claim that English can be a national and unifying language for Filipinos, the fact that the money-savvy entertainment divisions of media companies spend money on the Tagalog/Filipino language instruction of their upcoming stars, singers, and athletes in order to be accepted and gain following affirms the tenacity of Filipino and other local languages in the field of cultural production. Aside from imported telenovelas from Latin America, Taiwan, and Korea, a growing number of Hollywood movies and Japanese anime cartoons are also dubbed in Filipino and are shown in late morning, early afternoon, and late evening time slots. These shows are popular in public transportation terminals all throughout the country.
Transnationalization

It has become a necessity for Philippine media networks to engage the transnational audience. Transnationalization began in the Marcos regime when crony companies had to tie up with foreign conglomerates because of the capital-intensive building of mass media and telecommunications infrastructures. Before, Filipino firms had to partner with big multinational corporations for financial capital and technological expertise. Now foreign companies have to affiliate with local firms in the target countries of broadcast, with the foreign firms paying them for the exclusive right to distribute popular and profitable Filipino shows.

Today, the transnational turn is spearheaded by the biggest television networks which largely aim to cater to the Filipino audience worldwide. ABS-CBN Global Limited’s The Filipino Channel, formed in Sep 1994 and based in Redwood City, California, is the Lopez company’s response to the ever-growing demand of overseas Filipinos for news on the Philippines and Filipino television and film productions. Through its partnership with DirectTV of the United States for the exclusive DTH (direct-to-home) distribution, the network is able to export ABS-CBN News, Cinema One films, and radio channel reports, and now has more than two million subscribers. GMA Pinoy TV, under GMA Worldwide Inc, broadcasts GMA shows to North America, East Asia, the Middle East, and Africa. Its most lucrative market is Southeast Asia where Filipino TV drama productions are avidly followed. TV5 Network Inc has formed Kapatid TV5 to distribute Kapatid TV and Aksyon TV shows to its clients in the United States, Middle East, North Africa, and Guam.

Noteworthy about this development is that Filipino TV productions, which originally catered to Filipino viewers in host countries, have become popular with foreign audiences as well. The television drama Pangako sa ’Yo became a hit in Southeast Asia and East Africa, making its actors Jericho Rosales and Kristine Hermosa popular in these regions. Foreigners have come to admire the looks of Filipino performers, the themes and plots, and even the language itself, as shows were only given subtitles and not dubbed, unlike the showing of imported Latin and Asian telenovelas in the country.
Conclusion

Broadcasting has witnessed and chronicled the most important milestones in the history of the Philippines in the last century, particularly in the struggle of Filipinos against colonization, war, dictatorship, and natural and human-induced tragedies that had chanced upon each other in rapid succession. It has mirrored the various paths that Filipinos and Filipino cultures have taken and has served as a deep reservoir of the significant experiences shared by the country’s diverse communities.

More than a reflection and a repository of the struggles and vision of a people, radio and television, in several instances, have been direct players in the people’s journey toward the creation of a nation, as happened during the Japanese occupation, the revolt against the dictatorship of Marcos, and the condemnation of vertiginous political corruption that has jarred the foundations of the country’s political institutions. The ravaging consequences of these sociopolitical tragedies continue to haunt the present. During these instances, radio and television have provided the people with a sense of a larger, common community and an imagination of a nation.

Radio and television have contributed to the progress and maturation of Filipinos and their cultures, and to the way those cultures see themselves, particularly as expressed in the fields of popular culture and the practice of journalism. Perhaps, more than the political structure of the educational system, radio and television have been effective avenues for the spread of a common language among a people fragmented, yet connected, by diverse geographies, cultures, and tongues. Perhaps, more than the traditional transmitters of a culture’s values, ideologies, and sentiments—such as the church, the state, the school, and the family—radio and television, almost throughout the 20th century, have provided the platform for the negotiation of changes and adjustments that cultures assume in the course of their movement in history.

As broadcast personalities continue to become household names, with some approaching the status of cultural icons, Philippine broadcasting at the beginning of the third millennium endures as a cultural force. While much of radio and television’s form and substance is often criticized as Western, degraded and degrading, commercialized and debilitating, Filipinos have appropriated these broadcast platforms as their own. Both radio and television inform and entertain, articulate the values and attitudes of a people, move the nation to action when the situation demands them, interpret and transmit contemporary history, and afford their audiences a sense of connection to the rest of the nation and the world. Written by Eulalio R. Guieb III and JPaul S. Manzanilla, with notes from Elizabeth L. Enriquez, Marinela M. Aseron, Clodualdo del Mundo Jr, Florangel Rosario-Braid, Ramon R. Tuazon, Melba S. Estonilo, and Josefina M. C. Santos

Introduction

 

The content of broadcast programs has been inspired by many other cultural forms and expressions, like folklore and literature, theater, comic magazines, film, and, today, online media. Moreover, social realities experienced by the broadcasters and their audiences pervade radio and television shows, such as true-to-life events, religion, and legal cases. Furthermore, broadcasters and production staff, as well as the structure of programming, production designs and the conventions and practices of production, and the technological foundations of Philippine broadcasting are shaped by internal and external forces, such as the effects of radio and television on each other, and the impact of foreign broadcasting on the manner in which Filipino broadcasters craft Philippine radio and television.

 

Such sources and influences, and even appropriations as in the case of foreign broadcasting, do not occur singularly in each program, but combine and clash in the daily radio and television productions, often with imaginative results. For example, a character may be an amalgam of a mythical Filipino deity and fictional Western superhero, whose story is reinterpreted locally with a Filipino brand of folk fantasy, melodramatic narrative, or comedic satire. Neither are the influences and appropriations linear. Traditionally, the route of adaptation had been from a source like literature, to radio, to film, and then television. In recent decades, the path of adaptation has taken any course and even simultaneously. All these as broadcast technologies and production methods change, and as Filipino social realities and experiences evolve and shift.

 

 

Folklore and Literature

 

Folklore, as a body of indigenous knowledge, is so deeply intertwined with daily life that it predictably influences any permutation of mass and popular culture, both relatively recent phenomena. While there are economic and political factors at play in the broadcast industry, popular media, such as radio and television, to a certain extent inherently embody and articulate the aspirations of common folk, as it “indiscriminately absorb[s] all folk themes, both rural and urban, then feed[s] them back to millions of audiences in a mass cultural feedback” (Lopez 2006, 66).

 

Folk literature, such as riddles, myths, legends, and tales, and other literary forms, such as epics, novels, short stories, and poetic forms, permeate radio and television in varied ways. These include the straightforward adaptation of content, such as the eponymous radio drama featuring the stories in Mga Kuwento ni Lola Basyang (Stories of Grandma Basyang); the recurrence of tropes and archetypes, as in the prevalence of melodrama and Maria Clara–type characters in modern soap operas; the influence in format, such as the serial radio drama in the heels of serialized novels in popular magazines; and the continuation of a broader folk sensibility, as in the humorous, didactic spirit of numbskull tales featuring Juan Tamad (Lazy Juan), still evident in the heroes of 1990s sitcoms like Home along da Riles (Home along the Railroad).

 
 

It is a symbiotic relationship. Beginning in the 1950s with the introduction of television to Filipino homes and radio’s growing popularity, mass media became instrumental in the preservation of folklore and literature in the popular imaginary. In some ways, this development is but an extension of folklore’s characteristic orality. In 1959, when then president Carlos P. Garcia facilitated the donation of a few thousand transistor radios to the barrios, they became a “towering presence” in areas where the only method of transmitting information was by word of mouth (Fernandez 1981, 35). This phenomenon would further evolve in the coming decades with the advent of urbanization, on the one hand, and mobile technology and the Internet, on the other.

 

The earliest known foray of literature into the broadcast medium was in the 1950s, with DZPI’s child-oriented Mga Kuwento ni Lola Basyang, based on the eponymous stories by Severino Reyes which first appeared in Liwayway magazine in the 1920s. The show’s success has been attributed to the intimacy that it created, how it “encapsulated not only society’s [oral] mode of retelling but stressed the importance of the narrator” (Reyes 2005, 47). The titular character has since been immortalized in the popular imagination, the image of “an old bespectacled woman wearing her native saya seated in her silyon (a native chair), surrounded by her grandchildren” (Reyes 2009, 402). The retellings popularized numerous folk narratives such as “Maryang Makiling,” “Ang Dalagang Bukid na Naging Prinsesa” (The Mountain Lass Who Became a Princess), and “Ang Sirena sa Uli-Uli ng Pasig” (The Mermaid at the Eddy of Pasig). A 2007 television update on GMA 7 features Lola Basyang’s strong-willed granddaughter, played by Manilyn Reynes, traveling with a mobile library van to share what by then were “classic” tales by her grandmother.

 

 

Also in the 1950s, the DZRH radio horror drama Gabi ng Lagim (Night of Terror) began to appropriate figures from folk mythology, often rendering them as malevolent creatures of the dark. However, the negative portrayal, which endures to this day, continued the successful demonization of indigenous lore by the propagators of the new Catholic faith. In the 1980s, with urban folk’s experience of unbridled urbanization and attendant terrors like crime and grinding poverty, the horror mode became all the more germane, seen in the weekly GMA horror serial Regal Shockers, 1985-91; the highly anticipated annual All Souls’ Day specials of ABS-CBN’s Magandang Gabi, Bayan (Good Evening, Nation), 1988-2005; and the weekly quasi-investigative shows featuring paranormal stories like Verum Est: Totoo Ba Ito? (Verum Est: Is This True?) 2001, and Misteryo (Mystery), 2009. While urban legends still spread through word of mouth, the transmission is accelerated by something as pervasive as television and radio.

 

The fantasy genre offered more positive renditions of the same source material, as in the primetime sitcom Okay Ka, Fairy Ko! (You’re Okay, My Fairy!), 1987-89, IBC 13, 1989-95, ABS-CBN, and 1995-97, GMA. The show followed the marriage of mortal Enteng Kabisote (Vic Sotto) and the “fairy” Faye (Alice Dixson). While the two “worlds” could be seen as a stand-in for social classes and there was unmistakable Western influence in the construction of the magical beings, they were nevertheless imbued with divine qualities, hewing close to their indigenous origins. The GMA 7 series Encantadia (Fairyland), 2005, expanded this canvas with an enchanted realm divided into four kingdoms where lived different mythical entities. The Cebuano radio series Mga Asoy ni Teban ug Goliat (Stories of Teban and Goliat), DHYP (Radio Mindanao Network Cebu), starring the comedy duo Julian Bacus “Teban” Daan and Allan “Goliat” Nacorda, mixed comedy with fantasy and often drew on Visayan folkloric creatures. Daan and Nacorda are also known for their popular comedy skits “Mga Pakatawa ni Teban ug Goliat” (The Jokes of Teban and Goliat), some of which use humorous wordplays and folk beliefs. In one in which a character’s mental illness is attributed to spirits, the phonemic difference between “gitiawan” (played a joke on) and “gitinuod” (taken seriously) is the source of the humor. Another AM radio series is Mutya sa Saging Minantikan (Jewel of Banana Fritter), about Maria’s amulet extracted from a banana bud. The success of these radio programs spawned the hit television series Si Goot da Wanderpol (Goat the Wonderful) in the 1990s. Produced by Marcos Sacol, the picaresque featured Teban and Goliat who look after a magical goat that defecates gold coins, a local spin on a Western fairy tale.

 

This indigenous precolonial world captured in the country’s epics is the inspiration behind the so-called epic-serye Amaya, 2011-12, which followed the titular character as a princess and binukot (kept maiden) who, through a series of events, became an uripon (slave), a baybayin (ancient Philippine script) teacher in exile, and eventually a warrior leader who helped save from tyrannical rule an unnamed kingdom in Central Visayas. To a certain extent, some of the tropes used in the series, like the fall from grace and the drawn-out quest for revenge, are soap opera staples, but the show’s world admirably drew on indigenous lore, in particular on social order, cosmology, and even Visayan epic conventions. Amaya’s sequel Indio (Christianized Native), 2013, which opened with the death of Amaya and followed her demigod son Malaya, continued the use of epic tropes, this time set against the backdrop of oppressive Spanish colonization. Adopted by an abusive encomendero, Malaya was renamed Simeon, an undisguised nod to Jose Rizal’s El Filibusterismo (Subversion), 1891.

 

Programs designed for children are another popular platform for this material. The individual episodes of the children’s show Hiraya Manawari (Reaching One’s Dreams), 1995-2003, ABS-CBN, revolve around one value, like self-discipline or humility, sometimes dramatized through journeys to mystical lands populated by magical creatures. The Carlo Aquino starrer Pahina (Pages), 2000-2001, was a weekly drama anthology that features and dramatizes noted Filipino literary works that also promoted values necessary in the character development of the youth. Finally, the weekly anthology Ang Mahiwagang Baul (The Enchanted Chest), 2005-7, showcased Philippine myths, legends, and folklore.

 

Short stories and novels also became material for television dramas early on. Some of the most notable episodes of ABC Channel 5’s drama anthology Balintataw (The Mind’s Eye) in the 1960s were “Isang Gabi ng Tagsibol” (A Night in Spring); Alberto Florentino’s adaptation of Nick Joaquin’s “May Day Eve;” “Kabalyerong Tanso” (Fake Knight), based on Wilfrido Nolledo’s “Rice Wine;” and “Kudyapi” (Two-Stringed Lute), Lino Brocka’s adaptation of Bienvenido Santos’s “The Day the Dancers Came.” Featuring productions of the Philippine Educational Theater Association, the program’s directors include stalwarts such as Brocka, Elwood Perez, and Joey Gosiengfiao. RPN 9’s Malayo Pa ang Umaga (The Morn Is Yet So Far), 1979, is based on Stevan Javellana’s World War II novel Without Seeing the Dawn, 1947. Produced by Armida Siguion-Reyna, it is the first known miniseries on Philippine television, the precursor to the telenovela format in the 2000s.

 

In terms of form, a radio program in 1934 featured the form of the balagtasan, a poetic exchange or joust on a social issue. Interrupted by World War II, it returned in the 1950s on DZRH, hosted by the poet Emilio Mar Antonio. Every Sunday, he engaged a guest poet in a debate in Tagalog verse on the burning issue of the day, such as divorce or statehood for the Philippines under the United States. The format of other forms of folk poetry, like riddles and proverbs, have today evolved into fodder for jokes in sketch comedies like Bubble Gang, which also pioneered a segment on “fliptop,” the modern, if raunchy and less socially relevant, incarnation of the balagtasan.

 

The format of the radio drama and, eventually, telenovelas, also follows a literary form, in particular the serialized novels in the massively popular chain of Liwayway Publications that flourished in the decades leading to World War II. These include the Tagalog Liwayway, 1922; the Cebuano Bisaya, 1930; the Ilocano Bannawag, 1934; and Hiligaynon, 1934. Sometimes criticized for being lowbrow (especially vis-à-vis English publications), the stories, from melodramas to sitcoms and satires, nevertheless played a key role in cultivating a popular appetite for literature and in shaping popular sensibilities. The first postwar soap is Liwayway Arceo’s Ilaw ng Tahanan (Light of the Home), which aired on DZRH in Mar 1949, followed shortly by Lina Flor’s Gulong ng Palad (Wheel of Fate), also on DZRH. The daily 15-minute programs chronicled the highs and lows in the life of ordinary Filipino families. Other notable ones include Fundador Soriano’s Kahapon Lamang (Just Yesterday) and Flordeluna, which first aired in Cebu radio and translated to Tagalog in the late 1970s. Gulong ng Palad also became the pioneer daily serialized drama on television in 1977, which aired on BBC 2 from 1977 to 1985. Soon, Flordeluna was also adapted to television, which ran from 1979 to 1984 with Janice de Belen in the title role. These pioneers would be revisited in recent times, occasionally remade with a more contemporary twist.

 

Aside from formal similarities with serialized novels, soap operas routinely resound with characteristics that are directly traceable to centuries-old literary forms like metrical romances, such as awit or korido. These include conventions, such as the emotional intensity of Balagtas’s lyric poems manifesting as pervasive melodrama, or the ubiquitous archetype of the perpetually martyred and suffering woman. His Florante at Laura (Florante and Laura) had utilized emotion between the titular lovers to unpack its themes. As an element, melodrama has remained a staple in radio and television, from the pioneering radio counseling drama Ito ang Inyong Tiya Dely (This Is Your Aunt Dely) in the 1950s to the long-running television drama Coney Reyes on Camera in the 1990s.

 

The satirical spirit of folktales, often humorous accounts that are also oblique social commentaries, finds echoes in modern satirical comedies, including the pioneering radio show Kuwentong Kutsero (Tall Tales), which first aired in 1938 and became widely popular in the 1950s and 1960s. In the same way that the numbskull tales featuring Juan Tamad cautions against laziness, Kuwentong Kutsero spoofed Filipino manners, politics, customs, and government officials. Conceptualized by Horacio de la Costa and James Reuter, who would both become Jesuit priests, the show’s format was successfully replicated in provincial stations and, in the 1960s, as a television sitcom on ABS-CBN Channel 3. Other notable satires are Sic O’Clock News, 1987-89, IBC 13, which parodied social issues in the format of a news program; the sitcom Abangan ang Susunod na Kabanata (Watch for the Next Chapter), 1991-97, ABS-CBN, which poked fun at social stratification with stock characters from politics and normal folk; and Mongolian Barbecue, 1990-91 and 1993-95, RPN, which used the “grill-and-roast” interview format to make fun of politicians and personalities.

 

The trickster trope also survives. Some of the exploits of Kevin Kosme (Dolphy), the protagonist of family-oriented sitcom Home along da Riles, render him as a trickster hero in the tradition of Juan Pusong. A regular source of humor are Kevin’s often successful attempts to outsmart or trick someone in a position of power, from his rich and devoted admirer Ason (Nova Villa) to his boss Steve (Bernardo Bernardo) and the neighborhood sari-sari (variety) store owner Tomas (Tommy Angeles).

 

The influence of folklore and literature on radio and television is sometimes direct, as in adaptations of legends and short stories, and sometimes more oblique, in terms of a broader folk sensibility. That many urban legends still feature entities from Philippine lower mythology prove the survival of the folk literary tradition and the folk memory despite the shift in milieu. Even folk poetry, such as riddles and proverbs, continue to find modern incarnations, such as in jokes and punch lines commonly heard in the stingers of so-called masa radio stations and recurring gags in television comedies. There is little doubt that this intimate link will persist in the years, perhaps decades, ahead.Written by Glenn Diaz w ith notes from Julian dela Cerna and John Bengan

 

 

Theater

Long before the advent of radio in the 1920s and television in the 1950s, Filipino audiences of different classes had enjoyed what were then the only sources of public entertainment: the Spanish-influenced komedya, sinakulo, sarsuwela, and drama; and the American-influenced bodabil. Through theater directors, artists, producers, and even technicians who were hired to work in the new broadcast media, the themes, characters, plots, and even style of performance and production design of these Filipino dramatic genres survived the onslaught of the new media, precisely by migrating to and taking root in the electronic media of radio and television themselves.

 

The centuries-old komedya, which flourished in the 19th century and declined in the 20th, revolved around themes of love and war between royal characters in the kingdoms of medieval Europe (like España, Francia, Alemania, Italia) and the Middle East (like Persia, Turkiya, Arabia, and Marruecos). Taking their stories from the orally transmitted or printed verse narratives called awit and korido, the komedya developed a production style marked by a stylized delivery of verse dialogue, choreographed fighting, and magical effects. Cristianos and Moros were characterized as heroes and villains, respectively, and identified as such by their marches, acting style, and costumes (dark colors for Christians, red for Moors).

 

From the komedya tradition derived the stories of Severino Reyes, which were serialized more than once on radio and television as Mga Kuwento ni Lola Basyang (Stories of Grandma Basyang); as well as the episodes of royal fantasy in radio serial dramas like Prinsipe Amante (Prince Amante) and Zimatar, and stories of magical swords as in the television series Juan dela Cruz. On both radio and television, the characters of the ailing father/king, the young, kindhearted prince, the princess in distress, the jealous or conspiring courtiers, the irreverent but delightful trickster, and the old ermitanyo (hermit) who turns out to be Christ or a person with powers, replicate the komedya’s own dramatis personae. Scenes of swordplay, tournaments for the hand of a princess, and royal romance that ends in a royal wedding are also straight out of the komedya, although the influence of children’s stories and films about royal characters from the West cannot be discounted.

 

The sinakulo or passion play began as a dramatization of the pasyon, the verse narrative of the story of Christian salvation, from genesis to the coronation of the Virgin Mary in heaven, with particular emphasis on the sufferings, death, and resurrection of Jesus Christ. As the pasyon is chanted on the Sundays of Lent and all throughout Holy Week, so the sinakulo may be performed anytime in Lent, but especially during Holy Week. If the Christians and Moors are the bida (heroes) and kontrabida (villains) respectively in the komedya, in the sinakulo the bida are the banal or holy people, including Christ, the Virgin and their followers, while the kontrabida are the hudyo, the generic name applied to all who persecuted Christ whether Jews or Romans. While the banal are meek and gentle, the hudyo are pompous and violent, as further emphasized by their respective styles of chanting, acting, and marches.

 

The sinakulo theme of the oppression and eventual triumph of the underdog, as well as the characters of the virtuous but destitute hero, the ever-suffering and maudlin mother, the repentant vamp, the hard-hearted traitor, is very much evident not only in Lenten presentations like Kalbaryo ni Hesus (Calvary of Jesus) on radio but also in regular radio dramas like True Confessions and Lumipas na Madaling Araw (Forgotten Morn) and in telenovelas like May Bukas Pa (There’s Still Tomorrow) and Nathaniel. In fact, even scripts supposedly based on “real stories” of letter writers, as in Maalaala Mo Kaya (Will You Remember) and Magpakailanman (Forever) on television, tend to pattern their characters after those of the sinakulo, and to conclude their stories with moralistic themes that assure audiences that those who suffer shall inherit the kingdom of heaven.

 

Introduced by Spanish troupes in the 19th century, the drama and sarsuwela, as written by Filipinos from the 1900s to the 1940s, presented issues, characters, and stories, no longer from foreign narratives like the komedya and sinakulo but from contemporary Philippine society. The drama and sarsuwela are two different dramatic genres—the first is a straight play in prose, while the second is a prose play with songs and dances—but they pursue identical or at least similar sociocultural themes, like the conflict between the rich and the poor in love and business, the colonial mentality of Filipinos, the corruption of politicians, vote-buying during elections, cockfighting and other vices, infidelity of husband or wife, divorce, social climbing, and misunderstandings between parents and children. Such themes may be treated in comic or satirical fashion in the drama comico or sarsuwela, or in tragic mode in the melodrama, also called drama tragico. Characters in the drama and sarsuwela are based on real social types (politicians, gamblers, peasants, workers, parents, children, lovers), but they are so idealized that they may also be categorized as bida and kontrabida. Heroes and heroines as well as villains and vixens are identified as such by their costumes and makeup, style of acting and dialogue delivery, and types of songs. So are the witty servant-comedians. Lastly, drama and sarsuwela most commonly have plots whose conflicts are resolved gratuitously by coincidences and other dei ex machina and whose narrative closure must always affirm the political, social, and moral values of the ruling establishment.

 

The black-and-white characters (the bida who sacrifice everything for love of parents and partners and the kontrabida who connive at every point to take what is not rightfully theirs), the stylized manner of speaking (soft vs harsh) and acting (gentle vs violent), the stereotyped costume design (prettily conservative for heroes and heroines and modish and daring for villains and villainesses), the manipulated plots (sworn enemies turn out to be brothers or sisters after all) and coincidences (the villain accidentally falls into a cliff during a fight), and the reconciliatory endings of the drama and sarsuwela (the rich and the poor marry each other in the end) are very much alive and evident in radio dramas like Gulong ng Palad (Wheel of Fate), 24 Oras (24 Hours), Habang May Buhay (While There Is Life) and television dramas like Mga Kuwento ng Pag-ibig (Stories of Love). They are also found in drama episodes of weekly radio shows like Lovingly Yours, Helen and Kahapon Lamang (Just Yesterday), as well as in the seasons-long telenovelas like Pangako sa ’Yo (The Promise), Tayong Dalawa (The Two of Us), and Mara Clara.

 

Introduced from the USA in the 1920s, bodabil was a variety show that combined solo, duo, or trio singing, pair or chorus dancing, comedy skits, magician tricks, and even animal acts in a wildly entertaining performance, usually alternating with the screening of local or foreign movies in theaters. Although bodabil drew heavily from American popular culture, bodabil artists managed to indigenize the form through the use of topical or issue-based humor, local adaptations of American songs, locally conceptualized production numbers, local variations or modifications of foreign dances and costumes, popularization of local counterparts of foreign singers, and creation of original Filipino songs using the musical template of American pop songs. The bodabil stage trained and built up some of the most famous singers, dancers, and comedians who, because of their popularity and talent, were sought out by the first producers and writers in broadcast media, who in many cases also had roots in or were exposed to bodabil.

 

On radio, the bodabil traditions are found in the variety shows like Camay Theater of the Air, The San Miguel Brewery Hour, and even in famous song competitions like Tawag ng Tanghalan (Call of the Stage), especially because these are hosted by former bodabil performers. On the other hand, bodabil humor, dancing, and even magical acts were carried over into television by shows like Oras ng Ligaya (Happy Hour), Showbiz with the Salvadors, and Germspesyal. Buhay Artista (Actor’s Life) became famous for its opening numbers where Dolphy and Panchito transliterate English songs into Tagalog with hilarious results. Other bodabil-type TV shows are the The Nida-Nestor Show, VIP or Vilma in Person, Loveli-ness, and Superstar, which showcase not only the dancing and singing talents of their stars but create production numbers with lavish costumes and sets like those in bodabil. Descended from both the drama comico and the bodabil or stage show are the situation comedies or sitcoms, like John en Marsha (John and Marsha), Home along da Riles (Home along the Railroad), Tang-Tarang-Tang, and Iskul Bukol (School Bumps) where humor comes from play on words, mistaken identities, and wacky characters like a moralizing mother-in-law, a gay antagonist, a goofy man-child, a crusty old teacher, and a band of ne’er-do-well students.

 

All in all, the influence of traditional theater on radio and television may be seen in the following aspects of script and production: the division of idealized characters into bida and kontrabida, with their corresponding styles of acting, speaking, and dressing; the chronologically arranged plots with highly colorful events whose conflicts are resolved by extrinsic forces and end by affirming the validity of the establishment’s beliefs and values; a directorial style that merely strings together episodes and veers away from innovation or radical change; photography work where the camera is a recorder and rarely an interpreter of scenes being shot; and editing that is invisible, leisurely, and predictable.

 

Although the radio and television mainstream shows continue to use and propagate the practices of traditional theater to this date, a few artists, mostly associated with theater and film, have produced a few programs on television that were influenced by another type of theater that came into the country after World War II. Through literature classes, the younger generation of directors in the 1960s and 1970s encountered modernism in the plays of European playwrights like Henrik Ibsen and August Strindberg and American writers like Arthur Miller and Tennessee Williams. Writing in the mode of realism favored by these foreign playwrights, Filipino writers like Nick Joaquin, Alberto Florentino, and Nestor Torre Jr wrote plays in English which were translated into Filipino and produced for television in shows like Balintataw. Later, film directors trained in literature and theater directed drama anthologies with realistic plots and characters, such as Hilda, Lino Brocka Presents, and Ang Makulay na Daigdig ni Nora. In these productions, realism permeates the choice of costumes, sets, and, most of all, the internalized acting which gives life to highly individualized characters. Because such stories usually had endings that were often open-ended or downright tragic, TV producers have avoided such narratives, preferring the feel-good, if unrealistic and escapist, closures typical of traditional theater.Written byNicanor G. Tiongson

 

Komiks

 

Among the major sources of radio and television materials are the komiks (comics) and the comic strips. Adapted from the English illustrated comics, the Filipino komiks is magazine in format. Published weekly, each issue is composed of 5-10 illustrated stories framed in panels arranged in chronological sequences. Each story covers at least four pages. A story can be a serial, which may run for over a year. Some stories are wakasan in format; they begin and end in one installment. Elements such as narrative flow, scenes, temporal settings, characters, emotions, thoughts, dialogues, and sound effects are presented in framed illustrations, balloons, panels or captions. The comic strip, on the other hand, is a single-tier panel of a vignette of life that is regularly published in the entertainment or editorial section of a daily broadsheet or tabloid, or in its weekend edition or magazine supplement. The comic strip is often a brief and humorous commentary on current issues or morals or a caricature of personalities.

 

The comic strip is a preferred source of material for the comedy in Philippine broadcast. Komiks materials, especially adventure-fantasy and the melodramatic love story, are borrowed often by film and sometimes by radio, particularly in the 1950s and 1960s, and then adapted for television beginning in the late 1970s. Some adventure-fantasy stories from komiks are turned into animation productions, specifically in the 1980s. The turn of the 21st century saw some komiks materials and foreign graphic novels being directly adapted for television and, more recently, into independent productions, mainly in digital animation, that are primarily circulated in emerging media platforms, such as the Internet, personal blog sites, and social media. In the 20th century, adaptations of komiks followed a more or less predictable route: from komiks to radio, to film, and finally television. Radio was a testing ground for the acceptability of komiks characters and narratives on the big screen. Once tested, many such characters and narratives are reproduced for the small screen. Since the late 1990s, the sequence has become unpredictable. For example, some komiks characters and stories have been adapted straight into television, bypassing radio and film.

 

One of the early komiks characters was illustrated by Jose Zabala Santos and Francisco Reyes for the 1955 Purico advertisement of the Philippine Manufacturing Company (now Procter & Gamble). They produced Juan Tamad (Lazy Juan), a six-minute 35 mm film intended for TV, but it was never aired. Juan Tamad was used as part of a political satire on TV in the 1960s until the declaration of martial law in 1972, on Channel 13. It was resurrected in 1979 on GTV 4, both of which were directed by now National Artist for film Manuel Conde, who also portrayed the legendary lazybones hero—a caricature of the Filipino—with Gloria Romero and Aurora Salve. The character Juan Tamad spawned five movies, all by Conde, from 1947 to 1963.

 

Many popular comic strips in Tagalog, serialized in daily English broadsheets, were made into weekly comedy series on television. Ben Alcantara’s Gorio and His Jeepney, 1966-69, ABC DZTM-TV Channel 5, directed by Rene Pangan, was from the daily broadsheet Manila Times. It is about the daily routine of a jeepney driver played by Chiquito. Tisoy (slang for mestizo), 1968-69, ABC Channel 5, played by Jimmy Morato and co-starring Pilar Pilapil, Edmund Sicam, Bert “Tawa” Marcelo, and Moody Diaz, directed by Nick Lizaso, was based on a daily cartoon comic strip of the same title by Nonoy Marcelo in the Manila Times in 1963. The cartoon strip, on the other hand, was based on the comic strip Pytik, which Marcelo, while a student, created for The Advocate, the student paper of Far Eastern University. It is a social satire on the beatnik culture of the restless urban youth of the 1960s. Tisoy was turned into a movie, first in 1979, directed by Lauro Pacheco, and then in 1977, directed by now National Artist for film Ishmael Bernal. Baltic & Co., 1974-76, GMA 7, starring Nanding Flores as Baltic, who was later replaced by Prospero Luna, then by Bert Marcelo, and directed by Ricky Manalo, was from Roni Santiago’s cartoon strip that started to appear daily in the Manila Bulletin in the 1970s and continues until the present. It is about a hotheaded boss and the daily concerns of his employees, one of whom is Miss Tapia, played by Mely Tagasa, whose character would be transported to the highly popular weekly TV sitcom Iskul Bukol, 1977-90, IBC 13. Larry Alcala’s Asiong Aksaya (Wasteful Asiong), 1977, GTV 4, portrayed by radio drama talent Tony Angeles and directed by Ading Fernando, came from the Philippines Daily Express in which it appeared from 1976 to 1984 and a weekly version serialized in the komiks Tagalog Klasiks. It lampooned the people’s wasteful consumption of electricity, water, and gas at the height of the energy and power supply crises in the 1970s. Rated PB (Pambayan): Pugad Baboy sa TV (Rated National: Swine’s Nest on TV), 1993, GMA 7, directed by Leo Martinez and starring Edgar Mortiz, Giselle Sanchez, and Rudy Meyer, was from Pol Medina Jr’s Pugad Baboy (Swine’s Nest), a daily cartoon strip that ran in the Philippine Daily Inquirer, 1988-2013, and in Rappler starting 2013. It is about a Manila community of obese people and their astute and witty observations about national issues that affect their village.

 

Adventure-fantasy, which has elements of science fiction and Philippine folklore, from komiks to television was experimented with only in the late 1970s, abandoned for a long period, and attempted again by television networks in the mid-2000s. The main reason for the late and intermittent exploration of the genre on television was the lack of broadcast technology and facilities, combined with the prohibitive cost of producing a program in this genre. Notable examples are the classic komiks superhero characters created by Mars Ravelo, especially Darna, Varga, Kapitan Boom, Dyesebel, Captain Barbell, and Lastikman.

 

Darna, a Pilipino Komiks serial on the exploits of a titular flying wonder woman character created in 1950 and illustrated by Nestor Redondo, for Pilipino Komiks, was turned into a TV series in 1977 on RPN 9 starring Lorna Tolentino, in 2005 on GMA 7 starring Angel Locsin, and in 2009-10, again on GMA 7, starring Marian Rivera. The character of Darna also made cameo appearances in a series of Toyota Tamaraw FX television commercials in 1993, played by Anjanette Abayari, Alma Concepcion, and Daisy Reyes, and in the dream sequence of the 2010 drama series Trudis Liit (Small Trudis), with Jillian Ward portraying the roles of the child character and the child Darna defeating the snake-headed villain Valentina. Before TV, Darna was made several times into a movie, the first of which was as early as 1951 starring Rosa del Rosario and directed by Fernando Poe Sr.

 

The character Darna was a reconceptualization of an earlier komiks character, Varga, also by Ravelo, that first appeared in Bulaklak Magazine in 1947. Varga made her first TV appearance in a cameo role, portrayed by Mariel Rodriguez, in Kapitan Boom (Captain Boom), 2008, ABS-CBN 2. Varga was made as a TV series by ABS-CBN 2 immediately following the run of Kapitan Boom in Aug 2008, with the character portrayed again by Rodriguez. Varga is like Darna, but unlike Darna whose human alter ego is a person with disability, Varga is already a human possessing superhero qualities, including the ability to fly, which she would only find out later in her life. Ravelo’s fumbling hero Kapitan Boom, on the other hand, first appeared in United Komiks in 1966, and the character in the 2008 TV series was played by Bench model Jon Avila.

 

Dyesebel, the story of a mermaid, illustrated by Elpidio E. Torres, who is now acknowledged as the Amorsolo of Philippine komiks, appeared in Pilipino Komiks, 1952-53, and in Kampeon Komiks, 1975. It was produced by GMA 7 in 2008 starring Marian Rivera and by ABS-CBN 2 in 2014 starring Anne Curtis. Before all these, Premiere Productions first popularized the comics mermaid in Dyesebel, 1953, a film directed by Gerardo de Leon.

 

Captain Barbell, a muscular hero whose alter ego is a lanky and asthmatic person, appeared in Pinoy Komiks, 1963-65, and in Liwayway, 1966, both illustrated by Jim Fernandez; in Pilipino Komiks, 1985-86, illustrated by Clem Rivera; and in the online fan-comics Digmaan (War), 2005, recreated and illustrated by Gilbert Monsanto. Captain Barbell first appeared on television in a cameo role in the final episode of Darna, 2005, GMA 7. The character then had his own series in 2006-7 with a remake in 2011, both on GMA 7 and both starring Richard Gutierrez. The two TV serials were expanded versions of the original story, presenting more details of the main character and introducing more villains. Like other Mars Ravelo characters, film versions of Captain Barbell came earlier and more in number than broadcast adaptations, the first of which was in 1964 starring Bob Soler and directed by Herminio Bautista.

 

Lastikman, patterned after DC comics hero Plastic Man, first appeared in Aliwan Komiks in 1964-65, revived in 1995 by Aliwan publisher Graphics Arts Service Inc with new stories by new writers in a magazine of its own called Lastikman Komiks, went back to Aliwan Komiks in 1996-97, and was reworked into a 56-page issue of Mango Comics in 2004 by writer Gerry Alanguilan and artists Arnold Arre and Edgar Tadeo. It was turned into a TV series in 2007 by ABS-CBN, starring Vhong Navarro and directed by Chito Roño. The TV series won the Silver World Medal for the Action-Adventure category in the New York Festivals, 2009. Like most Ravelo creations, Lastikman was earlier seen in three film versions, the first of which was in 1968 starring Von Serna.

 

There are other superhero characters that were created first for either radio or film, recreated as a komiks material, then transported to a television series. One is Kapitan Kidlat (Captain Lightning), created in the 1950s by Leonardo P. Abutin Sr for a radio series of the same title on DZRH, transported to film in 1953 starring Armando Goyena and directed by Oscar del Rosario, rewritten as Kidlat by Pablo S. Gomez in a 25-issue magazine called Kidlat Komiks Magazine, 1967-68, then made as a TV series, with the title Kidlat, 1985-86, IBC 13, starring Ricky Davao, and Kapitan Kidlat, 2013, TV5, starring Derek Ramsay.

 

A trend in the 2000s was the adaptation of komiks superheroes directly to television, without having to be produced first in film. The trend was spearheaded by ABS-CBN in its anthology serial titled Mars Ravelo’s Komiks Presents. Each series of the anthology ran for 13-15 episodes. Some komiks materials that were included in the anthology were Kapitan Boom and Varga, both in 2008, and Flash Bomba, 2009, which first appeared in Tagalog Klasiks, 1967-68. One of the anthology’s most interesting series is Isang Lakas (One Force), 2011, which unites all the Mars Ravelo superheroes into one team, called Sanlakas (United Front), to battle the evils of the human world.

 

Also included in the Mars Ravelo’s Komiks Presents, although not about a superhero but about mediums, ghosts, and reincarnations, was Nasaan Ka, Maruja (Where Are You, Maruja), 2009, from Ravelo’s Gumising Ka … Maruja (Wake Up … Maruja), with the character role played by Kristine Hermosa. Gumising Ka … Maruja was first published in Pilipino Komiks in 1966, illustrated by Rico Rival, and had three film adaptations: in 1966 and 1978, both starring Susan Roces, and in 1996, with Carmina Villaroel.

 

Komiks heroes have not only been made into live-action television series. Some have been produced as single-airing animation productions on television, such as Darna and Captain Barbell, both illustrated for the animation by Gerry Garcia and produced by RPN 9, both in 1986. One highly popular komiks hero that was rendered both in animation and live-action feature and broadcast as a television series was Ang Panday (The Blacksmith), who has superior swordsmanship skills whose dagger is made of ore from a meteorite that fell from the sky. The character was created by Carlo J. Caparas and illustrated by Steve Gan. Ang Panday was first serialized in Pilipino Komiks beginning in 1976 and republished as a serial in Liwayway, 1979, and as a strip in People’s Journal, 1979. The animated Ang Panday, RPN 9, 1986-87, was created by cartoonist Gerry Garcia and is considered the first Filipino animated series. The title role in the action-drama teleserye Ang Panday, ABS-CBN, 2005-6, was played by Jericho Rosales. Ang Panday had several film adaptations, the most popular of which were the four-part series by Fernando Poe Jr in 1980, 1981, 1982, and 1984.

 

Other popular komiks characters created by Caparas that were made into a daily serials on television were Bakekang, from Bondying Komiks, 1976-78, illustrated by Mar T. Santana, aired on GMA, 2006-7; Kamandag (Venom), from the komiks section of the daily tabloid People’s Journal, mid-1980s, illustrated by Karl Comendador, aired also on GMA, 2007-8; and Joaquin Bordado (Joaquin, the Tattooed), a graphic novel, late 1970s to early 1980s, also on GMA, 2008.
