article.value: It is a symbiotic relationship. Beginning in the 1950s with the introduction of television to Filipino homes and radio’s growing popularity, mass media became instrumental in the preservation of folklore and literature in the popular imaginary. In some ways, this development is but an extension of folklore’s characteristic orality. In 1959, when then president Carlos P. Garcia facilitated the donation of a few thousand transistor radios to the barrios, they became a “towering presence” in areas where the only method of transmitting information was by word of mouth (Fernandez 1981, 35). This phenomenon would further evolve in the coming decades with the advent of urbanization, on the one hand, and mobile technology and the Internet, on the other.

The earliest known foray of literature into the broadcast medium was in the 1950s, with DZPI’s child-oriented Mga Kuwento ni Lola Basyang, based on the eponymous stories by Severino Reyes which first appeared in Liwayway magazine in the 1920s. The show’s success has been attributed to the intimacy that it created, how it “encapsulated not only society’s [oral] mode of retelling but stressed the importance of the narrator” (Reyes 2005, 47). The titular character has since been immortalized in the popular imagination, the image of “an old bespectacled woman wearing her native saya seated in her silyon (a native chair), surrounded by her grandchildren” (Reyes 2009, 402). The retellings popularized numerous folk narratives such as “Maryang Makiling,” “Ang Dalagang Bukid na Naging Prinsesa” (The Mountain Lass Who Became a Princess), and “Ang Sirena sa Uli-Uli ng Pasig” (The Mermaid at the Eddy of Pasig). A 2007 television update on GMA 7 features Lola Basyang’s strong-willed granddaughter, played by Manilyn Reynes, traveling with a mobile library van to share what by then were “classic” tales by her grandmother.

article.value: Also in the 1950s, the DZRH radio horror drama Gabi ng Lagim (Night of Terror) began to appropriate figures from folk mythology, often rendering them as malevolent creatures of the dark. However, the negative portrayal, which endures to this day, continued the successful demonization of indigenous lore by the propagators of the new Catholic faith. In the 1980s, with urban folk’s experience of unbridled urbanization and attendant terrors like crime and grinding poverty, the horror mode became all the more germane, seen in the weekly GMA horror serial Regal Shockers, 1985-91; the highly anticipated annual All Souls’ Day specials of ABS-CBN’s Magandang Gabi, Bayan (Good Evening, Nation), 1988-2005; and the weekly quasi-investigative shows featuring paranormal stories like Verum Est: Totoo Ba Ito? (Verum Est: Is This True?) 2001, and Misteryo (Mystery), 2009. While urban legends still spread through word of mouth, the transmission is accelerated by something as pervasive as television and radio.

The fantasy genre offered more positive renditions of the same source material, as in the primetime sitcom Okay Ka, Fairy Ko! (You’re Okay, My Fairy!), 1987-89, IBC 13, 1989-95, ABS-CBN, and 1995-97, GMA. The show followed the marriage of mortal Enteng Kabisote (Vic Sotto) and the “fairy” Faye (Alice Dixson). While the two “worlds” could be seen as a stand-in for social classes and there was unmistakable Western influence in the construction of the magical beings, they were nevertheless imbued with divine qualities, hewing close to their indigenous origins. The GMA 7 series Encantadia (Fairyland), 2005, expanded this canvas with an enchanted realm divided into four kingdoms where lived different mythical entities. The Cebuano radio series Mga Asoy ni Teban ug Goliat (Stories of Teban and Goliat), DHYP (Radio Mindanao Network Cebu), starring the comedy duo Julian Bacus “Teban” Daan and Allan “Goliat” Nacorda, mixed comedy with fantasy and often drew on Visayan folkloric creatures. Daan and Nacorda are also known for their popular comedy skits “Mga Pakatawa ni Teban ug Goliat” (The Jokes of Teban and Goliat), some of which use humorous wordplays and folk beliefs. In one in which a character’s mental illness is attributed to spirits, the phonemic difference between “gitiawan” (played a joke on) and “gitinuod” (taken seriously) is the source of the humor. Another AM radio series is Mutya sa Saging Minantikan (Jewel of Banana Fritter), about Maria’s amulet extracted from a banana bud. The success of these radio programs spawned the hit television series Si Goot da Wanderpol (Goat the Wonderful) in the 1990s. Produced by Marcos Sacol, the picaresque featured Teban and Goliat who look after a magical goat that defecates gold coins, a local spin on a Western fairy tale.

This indigenous precolonial world captured in the country’s epics is the inspiration behind the so-called epic-serye Amaya, 2011-12, which followed the titular character as a princess and binukot (kept maiden) who, through a series of events, became an uripon (slave), a baybayin (ancient Philippine script) teacher in exile, and eventually a warrior leader who helped save from tyrannical rule an unnamed kingdom in Central Visayas. To a certain extent, some of the tropes used in the series, like the fall from grace and the drawn-out quest for revenge, are soap opera staples, but the show’s world admirably drew on indigenous lore, in particular on social order, cosmology, and even Visayan epic conventions. Amaya’s sequel Indio (Christianized Native), 2013, which opened with the death of Amaya and followed her demigod son Malaya, continued the use of epic tropes, this time set against the backdrop of oppressive Spanish colonization. Adopted by an abusive encomendero, Malaya was renamed Simeon, an undisguised nod to Jose Rizal’s El Filibusterismo (Subversion), 1891.

Programs designed for children are another popular platform for this material. The individual episodes of the children’s show Hiraya Manawari (Reaching One’s Dreams), 1995-2003, ABS-CBN, revolve around one value, like self-discipline or humility, sometimes dramatized through journeys to mystical lands populated by magical creatures. The Carlo Aquino starrer Pahina (Pages), 2000-2001, was a weekly drama anthology that features and dramatizes noted Filipino literary works that also promoted values necessary in the character development of the youth. Finally, the weekly anthology Ang Mahiwagang Baul (The Enchanted Chest), 2005-7, showcased Philippine myths, legends, and folklore.

Short stories and novels also became material for television dramas early on. Some of the most notable episodes of ABC Channel 5’s drama anthology Balintataw (The Mind’s Eye) in the 1960s were “Isang Gabi ng Tagsibol” (A Night in Spring); Alberto Florentino’s adaptation of Nick Joaquin’s “May Day Eve;” “Kabalyerong Tanso” (Fake Knight), based on Wilfrido Nolledo’s “Rice Wine;” and “Kudyapi” (Two-Stringed Lute), Lino Brocka’s adaptation of Bienvenido Santos’s “The Day the Dancers Came.” Featuring productions of the Philippine Educational Theater Association, the program’s directors include stalwarts such as Brocka, Elwood Perez, and Joey Gosiengfiao. RPN 9’s Malayo Pa ang Umaga (The Morn Is Yet So Far), 1979, is based on Stevan Javellana’s World War II novel Without Seeing the Dawn, 1947. Produced by Armida Siguion-Reyna, it is the first known miniseries on Philippine television, the precursor to the telenovela format in the 2000s.

In terms of form, a radio program in 1934 featured the form of the balagtasan, a poetic exchange or joust on a social issue. Interrupted by World War II, it returned in the 1950s on DZRH, hosted by the poet Emilio Mar Antonio. Every Sunday, he engaged a guest poet in a debate in Tagalog verse on the burning issue of the day, such as divorce or statehood for the Philippines under the United States. The format of other forms of folk poetry, like riddles and proverbs, have today evolved into fodder for jokes in sketch comedies like Bubble Gang, which also pioneered a segment on “fliptop,” the modern, if raunchy and less socially relevant, incarnation of the balagtasan.

The format of the radio drama and, eventually, telenovelas, also follows a literary form, in particular the serialized novels in the massively popular chain of Liwayway Publications that flourished in the decades leading to World War II. These include the Tagalog Liwayway, 1922; the Cebuano Bisaya, 1930; the Ilocano Bannawag, 1934; and Hiligaynon, 1934. Sometimes criticized for being lowbrow (especially vis-à-vis English publications), the stories, from melodramas to sitcoms and satires, nevertheless played a key role in cultivating a popular appetite for literature and in shaping popular sensibilities. The first postwar soap is Liwayway Arceo’s Ilaw ng Tahanan (Light of the Home), which aired on DZRH in Mar 1949, followed shortly by Lina Flor’s Gulong ng Palad (Wheel of Fate), also on DZRH. The daily 15-minute programs chronicled the highs and lows in the life of ordinary Filipino families. Other notable ones include Fundador Soriano’s Kahapon Lamang (Just Yesterday) and Flordeluna, which first aired in Cebu radio and translated to Tagalog in the late 1970s. Gulong ng Palad also became the pioneer daily serialized drama on television in 1977, which aired on BBC 2 from 1977 to 1985. Soon, Flordeluna was also adapted to television, which ran from 1979 to 1984 with Janice de Belen in the title role. These pioneers would be revisited in recent times, occasionally remade with a more contemporary twist.

Aside from formal similarities with serialized novels, soap operas routinely resound with characteristics that are directly traceable to centuries-old literary forms like metrical romances, such as awit or korido. These include conventions, such as the emotional intensity of Balagtas’s lyric poems manifesting as pervasive melodrama, or the ubiquitous archetype of the perpetually martyred and suffering woman. His Florante at Laura (Florante and Laura) had utilized emotion between the titular lovers to unpack its themes. As an element, melodrama has remained a staple in radio and television, from the pioneering radio counseling drama Ito ang Inyong Tiya Dely (This Is Your Aunt Dely) in the 1950s to the long-running television drama Coney Reyes on Camera in the 1990s.

The satirical spirit of folktales, often humorous accounts that are also oblique social commentaries, finds echoes in modern satirical comedies, including the pioneering radio show Kuwentong Kutsero (Tall Tales), which first aired in 1938 and became widely popular in the 1950s and 1960s. In the same way that the numbskull tales featuring Juan Tamad cautions against laziness, Kuwentong Kutsero spoofed Filipino manners, politics, customs, and government officials. Conceptualized by Horacio de la Costa and James Reuter, who would both become Jesuit priests, the show’s format was successfully replicated in provincial stations and, in the 1960s, as a television sitcom on ABS-CBN Channel 3. Other notable satires are Sic O’Clock News, 1987-89, IBC 13, which parodied social issues in the format of a news program; the sitcom Abangan ang Susunod na Kabanata (Watch for the Next Chapter), 1991-97, ABS-CBN, which poked fun at social stratification with stock characters from politics and normal folk; and Mongolian Barbecue, 1990-91 and 1993-95, RPN, which used the “grill-and-roast” interview format to make fun of politicians and personalities.

The trickster trope also survives. Some of the exploits of Kevin Kosme (Dolphy), the protagonist of family-oriented sitcom Home along da Riles, render him as a trickster hero in the tradition of Juan Pusong. A regular source of humor are Kevin’s often successful attempts to outsmart or trick someone in a position of power, from his rich and devoted admirer Ason (Nova Villa) to his boss Steve (Bernardo Bernardo) and the neighborhood sari-sari (variety) store owner Tomas (Tommy Angeles).

The influence of folklore and literature on radio and television is sometimes direct, as in adaptations of legends and short stories, and sometimes more oblique, in terms of a broader folk sensibility. That many urban legends still feature entities from Philippine lower mythology prove the survival of the folk literary tradition and the folk memory despite the shift in milieu. Even folk poetry, such as riddles and proverbs, continue to find modern incarnations, such as in jokes and punch lines commonly heard in the stingers of so-called masa radio stations and recurring gags in television comedies. There is little doubt that this intimate link will persist in the years, perhaps decades, ahead.Written by Glenn Diaz w ith notes from Julian dela Cerna and John Bengan
Theater

Long before the advent of radio in the 1920s and television in the 1950s, Filipino audiences of different classes had enjoyed what were then the only sources of public entertainment: the Spanish-influenced komedya, sinakulo, sarsuwela, and drama; and the American-influenced bodabil. Through theater directors, artists, producers, and even technicians who were hired to work in the new broadcast media, the themes, characters, plots, and even style of performance and production design of these Filipino dramatic genres survived the onslaught of the new media, precisely by migrating to and taking root in the electronic media of radio and television themselves.

The centuries-old komedya, which flourished in the 19th century and declined in the 20th, revolved around themes of love and war between royal characters in the kingdoms of medieval Europe (like España, Francia, Alemania, Italia) and the Middle East (like Persia, Turkiya, Arabia, and Marruecos). Taking their stories from the orally transmitted or printed verse narratives called awit and korido, the komedya developed a production style marked by a stylized delivery of verse dialogue, choreographed fighting, and magical effects. Cristianos and Moros were characterized as heroes and villains, respectively, and identified as such by their marches, acting style, and costumes (dark colors for Christians, red for Moors).

From the komedya tradition derived the stories of Severino Reyes, which were serialized more than once on radio and television as Mga Kuwento ni Lola Basyang (Stories of Grandma Basyang); as well as the episodes of royal fantasy in radio serial dramas like Prinsipe Amante (Prince Amante) and Zimatar, and stories of magical swords as in the television series Juan dela Cruz. On both radio and television, the characters of the ailing father/king, the young, kindhearted prince, the princess in distress, the jealous or conspiring courtiers, the irreverent but delightful trickster, and the old ermitanyo (hermit) who turns out to be Christ or a person with powers, replicate the komedya’s own dramatis personae. Scenes of swordplay, tournaments for the hand of a princess, and royal romance that ends in a royal wedding are also straight out of the komedya, although the influence of children’s stories and films about royal characters from the West cannot be discounted.

The sinakulo or passion play began as a dramatization of the pasyon, the verse narrative of the story of Christian salvation, from genesis to the coronation of the Virgin Mary in heaven, with particular emphasis on the sufferings, death, and resurrection of Jesus Christ. As the pasyon is chanted on the Sundays of Lent and all throughout Holy Week, so the sinakulo may be performed anytime in Lent, but especially during Holy Week. If the Christians and Moors are the bida (heroes) and kontrabida (villains) respectively in the komedya, in the sinakulo the bida are the banal or holy people, including Christ, the Virgin and their followers, while the kontrabida are the hudyo, the generic name applied to all who persecuted Christ whether Jews or Romans. While the banal are meek and gentle, the hudyo are pompous and violent, as further emphasized by their respective styles of chanting, acting, and marches.

The sinakulo theme of the oppression and eventual triumph of the underdog, as well as the characters of the virtuous but destitute hero, the ever-suffering and maudlin mother, the repentant vamp, the hard-hearted traitor, is very much evident not only in Lenten presentations like Kalbaryo ni Hesus (Calvary of Jesus) on radio but also in regular radio dramas like True Confessions and Lumipas na Madaling Araw (Forgotten Morn) and in telenovelas like May Bukas Pa (There’s Still Tomorrow) and Nathaniel. In fact, even scripts supposedly based on “real stories” of letter writers, as in Maalaala Mo Kaya (Will You Remember) and Magpakailanman (Forever) on television, tend to pattern their characters after those of the sinakulo, and to conclude their stories with moralistic themes that assure audiences that those who suffer shall inherit the kingdom of heaven.

Introduced by Spanish troupes in the 19th century, the drama and sarsuwela, as written by Filipinos from the 1900s to the 1940s, presented issues, characters, and stories, no longer from foreign narratives like the komedya and sinakulo but from contemporary Philippine society. The drama and sarsuwela are two different dramatic genres—the first is a straight play in prose, while the second is a prose play with songs and dances—but they pursue identical or at least similar sociocultural themes, like the conflict between the rich and the poor in love and business, the colonial mentality of Filipinos, the corruption of politicians, vote-buying during elections, cockfighting and other vices, infidelity of husband or wife, divorce, social climbing, and misunderstandings between parents and children. Such themes may be treated in comic or satirical fashion in the drama comico or sarsuwela, or in tragic mode in the melodrama, also called drama tragico. Characters in the drama and sarsuwela are based on real social types (politicians, gamblers, peasants, workers, parents, children, lovers), but they are so idealized that they may also be categorized as bida and kontrabida. Heroes and heroines as well as villains and vixens are identified as such by their costumes and makeup, style of acting and dialogue delivery, and types of songs. So are the witty servant-comedians. Lastly, drama and sarsuwela most commonly have plots whose conflicts are resolved gratuitously by coincidences and other dei ex machina and whose narrative closure must always affirm the political, social, and moral values of the ruling establishment.

The black-and-white characters (the bida who sacrifice everything for love of parents and partners and the kontrabida who connive at every point to take what is not rightfully theirs), the stylized manner of speaking (soft vs harsh) and acting (gentle vs violent), the stereotyped costume design (prettily conservative for heroes and heroines and modish and daring for villains and villainesses), the manipulated plots (sworn enemies turn out to be brothers or sisters after all) and coincidences (the villain accidentally falls into a cliff during a fight), and the reconciliatory endings of the drama and sarsuwela (the rich and the poor marry each other in the end) are very much alive and evident in radio dramas like Gulong ng Palad (Wheel of Fate), 24 Oras (24 Hours), Habang May Buhay (While There Is Life) and television dramas like Mga Kuwento ng Pag-ibig (Stories of Love). They are also found in drama episodes of weekly radio shows like Lovingly Yours, Helen and Kahapon Lamang (Just Yesterday), as well as in the seasons-long telenovelas like Pangako sa ’Yo (The Promise), Tayong Dalawa (The Two of Us), and Mara Clara.

Introduced from the USA in the 1920s, bodabil was a variety show that combined solo, duo, or trio singing, pair or chorus dancing, comedy skits, magician tricks, and even animal acts in a wildly entertaining performance, usually alternating with the screening of local or foreign movies in theaters. Although bodabil drew heavily from American popular culture, bodabil artists managed to indigenize the form through the use of topical or issue-based humor, local adaptations of American songs, locally conceptualized production numbers, local variations or modifications of foreign dances and costumes, popularization of local counterparts of foreign singers, and creation of original Filipino songs using the musical template of American pop songs. The bodabil stage trained and built up some of the most famous singers, dancers, and comedians who, because of their popularity and talent, were sought out by the first producers and writers in broadcast media, who in many cases also had roots in or were exposed to bodabil.

On radio, the bodabil traditions are found in the variety shows like Camay Theater of the Air, The San Miguel Brewery Hour, and even in famous song competitions like Tawag ng Tanghalan (Call of the Stage), especially because these are hosted by former bodabil performers. On the other hand, bodabil humor, dancing, and even magical acts were carried over into television by shows like Oras ng Ligaya (Happy Hour), Showbiz with the Salvadors, and Germspesyal. Buhay Artista (Actor’s Life) became famous for its opening numbers where Dolphy and Panchito transliterate English songs into Tagalog with hilarious results. Other bodabil-type TV shows are the The Nida-Nestor Show, VIP or Vilma in Person, Loveli-ness, and Superstar, which showcase not only the dancing and singing talents of their stars but create production numbers with lavish costumes and sets like those in bodabil. Descended from both the drama comico and the bodabil or stage show are the situation comedies or sitcoms, like John en Marsha (John and Marsha), Home along da Riles (Home along the Railroad), Tang-Tarang-Tang, and Iskul Bukol (School Bumps) where humor comes from play on words, mistaken identities, and wacky characters like a moralizing mother-in-law, a gay antagonist, a goofy man-child, a crusty old teacher, and a band of ne’er-do-well students.

All in all, the influence of traditional theater on radio and television may be seen in the following aspects of script and production: the division of idealized characters into bida and kontrabida, with their corresponding styles of acting, speaking, and dressing; the chronologically arranged plots with highly colorful events whose conflicts are resolved by extrinsic forces and end by affirming the validity of the establishment’s beliefs and values; a directorial style that merely strings together episodes and veers away from innovation or radical change; photography work where the camera is a recorder and rarely an interpreter of scenes being shot; and editing that is invisible, leisurely, and predictable.

Although the radio and television mainstream shows continue to use and propagate the practices of traditional theater to this date, a few artists, mostly associated with theater and film, have produced a few programs on television that were influenced by another type of theater that came into the country after World War II. Through literature classes, the younger generation of directors in the 1960s and 1970s encountered modernism in the plays of European playwrights like Henrik Ibsen and August Strindberg and American writers like Arthur Miller and Tennessee Williams. Writing in the mode of realism favored by these foreign playwrights, Filipino writers like Nick Joaquin, Alberto Florentino, and Nestor Torre Jr wrote plays in English which were translated into Filipino and produced for television in shows like Balintataw. Later, film directors trained in literature and theater directed drama anthologies with realistic plots and characters, such as Hilda, Lino Brocka Presents, and Ang Makulay na Daigdig ni Nora. In these productions, realism permeates the choice of costumes, sets, and, most of all, the internalized acting which gives life to highly individualized characters. Because such stories usually had endings that were often open-ended or downright tragic, TV producers have avoided such narratives, preferring the feel-good, if unrealistic and escapist, closures typical of traditional theater.Written byNicanor G. Tiongson
Komiks

Among the major sources of radio and television materials are the komiks (comics) and the comic strips. Adapted from the English illustrated comics, the Filipino komiks is magazine in format. Published weekly, each issue is composed of 5-10 illustrated stories framed in panels arranged in chronological sequences. Each story covers at least four pages. A story can be a serial, which may run for over a year. Some stories are wakasan in format; they begin and end in one installment. Elements such as narrative flow, scenes, temporal settings, characters, emotions, thoughts, dialogues, and sound effects are presented in framed illustrations, balloons, panels or captions. The comic strip, on the other hand, is a single-tier panel of a vignette of life that is regularly published in the entertainment or editorial section of a daily broadsheet or tabloid, or in its weekend edition or magazine supplement. The comic strip is often a brief and humorous commentary on current issues or morals or a caricature of personalities.

The comic strip is a preferred source of material for the comedy in Philippine broadcast. Komiks materials, especially adventure-fantasy and the melodramatic love story, are borrowed often by film and sometimes by radio, particularly in the 1950s and 1960s, and then adapted for television beginning in the late 1970s. Some adventure-fantasy stories from komiks are turned into animation productions, specifically in the 1980s. The turn of the 21st century saw some komiks materials and foreign graphic novels being directly adapted for television and, more recently, into independent productions, mainly in digital animation, that are primarily circulated in emerging media platforms, such as the Internet, personal blog sites, and social media. In the 20th century, adaptations of komiks followed a more or less predictable route: from komiks to radio, to film, and finally television. Radio was a testing ground for the acceptability of komiks characters and narratives on the big screen. Once tested, many such characters and narratives are reproduced for the small screen. Since the late 1990s, the sequence has become unpredictable. For example, some komiks characters and stories have been adapted straight into television, bypassing radio and film.

One of the early komiks characters was illustrated by Jose Zabala Santos and Francisco Reyes for the 1955 Purico advertisement of the Philippine Manufacturing Company (now Procter & Gamble). They produced Juan Tamad (Lazy Juan), a six-minute 35 mm film intended for TV, but it was never aired. Juan Tamad was used as part of a political satire on TV in the 1960s until the declaration of martial law in 1972, on Channel 13. It was resurrected in 1979 on GTV 4, both of which were directed by now National Artist for film Manuel Conde, who also portrayed the legendary lazybones hero—a caricature of the Filipino—with Gloria Romero and Aurora Salve. The character Juan Tamad spawned five movies, all by Conde, from 1947 to 1963.

Many popular comic strips in Tagalog, serialized in daily English broadsheets, were made into weekly comedy series on television. Ben Alcantara’s Gorio and His Jeepney, 1966-69, ABC DZTM-TV Channel 5, directed by Rene Pangan, was from the daily broadsheet Manila Times. It is about the daily routine of a jeepney driver played by Chiquito. Tisoy (slang for mestizo), 1968-69, ABC Channel 5, played by Jimmy Morato and co-starring Pilar Pilapil, Edmund Sicam, Bert “Tawa” Marcelo, and Moody Diaz, directed by Nick Lizaso, was based on a daily cartoon comic strip of the same title by Nonoy Marcelo in the Manila Times in 1963. The cartoon strip, on the other hand, was based on the comic strip Pytik, which Marcelo, while a student, created for The Advocate, the student paper of Far Eastern University. It is a social satire on the beatnik culture of the restless urban youth of the 1960s. Tisoy was turned into a movie, first in 1979, directed by Lauro Pacheco, and then in 1977, directed by now National Artist for film Ishmael Bernal. Baltic & Co., 1974-76, GMA 7, starring Nanding Flores as Baltic, who was later replaced by Prospero Luna, then by Bert Marcelo, and directed by Ricky Manalo, was from Roni Santiago’s cartoon strip that started to appear daily in the Manila Bulletin in the 1970s and continues until the present. It is about a hotheaded boss and the daily concerns of his employees, one of whom is Miss Tapia, played by Mely Tagasa, whose character would be transported to the highly popular weekly TV sitcom Iskul Bukol, 1977-90, IBC 13. Larry Alcala’s Asiong Aksaya (Wasteful Asiong), 1977, GTV 4, portrayed by radio drama talent Tony Angeles and directed by Ading Fernando, came from the Philippines Daily Express in which it appeared from 1976 to 1984 and a weekly version serialized in the komiks Tagalog Klasiks. It lampooned the people’s wasteful consumption of electricity, water, and gas at the height of the energy and power supply crises in the 1970s. Rated PB (Pambayan): Pugad Baboy sa TV (Rated National: Swine’s Nest on TV), 1993, GMA 7, directed by Leo Martinez and starring Edgar Mortiz, Giselle Sanchez, and Rudy Meyer, was from Pol Medina Jr’s Pugad Baboy (Swine’s Nest), a daily cartoon strip that ran in the Philippine Daily Inquirer, 1988-2013, and in Rappler starting 2013. It is about a Manila community of obese people and their astute and witty observations about national issues that affect their village.

Adventure-fantasy, which has elements of science fiction and Philippine folklore, from komiks to television was experimented with only in the late 1970s, abandoned for a long period, and attempted again by television networks in the mid-2000s. The main reason for the late and intermittent exploration of the genre on television was the lack of broadcast technology and facilities, combined with the prohibitive cost of producing a program in this genre. Notable examples are the classic komiks superhero characters created by Mars Ravelo, especially Darna, Varga, Kapitan Boom, Dyesebel, Captain Barbell, and Lastikman.

Darna, a Pilipino Komiks serial on the exploits of a titular flying wonder woman character created in 1950 and illustrated by Nestor Redondo, for Pilipino Komiks, was turned into a TV series in 1977 on RPN 9 starring Lorna Tolentino, in 2005 on GMA 7 starring Angel Locsin, and in 2009-10, again on GMA 7, starring Marian Rivera. The character of Darna also made cameo appearances in a series of Toyota Tamaraw FX television commercials in 1993, played by Anjanette Abayari, Alma Concepcion, and Daisy Reyes, and in the dream sequence of the 2010 drama series Trudis Liit (Small Trudis), with Jillian Ward portraying the roles of the child character and the child Darna defeating the snake-headed villain Valentina. Before TV, Darna was made several times into a movie, the first of which was as early as 1951 starring Rosa del Rosario and directed by Fernando Poe Sr.

The character Darna was a reconceptualization of an earlier komiks character, Varga, also by Ravelo, that first appeared in Bulaklak Magazine in 1947. Varga made her first TV appearance in a cameo role, portrayed by Mariel Rodriguez, in Kapitan Boom (Captain Boom), 2008, ABS-CBN 2. Varga was made as a TV series by ABS-CBN 2 immediately following the run of Kapitan Boom in Aug 2008, with the character portrayed again by Rodriguez. Varga is like Darna, but unlike Darna whose human alter ego is a person with disability, Varga is already a human possessing superhero qualities, including the ability to fly, which she would only find out later in her life. Ravelo’s fumbling hero Kapitan Boom, on the other hand, first appeared in United Komiks in 1966, and the character in the 2008 TV series was played by Bench model Jon Avila.

Dyesebel, the story of a mermaid, illustrated by Elpidio E. Torres, who is now acknowledged as the Amorsolo of Philippine komiks, appeared in Pilipino Komiks, 1952-53, and in Kampeon Komiks, 1975. It was produced by GMA 7 in 2008 starring Marian Rivera and by ABS-CBN 2 in 2014 starring Anne Curtis. Before all these, Premiere Productions first popularized the comics mermaid in Dyesebel, 1953, a film directed by Gerardo de Leon.

Captain Barbell, a muscular hero whose alter ego is a lanky and asthmatic person, appeared in Pinoy Komiks, 1963-65, and in Liwayway, 1966, both illustrated by Jim Fernandez; in Pilipino Komiks, 1985-86, illustrated by Clem Rivera; and in the online fan-comics Digmaan (War), 2005, recreated and illustrated by Gilbert Monsanto. Captain Barbell first appeared on television in a cameo role in the final episode of Darna, 2005, GMA 7. The character then had his own series in 2006-7 with a remake in 2011, both on GMA 7 and both starring Richard Gutierrez. The two TV serials were expanded versions of the original story, presenting more details of the main character and introducing more villains. Like other Mars Ravelo characters, film versions of Captain Barbell came earlier and more in number than broadcast adaptations, the first of which was in 1964 starring Bob Soler and directed by Herminio Bautista.

Lastikman, patterned after DC comics hero Plastic Man, first appeared in Aliwan Komiks in 1964-65, revived in 1995 by Aliwan publisher Graphics Arts Service Inc with new stories by new writers in a magazine of its own called Lastikman Komiks, went back to Aliwan Komiks in 1996-97, and was reworked into a 56-page issue of Mango Comics in 2004 by writer Gerry Alanguilan and artists Arnold Arre and Edgar Tadeo. It was turned into a TV series in 2007 by ABS-CBN, starring Vhong Navarro and directed by Chito Roño. The TV series won the Silver World Medal for the Action-Adventure category in the New York Festivals, 2009. Like most Ravelo creations, Lastikman was earlier seen in three film versions, the first of which was in 1968 starring Von Serna.

There are other superhero characters that were created first for either radio or film, recreated as a komiks material, then transported to a television series. One is Kapitan Kidlat (Captain Lightning), created in the 1950s by Leonardo P. Abutin Sr for a radio series of the same title on DZRH, transported to film in 1953 starring Armando Goyena and directed by Oscar del Rosario, rewritten as Kidlat by Pablo S. Gomez in a 25-issue magazine called Kidlat Komiks Magazine, 1967-68, then made as a TV series, with the title Kidlat, 1985-86, IBC 13, starring Ricky Davao, and Kapitan Kidlat, 2013, TV5, starring Derek Ramsay.

A trend in the 2000s was the adaptation of komiks superheroes directly to television, without having to be produced first in film. The trend was spearheaded by ABS-CBN in its anthology serial titled Mars Ravelo’s Komiks Presents. Each series of the anthology ran for 13-15 episodes. Some komiks materials that were included in the anthology were Kapitan Boom and Varga, both in 2008, and Flash Bomba, 2009, which first appeared in Tagalog Klasiks, 1967-68. One of the anthology’s most interesting series is Isang Lakas (One Force), 2011, which unites all the Mars Ravelo superheroes into one team, called Sanlakas (United Front), to battle the evils of the human world.

Also included in the Mars Ravelo’s Komiks Presents, although not about a superhero but about mediums, ghosts, and reincarnations, was Nasaan Ka, Maruja (Where Are You, Maruja), 2009, from Ravelo’s Gumising Ka … Maruja (Wake Up … Maruja), with the character role played by Kristine Hermosa. Gumising Ka … Maruja was first published in Pilipino Komiks in 1966, illustrated by Rico Rival, and had three film adaptations: in 1966 and 1978, both starring Susan Roces, and in 1996, with Carmina Villaroel.

Komiks heroes have not only been made into live-action television series. Some have been produced as single-airing animation productions on television, such as Darna and Captain Barbell, both illustrated for the animation by Gerry Garcia and produced by RPN 9, both in 1986. One highly popular komiks hero that was rendered both in animation and live-action feature and broadcast as a television series was Ang Panday (The Blacksmith), who has superior swordsmanship skills whose dagger is made of ore from a meteorite that fell from the sky. The character was created by Carlo J. Caparas and illustrated by Steve Gan. Ang Panday was first serialized in Pilipino Komiks beginning in 1976 and republished as a serial in Liwayway, 1979, and as a strip in People’s Journal, 1979. The animated Ang Panday, RPN 9, 1986-87, was created by cartoonist Gerry Garcia and is considered the first Filipino animated series. The title role in the action-drama teleserye Ang Panday, ABS-CBN, 2005-6, was played by Jericho Rosales. Ang Panday had several film adaptations, the most popular of which were the four-part series by Fernando Poe Jr in 1980, 1981, 1982, and 1984.

Other popular komiks characters created by Caparas that were made into a daily serials on television were Bakekang, from Bondying Komiks, 1976-78, illustrated by Mar T. Santana, aired on GMA, 2006-7; Kamandag (Venom), from the komiks section of the daily tabloid People’s Journal, mid-1980s, illustrated by Karl Comendador, aired also on GMA, 2007-8; and Joaquin Bordado (Joaquin, the Tattooed), a graphic novel, late 1970s to early 1980s, also on GMA, 2008.

Television comedy also derived some of its material from komiks. The comic character of Bondying, played by Bentot, in the television sitcom Tang-Tarang-Tang, 1960s, BBC 2, was from Bondying, a komiks series created by Mars Ravelo and illustrated by Elpidio Torres. Prinsipe Abante (Prince Abante), 1979, GMA 7, directed by Ading Fernando and featuring Bert Marcelo, Tina Revilla, Dely Atay-atayan, Gene Palomo, and Prospero Luna, is a modern spoof of Prinsipe Amante (Prince Amante), 1949-53, a radio komedya by Clodualdo del Mundo Sr, broadcast live on DZRH from 1949 to 1953, adapted into a komiks serial by Mario del Mar in the 1950s, adapted into a movie in 1950 and a sequel movie in 1951, both produced by LVN and both starring Rogelio de la Rosa and Delia Razon and directed by now National Artist for film Lamberto Avellana.

The broadcast drama, especially the teleserye, derives some of its materials from the komiks, often the romance novels written by women authors. Examples include Bituing Walang Ningning (Star without Sparkle), 2006, ABS-CBN, by Nerissa Cabral, from Pilipino Komiks, 1984; Blusang Itim (Beauty Within), 2011, GMA, by Elena M. Patron, from Aliwan Komiks, 1980; and Sinasamba Kita (I Worship You), 2007, from Tagalog Klasiks, 1949, Kung Mahawi Man ang Ulap (Through It All), 2007, and Babangon Ako at Dudurugin Kita (Sweet Revenge), 2008, all on GMA and by Gilda Olvidado, from Darna Komiks, 1991, illustrated by Mar Santana.

Early adaptations on television were generally faithful to the original story in the komiks, with only minor changes introduced in the hero’s character. Lately, an emerging trend is the introduction of major changes in the narrative, settings, character traits, character history and development, costume designs, and visual effects, as well as the inception of new characters and new forms of superpower and human weaknesses. For example, the muscular Captain Barbell was given a new look when first adapted for film and later for TV. He was shirtless as a superhero, with an eye mask, in the komiks, but donned a yellow muscle-accentuated costume to highlight the build of the actors, who were not bodybuilders, in the character’s appearances on film and TV. In the 2006 and 2011 Captain Barbell TV series, the logo “CB” was added on the chest of the hero’s redesigned costume, and given a new weakness, which is exposure to the mineral element Askobar. In the 2005 Darna TV series, the heroine was shown possessing a heat vision as an addition to her arsenal of weapons, such as bracelets to deflect bullets, the ruby stone to augment her strength, and the white stone that she swallows to transform herself into a superhero. Darna’s two-piece bikini suit has likewise undergone several changes, which is becoming skimpier in later broadcast adaptations. Kapitan Kidlat’s red costume in komiks became primarily black in the 2013 TV series. Varga in the komiks is a violet-colored ghost, while she is an original human in the 2008 TV series.Written by Eulalio R. Guieb III
Film

Film has very strong links with broadcasting as an art form and as an industry in the Philippines. It has provided local television and radio programming with a source of revenue, content, artists, and formats. While film’s influence on radio has diminished, television, to a certain degree, has become an extension of film.

Part of radio programming from the beginnings of radio in the Philippines in the 1920s during the American period up to the 1950s or a decade after World War II were dramatizations of portions of Filipino movies that were showing or about to be shown in cinema houses. The model was American radio’s Lux Theater of the Air, while the local prewar version was the Lux Toilet Soap Theater of the Air. The movie actors as well as some radio personalities read live the radio version of the film script, with adoring fans inside the studio. This was a way to encourage radio listeners to watch the movies and to boost the popularity of the movie stars. Radio personalities were considered brighter stars than movie actors; the former were heard on the air every day while the latter appeared in just a few movies a year. Consequently, radio and its voices also enjoyed more newspaper and magazine publicity than film and its actors. Among the movie actors who reprised their film performances in the 1930s on radio were Leopoldo Salcedo, Carmen Rosales, and Rogelio de la Rosa.

After the war the format of live reenactments of Filipino movies continued, with Camay Theater of the Air as the most popular one. The show aired for an hour on Sunday nights first on DZRH, then on DZBB, with the film actors reenacting the movie live before a studio audience, complete with theme music, background music, and music bridges provided by a live full orchestra, and live sound effects. Film actor Jaime de la Rosa hosted the show. It was an acid test for many of the movie actors who, unlike radio drama actors, were not used to live performances and who had the luxury of retakes if a scene did not go well. However, some passed the test and earned radio program hosting and acting jobs, which increased their public presence. Among them was Gloria Romero, who hosted the drama series Ang Inyong Lingkod, Gloria Romero (At Your Service, Gloria Romero), DZRH, 1959-60, written by Genoveva Edroza-Matute. Apart from hosting the show, Romero also performed the lead roles in the episodes, with guest actors from film including Luis Gonzales, Juancho Gutierrez, Romeo Vasquez, Carmen Rosales, Daisy Romualdez, Carlos Salazar, Mario Montenegro, Oscar Moreno, Eddie Garcia, Jose Mari, Van de Leon, Jose de Villa, and the comedians Dolphy, Panchito, Chichay, and Matimtiman Cruz.

When more Filipinos began to acquire television sets in the 1960s, television began to overtake radio as the more effective platform for promoting movies and movie actors and as an additional outlet for screening old movies. Film’s presence on radio waned, save for the occasional movie ads.

On television, Filipino movies are broadcast as trailer commercials to promote film producers’ latest offerings. Movie excerpts are often shown between television programs as paid promotional materials or as short features in a talk entertainment program, especially when film stars are invited as guests to ask TV audiences to support a movie project. Some TV segments of these entertainment programs are paid by film companies to provide their stars a slot to talk about the movie, increasing the visibility of the movie and its stars to the captive audiences of television, increasing the chances of the movie’s success in the box office. In some instances, film producers sponsor contests or games as an occasional segment of a TV program, such as acting competitions in which live studio audiences reenact a selected sequence, usually the film’s most dramatic part, and deliver the movie dialogue of the film’s lead stars. In the 1970s, one television program format was the movie guide, a daily 30-minute program, usually programmed before a major show, that featured excerpts of movies currently showing or about to be shown in movie houses in Manila and clips of movies-in-the making. Examples of programs of this format were Movie Parade and Movie Date, IBC 13.

Film has also provided television with a regular programming material, such as daily or weekly reruns of movies, especially in the TV station’s regular afternoon or evening programming. Examples in the 1970s include Sinehan Dos (Movie Theater on Two) and Sunday Super Sine (Sunday Super Movie) on BBC 2; Tagalog Movie on GTV 4; Aliwang Pang-umaga (Morning Entertainment), Sine Siete (Cinema Seven), and Sine Espesyal (Special Movies) on GMA 7; and Cine Pinoy (Pinoy Cinema), Piling-Piling Pelikula (Well Selected Movies), IBCinema 1, and Roadshow Pilipino on IBC 13. Beginning in the 1980s and on through the 2000s, television networks have creatively packaged movie reruns, providing a one-season programming series of hit movies by big stars. An example was FPJ sa GMA (FPJ on GMA), 1987-92, Channel 7, a weekly series of 200 film hits by movie box-office king Fernando Poe Jr, who was reportedly paid 10 million pesos by GMA for the first-run rights to his movies. This was followed up by ABS-CBN in 1988 through its Cinema FPJ: Da King on ABS-CBN (Cinema FPJ: The King on ABS-CBN). Regal Films featured its hit movies in Regal Presents, 1986, ABS-CBN, while Viva Films showed the studio’s movies on Viva Box Office, 1988, IBC 13, Viva Sinerama, 1990-91, GMA, and MVP: Monday Viva Presentations, 1994, GMA.

Film retrospectives are also produced by television networks to pay tribute to industry achievers, such as Gerardo de Leon, Lamberto V. Avellana, Lino Brocka, Nora Aunor, and Vilma Santos. Annual film awarding ceremonies have also become regular features of television stations.

Documentary films from different embassies based in Manila are also shown on local television, often as program fillers. One example in the 1970s was Embassy Film, GMA 7. Hollywood movies are also regularly shown on local television. Lately, these Hollywood movies, together with Korean and Japanese movies, are dubbed in Filipino, and shown on free VHF television. Movies from various countries are shown on UHF television.

Film producers are also blocktimers on television. Movie outfits Regal Films, Viva Films, and Seiko Films produce weekly primetime shows, mainly drama anthologies for their stable of movie actors. Regal Films had drama anthologies like Maricel Regal Drama Special, 1987-90, ABS-CBN, and Mother Studio Presents, 1986-96, GMA, and the weekly sitcom Palibhasa Lalake (Because They Are Guys), 1987-98, ABS-CBN. To complement Regal’s Shake, Rattle and Roll movie series, it produced the weekly horror serial Regal Shockers, 1985-91, GMA. Viva Television produced regular programs on GMA, such as the weekly drama anthology Spotlight, 1993-98; the daily soap operas Villa Quintana, 1995-96, and Anna Karenina, 1996-2002; the comedy shows Ober da Bakod (Over the Fence), 1992-96, Haybol Rambol (Rumble in the House), 1993-95, and Si Manoy at si Mokong (Manoy and Mokong), 1997-98; and the youth-oriented shows T.G.I.S. (Thank God It’s Sabado [Saturday]), 1995-99, and Growing Up, 1997-98.

Some films were also remade into television drama series, which came to be known as teleseryes or telenovelas, but with changes in characters, settings, or narrative plots. In some cases, the teleserye used only the film’s title and completely changed the narrative of the original film. ABS-CBN was a frontrunner in this format, particularly with its Sine Serye (Movie Serialized TV Series), 2005-9, which included hit serials based on movies like Kampanerang Kuba (Hunchbacked Lady Bell Ringer), 2005; Bituing Walang Ningning; 2006; Palimos ng Pag-ibig (Begging for Love), 2007; Patayin sa Sindak si Barbara (Kill Barbara with Fright), 2008; Maligno (Evil Spirit), 2008; and Florinda, 2009. GMA had TV adaptations of Bakekang, 2006-7, and Machete, 2011. TV5 adapted the film Batang X (Child X), 2008, into television. Some of these works first came out in komiks, then made into films before they were adapted for TV.

Movies are also a rich source of artists for television. Movie actors serve as performers of television programs in all formats and genres, such as drama, comedy, variety shows, talk entertainment shows, magazine programs, and even documentaries, public affairs programs, and news. Some big film actors spent a huge part of their career on television, such as Nora Aunor in the long-running weekly variety show Superstar, 1971-89, RPN 9, and the weekly drama anthology Ang Makulay na Daigdig ni Nora (The Colorful World of Nora); Vilma Santos in the weekly teen musical The Sensations, 1971-72, ABS-CBN, the weekly drama anthology Dulambuhay ni Rosa Vilma (Life Story of Rosa Vilma), 1974, BBC 2, and the weekly variety show V.I.P: Vilma in Person, 1986-95, GMA; and Dolphy in the weekly sitcoms John en Marsha, 1973-90, RPN 9, and Home along da Riles, 1992-2003, ABS-CBN. Film directors, like Ishmael Bernal, Lino Brocka, Lupita Concio, Marilou Diaz-Abaya, Mario O’Hara, Maryo J. de los Reyes, Soxy Topacio, Jose Javier Reyes, and Peque Gallaga, and film scriptwriters, such as O’Hara, Javier Reyes, Ricky Lee, Tony Perez, Lualhati Bautista, Jake Tordesillas, and Roy Iglesias, wrote drama programs and documentaries. Film critics, such as Isagani Cruz, Mario Hernando, and Butch Francisco, served as in-house critics or hosts of some entertainment talk shows on television. Film viewers are also mainly the audience of television programs.

Television has also drawn on film for some aesthetics, such as techniques of cinema verité in documentaries, like Reel Time and Front Row, 2012, both on GMA News TV, and experimental narratives, like those employed in the weekly horror-suspense drama Malikmata (Illusion), 1972, ABC 5, directed by Lupita Concio, then by Lino Brocka; the historical drama Katipunan (Brotherhood), 2013, GMA News TV, directed by King Marc Baco; and some episodes of the drama anthology Wagas (Sincere), 2014, GMA News TV. Artists from the independent film movement have also hugely contributed to emerging television program aesthetics in direction, script, camera, and performance. Some of these artists are Jon Red, Adolf Alix Jr, Ian Victoriano, Alvin Yapan, Coco Martin, Mercedes Cabral, and Sid Lucero.Written byEulalio R. Guieb III and Elizabeth L. Enriquez
Foreign Broadcasting

Philippine broadcasting has a long history of appropriations of foreign broadcasting that is still quite evident in contemporary Filipino television and radio. It has affected program content, the adaptation and creation of genres and formats, the way shows are programmed, production practices, and the performance styles of Filipino broadcasters.

Early radio and television programming relied heavily on foreign canned programs, particularly those imported from the United States. It was cost-efficient especially for a broadcast industry that had yet to establish itself in terms of programming and program production. Importing programs has been inexpensive as such are actually rebroadcasts of shows that have already been produced for another market, consumed by it, and thus have already paid off such that selling it to another market is simply a bonus. This process of importation and exhibition may be considered the first form of appropriation of foreign broadcasting for the Filipino market. As canned programs were imported, programming modes were similarly imported and appropriated to suit the length, format, and schedule of such programs. What local production shows made, in turn, appropriated the same production aesthetics and performance styles of broadcasters.

This trend started in radio from the time radio broadcasting began in the Philippines in the 1920s. With the development of a more sophisticated recording technology after World War II as well as the growth of the song recording industry, this influence intensified as Western music was the most inexpensive source of radio music programming. Moreover, the introduction of other program formats from American radio, such as the soap opera, contoured both the format and the content of radio programs in the Philippines. Counseling programs, for example, like those inspired by advice columnist Dorothy Dix in the United States, in turn inspired Ito ang Inyong Tiya Dely and a score of other counseling programs on radio and television such as Napakasakit, Kuya Eddie (It Hurts, Brother Eddie) and Lovingly Yours, Helen. This counseling influence is still present in more contemporary programs like Maalaala Mo Kaya and Magpakailanman. Early Philippine television programming reflected this same tendency by exhibiting a significant proportion of canned American television programs, and then adapting the same formats and genres to local productions. American programming structure has also been evident in the organization of local programming, determining which shows should occupy primetime and premium slots.

Philippine television program genres have also been influenced by foreign, particularly American, genres. This is evident in a range of television formats that have developed through time. Philippine comedies, for example, have focused on a studio production practice with a more static set, with content that usually deals with the subjects’ familial or group dynamics. While adapting the 30-minute American situational comedy as a genre, however, there is a twist in the Filipino television sitcom, stretching to an hour or even an hour and a half, which also improves the production cost per hour of programming while increasing the advertising income of the program. Successful comedy formats include John en Marsha and Home along da Riles. Noticeable in the sitcoms is the slapstick style of comedy that is influenced by the physical comedy of American actor Charlie Chaplin.

Children’s and youth programming have been similarly influenced by American formats as well as content. A common practice is to fill with American cartoons the daily late morning slots and entire Saturday morning lineups of television with American cartoons, such as The Flintstones and Scooby Doo. Other children’s programs from the United States have also been shown locally. The very popular Sesame Street was shown in the Philippines for decades, impacting the lives of generations of Filipino viewers. Sesame Street influenced local children’s programs like the iconic Batibot (Small but Strong) and Pen Pen de Sarapen. These educational children’s programs also adapted the use of puppets and mascots, much like the Sesame Street model.

In the late 1990s, youth programming became a focus in the United States when the WB (Warner Bros.) Channel started producing and airing programs targeted at the young, particularly the adolescent market. This led to the production of the hits Dawson’s Creek, 1998; Charmed, 1998; and the extremely popular Buffy the Vampire Slayer, 1997. The practice of adapting American trends continued when Studio 23, the UHF station of ABS-CBN, was launched in 1996 and targeted a similar adolescent market, airing programs that mostly came from the WB Channel.

Local VHF programming also produced more programs targeting the youth. While programs with fantasy and supernatural plots like Charmed and Buffy the Vampire Slayer, which required expensive production design, were not initially made, the format of Dawson’s Creek was embraced through its local counterpart and almost near-namesake Tabing Ilog (Riverside), 2000. The fantasy influence was more evident in the pantaserye (portmanteau of “fantasy” and “series”) themes of primetime soap operas in 2000s as production practices and budgets accommodated such genres in the primetime slot. It is important to note, however, that a distinctly Filipino youth programming trend may have already started in 1996 with T.G.I.S. However, most local youth programming in the country, like Click, 1999, and G-mik (Gimmick), 1999, started after the airing of Dawson’s Creek.

The most evident foreign influence on Philippine television programming is found in the dramatic genres, particularly the soap opera. The Filipino soap opera, however, both on radio and television, is infused with a more melodramatic feel. The initial influence in the local soap opera is the American model, which was and still is primarily sponsored by soap companies and targeted at female audiences. As with the American model, Philippine soap operas also initially aired in time slots that were presumed “feminine,” such as the afternoon hours when husbands and children were at work and school, respectively, and housewives were home. Soap operas on radio in the 1950s and the 1960s ran for several years before coming to a conclusion, much like their American counterparts. Such was the case with Flordeluna, Anna Liza, and Gulong ng Palad. However, the American model was not the only soap opera influence on the current dramatic genres on Philippine television. Two distinct developments in programming likewise directed the evolution of dramatic genres in the Philippines. Pivotal in the development of the genres were the telenovela (term used for Spanish soap operas, portmanteau of “television” and “novel”) Marimar and the chinovela (Chinese telenovela) Meteor Garden.

In 1996, only four months after the initial airing of the program on RPN Channel 9, Marimar, imported from Mexico, rose to number one in ratings. The impact was industry-wide. The adjustments the networks made, particularly the leading network ABS-CBN, to address the competition also shifted the face of primetime programming. ABS-CBN Channel 2’s one-hour news program TV Patrol, which aired at the same time as Marimar, 6:00-7:00 pm, was reduced to 30 minutes, 6:00-6:30 pm, and its top-rating afternoon soap opera Mara Clara was moved to the pre-primetime slot of 6:30-7:00 pm. The transfer led to the eventual shift of the soap opera genre to the primetime schedule and the adoption of stripping, or scheduling the same program on a daily basis instead of the usual once-a-week programming approach with soaps, also and this became the principal strategy on Philippine prime time. The success of Marimar opened up the programming of several stations to the importation and placement of Latin American telenovelas in both primetime and non-primetime schedules.

Meteor Garden, on the other hand, did to chinovelas and koreanovelas (Korean telenovelas), collectively called asianovelas (Asian telenovelas), what Marimar did to the telenovela. Filipino audiences equally embraced the telenovela and the East Asian imports in their primetime and non-primetime viewing habits. Even the aesthetic and content of local soap operas were influenced by the Asian soaps. East Asian-looking Filipino actors like Kim Chiu, Enchong Dee, and Xian Lim rose in popularity. A later influence of both telenovelas and asianovelas was the local remakes of the popular imports, thus the Filipino versions of the telenovelas Marimar, Maria la del Barrio, and Rosalinda and the asianovelas Kim Sam Soon, Lovers in Paris, and Stairway to Heaven.

A strong and direct influence of foreign broadcasting on Filipino broadcasting is the television franchise, which involves programs usually airing in the United States or Europe that are sold to markets in other countries. Unlike the exported canned program, the television franchise producers sell the concept and the right to produce a similar program in another country rather than a canned copy of the original program. The franchiser supervises the local conceptualization and execution of the franchised program to ensure that the look and feel of the original material is retained in the local production. Most franchised materials are reality programs as they are easier to translate to local counterparts, such as Pinoy Big Brother, Kapamilya Deal or No Deal, Survivor Philippines, and The Voice Philippines. The first successful franchise was the production of the global phenomenon Who Wants to Be a Millionaire on IBC Channel 13 in 2000, but it was discontinued in 2002. IBC also successfully produced the franchised program The Weakest Link during the period. The game show franchises inspired the production of local game shows and reality formats, such as the original and long-running Game KNB? (Are You Ready to Play?). Recent developments indicate that networks are more inclined to produce franchised programs instead of developing original shows.

Philippine broadcasting in this time of global circulation of popular culture continues to be influenced by foreign media products. Local tastes evolve and shape the programs that are produced, acquired, and consumed in the country while constantly shifting production technologies and programming practices that are imported, borrowed, and adapted from foreign broadcast industries impact Philippine broadcasting. Written by Jane O. Vinculado
True-to-Life Events

True-to-life, reality, historical, and everyday events have been sources of and have influenced stories on radio and television, but have been used or incorporated in various ways. Drama programs on both radio and television use true-to-life or reality and everyday events in order to make fiction more realistic, easy to relate to, and even popular, while historical fiction uses actual people, places, and events to weave interesting stories. Sometimes, drama programs feature fictional characters with actual historical events as backdrops or devices. The same is true for comedy. Current events, trends, and common knowledge are some of the most effective components of comedy. Political satire uses comedy and entertainment to criticize both political situations and politicians. It has always been popular in the Philippines, except during World War II and martial law. Horror programs on radio and television are often fictitious but usually draw on folklore and people’s accounts, whether firsthand or as told to them by others. In counseling and outreach programs, audiences share their stories by writing letters or calling (if aired live) and experts are invited to give advice. Outreach programs feature stories of the destitute, terminally ill, or those whom the program producers can help in some way. Some provide help directly while others appeal to the public or solicit donations. Biographical and inspirational programs often ask viewers to send in their stories or research on lives of celebrities to dramatize their struggles and triumphs.

Drawing from true-to-life events, the drama serial has attracted a loyal audience since the first soap operas in 1949: Ilaw ng Tahanan (Light of the Home) and Gulong ng Palad (Wheel of Fate). From 1949 to 1957, Gulong ng Palad aired over KZRH (later DZRH). Sponsored by Procter & Gamble (now Philippine Manufacturing Company), the show was written by society columnist Lina Flor, whose sister Loida Flores Viriña, then a working student, played the lead character Luisa. Viriña later wrote the enormously popular original TV version of Gulong ng Palad from 1977 to 1985, which starred Marianne dela Riva and Ronald Corveau and aired first over BBC Channel 2 and later on RPN Channel 9. In 2006, ABS-CBN Channel 2 revived the serial, this time starring Kristine Hermosa and TJ Trinidad. Soap became the most popular TV format in 1996 when RPN Channel 9 aired the Mexican telenovela Marimar starring Thalia Sodi Miranda. True-to-life events remained the main source of drama material, but situations were treated in various degrees or types of dramatization, from melodrama to romance-comedy or “romcom.” By the 1990s, television had become much more accessible to the masses. A significant demographic group among the audiences was the lower middle class, who avidly watched Marimar. When the show topped the ratings in 1996, it was a cue for the networks to produce more drama serials that depict the lives of ordinary people.

As more and more soap operas were produced and aired not just on prime time but on other time slots as well, other subgenres, such as historical fiction, emerged. As early as 1992, the Cultural Center of the Philippines produced a 13-episode TV series of Jose Rizal’s novel Noli Me Tangere (Touch Me Not) under the direction of National Artist for film Eddie Romero. This was shown on TV5 (then ABC 5). But it was GMA’s Amaya, which aired from 2011 to 2012, that was billed as the first epic-serye or epic drama on Philippine television. Amaya was set in the 1500s, at the time of the Spanish colonization. While the story was fictitious, its creator Suzette Doctolero conducted intensive research and consulted historians to ensure that Amaya’s portrayal of Philippine society and local lore during the said period was as accurate as possible. Based on ancient descriptions, a legendary warship known as the karakoa was built for the production at the cost of two million pesos. A year later, GMA Network produced another big-budget primetime “historical” soap titled Indio. Loosely picking up from where Amaya left off, Indio, according to Doctolero, was a combination of Philippine history and mythology.

The dramatization of true-to-life and everyday events has merged with other formats such as counseling, inspiration, or outreach. Advice programs dramatize stories of letter senders, who often sought guidance on how to deal with a dilemma or predicament. After the dramatization, the program host offers an opinion or a suggestion to the letter sender. Dely Magpayo’s Kasaysayan sa mga Liham kay Tiya Dely (Stories in Letters to Aunt Dely), 1950s, DZRH, and Eddie Ilarde’s Kahapon Lamang (Just Yesterday), 1976-86, GMA Channel 7, were among the first advice programs. Ilarde became a popular radio personality by hosting Student Canteen beginning in the 1950s, first on radio then later on television. When Kahapon Lamang ended, Ilarde joined rival network ABS-CBN and hosted Napakasakit, Kuya Eddie (It Hurts, Brother Eddie), also an advice program that aired between 1986 and 1988. A similar program was the vastly popular Lovingly Yours, Helen, 1980-84 and 1986-96 on GMA Channel 7, and 1984-86 on BBC City Channel 2, which started as a daily counseling program on radio over DZBB (GMA’s AM station).

Often referred to as MMK for short, Maalaala Mo Kaya (Will You Remember), ABS-CBN Channel 2, 1991 to present, hosted by Charo Santos-Concio, is described as inspirational dramatization. MMK features stories ranging from true-to-life accounts of letter senders to composite stories from different sources. MMK has also spawned a radio program, 2007 to present, Maalaala Mo Kaya sa DZMM (Will You Remember on DZMM). GMA Channel 7 produces a similar drama anthology, Magpakailanman (Forever), 2002-8 and 2012-present, hosted by Mel Tiangco. Likewise featuring inspiring true-to-life stories, Magpakailanman includes an interview of the featured person during the episode.

The legal drama Ipaglaban Mo (Fight for It), hosted by lawyer Jose C. Sison, IBC Channel 13, 1988-92, dramatized actual legal cases settled in the Supreme Court and the Court of Appeals. The show transferred to ABS-CBN Channel 2 in 1992, this time with lawyer Jopet Sison as co-host. Initially a blocktimer, it aired the following year as an ABS-CBN production until 1999. In 2013, the legal drama made a comeback on ABS-CBN with the shortened title Ipaglaban Mo (Fight for It). Other legal dramas include legal counsel by the host. An example is Compañero y Compañera (in Spanish, literally, “companion” or “colleague”), which featured legal experts who answered questions from the audience in the studio. The program aired from 1994 to 1997 on DZMM, then 1997-98 on ABS-CBN Channel 2, 1998-2000 on GMA Channel 7, and finally 2000-1 on RPN Channel 9.

The public service program includes dramatized situations as well as talk. Much of the segments in Noli de Castro’s Magandang Gabi, Bayan (Good Evening, Nation) exposed anomalies in government. Its highest-rating episodes, however, were Halloween specials that featured dramatized “true-to-life” ghost stories, complete with special effects and scary musical scoring. Isumbong Mo kay Tulfo (Report It to Tulfo), initially a blocktimer on RPN 9 and since 1994 heard on DWIZ, helps listeners obtain service especially from government agencies. A spin-off of Ramon Tulfo’s segment on Action 9, Isumbong Mo kay Tulfo dramatizes cases with cinematic value weekly on television, interspersed with actual footage of the sumbong (report), confrontation scenes in the presence of the host, and the resolution of the case.

Other public service TV programs post-EDSA are based on true-to-life grievances of the public, such as those aired on Hoy Gising (Hey, Wake Up), 1992-2001, ABS-CBN Channel 2. Hoy Gising started as a segment in the ABS-CBN flagship news program TV Patrol. Imbestigador (Investigator), 2000 to present, GMA Channel 7, is another public service program that exposes anomalies, investigates crimes and public issues, and provides assistance to viewers. It has an action center that accommodates people requesting various types of help. Imbestigador has a radio counterpart that airs over DZBB. More recent episodes of the program have also adopted the docudrama format. Outreach programs that grant wishes and provide assistance include GMA Channel 7’s Wish Ko Lang! (Just My Wish!), since 2002, initially hosted by Bernadette Sembrano before her move to rival network ABS-CBN and later taken over by Vicky Morales; ABS-CBN Channel 2’s Willingly Yours, 2002-3, hosted by Willy Revillame; and Karen Davila’s short-lived Simpleng Hiling (Simple Request) also on Channel 2.

Highlighting the incongruencies of true-to-life day-to-day situations makes comedy effective. During the early days of Philippine television, comedy programs were imported from radio. First produced by Horacio de la Costa and aired on radio before World War II, Epifanio Matute’s Kuwentong Kutsero (Tall Tales) was directed in the 1950s and the 1960s by Narciso Pimentel, first on stage, then on radio, and later on TV. A production of Pimentel’s Dramatic Philippines, it was a precedent-setting radio satire that spoofed politicians and government officials with humorous episodes that delighted radio audiences. Tang-Tarang-Tang, Buhay Artista (Actor’s Life), and Super Laff-In, which all started on radio before going on television, were fictional comedy programs but depicted and made references to everyday events and issues. Dolphy and Panchito’s Buhay Artista always ended with a song translation from English to Tagalog, often with references to current issues and events. Super Laff-In, 1969-72, ABS-CBN, directed by Rollie Grande, was a takeoff from the US sketch comedy Rowan & Martin’s Laugh In. Its cast included Balot, Babalu, June Keithley, Mitch (then known as Maya) Valdez, and Ramon Zamora who came up with memorable Hitler sketches. ABS-CBN revived the show in the 1990s (1996-99), this time with Redford White, Norman Mitchell, Diether Ocampo, Bayani Agbayani, Vhong Navarro, Mylene Dizon, Regine Tolentino, and Glydel Mercado, among others.

The media landscape drastically changed when martial law was declared but comedy programs quickly came back without the political innuendos. The most successful and memorable comedy program during the martial law era was RPN 9’s John en Marsha, 1973-90, starring Dolphy and Nida Blanca and written and directed by Ading Fernando. Fernando used common situations as a starting point in John en Marsha. Divino Reyes, one of the show’s writers, recalls that Fernando often treated the production staff to drinking sessions so he could hear them talk about their everyday lives, episodes of which were often written into the show’s story lines. Though politically repressed, media managed to air social commentary. Nanette Inventor’s “Doña Buding” segment in the Sunday night variety show Penthouse Live, 1982-87, GMA Channel 7, was a parody of the nouveau riche. Using monologues, commentaries, impersonations, and spoofs, other stand-up comics poked fun at anything and everyone. For example, Tessie Tomas appeared as Amanda Pineda, a caricature of PAGASA weatherman Amado Pineda in the gag show Champoy (name of a salty-sweet dried fruit, a popular snack). Outright criticism and condemnation of the rich and powerful became possible only after the 1986 EDSA Revolt.

The restoration of press freedom after the ouster of then president Ferdinand Marcos in Feb 1986 ushered in several new programs that tackled politics and other contentious issues. No-holds-barred discussions and features found their way on the airwaves while newscasts presented all sides of issues confronting the public. Many hard-hitting public affairs programs and documentaries were produced, making research an important part of such productions. Even comedy programs tackled highly sociopolitical issues of the day, among them Barrio Balimbing (A Barrio of Turncoats), 1986-87 on IBC Channel 13 and 1987-88 on ABS-CBN Channel 2. Many of the discussions and conflicts developed and took place at the usual tambayan (hangout), Mang Akong’s sari-sari store. Another hard-hitting comedy program was the wittily titled Sic O’Clock News, 1987-90, IBC Channel 13. Patterned after Not Necessarily the News, a satirical sketch comedy series on the US cable channel HBO, it had the format of a newscast with anchors Lilian Polly Katubusan Labaybay (Ces Quesada) and Sonny Esguerra (Jaime Fabregas) under the direction of Marilou Diaz-Abaya. Another political satire that used the talk show format was Mongolian Barbecue, 1980s, IBC Channel 13 and RPN Channel 9, anchored by Mr Shooli (Jun Urbano) with his assistant Kuhol.

Horror has always attracted viewers and listeners. A characteristic wail of a dog opens each episode of the Gabi ng Lagim (Night of Terror) radio show over DZRH that has been airing since the 1950s. Like urban legends, stories featured on Gabi ng Lagim about encounters with ghosts and mythical creatures seem true-to-life, its viewers and listeners claiming to know of people who have had such experiences. Several varieties of the horror program have aired on television. In the 1980s, Pinoy Thriller, IBC Channel 13, and Regal Shockers, GMA Channel 7, rated well. They featured works of fiction inspired by scary local stories and some foreign influence. TV5 revived Regal Shockers in 2011 until 2012. Okatokat (reverse spelling of Takot ako! [I’m scared!]) was a weekly series on ABS-CBN Channel 2 that starred Agot Isidro and Ricky Davao from 1997 to 2002. The show had a sitcom feel to it as there were many funny, light moments in the series.

Other shows based on “true” ghost stories and paranormal phenomena were the weekly ABS-CBN Channel 2’s Nginiiig (Tremor), 2003, and GMA Channel 7’s Huwag Kang Kukurap (Do Not Blink), 2004-6. Horror as a theme was also used in soaps like Spirits, 2004-5, and the 15-episode Patayin sa Sindak si Barbara, 2008, both on ABS-CBN Channel 2. The latter was a spin-off of a Susan Roces movie in 1974 of the same title, which was also remade as a movie in 1995 and starred Lorna Tolentino. From 2008 to 2009, TV5 came up with the reality horror-suspense program Philippines’ Scariest Challenge, which featured ghost stories and other strange phenomena. The show featured celebrities who were dared to complete tasks in haunted places.

Few historical programs were aired on commercial television as it was not as popular as other genres like drama and comedy. Nonetheless, several programs narrating historical events or featuring historical figures have been aired. ABS-CBN Channel 2 produced a children’s program about Filipino heroes titled Bayani (Hero), 1995-2001, one of a few produced in cooperation with the Department of Education, aligned with elementary students’ curriculum. RPN Channel 9 produced a series called Alab ng Lahi (Ardor of the Race) in the 1980s, which featured historical highlights in each episode. GMA Channel 7 produced two historical series shown on prime time: Katipunan (name of Filipino revolutionary movement against Spain in the late 1800s), 2013, a 10-episode miniseries on the history of the Katipunan, Bonifacio, and the internal struggles of the revolutionary movement; and Ilustrado (Educated Native), a 20-episode docudrama on the life of Jose Rizal. In 2013, TV5 produced History with Lourd de Veyra: Tsismis Noon, Kasaysayan Ngayon (History with Lourd de Veyra: Rumor Then, History Now), a different take on historical events and trivia.

True-to-life events, such as historical and everyday realities, are said to be often stranger than fiction. The audience interest, fascination, and wonder that they generate will continue to inspire content on radio and television.Written by Jose Bartolome
Religion

The Philippines became predominantly Roman Catholic due to the forced imposition of the faith during the Spanish colonization. However, with the coming of the Americans in 1898, freedom of religion was allowed while Protestant denominations were introduced. It was during the American colonial period when a few new religious groups were established, among them the Iglesia ni Cristo (INC) and the Philippine Independent Church, also known as the Aglipayan Church, named after its founder Gregorio Aglipay. With the introduction of radio broadcasting in the 1920s, religious groups began to make a small presence on the air by producing programs like Tagalog Gospel Hour on KZRF in 1941. In an effort to appeal culturally to Filipinos, even the Japanese-controlled radio station PIAM aired the program Time for Church in the Morning during the Japanese occupation of the Philippines in World War II.

After the war, the first religious radio station KZAS, later DZAS, was established in Jun 1948 by Protestant missionaries through the Far East Broadcasting Company (FEBC). FEBC continues to operate DZAS on the AM band as well as DZFE on FM and other radio stations in Isabela, Albay, Iloilo, South Cotabato, and Zamboanga. Programs on FEBC stations include bible studies, prayers, exhortations, phone-ins for prayer requests or spiritual advice, and worship songs, apart from classical music on DZFE and news and information on DZAS. By the 2000s, at least 20 radio stations were owned and/or operated by religious groups. Most assume standard or commercial radio formats, broadcasting news and popular music while inserting religious messages within regular programming. Others are overtly religious such as DZEM of the INC and DWXI of El Shaddai, whose operation is described as religious broadcasting. El Shaddai, considered the largest charismatic movement in the country, started as a radio station or “radio apostolate.” It has flourished into a full-fledged movement and has a number of radio, TV, and online shows that are used to reach out to both members and the general public, to showcase miraculous healings or preaching, and to evangelize (Kessler and Ruland 2006, 73). Religious stations and programs are also using online technology to expand their reach. The Jesuit Communications of the Roman Catholic Society of Jesus, for instance, produces interactive video reflections of Gospel readings such as The Word Exposed, shown both on television and social media formats.
