With the rise of new religions such as Ang Dating Daan, whose founder, Eli Soriano, is a former member of the INC, religious programs and stations have become a platform to refute each other’s doctrines. Ministers of the INC and Ang Dating Daan are constantly engaged in a vigorous debate through their respective radio and television stations. The INC lectures through its Eagle Broadcasting Corporation, which owns DZEC-TV Net 25, DZEC radio on the AM band, DWDM radio on the FM band; and the Christian Era Broadcasting Service, which owns INC-TV Channel 49 on VHF. On the other hand, Ang Dating Daan responds through its Progressive Broadcasting Corporation, which owns DWAO-TV UNTV Channel 37 on the VHF band and DWUN on the AM band.

Aside from evangelization, several religious stations have included public and community service in their main agenda. The Catholic Media Network (CMN) uses radio to reach remote and impoverished communities. CMN is the largest religious media network in the country. It operates 30 AM and 32 FM stations across the Philippines, including areas in Sulu. It also operates TV Maria as its television network, whose signals are delivered via satellite broadcasting and cable.

Broadcast content to expand their respective congregations and strengthen the faith of their members is expected of radio and television stations owned and operated by religious groups. However, commercial radio and television stations also include religious programs into their regular schedules, such as the Catholic programs Salitang Buhay (Living Word) and Light Moments on DZMM, the Catholic Sunday mass broadcast on ABS-CBN Sports+Action Channel 23, and the Protestant program Diyos at Bayan (God and Country) on GMA News TV Channel 11. ABS-CBN Channel 2 and DZMM also air devotionals such as the three o’clock prayer, and produce segments and programs in the observance of Christmas and Lent. Solar Entertainment Channels, which include cable channels ETC, Jack TV, Jack City, and 2nd Avenue, produce public materials in commemoration of Christmas and Lent. Free-to-air television stations ABS-CBN, GMA Channel 7, and TV5 produce special Christmas station identification plugs, and co-produce or broadcast Catholic shows during the Holy Week, such as GMA’s airing of the theatrical production Siete Palabras (Seven Last Words) from the Santo Domingo Church. ABS-CBN has been airing religious shows hosted by Fr Jerry Orbos, S.V.D., and Manila Archbishop Luis Antonio Cardinal Tagle.

Religious activities have always been included in news programs. Regular celebrations like All Saints’ Day, Christmas, Lent, the Black Nazarene Quiapo Festival, the Muslim Ramadan, and other religious observances are reported on in the news. Other events of religious significance that are covered in the newscasts include papal conclaves; papal visits to the Philippines by Paul VI in 1970, John Paul II in 1981 and 1995, and Francis in Jan 2015; the canonization and beatification of Lorenzo Ruiz, Pedro Calungsod, and John Paul II; the abdication of Benedict XVI from the papacy in 2013; and massive public gatherings of religious denominations such as those of Jesus Is Lord (JIL) Movement and the INC. Moreover, religious flavor is infused in some standard commercial program formats. For example, opening and closing prayers are included in Failon Ngayon (Failon Now) on DZMM and Relasyon (Relationship) on Radyo Singko (Radio 5).

A Catholic station, DZRV (RV stands for Radyo Veritas, meaning Truth Radio), is memorable for the roles it played in the country’s recent history. The station began as the campus radio of the University of Santo Tomas in 1950. In 1969, it was transferred to the supervision of the Archdiocese of Manila, under the official name Radio Veritas and the call letters DZRV. In Aug 1983, at the height of public discontent with the Marcos regime and the hope of many to find a new leader in the person of former senator Benigno “Ninoy” Aquino Jr, DZRV was the only radio station that aired the coverage of Aquino’s assassination and the mammoth crowd that attended his burial, forming a funeral cortege cum protest march from the Santo Domingo Church in Quezon City to the Manila Memorial Park in Parañaque that took at least 12 hours. DZRV was also the medium used by Jaime Cardinal Sin in Feb 1986 to call on the public to troop to EDSA to support Marcos defectors, then defense minister Juan Ponce Enrile and Armed Forces of the Philippines (AFP) vice chief of staff Fidel Ramos and their men. Around a million heeded Sin’s appeal, which led to the bloodless overthrow of the Marcos government following what is now described as a display of People Power. In Jan 2001, Sin again went on the air on DZRV to rally the people to what was dubbed People Power II to overthrow the government of then president Joseph Estrada, which ended in the succession to the presidency of Gloria Macapagal Arroyo.

Religions have contributed to radio and television not only in terms of content but also in the sociopolitical role of broadcasting. Combined with online media, radio and television are a site for religious expression, worship, ritual, and experience.Written byGian Carlo C. Librojo and Erika Jean Cabanawan
Legal Cases

Programs on television and radio following the legal drama format are based either on actual or fictional cases. In the first category, the cases range from highly publicized ones to those virtually unknown outside of law schools and law firms. Under the second category, the fictional cases are the products of the creativity and imagination of the scriptwriter, but echo the premises of real-life legal cases. Deriving program content from actual cases is less challenging than sourcing them from fiction writers, for several reasons. First, actual cases or jurisprudence belong to the public domain because they are based on existing judicial records, which are public records that are, by law, accessible to the public. For this reason, anybody may use them without being required to pay any royalties. Since no copyright exists in decisions rendered by courts of law, no copyright infringement takes place even if the name of the actual case is not mentioned in the program credits.

Second, there are many actual cases to choose from in existing jurisprudence. One does not even need to be a lawyer to understand these cases. Almost all cases, particularly those that are resolved by the Supreme Court, are written for the easy understanding of lay persons. Moreover, case texts and case digests (simplified summaries of cases) are available in many books and online. Third, there is no need for expensive legal research when a producer, director, or scriptwriter chooses to source the program from an actual case. All that has to be done is to rewrite the case into a teleplay. There is nothing inherently original in the rewritten material.

Ginang Hukom (Madam Judge) was the first legal drama on radio formatted like a soap opera. Its episodes, aired on DZRH in the 1950s, were based on cases decided by Philippine courts. Like many other soaps of the period, it became so popular that it inspired a movie of the same title produced by Sampaguita Pictures, starring Luis Gonzales, Amalia Fuentes, Eddie Gutierrez, Lolita Rodriguez, and Josephine Estrada. Veteran film star Rosa Mia played the title role. It was some time after Ginang Hukom folded up before legal cases again became a source of content on radio. In the 1990s, programs like Compañero y Compañera and Usapang de Campanilla dispensed legal advice to callers faced with minor legal issues. Compañero is a Spanish word which means colleague. Lawyers in the Philippines call a colleague in the legal profession either a compañero (for males) or a compañera (for females). The Spanish phrase de campanilla is taken from abogado de campanilla (literally meaning a lawyer with a small bell), which means a high-end, high-charging lawyer. In turn, usapang de campanilla means a discourse between high-end, expensive lawyers. Both programs aired on DZMM and had television versions on ABS-CBN Channel 2. Compañero y Compañera has ended its run while Usapang de Campanilla is still on the air.

On television, legal drama programs imported from the United States preceded similar local productions. Almost as soon as television became available in the Philippines, dramatizations of fictional legal cases were seen in such programs as Perry Mason, 1957-66, IBC Channel 13; The New Perry Mason, 1970s, KBS Channel 9; and The Fugitive, 1960s and 1980s, ABS-CBN Channel 2. The shows had a lot of courtroom drama seasoned with suspenseful cat-and-mouse adventures outside the courtroom. Imported canned legal drama continues to be seen on local television and cable channels in programs like L.A. Law, Law and Order, and Suits, which dramatize not only the legal cases but also the personal lives and moral dilemmas faced by the characters.

On local television, Ipaglaban Mo (Fight for It), which has been airing on and off since 1988 on IBC Channel 13, GMA Channel 7, and ABS-CBN Channel 2, was the first to dramatize actual legal cases on prime time. Hosted by lawyer Jose C. Sison, it was based on Sison’s column in the daily Philippine Star, A Law Each Day, which narrates cases and explains actual decisions of the Supreme Court of the Philippines. Although Sison’s column covered different kinds of legal cases, including land registration disputes, paternity and filiation litigations, adoption suits, and insurance claims, Ipaglaban Mo focused on murder, rape, robbery, and kidnapping. The strategy worked and audiences watched while similar programs were also on the air, including Calvento Files, 1995-98, ABS-CBN Channel 2; S.O.C.O. (Scene of the Crime Operatives), 2005-11, DZMM Teleradyo; Crime Klasik (Crime Classic), since 2012, Aksyon TV Channel 5; and Case Unclosed, 2008-10, GMA Channel 7. Crime Klasik, whose style was copied by Case Unclosed, drew on more recent as well as historical cases like the separate cases of the murders of freedom fighters Andres Bonifacio and Diego Silang.

Inspired by American programs like The People’s Court, Judge Alex, Family Court with Judge Penny, and Street Court, where legal arbitration instead of adversarial litigation of actual small claims and disputes is conducted on television, ABC Channel 5 experimented with Public Atorni: Asunto o Areglo? (Public Attorney: Lawsuit or Amicable Settlement) beginning in 2010, where lawyer Persida Rueda-Acosta of the Public Attorney’s Office under the Department of Justice presided over the resolution of domestic quarrels and similar disputes before a live audience.

Legal cases continue to fascinate audiences and provide material for program content in various formats. While fictionalized dramatizations mesmerize audiences, actual legal cases and real-life legal conflicts prove equally if not more absorbing.Written byVictor C. Avecilla
Radio as an Influence on TV

Apart from old films, canned documentaries supplied by foreign diplomatic missions, and canned television programs imported mostly from the United States, most early local television productions were adaptations of successful radio programs. It was a strategy that worked for the fledgling medium. The broadcast hours had to be filled seven days a week with programs but television production is far more capital intensive than radio production, so creating television versions of tried-and-tested radio shows was less risky than gambling on new and unproven program concepts for the small screen. Besides, the first television stations were established by those already in the radio business, so migrating shows from radio to TV was unproblematic. Moreover, most of these radio shows came with performers who already had a following, thus partly guaranteeing the appeal of the television versions to TV audiences. Used to performing before live studio audiences, the radio performers adjusted nicely to performing before a camera. Having already internalized the commercial program structure of American radio and television, which follow the same logic in terms of flow from sign-on to sign-off, many of the first local television production staff were also migrants from radio, taking with them the production conventions and discipline of producing for radio.

Variety shows were the first radio programs that migrated successfully to television. Many shows retained the original radio titles while others modified the titles but kept the basic format. Continuing with the radio practice of airing the program live before a studio audience, Oras ng Ligaya and Student Canteen are among the more memorable ones. Oras ng Ligaya (Happy Hour), Monday to Saturday, 5:30-7:00 pm, 1960s to early 1970s, ABS-CBN Channel 3, took off from Tuloy ang Ligaya (On with the Fun) on DZRH, 1960s. Of the regular hosts of Tuloy ang Ligaya, Sylvia La Torre and Oscar Obligacion also hosted Oras ng Ligaya. Eddie San Jose, who hosted Edong Mapangarap (Edong the Dreamer), which began as a variety show and pitted against Tuloy ang Ligaya, aired at around the same time on DZFM, left the said show to join La Torre and Obligacion in Oras ng Ligaya. Directed by film veteran actor Tony Santos Sr, the show included amateur song-and-dance competitions, comic skits, on-air acting auditions for kids, quizzes, and running gags. Student Canteen, on the other hand, was a daily noontime show on CBN’s DZXL, 1950s, hosted by Eddie Ilarde, Leila Benitez, Bobby Ledesma, and Pepe Pimentel. It was aired from the canteen of CBN (before it merged with ABS) at the Manila Chronicle building on Aduana St, Manila, which was visited by many students, hence the title. When it launched on CBN’s Channel 9 in 1958, it became the first daily noontime variety show on Philippine television. It stopped airing when Ilarde entered politics in 1965, then went back on air on GMA Channel 7 from 1975 to 1986 and on RPN Channel 9 from 1989 to 1990. It had the same formula of short comic skits, running gags, quizzes, and various competitions.

Variety show variants that adapted well to television include the amateur singing contest and the game show, both mixed with hilarious gags and comic repartees. Among these were Tawag ng Tanghalan (Call of the Stage), perhaps the most unforgettable amateur singing contest on Philippine radio and television, producing several notable singing stars such as Nora Aunor, Diomedes Maturan, Cenon Lagman, Novo Bono, Jonathan Potenciano, Ric Manrique Jr, and Ofelia Dayrit. The show first went on the air in the 1950s moving from one radio station to another until it was put on television in the 1960s. From RBS’s DZBB, it transferred to MBC’s DZRH, then to ABS’s DZAQ, then CBN’s DZXL, and finally on ABS-CBN’s Channel 3. Among its various hosts were comedians Dolphy and Panchito while it was on radio, and Patsy and Lopito on television. In the 1950s, Kuarta o Kahon (Cash or Box) became the model of early game shows, the format of which is still seen in such game shows as Deal or No Deal. Contestants were asked relatively easy questions, and those who gave correct answers chose between a box, the contents of which was unknown, and an amount of money. It was originally the weekly show Mahiwagang Kahon (Mysterious Box) on DZRH in the mid-1950s when it moved to Channel 3, while at the same time it continued a radio version on DZAQ. Originally hosted by Jaime de la Rosa, the name most associated with it is Pepe Pimentel, who produced and hosted it on and off for almost four decades from the early 1960s, taking the show with him from one TV station to another (Aniceto 2007, 510-11). Children’s variety shows that began on radio were reproduced for television, such as Eskuwelahang Munti (Little Schoolhouse), which first aired on RBS’s DZBB before it aired on RBS’s Channel 7 in the 1960s. Produced by Tinno Lapus, the show nurtured young talents, some of whom graduated to a music recording career, or film careers, or to other television shows, such as Vilma Santos, Edgar Mortiz, Esperanza Fabon, and Ike Lozada.

Sitcoms followed variety shows in migrating to television while soaps took longer. The pioneering Kuwentong Kutsero (Tall Tales), a situational comedy spiked with political satire, aired before World War II on KZRM, 1938-41. After the war, it was on DZBB before it moved to RBS Channel 7 in the 1950s until the early 1960s. The sitcoms Tang-Tarang-Tang (a play on “Tatang,” a variant of Father in Tagalog) and Sebya Mahal Kita (Sebya, I Love You) were evolutions of the same radio program, Edong Mapangarap (Edong the Dreamer) on KZFM (later DZFM) in the 1940s, which moved to DZRH in the 1950s. Written by Beer Flores, the stories progressed from Edong Mapangarap to Sebya Mahal Kita and, by the time it went on television in the 1960s, Tang-Tarang-Tang. It had the same characters portrayed by Sylvia La Torre, Pugo, Bentot, and Eddie San Jose.

It was simple to move sitcoms from radio to television due to less complicated, static studio sets that the genre requires. Soaps were different. Writing for the ear and relying on the audience’s imagination, writers of radio soaps did not have to bother with the visual demands of writing for the small screen. Thus, scripts that demanded simpler production designs, such as sets that could be set up in studios rather than on location, had to be written into the soaps that were reproduced for television. This was the convention until digital technology made possible the manipulation of moving images beginning in the 2000s without the need for expensive sets, costumes, and special effects, allowing more imaginative teleplays, especially in dramas that involved fantasy and horror. Nevertheless, some radio soaps were successfully reproduced for television from radio, such as Prinsipe Amante (Prince Amante) in the 1960s on ABS-CBN Channel 2, and the memorable Flordeluna, 1978-82 on RPN Channel 9, 1982-86 on BBC Channel 2. Prinsipe Amante was a soap on KZRH in the late 1940s while Flordeluna was first a soap on Cebu radio before it was translated to Tagalog and aired from a Manila radio station, until its move to television. Of late, with the proliferation of the soap variant teleserye, some television soaps have been borrowing titles or story premises from iconic radio soaps that have defined the genre for radio, such as Gulong ng Palad, on ABS-CBN Channel 2 in 2006, and the various melodramas that reflect the struggles of Filipino families, often incorporating current social realities that have traditionally been the thesis of the Philippine radio soap.

Perhaps the most straightforward translations of radio to television were the news, commentary, and sports programs. Sports programs almost completely migrated to television, allowing audiences to visually enjoy athletic events, an experience that cannot be derived from radio. The visual character of television is its strength, and now that digital technologies continue to enhance the visual experience of audiences, radio may no longer be the principal source and influence of television.Written byElizabeth L. Enriquez
TV as an Influence on Radio

Radio was already successful by the time television began in the Philippines. This is the main reason why a lot of radio shows are adapted into TV. Some examples of these are the hit radio series Sebya Mahal Kita (Sebya, I Love You), Gulong ng Palad (Wheel of Fate), Flordeluna, and Annaliza. TV, however, has also been a rich source of material for radio and has had considerable influence on radio as a platform for art, a medium of communication, and an industry.

Since radio has a wider reach in rural places as compared to television, creating a radio version of the TV program increases the number of its potential audience. The children’s educational program Batibot, 1984-2002, aired on television stations RPN 9, PTV 4, ABS-CBN 2, and GMA 7, targeting children aged four to six, is one of the famous TV shows adapted into radio. Radyo Batibot was broadcast on DZAM 1026, 4:00-4:30 pm, targeting children audiences aged 7-12.

DZMM 630 broadcasts many programs adapted from TV as well. One of these is Maalaala Mo Kaya (Will You Remember), the longest-running drama anthology in the Philippines and in Asia. It tackles and reenacts the stories of Filipinos who send their entries to the program. Its radio counterpart, MMK sa DZMM (MMK on DZMM), was first aired on 8 Mar 2007 at the 12:30-1:00 pm time slot.

A dominant field in the TV-to-radio adaptation is the broadcast of news. Some programs aired on DZMM 630 include TV Patrol sa DZMM (TV Patrol on DZMM), Failon Ngayon, and S.O.C.O. sa DZMM (Scene of the Crime Operatives on DZMM). TV Patrol sa DZMM first aired in 2001. It is a simulcast of ABS-CBN’s news and current affairs program TV Patrol and DZMM Teleradyo. Failon Ngayon is a public service program that discusses present and specific issues in the country. It first aired in 2011 and runs from Monday to Friday at 8:00-10:00 am. S.O.C.O. sa DZMM is also a public service program that portrays crime investigation. It first aired in 2011 and runs every Thursday, 6:00-7:00 pm. GMA 7 has its television news programs 24 Oras and Saksi (Witness) on its AM radio station DZBB.

Not only do some TV programs have their respective versions or are broadcast simultaneously on radio, television networks have also reconfigured their operations of radio broadcasting to get a bigger share of the audience. A significant development on Philippine radio broadcasting was the entry of Media Quest Holdings Inc, led by telecommunications mogul Manuel “MVP” Pangilinan, into FM radio on 28 Nov 2010. Pangilinan’s group acquired the frequency 92.3 on FM and launched Radyo Singko, a news and talk-oriented radio component of TV5 of the Associated Broadcasting Company. It positioned itself as “Ang Bagong Tunog ng FM” (The New Sound of FM).

Perhaps one of the most important indicators of television’s close link with radio is the emergence of the teleradyo (television-radio), the merging of radio and television, with television transporting radio into the former’s platform, making visible radio programs and personalities, especially those on news, talk shows, and public service programs, whose identities to audiences used to be exclusively formed by sound. Radio personalities now have to perform not just before the microphone but also in front of the camera while broadcasting from the radio booth.

TV is also a rich source of talents for radio. Many radio talents also served the artistic and industry needs of television. The reverse has also become true: personalities who first worked on television are now also asked to serve as radio voice actors, news anchors and commentators, and entertainment talk hosts.Written by Claudine Keith V. Regino and Eulalio R. Guieb III
Social Media

The term “social media” refers to Web-based platforms where users build, share, and exchange content among users within the same fields of interest. Social network sites have enabled anyone with Internet access to create various user profiles that can connect and interact with other users across the globe. As of Jan 2015, the Philippines had 44.2 million Internet users and 40 million active social media accounts. The mobile platform—cellular phones and tablets—had 114.6 million connected users, about 13.7 percent more than the country’s listed population of 100.8 million. A typical Filipino Internet user spent an average of 6 hours and 17 minutes on the Internet, and 4 hours and 15 minutes on social media daily. The top three social media platforms preferred by Filipinos in 2015 were (1) Facebook, (2) Twitter, and (3) Google+. Facebook also tops the list of the most popular mobile applications downloaded and used by Filipinos.

Prior to the popularity of the Internet and social media in the Philippines, some television and radio shows already had attempts of fostering a social media character. Beginning in 1953, Dely Magpayo, named “First Lady of Philippine Radio” (San Diego 2008), read letters sent from all over the Philippines and provided on-air counseling in the show Mga Liham kay Tiya Dely (Letters to Aunt Dely). Similarly, DWTM, known as Magic 89.9, featured DJ Joe D’ Mango and his show Love Notes during the late 1980s. Love Notes started as a 15-minute counseling program, reading letters from lovelorn listeners and pairing love advice with popular love songs of the time. Initially conceptualized as a gimmick, Love Notes became a hit for office workers during Friday mornings, and was later developed as a TV show and a movie. ABS-CBN’s Maalaala Mo Kaya (Will You Remember), which premiered in 1988, was originally a 13-part miniseries to be written and directed by Lino Brocka. Brocka managed to finish only three episodes before his death in 1991. When aired, the episodes received rave reviews from critics, prompting the network to continue the show. Maalaala Mo Kaya then followed the format of another popular show, GMA’s Lovingly Yours, Helen, replacing fictional stories with stories sent by viewers. The noontime variety show Eat Bulaga! (Lunchtime Peek-a-Boo!) has incorporated the idea of a “home partner” in some of its segments. This allowed home viewers to share cash prizes with in-studio contestants. These types of shows offered a sense of interactivity and participation, albeit limited, among the content creators and the audience.

Advancements in telecommunications opened more opportunities for innovation. Short message service (SMS) or texting was the platform used by the youth-oriented drama show K2BU on ABS-CBN Channel 2 to allow viewers to affect the outcome of an episode by texting keywords to the show (Johnston 2002). SMS voting was utilized to determine the series finale of the teleserye Sana’y Wala Nang Wakas (I Wish This Were Forever). The teleserye production team filmed two alternate episodes, one with a grand wedding between the characters Christian and Arabella (played by Jericho Rosales and Kristine Hermosa), another a grand wedding between Arabella and Leo (played by Diether Ocampo). The voting ended an hour before the last episode. The winning finale, the wedding of Christian and Arabella, was aired simultaneously on ABS-CBN Channel 2 and its radio arm DZMM, with a live viewing event held at Plaza Miranda. The next evening, the other finale was shown as a special. Sana’y Wala Nang Wakas also facilitated an online voting through abs-cbn.com to cater to their international viewers, particularly subscribers of ABS-CBN’s The Filipino Channel, which is based in San Francisco, California.

Utilizing social media meant faster and more efficient user-centered interaction between content creators and target audience. Pop station DWRX 93.1 expanded its reach by adding station Facebook and Twitter accounts in 2009. Its early morning radio talk show The Morning Rush, which first aired in 1996, increased its popularity when it established The Morning Rush Facebook and Twitter pages in 2011. The show’s most popular segment, the “Top 10,” involves listeners who respond via Twitter to a post by the hosts, who then pick the 10 best entries submitted within the duration of the show. Through the use of hashtags, the audience sees the contributions updated in real time, including the contributions that were not picked and announced as part of the Top 10 list. Seeing the trends set by the show also meant seeing and possibly interacting with the show’s listeners via their respective social media handles. The Facebook page complements this interactivity, providing a space to post contributions to the daily Top 10 list, as well as upload additional multimedia content such as posters, video links, event photos, in-studio concert videos, and greetings from the show’s fans. The use of social media not only influences content but also amplifies the sense of community between producers, hosts, and the audience.

In 2007, GMA through its digital news arm GMA News TV, launched YouScoop, an online space that allowed Internet users to share photographs and video clips, allowing the public to make their own news “scoop.” Submitted entries from registered YouScoop users are featured regularly on the GMA news programs Saksi (Witness) and 24 Oras (24 Hours), and are also shared on their respective Facebook and Twitter pages. ABS-CBN launched a more specialized news campaign in 2010 through Boto Mo Ipatrol Mo (Guard Your Vote). The campaign tapped the ordinary Filipino netizen, dubbed Boto Patrollers, to provide coverage and assessment of the 2010 national elections. The project received reports through a daily average of 500 e-mails, 103 calls, and 3,058 texts during the electoral campaign. Boto Mo Ipatrol Mo peaked with 87,419 Boto Patrollers in its database, 125,487 fans on Facebook, 23,111 supporters on Twitter, 6,960 members on its microsite, and 3,701 members on the now-defunct platform Multiply.

By 2011, “trending” had become a way of feeling the public pulse (Calonzo 2011). Searching and developing trending social network topics had become important aspects of TV and radio content. Vice Ganda, host of the television shows It’s Showtime and Gandang Gabi Vice (Good Evening, Vice) on ABS-CBN Channel 2, coined and popularized “Vice Ganda-isms” such as boom panes (flop), push mo ’yan, teh (Go, sister), and eksaherada (exaggerated), with the help of Twitter and Facebook (Star Cinema 2014). Some of these buzzwords have inspired hit songs, recorded and performed by Vice Ganda himself, such as “Push Mo Yan ’Teh” and “Boom Panes” (ABS-CBN News 2014). The platform Instagram was tapped by It’s Showtime following a segment where Vice Ganda interviewed 16-year-old Pamela Reyes. A victim of bullying, Reyes sought advice from Vice Ganda. Vice Ganda, who identifies as gay, responded by removing his contact lens and wig on the air and enjoining the audience to post pictures of themselves without makeup or the use of a camera filter. Vice Ganda uploaded a photo of his bare face on Instagram with the hashtag #ProudToBeMe. It went viral, quickly and massively spreading among social media users.

Social media have become a platform for local artists to gain celebrity status by participating in online campaigns that go viral. Eat Bulaga! hosts Wally Bayola, Jose Manalo, Paolo Ballesteros, and Aiza Seguerra have famously joined the “makeup transformation challenge,” where challengers post step-by-step pictures of makeup application to look like a totally different person (Summit Express 2014). Popular love team Kathryn Bernardo and Daniel Padilla joined the “ALS Ice Bucket Challenge,” a campaign where people post pictures or videos of themselves being doused with ice-cold water to raise awareness and gather research funds for the disease amyotrophic lateral sclerosis or ALS (Rappler 2014). Charice Pempengco, Arnel Pineda, Zendee Rose Tenerefe, Aldrich Lloyd Talonding, and James Walter Bucong all had viral videos of their song performances on YouTube, which landed them in the American talk show Ellen. The mobile application Dubsmash, which enables users to record videos of themselves mimicking lines from popular movies and songs, became a venue for local actors and ordinary netizens to compete for local and global celebrity. The Indonesian magazine Sumatera Ekspres featured actors Teejay Marquez and Miguel Tan Felix after they posted their Dubsmash lip-synching of the song “Twerk It Like Miley,” while Maine Mendoza’s Dubsmash impressions of Kris Aquino captured not only the interest of online netizens but also the eyes of the Eat Bulaga! producers. The video, gaining a million views in just 24 hours, was Mendoza’s key to an interview on the program, which gave her the character name Divina Ursula Bukbukova Smash or Yaya Dub, the assistant of Wally Bayola’s Lola Nidora in Eat Bulaga!’s “Juan for All, All for Juan” segment. Yaya Dub subsequently became half of the phenomenal love team AlDub, with GMA artist Alden Richards.

Currently, network stations such as TV5 create and develop content sourced from social media and shared through all the station’s platforms. Programs such as Wattpad Presents tap the mobile application Wattpad—a literary platform founded in 2006 that houses writings from registered users, with a majority of material focused on romantic stories—for its content. The TV5 website offers live streaming, video on demand, uploads of previously aired TV episodes, and content designed specifically for online users. Tagged as TV5 Originals, the featured shows range from 2 to 10 minutes and are uploaded simultaneously on the network’s social media accounts. Initially, the shows featured in TV5 Originals were aired only in social media and in the TV5 website. Lately, programs such as Tanods (Guards) and Phenoms are aired both online and on analog and cable TV. TV5 Originals also hosts the radio podcast show Good Times with Mo, allowing the Filipino audience to interact with now US-based DJ Mo Twister. Having tie-ups with online streaming services for desktop and mobile tools, such as iFlix for television and Spotify for radio, and affordable mobile promos for Internet social media usage prepares the stations for the plan to shift broadcasting in the country from analog transmissions to 100 percent digital frequencies by 2020. Creating websites like the news portal Interaksyon.com—online portals dedicated to social media content management and distribution—not only proves social media’s viability as a main source and influence in the creation and management of broadcast content but also as a possible alternative medium to experience TV and radio.Written byVladimeir B. Gonzales
